DESCRIPTION: Rudolph II (1552-1612) was the son of the Holy Roman Emperor Maximilian II.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: He became King of Hungary in 1572 and King of Bohemia in 1575.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: Following the death of his father he also became Holy Roman Emperor and Archduke of Austria.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: His reign was a troubled time of great religious conflicts coupled with the external menace of the Turks.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: Unfortunately, politics was not a great interest of his.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: Instead he was familiar with a number of languages and was devoted to art and science, the latter including alchemy and astrology, a highly fashionable preoccupation at that time.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: He was also fascinated by magic and the occult.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: At the end of the 1590s mental illness rendered him incapable of governing his empire, which by that time was torn by disputes between Reformation and Counter-Reformation movements.
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: As a result, in 1611, he was forced to cede the crown of Bohemia to his brother Matthias and he died soon afterwards
AUTHOR: AACHEN, Hans von
TITLE: Portrait of Emperor Rudolf II

DESCRIPTION: From 1772 Abildgaard spent five years in Rome thanks to a scholarship granted by the Royal Danish Academy of Fine Arts in Copenhagen.
AUTHOR: ABILDGAARD, Nicolai
TITLE: The Wounded Philoctetes

DESCRIPTION: It was while in Rome that he created this depiction of the legendary hero Philoctetes, whose screams of pain caused by a festering snakebite made his comrades-in-arms abandon him on a Greek island during the Trojan war.Abildgaard used a principal work of classical sculpture as the basis for his rendition of Philoctetes' tormented state: the Torso Belvedere in the Vatican museum served as the model for the plastic and mannered rendition of the hero's upper body.
AUTHOR: ABILDGAARD, Nicolai
TITLE: The Wounded Philoctetes

DESCRIPTION: With this move, Abildgaard's stylistic innovation was imbued with features of a work canonised by neoclassicism - without, however, reducing the tensions in the painting
AUTHOR: ABILDGAARD, Nicolai
TITLE: The Wounded Philoctetes

DESCRIPTION: Intense colours characterize the still-lifes of Van Aelst, who worked for a time in France and Italy.
AUTHOR: AELST, Willem van
TITLE: Still-Life with Fruit and Crystal Vase

DESCRIPTION: In this painting, which was commissioned by Cardinal Giovan Carlo de' Medici, the intense blue of the table-cloth catches one's eye.
AUTHOR: AELST, Willem van

DESCRIPTION: The large crystal vase in the centre of the composition was probably in the possession of the Medici family.
AUTHOR: AELST, Willem van
TITLE: Still-Life with Fruit and Crystal Vase

DESCRIPTION: The painter placed his signature and the date on the hem of the white tablecloth: W.A.Aelst.
AUTHOR: AELST, Willem van

AUTHOR: AELST, Willem van
TITLE: Still-Life with Fruit and Crystal Vase

TITLE: Still-Life with Fruit and a Crystal Vase

DESCRIPTION: Here, he perhaps suggests the category's classical roots: the Greek painter Zeuxis's grapes, so lifelike that birds tried to eat them, and the split pomegranate recalling Demeter's bargain, and announcing winter's return, as Proserpina descends to Hades once more
AUTHOR: AELST, Willem van
TITLE: Still-Life with Fruit and a Crystal Vase

DESCRIPTION: The painting is an Ecce Homo fragment.
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Scene

DESCRIPTION: Similarly to other biblical paintings of Aertsen, the biblical event takes place at the back, while the foreground is dominated by a market scene.. Somewhere in the background, the picture - cut off at the top - affords a small glimpse of the platform where the masses are shouting 'Barabbas' (John 19:4-6).
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Scene

DESCRIPTION: This is optically overlaid by the bow-shaped arrangement of carts and market stalls - a reversal of emphasis which is typical of Aertsen
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Scene

DESCRIPTION: The painting demonstrates a wide range of agricultural products, made possible by the improvements in production methods.
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Woman with Vegetable Stall

DESCRIPTION: Offering her fruits and vegetables, the woman is almost an appendage to her produce.
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Woman with Vegetable Stall

DESCRIPTION: Despite all exaggeration, the picture quite adequately shows the new economic prosperity of the time.
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Woman with Vegetable Stall

DESCRIPTION: At the same time, however, it still contains a background scene in genre style of embracing lovers in a stable, thus relating the painting to late medieval peasant satires.
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Woman with Vegetable Stall

DESCRIPTION: Peasants were regarded as lustful, sensuous and carnal by the middle classes
AUTHOR: AERTSEN, Pieter
TITLE: Market Woman with Vegetable Stall

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the painting on the ceiling vault of the piano nobile loggia in the Palazzo Verospi, painted by Francesco Albani.
AUTHOR: ALBANI, Francesco
TITLE: Ceiling vault of piano nobile loggia

DESCRIPTION: The depictions are: Phoebus-Apollo and Personifications of the Seasons in the centre panel; Genii of Morning and Evening Twilight in the ovals; The Planetary Gods; Genii of Morning and Night with their Children Sleep and Death in the spandrels.Since antiquity, colonnades and porticoes with painted decoration have been distinguishing features of the palaces of ruling houses.
AUTHOR: ALBANI, Francesco
TITLE: Ceiling vault of piano nobile loggia

DESCRIPTION: In the seventeenth century the main focus in the painting of a loggia, an indispensable feature of the piano nobile in palaces and villas in Rome and elsewhere, was the vault.
AUTHOR: ALBANI, Francesco
TITLE: Ceiling vault of piano nobile loggia

DESCRIPTION: The original pattern for the Roman loggia was the loggia of the Villa Farnesina, painted by Raphael with free-floating figures in the spandrels and caps of the vault.
AUTHOR: ALBANI, Francesco
TITLE: Ceiling vault of piano nobile loggia

DESCRIPTION: The piano nobile loggia in the Palazzo Verospi, painted by Albani follows this pattern, but borrowings from the ceiling of the Galleria Farnese, from Reni's Aurora and Guercino's Aurora are also present
AUTHOR: ALBANI, Francesco
TITLE: Ceiling vault of piano nobile loggia

AUTHOR: ALBANI, Francesco

DESCRIPTION: What strikes us in this portrait is the convincing compromise between the formal purity acquired from Bronzino, the predilection for enlarged forms drawn from Michelangelo, and the balanced, rhythmic spatial models of Raphael, for Allori was a truly skilled alchemist in combining these various influences in a dignified way.The lady portrayed is certainly Bianca Cappello, already painted by Allori in a fresco which now hangs in the Tribune of the Uffizi.On the back of the portrait is an allegorical scene, the Dream of Human Life
AUTHOR: ALLORI, Alessandro
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: Grand Duke Francesco I de' Medici was a man of profound and obsessive passions.
AUTHOR: ALLORI, Alessandro

AUTHOR: ALLORI, Alessandro

DESCRIPTION: This painting relates the story of Jael and Sisera in tones of delicate colours that contrast emphatically with the drama of the biblical event recounted.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo

DESCRIPTION: It was painted after the artist's return too Venice from travels that took him to most of Europe, when his palette became brighter and more refined.Sisera was a cruel Canaanite leader who ruled the Israelites for twenty years.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Jael and Sisera

DESCRIPTION: Barak defeated his nine hundred charioteers by a surprise Israelite attack.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Jael and Sisera

DESCRIPTION: Sisera escaped and sought refuge in the tent of Jael, wife of Heber the Kenite.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo

DESCRIPTION: She gave the terrified Canaanite sanctuary.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Jael and Sisera

DESCRIPTION: When he fell asleep, she drove a tent peg into his brain.

DESCRIPTION: The act fulfilled the prediction of Debora, prophetess and Israelite leader, who foresaw that a woman would slay Sisera

DESCRIPTION: Amigoni had spent his early career in Venice, but he left the city to make a name for himself as an international artist, quickly finding an avid audience in the various courts of Europe which had developed a taste for the charm of the Venetian Rococo.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: In 1730, Amigoni arrived in London fresh from a series of pictorial triumphs in Venice, Rome and at the court of the Elector of Bavaria, and soon had eager patrons amongst the English nobility and even royalty.The pair of canvases of mythological subjects, Venus and Adonis, and Bacchus and Ariadne, represent one of the most important works by Amigoni from his seminal English sojourn.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: These subjects represent two of the most recognizable and classic of all mythological stories, both with a rich history of pictorial representation in Venetian art.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: They are taken from Ovid's Metamorphoses, and in the case of Venus and Adonis, Amigoni returned to the subject throughout his career
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: Amigoni treated this subject about fifteen times during his career.
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Virgin and Child

DESCRIPTION: It is difficult to reconstruct a chronological classification of these pieces
AUTHOR: AMIGONI, Jacopo
TITLE: Virgin and Child

DESCRIPTION: Although commissioned at the beginning of his career, it was carried out slowly and was completed between 1520-25, a particularly fine period of the work of Andrea del Sarto.Miraculously spared during the Siege of Florence in 1529-30, the fresco is placed under a large arch containing painted medallions with the Trinity and four Saints, protectors of the Vallombrosan Order.

DESCRIPTION: The room is Spartan but the variety of light-sources and Angelico's close observation give it interest.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Healing of Justinian by Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

DESCRIPTION: Light floods in from outside through the window on the left, illuminating its own frame and parts of the swags of curtain.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Healing of Justinian by Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

DESCRIPTION: Exterior space is indicated not only by the window but by the door opposite it, from whence comes more light.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Healing of Justinian by Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

DESCRIPTION: From the front left outside the picture comes the third source of light, which produces a broad diagonal sweep across the right wall.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Healing of Justinian by Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

DESCRIPTION: The curtain provides the rectangular backdrop parallel to the picture surface which is common to each of these predella panels, and also hints at more, obscured space behind it.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Healing of Justinian by Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

DESCRIPTION: The container hanging from a nail on the side of the bed, the glass and decanter, the slippers and the simple three-legged stool, all provide the constituents of a closely observed still-life
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Healing of Justinian by Saint Cosmas and Saint Damian

DESCRIPTION: This is the fresco on the wall of Cell 35 of the Convento di San Marco in Florence.In contrast to most frescoes in the cells of the friars and novices, those in the corridor of the lay brethren are illustrative narratives that closely follow the Gospel of Matthew.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Institution of the Eucharist (Cell 35)

DESCRIPTION: These portrayals were directed to a community that was less attuned to theological and visual abstraction.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Institution of the Eucharist (Cell 35)

DESCRIPTION: Many of the scenes are situated in mountainous landscapes or detailed architectural settings.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Institution of the Eucharist (Cell 35)

DESCRIPTION: The Institute of the Eucharist in Cell 35 underscored the Dominicans devotion to the Eucharist, which St Thomas articulated most eloquently in composing the office for the feast of Corpus Domini.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Institution of the Eucharist (Cell 35)

DESCRIPTION: It transpires in a spacious room similar to the convent's actual refectory and repeats elements of San Marco's own architecture - the arched windows of the dormitory, the well in the second cloister - to emphasize its relevance to the lay brother.This fresco was executed by an assistant of Fra Angelico
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Institution of the Eucharist (Cell 35)

DESCRIPTION: Sixtus II (257-258) had charged archdeacon Lawrence with dispersing the church's wealth to the needy.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: St Peter Consacrates St Lawrence as Deacon

DESCRIPTION: This deed aroused the ire of Emperor Valerian who had claimed the treasure for himself, and formed the basis for the charges brought against Lawrence and his eventual execution.In its setting in the Chapel of Pope Nicholas V in the Vatican, the dramatic impact of this fresco is aided by its position between two recessed windows.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: St Peter Consacrates St Lawrence as Deacon

DESCRIPTION: The scene is set in the nave of a basilica, the type of architectural space which in St Lawrence distributing Alms was used only as a backdrop.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: St Peter Consacrates St Lawrence as Deacon

DESCRIPTION: Five columns are visible on either side, and they are equalled in volume and monumentality by the bishops and other churchmen who witness St Lawrence kneeling before the Pope.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: St Peter Consacrates St Lawrence as Deacon

DESCRIPTION: The end wall of the basilica and its niche bring emphasis to no figure in the composition, for none stands at the centre.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: St Peter Consacrates St Lawrence as Deacon

DESCRIPTION: The central axis runs instead through the communion chalice which passes between the Pope and the saint.It is remarkable that in this fresco cycle the pope and the prelates wear azure vests, then rarely used and presently non-existent
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: St Peter Consacrates St Lawrence as Deacon

DESCRIPTION: The lunette represents two scenes: The Sermon of St Stephen; Dispute before the Sanhedrin.On the left St Stephen preaches to an array of figures placed throughout the vista of space.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Lunette of the north wall

DESCRIPTION: To the right, in a chamber which is also embedded in the lefthand scene yet has a different perspective framework, he addresses the council.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Lunette of the north wall

DESCRIPTION: Here the depth of the picture is truncated by a blank wall hung with a curtain
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Lunette of the north wall

DESCRIPTION: The fresco cycle consists of scenes from the lives of the archdeacons Stephen (lunette) and Lawrence (bottom register).On the east wall the narratives run parallel.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: East wall of the chapel

DESCRIPTION: To the left in the lunette St Stephen is being led to his martyrdom, and to the right we see him being stoned to death.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: East wall of the chapel

DESCRIPTION: In the lower register Lawrence is first condemned by Emperor Valerian, then in the adjacent scene he is martyred by being roasted on a gridiron.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: East wall of the chapel

DESCRIPTION: Between these is an auxiliary motif, seen through a small window, showing the conversion of St Hyppolitus, the chief jailer
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: East wall of the chapel

DESCRIPTION: This scene is the right half the lunette on the east wall.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Stoning of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: The left half depicts St Stephen being led to his martyrdom.In this scene he is portrayed at prayer following the description that 'he kneeled down, and cried with a loud voice, Lord, lay not this sin to their charge.'
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Stoning of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: (Apostles 8, v.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Stoning of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: Around him are the stones which have bloodied his face; two more bounce off the back of his head; one of his executioners raises another one high, about to strike again, and holds more in his robe.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Stoning of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: Saul, who was a consenting witness to the execution, is shown, following the details given in the Acts of the Apostles, as a young man holding part of Stephen's clothes which had been laid at his feet by the witnesses.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Stoning of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: This painting formed the central panel of a dismembered altarpiece and is enclosed in its original frame.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Madonna of Humility
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 102 x 58 cm

DESCRIPTION: It was commissioned by the illustrious Florentine Giugni family.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Madonna of Humility
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 102 x 58 cm

DESCRIPTION: The patronage by so prominent a family indicates the professional stature the painter had achieved at this time.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Madonna of Humility
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 102 x 58 cm

DESCRIPTION: The panel was inspired by the paintings of this theme by Lorenzo Monaco and his workshop
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Madonna of Humility
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 102 x 58 cm

DESCRIPTION: This panel was inspired by the Madonna and Child with Saint Anne by Masaccio and Masolino
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Madonna and Child of the Grapes
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 102 x 59 cm

DESCRIPTION: This small high quality panel shows the Virgin in glory between two groups of praying angels.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Virgin and Child with Sts Dominic and Catherine of Alexandria
TECHNIQUE: Tempera with gilding on wood, 24 x 19 cm

DESCRIPTION: She is worshipped by Saint Dominic and Saint Catherine of Alexandria, who appear on a smaller scale at the sides of the throne.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Virgin and Child with Sts Dominic and Catherine of Alexandria
TECHNIQUE: Tempera with gilding on wood, 24 x 19 cm

DESCRIPTION: The former, wearing the Dominican habit, holds a lily in one hand, and in the other the book of the Constitutions of the Order of Preachers (Dominicans); the latter, recognizable by her attribute, the wheel, holds the martyr's palm between her hands.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Virgin and Child with Sts Dominic and Catherine of Alexandria
TECHNIQUE: Tempera with gilding on wood, 24 x 19 cm

DESCRIPTION: The holy child, standing on his mother's lap, strokes her cheek with his right hand while she holds him close, and in her free hand she holds a white rose.The early provenance of the panel is not known
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Virgin and Child with Sts Dominic and Catherine of Alexandria
TECHNIQUE: Tempera with gilding on wood, 24 x 19 cm

DESCRIPTION: There are four panels in various collections which belonged originally to the predella of an unidentified altarpiece.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Naming of St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 24 cm

DESCRIPTION: The panels illustrate stories from the legends of the Virgin Mary, the apostle St James the Great, St John the Baptist, and Sts Francis and Dominic.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Naming of St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 24 cm

DESCRIPTION: The scenes are the following: The Apostle St James the Great Freeing the Magician Hermogenes; The Naming of St John the Baptist; The Burial of the Virgin and the Reception of Her Soul in heaven; The Meeting of Sts Dominic and Francis of Assisi.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Naming of St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 24 cm

DESCRIPTION: The fifth panel of the predella is lost.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Naming of St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 24 cm

DESCRIPTION: The altarpiece would have shown the Virgin and Child and the same saints whose scenes are depicted in the predella.The predella panels show the influence of Masaccio's frescoes in the Brancacci Chapel, specific derivations from them can be detected in most scenes
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Naming of St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 24 cm

TITLE: The Burial of the Virgin and the Reception of Her Soul in Heaven
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The scenes are the following: The Apostle St James the Great Freeing the Magician Hermogenes; The Naming of St John the Baptist; The Burial of the Virgin and the Reception of Her Soul in heaven; The Meeting of Sts Dominic and Francis of Assisi.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Burial of the Virgin and the Reception of Her Soul in Heaven
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The fifth panel of the predella is lost.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Burial of the Virgin and the Reception of Her Soul in Heaven
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The altarpiece would have shown the Virgin and Child and the same saints whose scenes are depicted in the predella.The predella panels show the influence of Masaccio's frescoes in the Brancacci Chapel, specific derivations from them can be detected in most scenes
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Burial of the Virgin and the Reception of Her Soul in Heaven
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 26 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: In this painting, the image of Mary recalls the ideal of beauty promoted in International Gothic art, although her pose and shape give her a three-dimensionality and solidity closer to the art of Masaccio.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Virgin of Humility

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin is placed, following the traditional iconography of the Virgin of Humility, on a cushion rather than a throne.The painting is notable for its brilliant and luminous palette, in which reds, blues and golds are harmoniously combined.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Virgin of Humility

DESCRIPTION: Also outstanding is the sweetness and spirituality of the faces of the figures, whose poses and gestures are depicted with great naturalism
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: The Virgin of Humility

DESCRIPTION: The earliest of Fra Angelico's mural paintings is the Crucified Christ in the Chapter House of San Domenico, the room where the friars, sometimes joined by the laity, assembled for meetings.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Crucified Christ

DESCRIPTION: To enhance its poignant realism, the artist foreshortened Christ's lowered head and torso from the perspective of the kneeling worshipper.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Crucified Christ

DESCRIPTION: The slender, idealized body is anatomically detailed and luminously modelled.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Crucified Christ

DESCRIPTION: The inscriptions - in Hebrew, Greek and Latin - on the titulus of the cross identify Christ as 'Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews.
AUTHOR: ANGELICO, Fra
TITLE: Crucified Christ

DESCRIPTION: Both the authorship of the portrait and the identity of the sitter are debated.
AUTHOR: ANGUISSOLA, Sofonisba
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The painting perhaps was executed by Sofonisba's sister, Lucia, and the sitter could be Minerva, another daughter of Amilcare Anguissola
AUTHOR: ANGUISSOLA, Sofonisba
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: This late painting by Antonello was executed for private devotion
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Christ at the Column

DESCRIPTION: The painting is one of the portraits which were famed for their realism.
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: Due to his knowledge of Flemish pictures, the painter had made a decisive contribution to the spreading and perfection in Italy of what was at that time the new medium of oil painting, and normally depicted figures in three quarter life-size as statue-like half-length portraits in front of a barrier.
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: As in this portrait, the face is particularly emphasized by the dark background and simple headgear, with the eyes directed straight at the observer
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: This superb panel painting has been mistreated over the centuries, and to complicate matters, the artist himself had adjusted his original ideas, including a change in the placement of Christ's right hand.
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Salvator Mundi

DESCRIPTION: The insistent frontality of the figure recalls Byzantine images.
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Salvator Mundi

DESCRIPTION: Antonello's use of oil as a medium, a technique shared with Flemish painters, allowed him to produce more impressive trompe l'oeil effects like the cartellino applied to the bottom of the picture
AUTHOR: ANTONELLO da Messina
TITLE: Salvator Mundi

DESCRIPTION: This panel was executed after Giotto's famous mosaic on the west wall of the oratory of Santa Maria in Turri, in the atrium of the old St.
AUTHOR: ANTONIAZZO ROMANO
TITLE: The Navicella
TECHNIQUE: Wood, transferred to canvas, 190 x 179 cm

DESCRIPTION: Peter's in Rome
AUTHOR: ANTONIAZZO ROMANO
TITLE: The Navicella
TECHNIQUE: Wood, transferred to canvas, 190 x 179 cm

DESCRIPTION: This painting, formerly thought to be a workshop replica, is now considered an authentic variation of the Summer in Vienna.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: Because of the similar dimensions and support, the Autumn on loan at the Denver Art Museum and the Winter in the Menil Collection, Houston probably belonged to the same series
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: This painting is identifiable with a picture of Air by Arcimboldo.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Air

DESCRIPTION: It is a copy after Arcimboldo's painting, or perhaps a workshop version from a later series of elements, or perhaps a repetition made for the emperor.Like Earth and probably Water in the series, Air is also based on studies from nature.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Air

DESCRIPTION: Many of the birds whose heads are seen in this composite were drawn by Arcimboldo, along with many other avian species.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Air

DESCRIPTION: However, because they are crowded together, the individual species represented here are harder to identify
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Air

DESCRIPTION: There is no mistaking this masterpiece of fantasy and virtuoso imagination by Arcimboldo.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: The mythical Vertumnus (or Vortumnus), god of harvests and abundance, is in fact a bizarre portrait of the Habsburg Emperor Rudolf II.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: In the sixteenth century the emperor's cosmopolitan court in Prague became a centre of international art, where Arcimboldo moved in the refined and exclusive circles of late European Mannerism.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: His painting might appear almost irreverent, but in fact is the manifestation of his eager search for new ideas and his exploration of different ways of expression.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: (It also gives quite a good impression of the Emperor.)
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: This led him to break the usual rules in order to provoke uncensored reactions and emotions.
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: The paintings and objects contained in Rudolf of Habsburg's Wunderkammer (room of wonders) were unfortunately scattered after a Swedish army sacked Prague during the Thirty Years' War (1618-48)
AUTHOR: ARCIMBOLDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Vertumnus

DESCRIPTION: While paintings of flowers in a vase represented the most conventional type of flower piece in the 17th century, in the pair of Vase of Flowers, now in the same private collection, Arellano has depicted particularly rich arrangements in remarkably ornate bulbous glass vases with gilt mounts.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: The paintings could be surrogates for actual flower arrangements in the homes of wealthy contemporaries.The apparently natural floral arrangements seen in these paintings were the result of Arellano's careful ordering of the flowers.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: He derived this type of composition from his study of earlier Flemish flower paintings and prints, and varied it little throughout his career.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: It is hard to distinguish the flowers he painted from nature from those deriving from other pictures, graphic sources, memory and practice.While the repetitive nature of Arellano's still-lifes would not have been noticed in his own time, when his works were dispersed among different collections, this factor is augmented in pictures united by photography and exhibitions
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: This impressive still-life represents one of the finest achievements by the pre-eminent flower painter of 17th century Spain, Juan de Arellano.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: The painting was produced at the height of the artist's career and is remarkable for the quality of execution.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: This florero belongs to a small but coherent group of paintings of flowers in a wicker basket on a stone ledge, all of almost identical dimesions, painted by Arellano during the first few years of the 1670's.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: This still-life belongs to a small but coherent group of paintings of flowers in a wicker basket on a stone ledge, all of almost identical dimesions, painted by Arellano during the first few years of the 1670's.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: It depicts a still-life of roses, irises, morning glory, hyacinths, chrysanthemums and carnations in a wicker basket, set upon a stone ledge, together with a stem of lilies, butteflies, dragonflies and a snail.
AUTHOR: ARELLANO, Juan de
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: Arentsz.
AUTHOR: ARENTSZ., Arent
TITLE: Fishermen and Farmers in a Landscape

DESCRIPTION: established his own very distinctive interpretation of the polders of the Dutch coastal region, of which the present work is a good example
AUTHOR: ARENTSZ., Arent
TITLE: Fishermen and Farmers in a Landscape

DESCRIPTION: This subject was treated by Assereto several times
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: The story is recounted in the Book of Tobit.
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Tobias Healing the Blindness of His Father

DESCRIPTION: Tobias was sent by his father Tobit to Media to recover a sum of money he had hidden there earlier.
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Tobias Healing the Blindness of His Father

DESCRIPTION: Archangel Raphael, sent by God to help Tobit and his family, asked Tobit (who did not recognize the angel) whether he may escort his son on his journey and, in company with Tobias' faithful hound, they departed together.
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Tobias Healing the Blindness of His Father

DESCRIPTION: They reached the Tigris, where Tobias was attacked by a gigantic fish.
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Tobias Healing the Blindness of His Father

DESCRIPTION: The archangel ordered him to capture it and had him remove and conserve its gall, heart and liver.
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Tobias Healing the Blindness of His Father

DESCRIPTION: The innards proved to be a medicine which he can use to restore his father's sight
AUTHOR: ASSERETO, Gioachino
TITLE: Tobias Healing the Blindness of His Father

DESCRIPTION: Still-life paintings were popular in Dutch art and began to emerge as a genre in their own right during the 16th century.
AUTHOR: AST, Balthasar van der
TITLE: Still-Life with Apple Blossoms

DESCRIPTION: Despite their popularity with the general public, art academies of the period did not regard them as highly as landscape or religious paintings
AUTHOR: AST, Balthasar van der
TITLE: Still-Life with Apple Blossoms

DESCRIPTION: This still-life, unlike van der Ast's early ones, the arrangement of the still-life looks quite natural, as if the artist simply portraying a basket that he had filled with fresh flowers in his studio.
AUTHOR: AST, Balthasar van der
TITLE: Still-Life with a Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: However, the painting was almost certainly carefully composed on the canvas, with the aid of individual studies of the various flowers and other motifs
AUTHOR: AST, Balthasar van der
TITLE: Still-Life with a Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: As a fishermen mends his nets in the foreground, fancier folk play on the ice in this winter landscape by Barend Avercamp, nephew and pupil of the more famous Hendrick Avercamp
AUTHOR: AVERCAMP, Barend
TITLE: Landscape with Frozen River

DESCRIPTION: This painting demonstrates the painter's mature technique with a miniaturist sense of detail
AUTHOR: AYALA, Josefa de
TITLE: Holy Family with the Infant St John the Baptist, St Elizabeth and Angels

DESCRIPTION: With Mercury looking on with amusement, Vulcan the god of fire is chaining Prometheus to a rock.
AUTHOR: BABUREN, Dirck van
TITLE: Prometheus Being Chained by Vulcan

DESCRIPTION: The eagle which is to devour his liver every day - Prometheus' punishment for stealing fire from the gods and giving it to mankind - is hovering ominously in a corner.
AUTHOR: BABUREN, Dirck van
TITLE: Prometheus Being Chained by Vulcan

DESCRIPTION: In this mythological scene, Van Baburen shows himself to be a true Caravaggist, with contrasts of light and shade, dramatic expressions and unidealized people with sun-tanned hands and faces.
AUTHOR: BABUREN, Dirck van
TITLE: Prometheus Being Chained by Vulcan

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the cupola, pendentives, transept vault, and antechoir of the church of Il Gesù in Rome.In Baroque churches, in addition to the choir, the nave vaults, transept chapels, and cupola (if present) offered large and attractive surfaces for painting.
AUTHOR: BACICCIO
TITLE: Cupola decoration

DESCRIPTION: Although fictive openings in ceilings and vaults had already been created in painting in the sixteenth century, permitting vivid views of events taking place in heaven, the heavenly visions of the seventeenth century take on a new quality, scale, and intensity.
AUTHOR: BACICCIO
TITLE: Cupola decoration

DESCRIPTION: The supreme example is the ceiling composition executed by Baciccio (Giovanni Battista Gaulli) in Il Gesù, the most spectacular of a fresco program encompassing virtually the entire church that Baciccio worked on for thirteen years (1672-85).
AUTHOR: BACICCIO
TITLE: Cupola decoration

DESCRIPTION: In earlier examples the architecture served as the framing for the pictures, in Il Gesù the relationship between architecture and painting was redefined: painting and decoration are confined to those portions of the church structure of greatest symbolic importance
AUTHOR: BACICCIO
TITLE: Cupola decoration

DESCRIPTION: The composition of the painting, painted for the Jesuits in Rome, derives from a design by Bernini, known by the Baciccio from an engraving
AUTHOR: BACICCIO
TITLE: The Preaching of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: This highly finished Garden of Eden is attributed to Jacob de Backer, one of the region's most orthodox interpreters of the Italian maniera
AUTHOR: BACKER, Jacob de
TITLE: Garden of Eden
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77,5 x 107,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a copy of a painting by the Master of Flémalle (Robert Campin)
AUTHOR: BAEGERT, Derick
TITLE: Saint Luke Painting the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: In 1672 the great European powers joined forces and attacked the Dutch Republic, threatening to overwhelm the country.
AUTHOR: BAEN, Jan de
TITLE: The Corpses of the De Witt Brothers

DESCRIPTION: This cost the De Witt brothers, Johan and Cornelis, their lives.
AUTHOR: BAEN, Jan de
TITLE: The Corpses of the De Witt Brothers

DESCRIPTION: De Baen's painting depicts their corpses hanging on the Groene Zoodje on the Vijverberg in The Hague.
AUTHOR: BAEN, Jan de
TITLE: The Corpses of the De Witt Brothers

DESCRIPTION: Johan de Witt was the Pensionary (the factual leader) of Holland, the most powerful province.
AUTHOR: BAEN, Jan de
TITLE: The Corpses of the De Witt Brothers

DESCRIPTION: He was assassinated by a carefully organized lynch "mob" after visiting his brother Cornelis de Witt in prison.
AUTHOR: BAEN, Jan de
TITLE: The Corpses of the De Witt Brothers

DESCRIPTION: He was decoyed into this trap by a forged letter
AUTHOR: BAEN, Jan de
TITLE: The Corpses of the De Witt Brothers

DESCRIPTION: Baglione, a colleague and rival of Caravaggio, explored the subject of St John the Baptist in the Wilderness as early as 1600 and he continued to paint images of St John the Baptist throughout his long and productive career.The probable model for the present version could be Caravaggio's St John the Baptist in Kansas City
AUTHOR: BAGLIONE, Giovanni
TITLE: St John the Baptist in the Wilderness

DESCRIPTION: This painting was made in competition with Caravaggio's Amor Victorious, but it is characteristic that Baglione's painting was later considered a Caravaggio.Baglione depicted an angel in full armour, which Orazio Gentileschi had criticized.
AUTHOR: BAGLIONE, Giovanni
TITLE: Heavenly Love and Earthly Love

DESCRIPTION: This angel is shown chastising a boy Cupid, painted in Caravaggio's style, with a sword of light
AUTHOR: BAGLIONE, Giovanni
TITLE: Heavenly Love and Earthly Love

DESCRIPTION: Baldovinetti's Annunciation is in the atrium of Santissima Annunziata in Florence.
AUTHOR: BALDOVINETTI, Alessio
TITLE: Nativity

DESCRIPTION: His interest in local landscape is evident in the Arno Valley view that he chose as the background of this fresco.
AUTHOR: BALDOVINETTI, Alessio
TITLE: Nativity

DESCRIPTION: In fact he painted only a few portions of the picture in true fresco, and then waited until the plaster had dried so that he could paint 'a secco.'
AUTHOR: BALDOVINETTI, Alessio
TITLE: Nativity

DESCRIPTION: But because the fresco was located in an atrium exposed to winter fogs and even rain, in time the a secco faces, hands, and drapery peeled off, and his underdrawing is now visible.

DESCRIPTION: Kneeling beneath the crosses of Calvary, the Virgin mourns her Son whose body lies before her.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: John supports the dead Christ's head, while Mary Magdalene, her long hair flowing, lifts one of His hands to her cheek.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Behind John stands Joseph of Arimathaea with an anointing-vessel, and behind the Virgin rises the upright of the bare cross, stained with the blood of the crucified Saviour; on the tree next to it can be seen the bound foot of one of the thieves.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Beyond is a rocky landscape with a castle on the edge of a lake.Apart from the Berlin panel, the theme of the Lamentation occurs in only one other painting by Baldung.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: The picture in the Landesmuseum at Innsbruck, which bears the date 1513 and is clearly an earlier work, is much more constricted, more angular and restless in its composition.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: In the Berlin painting the dramatic outburst of grief on the part of John and Mary Magdalene has given way to silent resignation.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: This simplification of the forms and softening of the outline is also apparent in two drawings on the same theme, a sketch in Basel for the Innsbruck painting, which bears the date 1513, and a drawing in a private collection, which is dated 1515.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: By studying as well two woodcuts on the same subject, the consistent development of Baldung's style from early apprenticeship to the full maturity of the Berlin Lamentation shows up in a telling manner.The artist, whose family came from Swabia, was born at Weyersheim near Strasbourg.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: At the age of 18 he began his apprenticeship in Dürer's workshop in Nuremberg.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: It may have been the patricians of the imperial city who later obtained for him the commission for two altarpieces which he completed around 1507 for Halle Cathedral.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: One, representing the Adoration of the Magi, eventually found its way to the Berlin Gallery.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: While in Strasbourg, of which town he had become a burgher in 1509, he received the important commission for the high altar in Freiburg Cathedral, whereupon he moved to Freiburg and spent several years there, roughly between 1512 and 1517.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: It was only towards the end of the second decade, when he had completed this major work, that Baldung seems to have painted the Lamentation, in which one can detect traces of the imposing Freiburg style, a distinct departure from the late-Gothic resonances of the Innsbruck panel.Hardly anything is known about the origins of this picture.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: The Lamentation of Christ

DESCRIPTION: At one time it belonged to a private collector in southern France.

DESCRIPTION: Mucius Scaevola (Livy 2:12-13) was a hero of Roman legend.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: When the Etruscan forces, led by Lars Porsena, king of Clusium, were besieging Rome, a young Roman nobleman, Caius Mucius, succeeded in penetrating the enemy lines in disguise, meaning to kill Porsena.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: By mistake he killed the king's secretary who was sitting beside him.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: Mucius was seized but, to show how cheaply he held his life, thrust his right hand into the flames of an altar fire and let it burn.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: Porsena, amazed by his endurance, set him free.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: He was thereafter called Scaevola, meaning 'left-handed'.In painting, of the Renaissance and later, Mucius stands for the virtues of patience and constancy.
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: His sacrifice was also held to be a prefiguration of Christ's sacrifice
AUTHOR: BALDUNG GRIEN, Hans
TITLE: Mucius Scaevola

DESCRIPTION: Ovid (Met.
AUTHOR: BALEN, Hendrick van
TITLE: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury

DESCRIPTION: 2:708-832) tells how three sisters, returning from the festival of Minerva and carrying her sacred baskets on their heads, were espied by Mercury who immediately fell in love with the most beautiful of them, Herse.
AUTHOR: BALEN, Hendrick van
TITLE: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury

DESCRIPTION: Another of the sisters, Aglauros, was consumed with envy, and tried to prevent Mercury entering Herse's chamber when he came to her one night.
AUTHOR: BALEN, Hendrick van
TITLE: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury

DESCRIPTION: He touched Aglauros with his wand and she turned to black stone, the colour of her thoughts.The present playful and sensuous representation of the story is similar both in style and theme to a number of others executed by van Balen and his circle.
AUTHOR: BALEN, Hendrick van
TITLE: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury

DESCRIPTION: Van Balen was specialised in small cabinet pictures which often depicted mythological scenes.
AUTHOR: BALEN, Hendrick van
TITLE: Herse and her Sisters with Mercury

DESCRIPTION: Paolo Antonio Barbieri, brother of the famous Guercino, was a master of the still-life.
AUTHOR: BARBIERI, Paolo Antonio
TITLE: The Spice Shop

DESCRIPTION: The austere composition of The Spice Shop, in which tall spice jars are arranged in a row parallel to the picture plane, has similarities with the art of Jacopo da Empoli, while the characterization of the youthful and romantic seller of spices reflects aspects of Guercino’s style, though the execution is drier
AUTHOR: BARBIERI, Paolo Antonio
TITLE: The Spice Shop

DESCRIPTION: Thomas Barker of Bath was a self-taught landscape and genre painter who was influenced by Gainsborough.

DESCRIPTION: He is mostly known for his rustic scenes.

DESCRIPTION: The present signed and dated landscape was executed in Rome
AUTHOR: BARKER, Thomas
TITLE: Italianate Landscape With Travellers

DESCRIPTION: Federico Barrocci's Aeneas' Flight from Troy with Anchises, his son Ascanius and his wife Creusa is the second version painted in 1598 of a picture executed ten years earlier for Emperor Rudolf II of Austria.
AUTHOR: BAROCCI, Federico Fiori
TITLE: Aeneas' Flight from Troy

DESCRIPTION: Cardinal Giuliano della Rovere presented Cardinal Scipione with this second version, which entered the Borghese collection before 1613.
AUTHOR: BAROCCI, Federico Fiori
TITLE: Aeneas' Flight from Troy

DESCRIPTION: It was this painting that inspired Cardinal Scipione to commission a large marble group on the same subject from Gian Lorenzo Bernini (also in the Borghese Gallery).
AUTHOR: BAROCCI, Federico Fiori
TITLE: Aeneas' Flight from Troy

DESCRIPTION: The myth of Aeneas, ancestor of Romulus and Remus, referred to the birth of Rome and thus confirmed the Borghese family's high status in the city.Barrocci's many drawings of nature led him to achieve a spontaneity and naturalness in movement, colour and airy effects, and a silvery luminosity that was to influence the 17th-century masters, particularly Rubens.
AUTHOR: BAROCCI, Federico Fiori
TITLE: Aeneas' Flight from Troy

DESCRIPTION: Never before had flames been painted so close to, with an energy suggesting even the crackle of the fire, from which Ascanius seems to be protecting himself by covering his ears.
AUTHOR: BAROCCI, Federico Fiori
TITLE: Aeneas' Flight from Troy

DESCRIPTION: But the human delicacy of Barrocci's anti-heroic and anti-rhetorical figures was not to be really appreciated in Rome, because it could not compete with the classical antique statuary
AUTHOR: BAROCCI, Federico Fiori
TITLE: Aeneas' Flight from Troy

AUTHOR: BARTOLINI, Lorenzo
TITLE: Trust in God

DESCRIPTION: The nudity of the adolescent figure was meant to represent the human soul placing its trust in the Lord, but much of the sculpture's appeal doubtless stems from its undertone of eroticism.The statue was commissioned from Bartolini by Rosa Trivulzio Poldi Pezzoli.
AUTHOR: BARTOLINI, Lorenzo
TITLE: Trust in God

DESCRIPTION: It was an immediate success, highly praised by critics
AUTHOR: BARTOLINI, Lorenzo

DESCRIPTION: The decoration encompassed New Testament scenes in the north aisle by Lippo Memmi (c.
AUTHOR: BARTOLO DI FREDI

DESCRIPTION: by Taddeo di Bartolo (c.

AUTHOR: BARTOLO DI FREDI

DESCRIPTION: The scenes are: The Departure of Abraham and Lot (above left), Abraham and Lot Separate (above right), God and Satan Agree on the Temptation of Job (below left), Sabeans and Chaldeans Kill Job's Servants.You can find a description of the frescoes in the north aisle in the section of Lippo Memmi

DESCRIPTION: Around 1475, Bartolomeo della Gatta painted this picture for the Benedictine Church of the Contesse in Cortona.
AUTHOR: BARTOLOMEO DELLA GATTA
TITLE: The Lady of the Assumption Gives St Thomas Her Belt

DESCRIPTION: It can be considered his masterpiece because it reaches a degree of lyricism only achieved previously by Piero della Francesca.The painting was moved into the Church of St Dominic in 1788 where the Servants of Mary, who used to run the church, repainted the two Benedictine saints in the foreground, St Benedict and St Scolastica, transforming them into Filippo Benizzi and Giuliana Falconeri, two saints of their religious order.
AUTHOR: BARTOLOMEO DELLA GATTA
TITLE: The Lady of the Assumption Gives St Thomas Her Belt

DESCRIPTION: recent restoration has returned the painting to its original beauty and has also removed a group of angels added in the eighteenth century
AUTHOR: BARTOLOMEO DELLA GATTA
TITLE: The Lady of the Assumption Gives St Thomas Her Belt

DESCRIPTION: Marco Basaiti, an admirer of Antonello da Messina and Giovanni Bellini found himself fascinated at the beginning of the sixteenth century by the new artistic manner pioneered by Giorgione.
AUTHOR: BASAITI, Marco
TITLE: Christ Praying in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: Already in 'Christ Praying in the Garden' which adorned the first altar on the right in the Church of San Giobbe and which belonged to the family of Francesco Foscari, the influence of the style of Antonello (visible in the integrity of colour of the figures and the arrangement of saints at the sides of the portico, of the apostles, and of Christ absorbed in prayer) gives way in the landscape to lyrically dreaming passages clearly drawing their spirit from Giorgione.
AUTHOR: BASAITI, Marco
TITLE: Christ Praying in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: Though this panel may not exactly offer a complete synthesis of the late fifteenth century world with the dazzling innovations of the early years of the sixteenth century, it is nevertheless emblematic of the meeting-point of two of the finest ages of Venetian painting.The doubt over the date derive from a faded inscription.
AUTHOR: BASAITI, Marco
TITLE: Christ Praying in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The represented saints are Louis of Toulouse, Francis, Dominic, and Mark
AUTHOR: BASAITI, Marco
TITLE: Christ Praying in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: Marco Basaiti's painting of St Peter on the throne surrounded by four Saints stands on the south wall of Venetian church of San Pietro di Castello
AUTHOR: BASAITI, Marco
TITLE: St Peter Enthroned and Four Saints

DESCRIPTION: Because he was in holy orders, Baschenis is sometimes referred to as Father Evaristo.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: The Bergamese Baschenis was, more than anything else, the perfect example of a "specialist" painter.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: In fact nearly all his oeuvre was dedicated to painting musical instruments, sometimes his pictures being finished by other painters who added figures (as in the case of two paintings that have recently been found in the Brera in Milan).
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: From this specific point of view, Baschenis is one of the most fascinating and focused painters of the whole of the seventeenth century.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: His use of realism and light is reminiscent of Caravaggio.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: His canvases had an intense quality which was dominated by his exceptional technical ability (one thing that stands out is the way in which he depicted dust on the back of stringed instruments).But Baschenis' work never degenerated into a mere display of virtuoso talent.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: It was rather directed to convey a sense of almost severe moral purpose.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: Baschenis' success with still-life gave rise, especially in Bergamo itself, to a real fashion for the genre, with other painters following his example.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments and a Small Classical Statue

DESCRIPTION: Evaristo Baschenis is universally acknowledged as the inventor of the musical instrument still-life and its most celebrated practitioner.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: He was himself a practicing musician who clearly had a deep understanding of the instruments that he painted.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: The instruments in the present painting are: a theorbo; below it a mandolino; a Venetian lute; a pentagonal spinet; a violin; an ebony inlaid guitar, and a harp.
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: The red damask cloth and the richly embroidered drapery overhead recur in other works by Baschenis
AUTHOR: BASCHENIS, Evaristo
TITLE: Still-Life with Musical Instruments in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: The design is a repetition of a larger composition by Francesco Bassano known in two signed versions in National Gallery in Prague, and the Musée des Beaux-Arts in Rouen
AUTHOR: BASSANO, Francesco
TITLE: The Presentation of Christ in the Temple

DESCRIPTION: An extraordinary burst of light bounces off the characters, casting silky reflections on the robes and making the gold glimmer.
AUTHOR: BASSANO, Jacopo
TITLE: St Valentine Baptizing St Lucilla

DESCRIPTION: The painter produced this masterpiece when he was well into his middle age.
AUTHOR: BASSANO, Jacopo
TITLE: St Valentine Baptizing St Lucilla

DESCRIPTION: It gives us tremendous insight into his enormously innovative power which fell between popular realism and magical effects.
AUTHOR: BASSANO, Jacopo
TITLE: St Valentine Baptizing St Lucilla

DESCRIPTION: It is astounding to think Jacopo Bassano was able to produce paintings of this stature when he was so removed from the major centres of art
AUTHOR: BASSANO, Jacopo
TITLE: St Valentine Baptizing St Lucilla

DESCRIPTION: This drawing is study for a large composition (destroyed in 1943) for the refectory of the abbey of Montecassino, the Miracle of the Loaves and the Fishes.

TITLE: Little Girl Carrying a Basket
TECHNIQUE: Pastel on burnished blue paper, 304 x 130 mm

TITLE: Little Girl Carrying a Basket

DESCRIPTION: In the second half of the fourteenth century, Augustinian nuns erected a church in the district of Cannareggio in Venice and dedicated the sacristy and a confraternity to St Jerome.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: They ambitiously decorated their headquarter with paintings depicting episodes from the life of the titular saint.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: Bastiani's contribution to the cycle consisted of two huge canvases, the Communion of St Jerome, and the Funeral of St Jerome.In the Communion of St Jerome, the saint is kneeling in his cell, as is confirmed by his bed, the open book, the crucifix, and the scourge.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: He is supported by his friend and disciple Eusebius and surrounded by the brethren.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: A pillar defines another scene.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: In the cloister of the monastery in Jerusalem, Jerome faces a person in eastern attire while he walks in the garden with another individual dressed in the Greek style, which may allude to his battle against heresy.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: The huge tree in the foreground is a symbol of salvation and life, while in the background, the hills, the battlements, and the well, although drawn from real life, are Marian symbols designed to inspire the devout to meditation and silent prayer.
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: On the right, the quail represent the church, and the lion, the usual attribute of the saint, also belongs to St Mark and thus to the Venetian Republic
AUTHOR: BASTIANI, Lazzaro
TITLE: Communion of St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: The paintig is signed and dated lower right: J. BASTIEN-LEPAGE 1881

DESCRIPTION: This is perhaps the most famous painting by Bazille.
AUTHOR: BAZILLE, Jean-Frédéric
TITLE: Family Gathering

DESCRIPTION: It depicts a family in the shade on a terrace at Méric, near Montpellier in the south of France.
AUTHOR: BAZILLE, Jean-Frédéric
TITLE: Family Gathering

DESCRIPTION: The painting was accepted at the 1868 Salon.
AUTHOR: BAZILLE, Jean-Frédéric
TITLE: Family Gathering

DESCRIPTION: The picture, showing Bazille's parents and relations, conveys a sense of family and of social status, a particular lifestyle, and a fresh response to Nature and light; in painting it, Bazille was also out to convince his family of his ability as an artist
AUTHOR: BAZILLE, Jean-Frédéric
TITLE: Family Gathering

DESCRIPTION: Though most of his activity took place in Mantua, Giuseppe Bazzani is usually ranged with the Settecento painters of Venice, owing to his stylistic relationship to them.
AUTHOR: BAZZANI, Giuseppe
TITLE: The Agony of Christ in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: His fluid brush-work, soft forms and fiery colours certainly show the influence of Venetian masters, but his dramatic expression and lively composition show greater individualism
AUTHOR: BAZZANI, Giuseppe
TITLE: The Agony of Christ in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: Beaumont's contribution to the painting of the Palazzo Reale includes, in addition to four living rooms, two galleries, of which the Galleria della Regina, later named after him, is one of the largest (60 m long) and the most magnificent of its kind.
AUTHOR: BEAUMONT, Claudio Francesco
TITLE: Aeneas Legend: Aeneas Landing on the Mouth of the Tiber

DESCRIPTION: In 1833, it was separated from the palace complex, and has since served as the Armeria Reale, housing the Savoyard weapon collection.The subject of the ceiling painting in the Galleria is the legend of Aeneas, the mortal son of Venus who escaped from the burning Troy with his father and his son, and after many trials and misadventures landed at last at the mouth of the Tiber.
AUTHOR: BEAUMONT, Claudio Francesco
TITLE: Aeneas Legend: Aeneas Landing on the Mouth of the Tiber

DESCRIPTION: There he became through his son Ascanius the progenitor of the gens Julia.The picture shows one of the two tondi with Aeneas Landing on the Mouth of the Tiber
AUTHOR: BEAUMONT, Claudio Francesco
TITLE: Aeneas Legend: Aeneas Landing on the Mouth of the Tiber

DESCRIPTION: In a theme that was majestically treated by Masaccio a century earlier, Beccafumi does not retain an orderly sense of scale for his figures, so that God the Father and the crucified Christ are much smaller in relation to the side saints (Sts Cosmas and John the Baptist at left, Sts John the Evangelist and Damian at right).
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Trinity

DESCRIPTION: All of his figures seem to deny pure volumetric presence, this despite the fact that Beccafumi was accomplished both as a bronze sculptor and painter
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Trinity

DESCRIPTION: Frescoes in the oratories of brotherhoods are found throughout Italy.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Oratory

DESCRIPTION: In 1516 to 1518 the Sienese brotherhood of Mary and Bernardino commissioned Girolamo del Pacchia, Sodoma, and Domenico Beccafumi to fresco the walls of their oratory with a cycle on the life of Mary, The artists painted two stories each: Pacchia, the Birth of Mary and the Annunciation; Sodoma, the Presentation of the Virgin and the Coronation of Mary; and Beccafumi, the Betrothal of Mary and the Death of the Virgin.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Oratory

DESCRIPTION: The missing scenes on the right-hand longitudinal wall, the Visitation and the Assumption of the Virgin were not painted by Sodoma until the late 1520s, and Baccafumi's altarpiece still later, between 1535 and 1537.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Oratory

DESCRIPTION: The cycle begins on the left wall (The Birth of Mary to THe Betrothal of Mary), and continues above the altar wall (Annunciation) and the right longitudinal wall (Visitation to Assumption of the Virgin) through the second of the short walls (The Coronation of Mary).
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Oratory

DESCRIPTION: In addition to the stories from the life of Mary, there are four frescoed standing figures of Franciscan saints in the corners of the longitudinal walls
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Oratory

DESCRIPTION: This panel is one of the surviving two predella paintings which belonged to the altarpiece commissioned for the church of San Niccolò al Carmine, Siena.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: The Appearance of St Michael on the Castel Sant'Angelo

DESCRIPTION: The predella depicted scenes from the legend of St Michael.Most unusually, in these panels Beccafumi has abandoned the oil he used for the altarpiece for the old-fashioned, less flexible medium of tempera.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: The Appearance of St Michael on the Castel Sant'Angelo

DESCRIPTION: It could be the influence of the newly discovered ancient Roman frescoes in the Baths of Titus which Beccafumi had seen in Rome
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: The Appearance of St Michael on the Castel Sant'Angelo

DESCRIPTION: Late in his career, Beccafumi executed an important series of paintings for the venerable Cathedral of Pisa.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and the Golden Calf

DESCRIPTION: Moses and the Golden Calf is disturbing in its originality because the figures have become increasingly thin, diaphanous, and dependent upon silhouette and outline to achieve convincing form.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and the Golden Calf

DESCRIPTION: Scale is unconventional and has little significance by normal usage.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and the Golden Calf

DESCRIPTION: Moses, holding the tablets, stands in a contorted pose and looks disapprovingly at the miniaturized golden calf nearby.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and the Golden Calf

DESCRIPTION: The sharply foreshortened nude youth in the left foreground is difficult to interpret.
AUTHOR: BECCAFUMI, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and the Golden Calf

DESCRIPTION: The painting portrays Mrs Simeon, standing in a landscape, with a dog by her side.
AUTHOR: BEECHEY, Sir William
TITLE: Portrait of Mrs Simeon

DESCRIPTION: Mrs Simeon, née Harriet Parry, was the daughter of Thomas Parry, a director of the East India Company between 1785-1816
AUTHOR: BEECHEY, Sir William
TITLE: Portrait of Mrs Simeon

DESCRIPTION: There are two other paintings (Kunsthalle, Hamburg and Museum, Leeuwarden) depicting the same Gothic village church and the funeral procession
AUTHOR: BEERSTRATEN, Jan Abrahamsz.
TITLE: Village of Nieukoop in Winter with Child Funeral

DESCRIPTION: A young woman strums her lute in an expansive, stone interior.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: A male accompanist, whose crude facial features contrast pointedly with the more delicate ones of his companion, sings and plays the violin beside her.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: His plain outfit differs from his friends elegant attire.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: The lavish fabrics are complemented by the expensive instruments: in addition to the violin and lute, a bass violin rests against the bench in the foreground while a shawm, the ancestor of the oboe, lies just above it.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: Costly music books are also heaped beside the figures.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: The murky, grayish-brown background of this ambiguous, lapidary setting also contains a large ewer and expansive curtain whose knots and folds echo the fabric encasing the lutenist.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: The emphasis here is upon luxury.
AUTHOR: BEGA, Cornelis
TITLE: The Duet

DESCRIPTION: This idyllic Italianate Landscape depicts a herdsman and his cattle resting near a tree.
AUTHOR: BEGEYN, Abraham Jansz.
TITLE: Italianate Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Begeyn is noted mainly for his intricate views of villages and towns and for his southern seaports and Italianate landscapes
AUTHOR: BEGEYN, Abraham Jansz.
TITLE: Italianate Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Barthel Beham was Dürer's most talented successor.
AUTHOR: BEHAM, Barthel
TITLE: Portrait of Duke Ludwig X of Bavaria

DESCRIPTION: His Portrait of Duke Ludwig X of Bavaria is distinguished by its exceptional quality: the fur and hair are executed with meticulous precision, as are the highlights on his forehead and the lines of his face.
AUTHOR: BEHAM, Barthel
TITLE: Portrait of Duke Ludwig X of Bavaria

DESCRIPTION: Noteworthy is the depiction of Ludwig's left hand resting on a parapet: it reaches out of the picture frame towards the viewer
AUTHOR: BEHAM, Barthel
TITLE: Portrait of Duke Ludwig X of Bavaria

DESCRIPTION: Leonhard van Eck (1480-1550) was the chancellor to Duke Wilhelm IV of Bavaria, who was the patron of Barthel Beham.
AUTHOR: BEHAM, Barthel
TITLE: Chancellor Leonhard van Eck
TECHNIQUE: Oil on spruce panel, 56 x 38 cm

DESCRIPTION: He opposed the Reformation and supported the Wittelsbach cause against the Habsburg monarchs.The identification of the portrait is based on an engraving bearing the initials of Barthel Beham that also provides the name of the sitter, his age (47) and the date (1527).
AUTHOR: BEHAM, Barthel
TITLE: Chancellor Leonhard van Eck
TECHNIQUE: Oil on spruce panel, 56 x 38 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is proposed that both the painting and the engraving are based on a now-lost drawing by the artist
AUTHOR: BEHAM, Barthel
TITLE: Chancellor Leonhard van Eck
TECHNIQUE: Oil on spruce panel, 56 x 38 cm

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the central panel of the triptych depicting the Virgin with the Child
AUTHOR: BELLEGAMBE, Jean
TITLE: The Le Cellier Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and oil on wood, 102 x 61 cm

DESCRIPTION: In this triptych the artist employed both late-Medieval and High Renaissance manners, the latter derived from secondhand sources such as Marcantonio Raimondi's reproductive prints
AUTHOR: BELLEGAMBE, Jean
TITLE: The Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 222 x 178 (central), 222 x 82 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: This canvas depicts the healing of Pietro dei Ludovici.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Gentile
TITLE: The Healing of Pietro dei Ludovici

DESCRIPTION: The miracle, which occurred through contact with a processional candle which had touched the relic of the Holy Cross, takes place inside a chapel which is in large part occupied by an extremely elegant ciborium surmounted by the eagle symbol of St John the Evangelist.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Gentile
TITLE: The Healing of Pietro dei Ludovici

DESCRIPTION: This detail and also the triptych on the altar which recalls the one painted by Bastiani in his canvas depicting the "Donation of the Relic", suggests that Gentile Bellini wished here to set the scene in the interior of the church of St John the Evangelist.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Gentile
TITLE: The Healing of Pietro dei Ludovici

DESCRIPTION: Echoing his father Jacopo's interest in Renaissance "umbratile", Gentile Bellini concentrates on the detailed rendering of the complex play of architectural surfaces within which human figures play their part
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Gentile
TITLE: The Healing of Pietro dei Ludovici

DESCRIPTION: This grave, pensive Madonna is typical of Bellini's early half-length Madonnas.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: Lifting her hands in prayer, Mary looks sadly down toward the sleeping Christ, whose slumber is meant to remind the observer of his death on the cross.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: Mary's face is suffused by light from below - sea light of Venice reflected from canals and palaces which Bellini used even for Madonnas set in landscapes
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: Of all the still youthful Madonnas by Bellini the masterpiece is the so called Greek Madonna of the Brera Gallery in Milan, which entered the Museum in 1808 following the Napoleonic repression.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: It was originally in the Ducal Palace in Venice.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: According to some sources the figures were originally set against a gold background, on which the words "Mother of God" and "Christ" were written in Greek (hence the name of the painting).
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: Obviously, a background of this type would have made it archaic and "archaizing", considerably accentuating the Byzantine appearance of the panel, a veritable Marian icon.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: The 1986 restoration has established that the still remaining traces of gold beside the Greek letters were a 16th-century addition, while Bellini had originally conceived the sky as it appears now: blue and almost entirely covered by a small curtain held up by a cord.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: Over the traditional preparatory ground (gypsum and animal glue) he had sketched out the preliminary drawing, marking in with extreme precision even the chiaroscuro with subtle and highly regular criss-cross strokes which can be seen in infra-red photography.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: This technique used by Bellini must have been famous if Paolo Pino in his Dialogo di pittura (1548) writes that "drawing the painting with such extreme diligence, composing it with chiaro and scuro as Giovanni Bellino was wont to do" was to be discouraged "for it is work thrown away since everything must be covered with the colours".This type of drawing shows similarities with the rigorous Flemish constructive technique, though under closer scrutiny it appears to be aimed at a search for a much more solid and volumetrically constructed plastic quality.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: The delicate imperturbability of the Madonna, which would always remain a distinctive feature of Bellini's Virgins, shows not only its aforementioned Byzantine-iconic roots, but also how much the artist's culture owes to this heritage
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child (Greek Madonna)

DESCRIPTION: It was assumed by Berenson that this Madonna is a posthumous portrait of the artist's sister.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas transferred from wood, 52 x 43 cm

DESCRIPTION: The sky was completely repainted
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna with the Child
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas transferred from wood, 52 x 43 cm

DESCRIPTION: The polyptich of St.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni

DESCRIPTION: Vincent Ferrer, executed for the altar dedicated to the saint in the Venetian basilica of St.

TITLE: Polyptych of San Vincenzo Ferreri

DESCRIPTION: John and St.

DESCRIPTION: Paul, is Bellini's first public assignment.

TITLE: Polyptych of San Vincenzo Ferreri

DESCRIPTION: It comprises nine panels arranged in three parts: above the Pietà with the Virgin and and the Angel of the Annunciation at the side;  in the centre the titular saint with St.

TITLE: Polyptych of San Vincenzo Ferreri

DESCRIPTION: Christopher and St.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
