DESCRIPTION: Sebastian at the sides; in the predella five miracles of the saint.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Polyptych of San Vincenzo Ferreri

DESCRIPTION: Formerly the painting was crowned by a lunette which is lost
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Polyptych of San Vincenzo Ferreri

DESCRIPTION: The painting, which has been in Bergamo since the 16th century, probably formed part of the dowry of the Carmelite nun Lucrezia Agliardi Vertova, abbess of the Sant'Anna monastery at Albino.On the parapet in front of the Virgin, a detail present in many other similar compositions, there is a fruit.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: Like the walled and many-towered city on the right, and the inlet on the left, it is a symbol referring to the Virgin, according to the attributes assigned to her by hymns, analects and lauds ever since the Middle Ages.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: The mother and child are linked, more than by the tender embracing gesture, by the rapt, reflective gaze with which the Madonna engulf her son.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: The painting is the prototype from which various similar compositions derive, such as the Madonna and Red Angels of the Accademia in Venice, with the child seated on the Virgin's left knee
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: The painting is one of a series of portraits executed by Bellini around 1500.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: The series culminated in the portrait of Doge Loredan (National Gallery, London)
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: This work, along with the Portrait of a Young Man conserved in the Galleria Capitolina, is recorded in the Inventories of 1753 as a self portrait, and as such it continues to be regarded, even though this supposition lacks any scientific foundation.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: The portrait is highly distinctive, the face having a mellow, moulded quality accentuated by its halo of soft curls and the round clouds which fill the sky in the background
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: One of the "Sacra conversazione" compositions of the artist, signed and dated as "IOANNES BELLINVS / M.D.VII.".
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Four Saints and Donator

DESCRIPTION: The four saints are John the Baptist and Francis at the left, Jerome and Sebastian at the right.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Four Saints and Donator

DESCRIPTION: The painting probably belonged to the altarpiece Chist Crowned with Thorns (now in Stockholm) which was donated to Louis XII, King of France
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Four Saints and Donator

DESCRIPTION: The Feast of the Gods was Giovanni Bellini's last great  painting and one of only a few that he executed on canvas.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: It was the first in a series of mythologies or bacchanals commissioned by Duke Alfonso d'Este to decorate the camerino d'alabastro, or alabaster study, of his castle in Ferrara.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: The artist, whose career began in the 1450s, was trained to paint on wooden panels, which require a very meticulous application of pigment.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: When he worked on canvas late in his career, Bellini retained his tight, precise brushwork.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: The flesh tones, iridescent silks, and even the foreground pebbles here demonstrate his delicate touch.According to the current interpretations, the scene illustrates a passage from Ovid's Fasti (The Feasts), a long classical poem that recounts the origins of many  ancient Roman rites and festivals.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: Ovid (43 B.C.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: - A.D.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: 17), describing a banquet given by the god of wine, mentioned an incident that embarrassed Priapus, god of  virility.The beautiful nymph Lotis, shown reclining at the far right, was lulled to sleep by wine.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: Priapus, overcome by lust, seized the opportunity to take advantage of her and is portrayed bending forward to lift her skirt.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: His attempt was foiled when an ass, seen at the left, "with raucous braying, gave out an ill-timed roar.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: Awakened, the startled nymph pushed Priapus away, and the god was laughed at by all."
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: Priapus, his pride wounded, took revenge by demanding the annual sacrifice of a donkey.The ass stands next to Silenus, a woodland deity who used the beast to carry wood, thus wears a keg on his belt because he was a follower of Bacchus, god of wine.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: Bacchus himself, seen as an infant, kneels before them while decanting wine into a crystal pitcher.Reading from left to right, the principal figures are:Silenus, a woodland god attended by his donkeyBacchus, the infant god of wine crowned with grape leavesFaunus or Silvanus, an old forest god wearing a wreath of pine needlesMercury, the messenger of the gods carrying his caduceus or herald's staffJupiter, the king of the gods accompanied by an eagleAn unidentified goddess holding a quince, a fruit associated in the ancient world with marriagePan, a satyr with a grape wreath who blows on his shepherd's pipesNeptune, the god of the sea sitting beside his trident harpoonCeres, the goddess of cereal grains with a wreath of wheatApollo, god of the sun and the arts, crowned by laurel and holding a Renaissance stringed musical instrument, the lira da braccio, in lieu of a classical lyrePriapus, the god of virility and of vineyards with a scythe, used to prune orchards, hanging from the tree above himLotis, one of the naiads, a nymph of fresh waters who represents chastity.These deities are waited upon by three naiads, nymphs of streams and brooks, and two satyrs, goat-footed inhabitants of the wilderness.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: On the distant mountain, which Titian added to Bellini's picture, two more satyrs cavort drunkenly and a hunting hound chases a stag
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Feast of the Gods

DESCRIPTION: This panel once belonged to an altarpiece.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St John the Evangelist

DESCRIPTION: It is characteristic of Jacopo Bellini's early art, the figure still Gothic, its niche Renaissance
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St John the Evangelist

DESCRIPTION: Jacopo Bellini had more than one opportunity to observe St Bernardino (1380-1444) and hear him preach.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St Bernardino da Siena

DESCRIPTION: His portrait gives us a close-up view of the saint who stands before a velvet cloth decorated with thistle leaves and Christ's monogram.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St Bernardino da Siena

DESCRIPTION: The saint's mouth is open, displaying three small teeth, and his eyes are directed downward toward a crucifix.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St Bernardino da Siena

DESCRIPTION: The saint is shown as a living, speaking presence, perhaps the first such portrait of the Renaissance.The Sienese preacher St Bernardino, a prominent figure in the reform branch of the Franciscan order known as the Observants, was widely portrayed.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St Bernardino da Siena

DESCRIPTION: In addition to a death mask, there are medals, standing and bust-length painted depictions, terracotta busts and statues, and engravings.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St Bernardino da Siena

DESCRIPTION: Following his canonization in 1450, he was shown repeatedly in altarpieces
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: St Bernardino da Siena

DESCRIPTION: Four triptychs can still be seen in the church of the Carità, for which they were painted, now incorporated into the Gallerie dell'Accademia.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: Triptych of St Lawrence

DESCRIPTION: The triptychs are the Triptych of St Lawrence, the Triptych of the Virgin, the Triptych of St Sebastian, and the Triptych of the Nativity.
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: Triptych of St Lawrence

DESCRIPTION: They were commissioned from Giovanni Bellini but are the collective products of Jacopo Bellini's workshop.The panels of this triptych are: St Lawrence (central panel), St John the Baptist and St Anthony of Padua (side panels), Virgin and Child with Angels (lunette)
AUTHOR: BELLINI, Jacopo
TITLE: Triptych of St Lawrence

DESCRIPTION: A few years later, during his second stay in Saxony, Bellotto depicted the demolition of this Gothic church.
AUTHOR: BELLOTTO, Bernardo
TITLE: The Kreuzkirche in Dresden

DESCRIPTION: There exists an almost identical version in the Gemäldegalerie, Dresden.
AUTHOR: BELLOTTO, Bernardo
TITLE: The Kreuzkirche in Dresden

DESCRIPTION: A few years later, during his second stay in Saxony, Bellotto depicted the demolition of this Gothic church.

DESCRIPTION: There exists an almost identical version in The Hermitage, St.

TITLE: The Kreuzkirche in Dresden

DESCRIPTION: Petersburg.

TITLE: The Kreuzkirche in Dresden

AUTHOR: BELLOTTO, Bernardo
TITLE: Liechtenstein Garden Palace in Vienna Seen from the East

DESCRIPTION: Combining flower painting with ancient sculpture - here, a relief showing an amorous couple - was a seventeenth-century subgenre in which Andrea Belvedere excelled.
AUTHOR: BELVEDERE, Andrea
TITLE: Flowers and Ducks

DESCRIPTION: This large work is one of his most famous
AUTHOR: BELVEDERE, Andrea
TITLE: Flowers and Ducks

DESCRIPTION: This polyptych originally was the altarpiece in the chapel of the Castello di Torrechiara (Emilia-Romagna).
AUTHOR: BEMBO, Benedetto
TITLE: Madonna and Saints

DESCRIPTION: It is a signed and dated work by Benedetto Bembo, who, together with his brother Bonifazio Bembo, decorated the Golden Room of the Castello.The polyptych of the Venetian type, adorned with a richly carved frame, depicts the Madonna with Sts Anthony Abbot, Nicodemus, Catherine of Alexandria and Peter Martyr
AUTHOR: BEMBO, Benedetto
TITLE: Madonna and Saints

DESCRIPTION: Bianca Maria was the natural daughter of Filippo Maria, last Visconti, Duke of Milan.
AUTHOR: BEMBO, Bonifazio
TITLE: Portrait of Bianca Maria Sforza

DESCRIPTION: She married Francesco Sforza in 1432.By means of an extremely delicate laying on of the tempera, Bembo has built up the face in diaphanously transparent layers that are perhaps a trifle cold.
AUTHOR: BEMBO, Bonifazio
TITLE: Portrait of Bianca Maria Sforza

DESCRIPTION: The masses achieve a quality of relief that is contained by the refinement of the colour and the elegance of the descriptive details
AUTHOR: BEMBO, Bonifazio
TITLE: Portrait of Bianca Maria Sforza

DESCRIPTION: The great solemnity of historical paintings was especially apparent in the large pictures by Gyula Benczúr.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: His master, Piloty, concerned himself with stage-like scenes from the history of Europe, but Benczúr who great up in Kassa in the turmoil of the War of Independence, felt that it was more important to depict Hungarian history.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: This early work of his, "László Hunyadi's Farewell", alredy shows his particular talent for composition, human characterization and realistic rendering.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: There is deep sorrow on the face of László Hunyadi, the central figure, and one feels his tragic fate looming over the paintful farewell of his friends, Subdued light falls on the group and is reflected from the white walls that are painted with masterly realism.The great succes of this painting marked the beginning of Benczúr's sparkling artistic career.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: He first exhibited it in Pest in 1867 and then in Paris with the works of eleven other Hungarian painters.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: In 1869, the Pest Picture Gallery Association bought it for the Hungarian National Museum.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: It became so popular that the weekly magazine "Hazánk" (Our Native Land) reproduced it as a colour supplement in the 1870s
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: László Hunyadi's Farewell

DESCRIPTION: Benczúr started to paint "The Recapture of Buda Castle in 1686" in 1885; the composition was completed for the Millennial Celebrations in 1896.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: The Recapture of Buda Castle in 1686

DESCRIPTION: This huge painting was the last such venture of Benczúr and of Hungarian Historical painting in general, since by the turn of the century this genre became out of date.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: The Recapture of Buda Castle in 1686

DESCRIPTION: The composition implies the historical necessity of the Austro-Hungarian Empire by emphasizing that Hungary was freed from Turkish suzerainty in 1686-1687 by the help of Karl of Lotharingia and Eugene of Savoy.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: The Recapture of Buda Castle in 1686

DESCRIPTION: Benczúr groups the figures ingeniously; thus, in spite of the numerous characters, the presentation still remains fluent.
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: The Recapture of Buda Castle in 1686

DESCRIPTION: The careful studies of costumes, props and faces, and their realistic and colourful rendering, were required to establish the historical authenticity of the final work
AUTHOR: BENCZÚR, Gyula
TITLE: The Recapture of Buda Castle in 1686

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the choir vault and apse with illusionistic architecture and scenes from the life of the Virgin (Annunciation, Assumption).The most important setting for the fictive dissolution of ceilings and walls with painting intended to evoke and illustrate heavenly sphere was the church, with its choir tribunes, inner façades, vaults and cupolas.
AUTHOR: BENSO, Giulio
TITLE: Choir vault and apse decoration

DESCRIPTION: The new type of the hall church evolved following the prototype of the Il Gesù in Rome, and offered fresco painters an ideal space to work in.
AUTHOR: BENSO, Giulio
TITLE: Choir vault and apse decoration

DESCRIPTION: The vaulted, single-aisle nave flanked by chapels, transepts flooded by light from the centre cupola, and a spacious choir made possible a sophisticated structuring of the pictorial program in conformity with the architecture.The painterly redecoration of the church of Santissima Annunziata del Vastato in Genoa following its modernization in the style of the Counter-Reformation began around 1625 with the vaults of the aisles.
AUTHOR: BENSO, Giulio
TITLE: Choir vault and apse decoration

DESCRIPTION: The painting of the choir by Giulio Benso began in 1635, and there are staged the most important events of the life of the Virgin as a theatrical spectacle.
AUTHOR: BENSO, Giulio
TITLE: Choir vault and apse decoration

DESCRIPTION: The Annunciation to the Virgin, central to the church's iconography, takes place in the vault, shifted to heavenly spheres with the help of quadratura.
AUTHOR: BENSO, Giulio
TITLE: Choir vault and apse decoration

DESCRIPTION: The drama of the Annunciation - Mary receives the angel's message in an airy loggia, while God floats down in glory above her - is then outdone by the ecstasy of the choir calotte's Assumption.This theatrical staging is considered one of the most successful combinations, with respect to foreshortening of quadratura and figural painting with the actual architecture
AUTHOR: BENSO, Giulio
TITLE: Choir vault and apse decoration

DESCRIPTION: Nicolaes Berchem, the son of a distinguished still-life painter, Pieter Claesz., was born in Haarlem.
AUTHOR: BERCHEM, Nicolaes
TITLE: Peasants with Cattle by a Ruined Aqueduct

DESCRIPTION: The town was a leading centre of landscape painting in the early seventeenth century and among Berchem's teachers was the landscapist Jan van Goyen.
AUTHOR: BERCHEM, Nicolaes
TITLE: Peasants with Cattle by a Ruined Aqueduct

DESCRIPTION: Like many Dutch artists, Berchem travelled to Italy immediately after completing his apprenticeship.
AUTHOR: BERCHEM, Nicolaes

DESCRIPTION: Joachim Beuckelaer, the nephew and pupil of Pieter Aertsen, specialised in market scenes and genre paintings.

TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: Following the path opened up by his uncle, he responded to the growing demand of a prosperous bourgeoisie that wished to decorate their houses with works that reflected the lay character of their surroundings, whilst retaining a moral and religious significance.Jesus' visit to the house of Martha and Mary, taken from St Luke's Gospel, formed the basis of several representations from the mid-16th century onwards.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: In the religious context of the time, this scene illustrated one of the fundamental differences opposing Catholics and Protestants.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: The latter sought salvation in action whilst the former placed greater value on the contemplative life.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: Here the artist relegates the teaching of the divine word to the back of the painting, devoting the entire foreground to active life, incarnated by Martha, and in so doing juxtaposing a genre scene and a still-life.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: Like Aertsen, he assembles the domestic scene in his studio, drawing from a repertory of standard objects and utensils that he was to constantly reproduce elsewhere in various combinations.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: Again like Aertsen, he has borrowed from Serlio's treatise the Renaissance architecture in which he places his composition.However, it would be unfair to dismiss Beuckelaer as a mere follower.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: Rather the artist stands out by his extraordinary ability to reproduce textures in their full sensuousness, using a light and subtle stroke and a delicately gradated palette.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: With considerable virtuosity and delight he precisely depicts the varnished terracotta of the crocks, the flaccid skin of the plucked fowl, the starched but still supple serviettes, and the fragility of the hair drawn back over the kitchen-maid's temples.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: The soft greasiness of the meat or the velvety softness of the mallard duck are set against the flat glint of the tin pot and the glazed transparency of the cabochon glasses or berkemeier.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: A search for harmony guides him in the distribution of objects, colours, light and shade, in a careful composition that leaves nothing to chance.Multiplying the different levels of interpretation, the image moves beyond a simple illustration of the Gospel story to become a philosophical exegesis of visible reality.
AUTHOR: BEUCKELAER, Joachim
TITLE: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary

DESCRIPTION: These symbols of secular and ecclesiastical power at the zenith of the composition are further explained by a richly decorated bowl, worked by a goldsmith.
AUTHOR: BOEL, Pieter
TITLE: Large Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: It shows mythological scenes of unhappy love relationships, partly covering those 'vanitates' which are of lower order - a tambourine, lute, sabre, coat of mail and painter's palette, to name but a few.
AUTHOR: BOEL, Pieter
TITLE: Large Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: The statue of a mourning female figure in one of the niches bears great resemblance to the woman whose contours can be seen in Nicolas Poussin's famous self-portrait  at the Louvre.
AUTHOR: BOEL, Pieter
TITLE: Large Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: She can be regarded as a late successor to the weeping women who surround the altar tomb of Philip the Bold in Dijon.Pieter Boel's painting contains all the features normally associated with baroque solemnity, i.e.
AUTHOR: BOEL, Pieter
TITLE: Large Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: pomp and splendour even where power and wealth have become subject to the darkness of death.
AUTHOR: BOEL, Pieter
TITLE: Large Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: However, although all earthly possessions and authority are marked as vain, the dialectic of the painting never leaves any doubt that their real substance remains undisputed in this world and that the earthly order is preserved intact
AUTHOR: BOEL, Pieter
TITLE: Large Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Boelema's work, especially in composition, owes much to his master, and several of the objects included in the present work are borrowed from Heda's paintings
AUTHOR: BOELEMA DE STOMME, Maerten
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Boilly painted frequently similar scenes in his period in Paris
AUTHOR: BOILLY, Louis Léopold
TITLE: The Toilet

DESCRIPTION: The composition and style of this painting reveal the influence of Jacob Jordaens
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Elijah Fed by an Angel

DESCRIPTION: Bol present himself as the archetypical man of quality holding a rattan cane in his right hand as he leans nonchalantly on a statue of sleeping Cupid.
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: Posed in a full-bottomed wig and an expensive house coat before a stately column on a base, it is a form of presentation which does not differ from the way in which Bol portrayed his rich clientele.The canvas is still in its original limewood frame with auricular carving and festoons which Bol undoubtedly ordered himself
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The story of Venus and Adonis is taken from the tenth book of Ovid's Metamorphoses.
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: Venus, the goddess of love, becomes enamoured of the beautiful young huntsman, Adonis.
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: In Bol's painting Venus and the young Cupid try in vain to prevent Adonis from going hunting, as the goddess has had a premonition that the hunting party will have fatal consequences, and indeed the hunter is killed by a wild boar.The story of Venus and Adonis was a favourite in the Netherlands.
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: Rubens painted the subject several times and Bol later painted another picture of the same theme.
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: It was probably the moral component that made the story popular: Adonis was seen as the epitome of reckless youth, whose rejection of Venus' advice led him to his death
AUTHOR: BOL, Ferdinand
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: This panoramic landscape with multiple figures shows the city of Antwerp on the horizon
AUTHOR: BOL, Hans
TITLE: Panoramic Landscape

DESCRIPTION: This painting was formerly attributed to Lucas Cranach the Younger.
AUTHOR: BOLLANDT, Heinrich
TITLE: Venus and Amor

DESCRIPTION: The pendant of this signed and dated painting, View of Vesuvius Erupting from the Pier of the Port of Naples, is in the Museo di San Martino, Naples
AUTHOR: BONAVIA, Carlo
TITLE: View of a Moonlit Mediterranean Harbour

DESCRIPTION: This painting and The Feast of Dives (Accademia, Venice) are considered Bonifacio's masterpieces.
AUTHOR: BONIFACIO VERONESE
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: He has used the subject as an excuse to paint an open-air holiday scene, in which the luxuriousness of the clothes melts into the opulent landscape dotted with little genre scenes.
AUTHOR: BONIFACIO VERONESE
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: In overall decorative effect, the painting is much like a tapestry.
AUTHOR: BONIFACIO VERONESE
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: Bonifacio's sources of inspiration include Titian and Dosso, with some influence from northern European painters.
AUTHOR: BONIFACIO VERONESE
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: The Veronese artist Francesco Bonssignori was best known to his contemporaries as a portraitist and court artist to the Gonzaga family.
AUTHOR: BONSIGNORI, Francesco
TITLE: Virgin with Child

DESCRIPTION: He was trained under Liberale whose painting style he retained even after arrving in Mantua about 1477, where he also received ideas from Mantegna.
AUTHOR: BONSIGNORI, Francesco
TITLE: Virgin with Child

DESCRIPTION: He worked for Francesco II Gonzaga
AUTHOR: BONSIGNORI, Francesco
TITLE: Virgin with Child

DESCRIPTION: During his lifetime Bonzi was particularly renowned for his still-lifes, but, like Filippo Napoletano, he was also active as a painter of landscapes.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: His output in this genre became entangled with that of Agostino Tassi, even though the two do not really have much in common.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: In addition to this canvas, Bonzi's certain works include The Martyrdom of St Sebastian and The Rest of Hercules (both in the Pinacoteca Capitolina, Rome), Nymph and Faun (Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica di Palazzo Barberini, Rome) and Latona and the Frogs (Musée du Louvre, Paris).Bonzi was clearly influenced by Annibale Carracci and to an even greater extent by Domenichino, but his compositions are more open on both sides and his terrain much flatter.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: His foregrounds spread out freely without obstacles such as large rocks or bushes, almost inviting the viewer to walk into the picture.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: His rather awkward figures tend to move parallel to the picture plane in a frieze-like procession.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: In the early 1620s he worked at the Palazzo Borghese on the Quirinal hill with Filippo Napoletano, each decorating different rooms.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: In this landscape Bonzi's close attention to naturalistic detail suggests the influence of Bril.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: Establishing a chronology for Bonzi's landscapes is almost impossible, but this work is perhaps not too far in date from the Pallavicini-Rospigliosi frescoes.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: The shepherds' nakedness indicates that the scene is not contemporary (even though sheep-farming had largely replaced cultivation in the Roman campagna around this time), but rather an episode from Virgil's Arcadia
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Landscape with Shepherds and Sheep

DESCRIPTION: A number of details indicate the artist's Caravaggesque training in the workshop of Giovanni Battista Crescenzi (1577-1635): the insistence on the description of the large vine leaves, and the young boy (a servant whose left hand holds the other end of the vine branch that rings his head) disguised as Bacchus, as well as the lustrous bronze reflections on the copper container.
AUTHOR: BONZI, Pietro Paolo
TITLE: Still-Life with a Young Boy as Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: In 1377 Pope Gregory XI returned to Rome and the magnificent palace of Avignon became only the residence of antipopes.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: The popes' "captivity in Babylon" had terminated, but Avignon continued to act as a channel through which Italian Gothic art gradually penetrated further and further into the rest of Europe.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: It was in Avignon that Luis Borrassá first came into contact with 'court' Gothic, in the period around 1400, when this style was widely adopted in numbers of countries; it became in fact an international style founded upon all that Borrassá has learned from the brothers Serra.The painting in the church of Santa Maria in Terrasa illustrates the text from St.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: Matthew: 'And Jesus, walking by the sea of Galilee, saw two brethren, Simon called Peter and Andrew his brother, casting a net into the sea; for they were fishers.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: And he saith unto them: Follow me, and I will make you fishers of men.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: And they straightway left their nets, and followed him' (4, 19-20).
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: This scene is connected with another one from the Gospel: 'Jesus constrained his disciples to get into a ship... the ship was now in the midst of the sea... Jesus went unto them, walking on the sea.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: And when the disciples saw him walking on the sea, they were troubled... And Peter said, Lord, if it be thou, bid me come unto thee on the water.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: And he said, Come.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: And when Peter was come down out of the ship, he walked on the water, to go to Jesus.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: But when he saw the wind boisterous, he was afraid; and beginning to sink he cried, saying, Lord, save me.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: And immediately Jesus stretched forth his hand, and caught him, and said unto him, O thou of little faith, wherefore didst thou doubt?'
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: Christ's face and his gesture are very beautiful, but the figures of both Christ and the two disciples are still stereotyped, differing in size in the traditional manner of early religious paintings: on the other hand, his treatment of the fishermen, particularly the one who is rowing, testifies to his own acute observation and his ability to make use of it.This altarpiece manifests a mixture of archaic technique and new characteristics of the International Gothic.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: The colour technique is Byzantine, but the shortening of the boats, the less sized figures in the background give some feeling of the perspective.
AUTHOR: BORRASSA, Lluis
TITLE: St Peter is Walking on the Water

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a fine example of the Viennese influence on Hungarian genre painting.In Borsos' picture, brocades, pleats, ribbons, jewels, candelabra, fashion magazines and carpet patterns rival one another in depicting the atmosphere after the girls' ball and the grandiose surroundings.
AUTHOR: BORSOS, József
TITLE: Young Maids after the Ball

DESCRIPTION: The artist arranged the scene himself  as if it were a tableau vivante according to the fashion of those days.
AUTHOR: BORSOS, József
TITLE: Young Maids after the Ball

DESCRIPTION: Borsos, who portrayed the life of  the upper class,  tested himself as a stage director.
AUTHOR: BORSOS, József
TITLE: Young Maids after the Ball

DESCRIPTION: The spell of the night, gossip and musing, a kind of freshness which made the artist want to arrest the irrevocable charm of the moment.
AUTHOR: BORSOS, József
TITLE: Young Maids after the Ball

DESCRIPTION: The artist's daughter was one of the models.
AUTHOR: BORSOS, József
TITLE: Young Maids after the Ball

DESCRIPTION: Borssum was a Dutch landscapist whose works show close familiary with Rembrandt's etchings and drawings
AUTHOR: BORSSOM, Anthonie van
TITLE: Extensive River View with a Horseman

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes in the Villa Cornaro are Bortolini's first known works.
AUTHOR: BORTOLONI, Mattia
TITLE: Judgment of Solomon

DESCRIPTION: The works on the first floor focus on episodes from the Old Testament, while those on the upper floor are derived from the New Testament.
AUTHOR: BORTOLONI, Mattia
TITLE: Judgment of Solomon

DESCRIPTION: On the first floor, the small rooms to the left of the main hall are dedicated to the narration of the stories of Moses and King Solomon, while those to the right are reserved for episodes relating to Noah, Abraham, and Jacob.
AUTHOR: BORTOLONI, Mattia
TITLE: Judgment of Solomon

DESCRIPTION: The images are extremely simplified in the presentation of the subject matter.The Judgment of Solomon occurs within the royal palace, where only the protagonists in the event are depicted - the king seated on his throne, the two mothers, the executioner who has been called in to cut the contested newborn in half, while the other baby lies abandoned on the ground.
AUTHOR: BORTOLONI, Mattia
TITLE: Judgment of Solomon

DESCRIPTION: There is no trace of the numerous and varied personalities who traditionally witness the scene in similar representation
AUTHOR: BORTOLONI, Mattia
TITLE: Judgment of Solomon

DESCRIPTION: In the midst of a luxuriant summer landscape, a surgeon removes an object from the head of a man tied to a chair; a monk and a nun look on.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: This little picture may not be entirely by Bosch; the awkward and inexpressive figures are perhaps by an inferior hand, but only Bosch could have been responsible for the landscape background whose delicately painted forms recall the vista in his early Epiphany.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: The open-air operation, its circular shape suggesting a mirror, is set within a framework of elaborate calligraphical decoration containing the inscription: "Master, cut the stone out, my name is Lubbert Das.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: "In Bosch's day, the stone operation was a piece of quackery in which the patient was supposedly cured of his stupidity through the removal of the stone of folly from his forehead.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: Fortunately, it was performed only in fiction, not in fact, for in literary examples of this theme it generally left the patient worse off than before.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: The name "Lubbert", on the other hand, frequently appears in Dutch literature to designate persons exhibiting an unusually high degree of human stupidity.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: The stone operation was occasionally represented by later Netherlandish artists, including Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: This subject undoubtedly inspired Bosch's picture, but no extant version of it accounts for the funnel and the book perched on the heads of two of the characters, nor does it explain the presence of the monk and the nun, although their apparent acquiescence in the quackery certainly places them in an unfavourable light.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: It will be noted, too, that what the surgeon extracts from Lubbert's head is not a stone, but a flower; another flower of the same species lies on the table at the right.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: The flowers has identified as tulips and their presence is explained as a play on the Dutch word for tulip which in the sixteenth century also carried the connotation of stupidity and folly.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Cure of Folly (Extraction of the Stone of Madness)

DESCRIPTION: The Magician belonging to Bosch's early paintings is now lost but it is known through a faithful copy at Saint-Germain-en-Laye.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: A mountebank has set up his table before a crumbling stone wall.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: His audience watches spellbound as he seems to bring forth a frog from the mouth of an old man in their midst; only one of the crowd, the young man with his hand on the shoulder of his female companion, appears to notice that the old man's purse is being stolen by the conjuror's confederate.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: The myopic gaze of the thief and the stupid amazement of the frog-spitting victim are superbly played off against the amused reactions of the bystanders, while the slyness of the mountebank is well conveyed in his sharp-nosed physiognomy.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: Bosch exploits the human face in profile for expressive purposes.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: Although the painting may possess a moralizing significance, it must have been inspired by a real-life situation closely observed.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: The perceptive, spontaneous humour of this little picture would be difficult to match in contemporary Flemish painting, but parallels can be found among Dutch manuscript illuminators
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: The Magician

DESCRIPTION: There are two panels in Rotterdam thought to have belonged to a triptych the central panel of which is lost.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Mankind Beset by Devils (reverse of Rebel Angels panel)

DESCRIPTION: The panel are painted both sides, the obverse sides representing the Fall of the Rebel Angels and Noah's Ark on Mount Ararat, respectively, while on the reverse sides two tondos each representing scenes of Mankind Beset by Devils.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Mankind Beset by Devils (reverse of Rebel Angels panel)

DESCRIPTION: The triptych of the Last Judgment is a fascinating work of art which comes surprisingly close to the unmistakable style of the strange moralist from 's-Hertogenbosch.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The emphasis in the development of the theme is on the all-besetting evil and perennial human stupidity that render the world a hell even before the day of divine jjudgment.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The extraordinary combination of motifs is often derived from vernacular symbolism and imagery: The inventive use of colours and the sharp, supple brushwork have persuaded many critics that Bosch himself was the author of this painting.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: In spite of the work's pictorial qualities, several factors seem to undermine this attribution.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: Nevertheless, the triptych remains an important example of Boschian invention.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: It dates from the early sixteenth century.At the time of his death, Bosch was internationally celebrated as an eccentric painter of religious visions who dealt in particular with the torments of hell.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: During his lifetime Bosch's works were in the inventories of noble families of the Netherlands, Austria, and Spain, and they were imitated in a number of paintings and prints throughout the 16th century, especially in the works of Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 99,5 x 60,3 cm (central panel), 99,5 x 29 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The left wing of the triptych represents the Paradise.Here, across the three inner panels, appear the First and Last Things, beginning with the Fall of Man on the left wing.The story recounted in the second and third chapters of Genesis has been placed in a lush garden; in the foreground we see the creation of Eve, followed by the temptation of the First Couple.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: In the middle distance they are driven from the garden by an angel.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: The expulsion of Adam and Eve from Eden is paralleled above by the expulsion from Heaven of the Rebel Angels, who are transformed into monsters as they descend to earth.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: Although the revolt of proud Lucifer and his followers is not mentioned in Genesis, it appears in Jewish legends and entered Christian doctrine at an early age.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: These were the angels who sinned and whose prince, envying Adam, caused him to sin in turn.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: It was further believed that Adam and Eve had been created by God in order that their offspring might fill the places left vacant by the fallen angels.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: In this panel, Bosch thus depicted the entrance of sin into the world and accounted for the necessity of the Last Judgment.The inclusion of the Fall of Adam and Eve in a representation of the Last Judgment is unusual; the other two panels of the Vienna triptych depart even more from traditional iconography
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Last Judgment Triptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Mixed technique on panel, 167 x 60 cm

DESCRIPTION: The right wing represents St Anthony in Meditation.The powerful evocation of a corrupt and stinking world is no less apparent in the right wing, where Bosch used as his starting point the story of the Devil-Queen, a subject he had already depicted in the Hermit Saints altarpiece.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Triptych of Temptation of St Anthony (right wing)

DESCRIPTION: The Devil-Queen appears in the river before Anthony, shielding her private parts with a false modesty and surrounded by her infernal court.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Triptych of Temptation of St Anthony (right wing)

DESCRIPTION: Anthony averts his eyes from this obscene group only to be summoned by a demon-herald to the devilish feast in the foreground.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Triptych of Temptation of St Anthony (right wing)

DESCRIPTION: The open-air table, the cloth slung tent-like over the tree stump beside the temptress, and the servants pouring wine seem like a grotesque parody of the traditional Garden of Love.
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Triptych of Temptation of St Anthony (right wing)

DESCRIPTION: In the background looms the city of the Devil-Queen, its demonic nature betrayed by the dragon swimming in the moat and by the flames erupting from the top of the main gate
AUTHOR: BOSCH, Hieronymus
TITLE: Triptych of Temptation of St Anthony (right wing)

DESCRIPTION: The sitter of this portrait, Frédéric Donnadieu, was a plantation owner in Saint Domingue (present day Haiti).
AUTHOR: BOSIO, Jean François
TITLE: Portrait of Frédéric Donnadieu and His Son Frédéric

DESCRIPTION: The exotic landscape pointed to by Donnadieu undoubtedly refers to this location, as does the black servant.
AUTHOR: BOSIO, Jean François
TITLE: Portrait of Frédéric Donnadieu and His Son Frédéric

DESCRIPTION: Elsewhere in the composition, Bosio renders with great delicacy the fashionable Empire furniture and musical instruments and scores, whose inclusion suggests that the sitter was a connoisseur of music and possibly a musician himself
AUTHOR: BOSIO, Jean François
TITLE: Portrait of Frédéric Donnadieu and His Son Frédéric

DESCRIPTION: The second half of the seventeenth century saw the rise of connoisseurship in the modern sense of the word.
AUTHOR: BOSSCHE, Balthasar van den
TITLE: A Nobleman's Picture Gallery

DESCRIPTION: In the present painting, van den Bossche's nobleman is shown surrounded by objects which infer his intellect and knowledge of art.
AUTHOR: BOSSCHE, Balthasar van den
TITLE: A Nobleman's Picture Gallery

DESCRIPTION: Around him, attendant figures hang on his every word as he apparently holds forth
AUTHOR: BOSSCHE, Balthasar van den
TITLE: A Nobleman's Picture Gallery

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed to the left on the wall: ABoth 1630.This is the earliest dated work of the artist, painted before he went to Italy.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Andries
TITLE: Hunting by Candlelight

DESCRIPTION: A ludicrous scene showing a peasant engrossed in the business of removing fleas from the body of a man kneeling half clothed in front of him.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Andries
TITLE: Hunting by Candlelight

DESCRIPTION: A third peasant holds a candle to illuminate the operation while a fourth watches with close attention.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Andries
TITLE: Hunting by Candlelight

DESCRIPTION: This picture of peasant 'hunting' is just as successful as the artist's Romantic, Baroque scenes of the hunting parties of the aristocracy
AUTHOR: BOTH, Andries
TITLE: Hunting by Candlelight

DESCRIPTION: Jan Both was one of the best known of the Dutch painters living in Italy for varying length of time in the 17th century (the so-called Italianates).
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: They painted landscapes without depicting a specific topography and almost all their works are imaginary compositions.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: Both's painting - although includes a draughtsman - is no exception.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: It shows a waterfall and a small gorge overgrown with bushes and trees close to a country road with a bridge which has just been crossed by a travelling party consisting of a carriage drawn by two horses led by grooms.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: By the side of the road are three groups of two figures each, all wearing rather rustic garbs.Judging by their poses and the sheet of paper held by one of them they are artists surveying the countryside.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: Opening up on the right is a broad view of the Roman campagna.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: Both painted the scene with remarkably light, bright colours, and exploited the effect of the sunlight to the full
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Italian Landscape with Draughtsman

DESCRIPTION: While in Rome, Both was associated with the Bamboccianti, or followers of Pieter van Laer (il Bamboccio), who painted low-life genre scenes.
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Southern Landscape with a Ruin

DESCRIPTION: On his return to Utrecht around 1641, he abandoned low-life genre images, turning his attention instead to Italianate landscapes.The painting is signed lower centre on a stone below the donkey: "Both"
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Southern Landscape with a Ruin

DESCRIPTION: On his return to Holland from Italy, Both's style, nurtured by numerous sketches from life done in Italy, was expressed in large-format landscapes vying with those of the classical landscape masters
AUTHOR: BOTH, Jan
TITLE: Landscape with a Peasant Woman on a Mule

DESCRIPTION: This painting shows the synthesis of trends that formed the style of Botticelli's painting.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna and Child with an Angel

DESCRIPTION: The composition of the painting resembles Lippi's art, but the figures are more delicately blended into the painting and their expressions and poses are more complicated.Behind the monumental, very sculptural figures is a broad, hilly landscape with a river.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna and Child with an Angel

DESCRIPTION: The boy-like angel appears to have just this moment stepped through the gap in the wall and come up to Mary and the child; he is presenting them with a bowl decorated with ears of grain and full of grapes.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna and Child with an Angel

DESCRIPTION: The Christ Child is blessing the gifts, which symbolize the bread and wine of the Eucharist.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna and Child with an Angel

DESCRIPTION: The picture's title is explained by the pomegranate in Mary's hand: this should be understood as symbolizing Christ's Passion, the wealth of seeds conveying the fullness of Christ's suffering.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna of the Pomegranate (Madonna della Melagrana)

DESCRIPTION: A comparison of this painting with Botticelli's earlier tondo Madonna del Magnificat reveals that the artist has now arranged the angels symmetrically, thereby avoiding the compositional difficulties of the older depiction.The Christ Child, whose hand is raised in blessing, is lying securely in the arms of Mary, but the sad, melancholy expression on the faces of mother and child are intended to remind the observer of the torments the Son of God will suffer in the future.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna of the Pomegranate (Madonna della Melagrana)

DESCRIPTION: The angels are worshipping Mary with lilies and garlands of roses.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna of the Pomegranate (Madonna della Melagrana)

DESCRIPTION: The Rosary is a prayer that was created in its present form in the 15th century, and rapidly became widespread.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna of the Pomegranate (Madonna della Melagrana)

DESCRIPTION: The beginning of this prayer is embroidered on the left angel s stola: AVE GRAZIA PLENA (Hail Mary, full of grace)
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Madonna of the Pomegranate (Madonna della Melagrana)

DESCRIPTION: This depiction of the Virgin and Child by Botticelli and his workshop repeats the central section of Botticelli's magnificent painting from 1488-90 known as the San Barnaba Altarpiece.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro

DESCRIPTION: The composition was carefully laid out using the same cartoon as the altarpiece, as was standard practice in Botticelli's workshop
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Virgin and Child

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the second predella panel of the St Barnaba Altarpiece.According to a legend, St Augustine the bishop, while he was thinking about the Holy Trinity, met a child on the beach who was attempting to use a spoon to transfer the waters of the ocean into a small hole.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Vision of St Augustine

DESCRIPTION: When Augustine explained to him that this was not possible, the child replied that it was far more foolish to try to find an explanation for the mystery of the Trinity
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Vision of St Augustine

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the fourth (central) predella panel of the St Barnaba Altarpiece.The Passion of Christ, to which the large main panel also alludes, is the theme of the predella panel.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Christ in the Sepulchre

DESCRIPTION: Christ is standing in a stone sarcophagus, displaying his stigmata.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Christ in the Sepulchre

DESCRIPTION: In front of him lie the instruments of his Passion, the crown of thorns and nails.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Christ in the Sepulchre

DESCRIPTION: To the right, in the background, the Bearing of the Cross can be made out.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro

DESCRIPTION: To the left, swans are swimming on a river.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Christ in the Sepulchre

DESCRIPTION: They were well-known for their delightful death songs
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro

AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro

DESCRIPTION: They had been concealed under old coats of paint for centuries.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: Villa Lemmi belonged to the Tornabuoni family, friend of the Medici.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is possible that the frescoes were commissioned on the occasion of a marriage between members of the Tornabuoni and Albizzi families.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: For a long time the view was held that the couple in question were Giovanna degli Albizzi and Lorenzo Tornabuoni, who married in 1486.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: This assumption has, however, since been proven wrong, for the face of Giovanna that we know from a medallion does not agree with the lady in Botticell's fresco.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: A possible alternative could be Nanna Tornabuoni and Matteo degli Albizzi, who married in about 1484.It is supposed the frescoes were executed to commemorate the marriage of Lorenzo Tornabuoni and Giovanna degli Albizzi.The frescoes are in a very poor state of preservation, because they were damaged when taken down from the wall.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: Two of the three fragments found were transferred to canvas and later sold to the Louvre in Paris.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: The two compositions were originally separated only by a window.One of the fragments probably  represents Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman, the other A Young Man Being Introduced to the Seven Liberal Arts.On this painting there is a strange lack of certainty as to the identity of the group of four young classically dressed women, who are gracefully stepping towards a young woman in front of the splashing spring in order to bring her gifts.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Fresco transferred to canvas, 211 x 284 cm

DESCRIPTION: They may be Venus and the Three Graces, symbolizing chastity, beauty and love

TITLE: Venus and the Three Graces Presenting Gifts to a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: Botticelli painted this portrait in a three quarter view like a silhouette against a pale blue sky.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: The young man, who is looking very slightly down towards the observer, is wearing a red jerkin and the characteristic headgear of the Florentine Quattrocento, the mazzocchio.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: The hat band which is casually draped across his shoulder provides an artistic frame for the young man's face.The sitter of the portrait is probably Gianlorenzo de' Medici, and it could very well be Botticelli's first commissioned work, and from the hair and the clothes, the portrait must date from no later than 1469
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: According to Berenson, the sitter of this portrait is Michele Marullo (1453-1500), known as Tarcaniota, a Greek humanist, who was the guest of the Medici's between 1489 and 1495.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Portrait of a Man
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 49 x 35 cm

DESCRIPTION: Later, in 1496, he returned to Florence and married the woman poet Alessandra Scala.
AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro
TITLE: Portrait of a Man
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 49 x 35 cm

DESCRIPTION: He left Florence in 1490 and soon after he died by drowning into the river Cecina.This painting can be considered an ideal scholar portrait, a forerunner of those portrayals of philosopher-heroes developed in the seventeenth century, e.g.

AUTHOR: BOTTICELLI, Sandro

DESCRIPTION: This canvas and its companion-piece, Allegory of Music, are examples of the small scale allegorical pictures which were created by Boucher to decorate the homes, and more specifically, overdoors within the intricately carved boiserie paneling that was installed in many mid-18th century Parisian hôtels
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Allegory of Poetry

DESCRIPTION: In this painting Boucher presents the mythological family where mother Venus and father Mercury are captured in a moment of parental responsibility.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: The Education of Cupid

DESCRIPTION: As Messenger of the Arts, Mercury seems to be instructing his offspring in lessons of love, catching Venus's eye in a moment of romantic encounter.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: The Education of Cupid

DESCRIPTION: The love goddess is shown in a typically Boucheresque "bottoms-up" pose.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: The Education of Cupid

DESCRIPTION: Boucher had never been a committed artistic believer.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: Although he had worked in Italy, the Italian tradition did not tempt him into vast imaginative schemes.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: He never aimed at a heroic vision.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: He expressed no glorious promises about heaven: either as an Olympian refuge for aristocratic families, or in ordinary Christian terms.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: Like most French eighteenth-century painters, he could not evolve a satisfactory idiom for religious pictures of any kind; and he was particularly unsuited to the task by the nature of his real abilities.The picture shows one of his rare paintings of religious subject
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: Pastoral scenes - so-called pastorale - were typical of French painting under Louis XV.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Dreaming Shepherdess

DESCRIPTION: They developed from the "fêtes galantes" of Antoine Watteau, who depicted courtiers disporting themselves in park-like landscapes, and from the "fêtes champêtres" - the rural festivals of Jean-Baptiste Pater, who combined court and country life.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Dreaming Shepherdess

DESCRIPTION: Boucher was the first to create high-quality pastorale, laying down the standards for the genre and showing idealised scenes from the love life of amorous shepherds and shepherdesses
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: Dreaming Shepherdess

DESCRIPTION: The companion piece The Setting of the Sun is also in the Wallace Collection.These extravagant and wonderful pictures show Apollo as God of the Sun leaving Tethys with her Nereids and Tritons in the river Ocean as he drives up the morning sun in his chariot drawn by four white horses, and then returning to her at nightfall.
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François
TITLE: The Rising of the Sun

DESCRIPTION: Boucher counted these amongst his most successful pictures
AUTHOR: BOUCHER, François

DESCRIPTION: The tradition he was following was primarily an English one, though Boudin did not paint ships at sea.

DESCRIPTION: The pictures he painted over the years in his loose, sketchy way did not, strictly speaking, possess any central subjects.
AUTHOR: BOUDIN, Eug?ne

DESCRIPTION: Even his market or beach scenes present an extensive panorama of colour and economically deployed line accentuation.

DESCRIPTION: The atmosphere is bright, moist and highly sensitively registered.

AUTHOR: BOULLOGNE, Bon

DESCRIPTION: The battle won, 'who should come out to meet him with tambourines and dances but his daughter, and she only a child'
AUTHOR: BOULLOGNE, Bon

DESCRIPTION: Nicholas miraculously restored them to life.

DESCRIPTION: The story is thought to have arisen out of another concerning three soldiers who were saved by Nicholas from being unjustly executed.
AUTHOR: BOULLOGNE, Bon

DESCRIPTION: In medieval stained glass the soldiers stand in a tower representing their prison.

DESCRIPTION: As was the custom, the saint's stature was greatly enlarged in relation to the other figures, which therefore were the size of children, beside him.

DESCRIPTION: In Rome the young Bourdon was exposed to some of the greatest portraits of the Renaissance in the collections there, as well as to the constant experiments of artists as diverse as Bernini, Lanfranco and Domenichino, who all painted portraits.
AUTHOR: BOURDON, Sébastien
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: from all these influences Bourdon compounded his own style, which inevitably became a formula, but a successful one.
AUTHOR: BOURDON, Sébastien
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: He often painted his sitters three-quarters on, in a soft and even light, and preferred waist-length portraits and a feeling of relative informality.
AUTHOR: BOURDON, Sébastien
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: With his curious mixture of Italian influences, Bourdon set the style for middle-class French portraiture for almost the rest of the century.
AUTHOR: BOURDON, Sébastien
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: One of the best examples is his Portrait of a Man at Montpellier, which is a "tour de force" of subtle modelling and lighting.
AUTHOR: BOURDON, Sébastien
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: Indeed, almost all the surviving middle-class portraits of the time in France, that are not by Philippe de Champaigne and his followers, copy this type.The sitter of this portrait is unknown
AUTHOR: BOURDON, Sébastien

DESCRIPTION: The Berlin panel, as its close likeness to the work of Aelbert Ouwater suggests, must have been one of his earlier works.The story of Jesus's visit to the house of Simon the Pharisee is told in St Luke's Gospel (vii, 36-50).
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: A woman from the city followed Christ there, 'and stood at his feet behind him weeping, and began to wash his feet with tears, and did wipe them with the hairs of her head, and kissed his feet, and anointed them with the ointment.'
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: Simon condemned the attitude of his guest, saying : 'This man, if he were a prophet, would have known who and what manner of woman this is that toucheth him; for she is a sinner.'
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: Christ answered with a parable and the words: 'Her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much; but to whom little is forgiven, the same loveth little.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: 'In a narrow, vaulted room, on the left of which is a window providing a glimpse of a landscape, Simon sits with his guests at a table laid for a meal.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: On the left of the table the sinner bends down to anoint Jesus's feet.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: The host, the only one present wearing shoes, and Peter beside him, observe the incident with astonishment and disapproval.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: The youthful John at the head of the table seems to be drawing the attention of the donor, a Dominican monk, to it.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: The latter kneels with hands raised in prayer and, as if he dare not look, averts his gaze.The arrangement of the figures at a laid table recalls two other themes from the life of Christ, the Last Supper and the Miracle at Emmaus, incidents which were frequently represented in painting and, furthermore, established a pictorial tradition of their own.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder
TITLE: Christ in the House of Simon

DESCRIPTION: Here the table is laid with bread, wine and fish, the last of these being an ancient Christian symbol.
AUTHOR: BOUTS, Dieric the Elder

DESCRIPTION: The composition of the various objects represents one of the most delightful still-lifes in old Netherlandish painting.

DESCRIPTION: Among the vessels on the table one can recognize a late medieval form of glass known as a 'cabbage-stalk'

DESCRIPTION: Lord Burlington created the most complex example of Palladian architecture.
AUTHOR: BOYLE, Richard, 3rd Earl of Burlington

DESCRIPTION: Chiswick House, built between 1723 and 1729, is close to the villas of the Veneto in Italy.
AUTHOR: BOYLE, Richard, 3rd Earl of Burlington
TITLE: Exterior view

DESCRIPTION: The ground plan, a square containing a central octagon, recalls Palladio's Villa Rotonda.
AUTHOR: BOYLE, Richard, 3rd Earl of Burlington
TITLE: Exterior view

DESCRIPTION: A suite of interconnecting geometric spaces surround the domed central hall; they extend into apses with statues in the niches.The exterior combines multiple references to antiquity.
AUTHOR: BOYLE, Richard, 3rd Earl of Burlington
TITLE: Exterior view

DESCRIPTION: The six Corinthian columns of the portico are from the temple of Jupiter Stator in Rome, the semi-circular, subdivided windows of the drum are reminiscent of Roman thermal baths.
AUTHOR: BOYLE, Richard, 3rd Earl of Burlington
TITLE: Exterior view

DESCRIPTION: These features do not represent a literal quotation from ancient buildings but rather a version of the sixteenth-century interpretations which were accessible to Burlington through Palladio's drawings and buildings
AUTHOR: BOYLE, Richard, 3rd Earl of Burlington
TITLE: Exterior view

DESCRIPTION: They are playing with pieces of wood, with bones, with hoops and barrels - specially crafted toys were rare in the 16th century.

DESCRIPTION: Their faces often appear ageless: perhaps the painter wished to warn the observer against frittering away his life as if it were a childlike game.

DESCRIPTION: The children, who range in age from toddlers to adolescents, roll hoops, walk on stilts, spin tops, ride hobby-horses, stage mock tournaments, play leap-frog and blind man's buff, perform handstands, inflate pigs' bladders and play with dolls and other toys.
AUTHOR: BRUEGEL, Pieter the Elder

DESCRIPTION: They have also taken over the large building that dominates the square: it may be a town hall or some other important civic building, in this way emphasizing the moral that the adults who direct civic affairs are as children in the sight of God.

AUTHOR: BRUEGEL, Pieter the Elder

DESCRIPTION: Most of them focus on the possible symbolism of the large woman in the foreground, with her suit of armor, sword, cutlery and money-box.

DESCRIPTION: She has been variously interpreted as a symbol of heresy or violence, the personification of hum,an evil and an allegory of instability.Recently it was proposed that Meg symbolizes Madness, a vice taken in the 16th century to include insanity, rage, gluttony, lust, avarice and ambition, and that the giant figure in the centre of the painting is an allegory of Folly.

DESCRIPTION: It was concluded that Bruegel's allegory was intended as an attack on both human nature and the political and religious situation in 16th-century Antwerp.We could fill a book with suggested interpretations of Mad Meg and it is highly doubtful whether it would bring the viewer any closer to the true meaning of the painting.
AUTHOR: BRUEGEL, Pieter the Elder
TITLE: Dulle Griet (Mad Meg)

DESCRIPTION: Nevertheless, the work never fails to fascinate, even without specialist knowledge.

DESCRIPTION: Pieter Bruegel the Elder was the most important figure in sixteenth-century Flemish painting, the founder of a dynasty of painters.

DESCRIPTION: His realistic painting of peasants in both his secular and religious works gave him the nickname of "Peasant Bruegel".
AUTHOR: BRUEGEL, Pieter the Elder
TITLE: The Sermon of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: A number of copies of this picture, both contemporary and dating from the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, have come down to us, and many of them are in museums in Flanders (Antwerp, Bruges, Brussels), as well as in Bonn, Schwerin, Leningrad, Munich and Cracow, mostly produced with the co-operation of his sons, Pieter and Jan, and his workshop employees.
AUTHOR: BRUEGEL, Pieter the Elder
TITLE: The Sermon of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: This tends to indicate that the picture remained in Brussels for a long time, or was in a collection in another town in the Netherlands which was easily accessible to the public.The numerous copies and variants of this painting with its theme of the Holy Baptism can also be explained by the widespread growth of the Anabaptist movement in those years of religious turbulence and strife.
AUTHOR: BRUEGEL, Pieter the Elder
TITLE: The Sermon of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The date of the painting coincides with a period of iconoclasm in the Netherlands.This picture is probably identifiable as that known to have been in the collection of the Infanta Isabella Clara Eugenia, Governor of the Netherlands, in 1633.

DESCRIPTION: Painted about 1567, this picture has traditionally been thought of simply as a depiction of peasant life.

DESCRIPTION: Less obvious is the identity of the bridegroom; he may be the man in black, with his back to the spectator, leaning back on his stool, mug in hand, calling for more wine.

DESCRIPTION: The still-life details enumerating many traditional symbols were painted by Jan Brueghel.The amazing increase in the commercial and agricultural product range caused a complete restructuring of people's perception - a change which can be seen very clearly in the numerous paintings and series of paintings on the subject of the Five Senses.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Jan the Elder
TITLE: The Sense of Hearing

DESCRIPTION: Jan Brueghel the Elder's famous variations on this motif - now in the Prado, Madrid - show a number of settings, each of which is associated with the five senses.

DESCRIPTION: The dramatic 'unity of character' has been divided into components of the senses, thus reflecting an increasing compartmentalization of the world into functional spheres - a world which is defined in terms of luxury goods.In Jan Brueghel's paintings, the part of purely passive reception or physical consumption is played by an allegorical female figure.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Jan the Elder
TITLE: The Sense of Hearing

DESCRIPTION: Interestingly, by depicting her naked or semi-naked breasts and sometimes her entire body, the painter emphasizes an element of eroticism.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Jan the Elder
TITLE: The Sense of Hearing

DESCRIPTION: In this way the consumption of luxury goods and an emotional state of ecstasy are recognized as a syndrome.In the still-life of Hearing we can examine nearly all the instruments of the period.

DESCRIPTION: Near the Flemish harpsichord we can see a drum, a trumpet, a trombone, a cornetto, a lysard, several flutes, various sizes of violas and gambas, a lute, and a shawm.
