AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Jan the Elder
TITLE: Monkeys Feasting

DESCRIPTION: It is a genre depicting monkeys aping human behaviour, often fashionably attired, intended as a diverting sight, always with a gentle cast of mild satire.In the present painting it is assumed that the seven monkeys populating the foreground and the four sitting on the draped table surrounding the plate of fruit to be by Jan Brueghel the Elder, with the remaining parts by his son and chief studio assistant at this time, Jan Brueghel the Younger.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Jan the Elder
TITLE: Monkeys Feasting

DESCRIPTION: The plate of fruit itself would also appear to be from the hand of the elder Brueghel
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Jan the Elder
TITLE: Monkeys Feasting

DESCRIPTION: The composition of The Bird Trap is one of the most popular created by the Brueghel family.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: The Bird Trap

DESCRIPTION: The prototype has generally been thought to be the painting by Pieter Brueghel the Elder.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: The Bird Trap

DESCRIPTION: Pieter Brueghel the Younger and his busy studio produced numerous (over forty) copies and variations of the composition.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: The Bird Trap

DESCRIPTION: The earliest known dated version by Brueghel the Younger is the painting dated 1601, the latest is dated 1626.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: The Bird Trap

DESCRIPTION: In this version, several figures were added to the composition c.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: The Bird Trap

DESCRIPTION: 1630-35, by an artist in the circle of Hendrick Avercamp
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: The Bird Trap

DESCRIPTION: This panel belongs to a set of five, intended to decorate a piece of furniture,  possibly the drawers of an ebony wood cabinet.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Two Peasant Couples

DESCRIPTION: The subjects may depict events before, during and after a peasant wedding
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Two Peasant Couples

DESCRIPTION: This is a rare example of a unique composition in Brueghel's oeuvre, and is entirely of his own devising.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Street with Peasants Dancing
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 72 cm

DESCRIPTION: Although loosely related to the composition known in seven versions depicting peasants feasting before a long village street with the Swan Inn to the left, the composition of the present picture is known in no other versions
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Street with Peasants Dancing
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 72 cm

DESCRIPTION: Pieter Breughel the Younger (the sons adopted a different spelling of the family name) specialized in copies of his father's work, though he ought really to be pictured as the head of a workshop in which a number of painters were employed.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Lawyer

DESCRIPTION: Some of these were more talented than others, which explains the substantial differences in quality between the many copies ascribed to him.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Lawyer

DESCRIPTION: The Village Lawyer, dated 1621, is believed to be an original work by Pieter the Younger rather than a copy.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Lawyer

DESCRIPTION: It too proved very popular and many versions of it have survived
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Lawyer

DESCRIPTION: One of the best works of the artist.
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Feast

DESCRIPTION: The composition is similar to that of the Children's Games by Pieter Bruegel the Elder
AUTHOR: BRUEGHEL, Pieter the Younger
TITLE: Village Feast

DESCRIPTION: This still-life painting is on the back of the portrait of Jane-Loyse Tissier
AUTHOR: BRUYN, Barthel the Elder
TITLE: Vanitas Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: This painting was probably the centre of an altarpiece for the principal altar in the newly founded chapel of the relics (one of the a piece of the Virgin's girdle which she was alleged to have dropped to the apostle Thomas at the moment of her assumption into heaven) within the Spedale di Santa Maria della Scala.
AUTHOR: BULGARINI, Bartolommeo
TITLE: The Virgin of the Assumption with St Thomas Receiving the Girdle

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin, surrounded by a mandorla of red-faced cherubim and accompanied by music-making angels, may have been framed by side panels depicting St Anthony Abbot and St John the Evangelist
AUTHOR: BULGARINI, Bartolommeo
TITLE: The Virgin of the Assumption with St Thomas Receiving the Girdle

DESCRIPTION: This is a fragment of an altarpiece originally in the church of Santi Cosma e Damiano on Giudecca.
AUTHOR: BUONCONSIGLIO, Giovanni
TITLE: Sts Benedict, Thecla, and Damian

DESCRIPTION: The church was partially destroyed by fire in 1700, and today only fragments of the altarpiece survive.
AUTHOR: BUONCONSIGLIO, Giovanni
TITLE: Sts Benedict, Thecla, and Damian

DESCRIPTION: The central panel depicting the Virgin and Child is held by the Banca Popolare Vicentina
AUTHOR: BUONCONSIGLIO, Giovanni
TITLE: Sts Benedict, Thecla, and Damian

DESCRIPTION: The sitter of this portrait was the Prussian General Johann Gerhard David von Scharnhorst (1755-1813)
AUTHOR: BURY, Friedrich
TITLE: Scharnhorst

DESCRIPTION: Representations of domestic life were popular in the nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: CABAILLOT-LASSALLE, Camille-Léopold
TITLE: Elegant Woman at a Mirror
TECHNIQUE: Oil on mahogany panel, 56 x 39 cm

DESCRIPTION: Cabaillot-Lassalle's painting, depicting an elegant woman looking at herself in a mirror, introduces the onlooker into the privileged, secluded life of educated women in the second half of the nineteenth century
AUTHOR: CABAILLOT-LASSALLE, Camille-Léopold
TITLE: Elegant Woman at a Mirror
TECHNIQUE: Oil on mahogany panel, 56 x 39 cm

DESCRIPTION: Cagnacci was an Italian painter and engraver who studied with Guido Reni and worked in northern Italian cities and later in Vienna, at the court of Emperor Leopold I
AUTHOR: CAGNACCI, Guido
TITLE: Martha Rebuking Mary for her Vanity

DESCRIPTION: Caillebotte often found his subjects near the family home by the river Yerres.
AUTHOR: CAILLEBOTTE, Gustave
TITLE: In a Café

DESCRIPTION: In 1880 an acquaintance modelled for his lifesize portrait of a café regular.
AUTHOR: CAILLEBOTTE, Gustave
TITLE: In a Café

DESCRIPTION: The subject, technique, colouring, use of space, and subtle deployment of the mirror, all have something of Manet or Degas.
AUTHOR: CAILLEBOTTE, Gustave
TITLE: In a Café

DESCRIPTION: But Caillebotte outdid Manet in expressing an entire social psychology in this portrait of a good-humoured, unfooled, slightly crafty man of the lower middle class
AUTHOR: CAILLEBOTTE, Gustave
TITLE: In a Café

DESCRIPTION: The stylistic characteristics of this painting, such as rounded faces and narrow, elongated eyes seem to be a general reflection of the foreign presence in Genoese painting at this time
AUTHOR: CAMBIASO, Luca
TITLE: Virgin and Child with the Young St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood panel, 91 x 80 cm

DESCRIPTION: The painter was one of the first foreign artists settled in Seville.
AUTHOR: CAMPA?A, Pedro de
TITLE: Crucifixion
TECHNIQUE: Canvas backed by wood, 54 x 39 cm

DESCRIPTION: This Crucifixion was executed in the first years of his activity there
AUTHOR: CAMPA?A, Pedro de
TITLE: Crucifixion
TECHNIQUE: Canvas backed by wood, 54 x 39 cm

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows the influence of Pieter Aertsen
AUTHOR: CAMPI, Vincenzo
TITLE: Chicken Vendors

DESCRIPTION: The iconography of this altarpiece is unusual in that it shows Christ, stripped of his purple robe and standing beside the cross upon which he will be crucified
AUTHOR: CAMPI, Vincenzo
TITLE: Christ Being Nailed to the Cross

DESCRIPTION: The entrance hall of the noble floor in the Palazzo Belloni Battagia was decorated by Giambattista Canal and Davide Rossi (1744-c.
AUTHOR: CANAL, Giambattista
TITLE: Scenes from the Homeric World

DESCRIPTION: The hall became a genuine optical illusion, thanks to open galleries with perspective colonnades with scenes from the Homeric world
AUTHOR: CANAL, Giambattista
TITLE: Scenes from the Homeric World

DESCRIPTION: The view is taken from the Palazzo Foscari on the sharp bend in the Grand Canal, known as the Volta de Canal, roughly equidistant from its entrance onto the Bacino di San Marco and the Rialto Bridge.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Venice: The Grand Canal, Looking North-East from Palazzo Balbi to the Rialto Bridge

DESCRIPTION: Looking North-East from there the whole of the longest straight stretch of the canal is visible, as far as the Rialto Bridge, part of which is shown in the far distance, with the roof and dome of the church of Santi Giovanni e Paolo beyond.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Venice: The Grand Canal, Looking North-East from Palazzo Balbi to the Rialto Bridge

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the four paintings ordered in 1725 from Canaletto by Stefano Conti, a textile merchant and collector from Lucca.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto described the first painting, saying that it showed "the Rialto Bridge from the side facing the Fondaco dei Tedeschi, across from the buildings where the magistrates of, for instance, the Camerlenghi work.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: These buildings border the market where all sorts of fruits and vegetables are unloaded for distribution to shops all over the city.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: Painted in the middle of the canal is a distinguished-looking sloop with figures in it being rowed swiftly across the water and, nearby, another gondola being rowed by the liveried servants of the imperial ambassador.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: "In these canvases Canaletto was apparently striving for the greatest verisimilitude, in which he succeeded by virtue of his great ingenuity and artistic sensibility.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: The curvature of the river is beautifully rendered in an arc flowing from the approaching sloop, under the dark bridge and on to the sunlit area beyond.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: This movement is effected by the curving roofline on the left and by the gondolas crossing the canal in the foreground, which binds the composition horizontally.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: As in so many other cases Canaletto was not the first to represent this particular cityscape; there is an early eighteenth-century print of the same subject by Filippo Vasconi which, in turn, is based on an etching by Israel Silvestre from the mid-seventeenth century.Here, too, Canaletto must have planned his composition with the help of two, now lost, preparatory drawings covering an angle of approximately ninety degrees.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: The compositional sketch (c.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: 1725, Ashmolean Museum, Oxford) for the painting has survived and in it we can see how the master combined the two views, creating an effect similar to that of a photograph produced by a wide-angle lens
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal near the Ponte di Rialto

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto's loose brushwork lends a dreamy air to the gondola's comings and goings
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Grand Canal

DESCRIPTION: The compositions of this work and its companion picture (The Molo: Looking West, in the same collection) complement each other very effectively; they both show dominant buildings in the foreground to one side of the picture, from which the eye meanders both across the painting and into the distance.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Riva degli Schiavoni: Looking East

DESCRIPTION: Their subjects are also complementary; they depict views of the waterfront on either side of the Molo, the seaward part of the Piazzetta.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Riva degli Schiavoni: Looking East

DESCRIPTION: In this painting the view extends from the Doge's Palace right along the quay known as the Riva degli Schiavoni.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Riva degli Schiavoni: Looking East

DESCRIPTION: Boats of all sizes throng the water, and Venetians are shown either in the lofty pursuit of trade and politics (a group of officials energe from the Doge's Palace), or the equally fascinating, although more down to earth business of begging and gossiping.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Riva degli Schiavoni: Looking East

DESCRIPTION: The other painting shows the view from the Column of San Teodoro over towards Santa Maria della Salute on the far side of the Grand Canal.These subjects became extremely popular and were rethought by Canaletto and his studio with small variations for a number of other clients.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Riva degli Schiavoni: Looking East

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto executed related drawings which both he and his assistants could use as a guide when plotting these views
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Riva degli Schiavoni: Looking East

DESCRIPTION: This painting was probably painted for the Venetian man of letters and bibliophile Giovan Battista Recanati.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Fonteghetto della Farina

DESCRIPTION: It depicts the Flour Warehouse, the building that in 1750 was to become the the first seat of the Academy of Painting and Sculpture
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Fonteghetto della Farina

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts the scene when the doge, accompanied by the senators, visits the church and Scuola di San Rocco on the occasion of the feastday of the Saint.The church of San Rocco at the right has housed the body of St Roch since 1485.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: In 1576 there was a very severe outbreak of the plague in Venice, and it was thought that his intercession prevented an even greater calamity, so from that year onwards his Feast day, 16 August, was celebrated by the Republic.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto here depicts one aspect of the festivities - a procession of resplendent dignitaries emerging from the church after they have attended Mass.The Scuola di San Rocco dominates the centre of the composition; its exterior is decorated with garlands and paintings, as was the custom on this occasion.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto and his artist nephew Bellotto are recorded as having sold some of their works at one of these exhibitions.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: Many of the figures walking before it and beneath the awning can be identified because of their distinctive and colourful clothes.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: They are, from left to right: Secretaries, who wear mauve; the Doge's chair- and cushion-bearers; the Cancelliere Grande who wears scarlet; the Doge himself in gold and ermine; the Guardiano Grande di San Rocco; the bearer of the sword of state; the Senators; and finally the Ambassadors.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: A number of them carry nosegays, which were presented as reminders of the plague; they were carried during outbreaks of the disease because it was believed that their scent helped prevent its spread.Canaletto shows an expansive view of this scene which could not, in fact, be observed, because the church of the Frari impinges too far on the near side of the square.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Feast Day of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: This painting is an example of Canaletto's mature style, with its extraordinary brilliance of colour and superb clarity.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Molo and the Riva degli Schiavoni from the Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: It was part of a group of 13 vedute
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Molo and the Riva degli Schiavoni from the Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: This attractive view of the Forum comes from the same series of paintings as The Arch of Constantine.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: Like the other three works from the group it is prominently signed and dated.The Forum was the site of the political and religious centre of ancient Rome; attempts to excavate it were made throughout the eighteenth century, and the ruins revealed were consistently revered by visitors to the city.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: The tourists shown here mainly scrutinize the remains of the temple of Castor and Pollux which dominates the foreground.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: One man, at the right, is so intent upon the ruin that he appears to be ignoring the cleric in black who is attempting to converse with him.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: Further back, at the left, between the columns can be seen a knife grinder, and over towards the right, the Temple of Saturn.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: Rising up above it is the Palazzo Senatorio which dominates the Capitoline Hill.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: These topographical elements have been depicted with considerable care, but elsewhere the artist has taken liberties with his subject - some of the houses at the left are invented, and their chimneys appear characteristically Venetian, rather than Roman.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Rome: Ruins of the Forum, Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: In this work and its companion picture (Capriccio: A Palladian Design for the Rialto Bridge, also in Parma) Canaletto created two of his most complex and intriguing capricci.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Capriccio: The Grand Canal, with an Imaginary Rialto Bridge and Other Buildings

DESCRIPTION: He had already depicted an unrealised scheme for the Rialto Bridge, but in these works went one stage further and painted alternatives to the actual bridge surrounded by a sophisticated and extensive group of invented buildings.The bridge and extraordinary circular temple at the left appear to be almost entirely imaginary.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Capriccio: The Grand Canal, with an Imaginary Rialto Bridge and Other Buildings

DESCRIPTION: Such spectacular flights of fancy may at root be based on reminiscences of details in works by Claude Lorraine (1600-82) and Giovanni Battista Piranesi (1720-78), but Canaletto has transformed possible sources of this type into a decorative creation all of his own.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Capriccio: The Grand Canal, with an Imaginary Rialto Bridge and Other Buildings

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto is first recorded in England in spring 1746, and his earliest paintings of London are depictions of the new Westminster Bridge, a subject he was to portray from various vantage points.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: The bridge was not actually completed until four years after this work was painted.In this picture he combines a view of its whole span with a depiction of festivities, which, although tamer than the Venetian spectacles he generally painted, partially recall them.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: The celebrations accompanied the appointment of the new Lord Mayor of London.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: The largest City Barge is shown taking him to Westminster Hall, by the Abbey at the right, where he will be sworn in.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: The prominent building on the horizon to the left of it is St John's Church, Smith Square, and over on the other side of the river is Lambeth Palace, the London home of the Archbishop of Canterbury.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: All the other spectacular barges are those of the different city guilds (Skinners, Goldsmiths, Fishmongers, Clothworkers, Vinters, Merchant Taylors, Mercers and Dyers); a number of them are firing salutes to honour the Mayor.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: In order to encapsulate all of this activity within such a broad panorama Canaletto has adopted an imaginary vantage point high above the Thames
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Westminster Bridge from the North on Lord Mayor's Day

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows a view of the old Horse Guards and Banqueting Hall, Whitehall, seen from Saint James's Park.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: View of the Old Horse Guards and Banqueting Hall

DESCRIPTION: It was executed in May or June of 1749, prior to the demolition of the old, red brick Horse Guards building, which began late that same year.This work shows the same subject as the Old Horse Guards from St James's Park in the Tate Gallery, but from a closer and more frontal viewpoint.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: View of the Old Horse Guards and Banqueting Hall

DESCRIPTION: To the right, behind Old Horse Guards on the far side of Whitehall, is Inigo Jones' Banqueting Hall.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: View of the Old Horse Guards and Banqueting Hall

DESCRIPTION: Near to it and almost hidden by the screen of trees can be seen part of the Holbein Gate.The painting is related to a working drawing in Canaletto's Accademia sketchbook (Galleria dell'Accademia, Venice)
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: View of the Old Horse Guards and Banqueting Hall

DESCRIPTION: Northumberland House at Charing Cross was the London residence of the Earl of Northumberland, who commissioned Canaletto to paint this picture.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Northumberland House

DESCRIPTION: The house had recently been inherited and refashioned, and Canaletto concentrated his attention on its elegant and mellow façade.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Northumberland House

DESCRIPTION: The impressive appearance of the building is enhanced by its towers which are surmounted by gilt weather vanes, and the row of obelisks that support lamps on the pavement before it.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Northumberland House

DESCRIPTION: The house was eventually demolished in 1873, making way for Northumberland Avenue, and the lion above the doorway was then moved to Syon House in Isleworth, Middlesex, where it can still be seen.Canaletto created far more than just a celebration of a particular building, however; he also provides us with an invaluable record of its surroundings, and a vivid impression of the capital coming to life early in the morning.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Northumberland House

DESCRIPTION: To the right is the statue of Charles I by Hubert Le Sueur (c.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Northumberland House

DESCRIPTION: 1650) that now stands at the entrance of Whitehall from Trafalgar Square, and at the left is the entrance to the Strand and the Golden Cross Inn, which has a sign standing in front of it.The painting was much copied and engravings were made after it; as a result of the distribution of these copies, it was to have a significant influence on the work of English artists who depicted urban scenes
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Northumberland House

DESCRIPTION: The Royal Hospital at Greenwich was completed in 1752, over half a century after it was begun.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Greenwich Hospital from the North Bank of the Thames

DESCRIPTION: Canaletto painted this depiction of it soon afterwards.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Greenwich Hospital from the North Bank of the Thames

DESCRIPTION: It shows the view, which has altered little, through the centre of the hospital complex to the Queen's House, and on towards the Royal Observatory at the top of the hill beyond.Canaletto has created a slightly 'wide angle' effect by combining what can be seen of the hospital from two separate viewpoints which are set a little way apart on the near side of the Thames.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Greenwich Hospital from the North Bank of the Thames

DESCRIPTION: He has slightly broken the potential symmetry of the composition by studying the buildings from a little left of centre.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Greenwich Hospital from the North Bank of the Thames

DESCRIPTION: In addition, the monotony of the river is relieved by the considerable variety of craft that is travelling up and down it, and also by the unrelenting verticals and horizontals of the design which are countered by the bold diagonal of the mast of the ship grounded at the right.The river and architecture were established first by the artist, and the boats then painted over the top; it is just possible to see the buildings through the sails of the boat to the left of the centre of the picture
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: London: Greenwich Hospital from the North Bank of the Thames

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the pendant of Canaletto's Vigilia di Santa Marta (also in Berlin) thus representing two of Venice's four local, annual, evening festivities - rare subjects for Venetian vedutisti.This painting records the Vigilia di San Pietro on June 28, the feast day of Sts Peter and Paul.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Vigilia di San Pietro

DESCRIPTION: San Pietro de Castello, the church shown.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Vigilia di San Pietro

DESCRIPTION: was the residence of the Republic's Patriarch and of great local importance prior to his move to San Marco.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Vigilia di San Pietro

DESCRIPTION: Backlit by the moon, this romantic vista is among Canaletto's most arresting, painted after his return from England in 1755-56
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: The Vigilia di San Pietro

DESCRIPTION: This painting is probably the companion piece of the Capriccio with Classical Ruins and Buildings with which it shares its use of light and colour.
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Capriccio with Ruins and Porta Portello, Padua

DESCRIPTION: The monument in the middle distance provides the greatest point of luminosity
AUTHOR: CANALETTO
TITLE: Capriccio with Ruins and Porta Portello, Padua

DESCRIPTION: This panel depicting St Margaret of Antioch was painted while Candid was living in Florence, and it shows the strong influence of Vasari.
AUTHOR: CANDID, Peter
TITLE: St Margaret of Antioch

DESCRIPTION: According to legend, St Margaret was cast into prison by the governor or Antioch and was swallowed whole by the devil in the form of a dragon.
AUTHOR: CANDID, Peter
TITLE: St Margaret of Antioch

DESCRIPTION: Armed with a cross, she pierced its belly and split the monster open, allowing her to walk free.
AUTHOR: CANDID, Peter
TITLE: St Margaret of Antioch

DESCRIPTION: She was eventually beheaded.The painting had a companion piece representing St Catherine of Alexandria whose cult was often linked to that of St Margaret's
AUTHOR: CANDID, Peter
TITLE: St Margaret of Antioch

DESCRIPTION: The theme of the Immaculate conception was often present in Cano's production, this example is one of the most important ones, dates from his Madrid period and anticipates the prototype that he'll create when he returns to Granada
AUTHOR: CANO, Alonso
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: From 1640 on, Cano's technique became increasingly pictorial, that is to say, increasingly Baroque, acquiring some of the subtleties he had previously ignored.
AUTHOR: CANO, Alonso
TITLE: Descent into Limbo

DESCRIPTION: Perhaps his most important painting is the Descent into Limbo (in the County Museum, Los Angeles), a strange, rather illustrative composition, anecdotal in the movement imparted to the figures, but including one of the rare, and one of the most beautiful female nudes in Spanish art
AUTHOR: CANO, Alonso
TITLE: Descent into Limbo

DESCRIPTION: This painting, contracted on 23 November 1635, was executed for the convent church of Santa Paula in Seville.
AUTHOR: CANO, Alonso
TITLE: Saint John the Evangelist's Vision of Jerusalem

DESCRIPTION: It is evident that the artist had mastered an Italianate manner of painting; the figure of the angel alone is sufficient to corroborate this observation.
AUTHOR: CANO, Alonso
TITLE: Saint John the Evangelist's Vision of Jerusalem

DESCRIPTION: The partly clad body, the complicated, foreshortened pose, and the mastery of anatomical drawing are unique elements in Sevillian painting of the time, as are the deep perspective of the landscape and the delicate, translucent colours.Cano's mastery of this facile, sophisticated style suggests that he had passed time in Italy, although there is not the slightest evidence that he left the city until his final departure in 1638
AUTHOR: CANO, Alonso
TITLE: Saint John the Evangelist's Vision of Jerusalem

DESCRIPTION: Cantarini was called Simone da Pesaro or Il Pesarese.
AUTHOR: CANTARINI, Simone
TITLE: Holy Family

DESCRIPTION: He was a painter of portraits and religious subjects in the style of Guido Reni
AUTHOR: CANTARINI, Simone
TITLE: Holy Family

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the ceiling of the Salone in the Palazzo Pepoli Campogrande.In the centre of the illusionistic ceiling system a large oval panel shows Hercules being welcomed to Olympus.
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Apotheosis of Hercules

DESCRIPTION: Huge "ignudi" with weapons and banners occupy diagonally placed lunettes in the corners of the room, each of them accompanied by a female personification painted in grisaille.
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Apotheosis of Hercules

DESCRIPTION: These seated giants lead over into the second register of framing, which is dominated by twelve standing telamones, some clothed, some nude, upon whose heads rest massive curved gables leading up to the inner framing of the ceiling
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Apotheosis of Hercules

DESCRIPTION: From a young age, the painter enjoyed the protection of the Pepoli family.
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Taddeo Pepoli Installed as Apostolic Vicar by Pope Benedict XII

DESCRIPTION: Count Odoardo Pepoli commissioned Canuti to paint two long oval ceiling pictures in the stairwell of the Palazzo Pepoli Campogrande.
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Taddeo Pepoli Installed as Apostolic Vicar by Pope Benedict XII

DESCRIPTION: They illustrated significant events from the life of Taddeo Pepoli.
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Taddeo Pepoli Installed as Apostolic Vicar by Pope Benedict XII

DESCRIPTION: Canuti here shows himself to have been a close student of Veronese, from whom, in addition to the oval shape and certain compositional elements, he adopted the extreme view from below
AUTHOR: CANUTI, Domenico Maria
TITLE: Taddeo Pepoli Installed as Apostolic Vicar by Pope Benedict XII

DESCRIPTION: The exquisite painted decoration of the chapels of the church in the Certosa di San Martino, done both in fresco and in oils, was executed by prominent representatives of the younger Neapolitan school of painting, who were greatly influenced by Caravaggio.
AUTHOR: CARACCIOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Januarius

DESCRIPTION: Of the works in fresco painting, the most outstanding example is the vault of the San Gennaro chapel, painted by Caracciolo in 1632 with four scenes from the life of the patron saint of Naples.
AUTHOR: CARACCIOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Januarius

DESCRIPTION: His highly compressed compositions with their wealth of figures and drapery almost threaten to burst through the frames of the relatively small picture panel
AUTHOR: CARACCIOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Januarius

DESCRIPTION: The canvas depicts an adolescent, seemingly a sleeping Cupid stretched out on a crimson damask bedspread and pillow trimmed with dark ochre braiding and tassels.
AUTHOR: CARACCIOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Sleeping Cupid

DESCRIPTION: A bow and arrow are set on them in the foreground, the tip of the arrow tucked into the folds of the spread.The most plausible names scholars have advanced so far for the attribution of the work are Orazio Riminaldi and Giovanni Battista Caracciolo.
AUTHOR: CARACCIOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Sleeping Cupid

DESCRIPTION: Currently the latter is the most convincing
AUTHOR: CARACCIOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Sleeping Cupid

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the artist's first works.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Ecstasy

DESCRIPTION: It has a perfectly Lombard air: the broad lines of the composition recall mannerist motives.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Ecstasy

DESCRIPTION: But Caravaggio's characteristic approach to reality is already at work, and his brushstroke shows a magic that could be obtained only by a thorough analysis of Venetian painting.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Ecstasy

DESCRIPTION: The two figures seen frontally are undoubtably portraits, and this fact disorients those who would like to make a conventional reading of the scene and concentrate on the noble, classical character of the composition, organized around the traditional opposition between the figure of the lute player and the corresponding figure whom we see from behind.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Musicians

DESCRIPTION: The face between these two is Caravaggio's; the figure on the left is taken from an earlier composition (Young Peeling a Pear) which we know only from copies.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Musicians

DESCRIPTION: The painting has an iconographically very unusual theme.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Martha and Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: It shows Martha reproaching Mary Magdalene for her vanity, a subject that we know through a series of copies.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Martha and Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: The painting at Detroit has recently been recognized as the original.The religious theme is treated in a substantially profane manner.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Martha and Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: It is a pretext for making passages of highly intensive painting and for constructing an image that, seen in the context of the usual dichotomy of Caravaggio's early years, is more of a genre scene than a religious one
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Martha and Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: The still undeveloped features of this young cleric, who later became Pope Urban VIII (1623-1644) were portrayed as a much more distinguished figure by the skills of Gianlorenzo Bernini (1598-1680).
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Portrait of Maffeo Barberini

DESCRIPTION: Here, the face appears in chiaroscuro against a neutral background in such a way that a wall appears to be screening off the figure from the left.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Portrait of Maffeo Barberini

DESCRIPTION: In order to give the figure more 'rilievo', or more three-dimensionality, the lit sections are painted against a dark, and the sections in shadow against a light, background
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Portrait of Maffeo Barberini

DESCRIPTION: This painting exists in two versions, both of which are probably by Caravaggio (who frequently copied his own paintings).
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St John the Baptist (Youth with Ram)

DESCRIPTION: Both versions are in Rome, the other in the Galleria Doria Pamphilj.The image is a masterpiece of virtuosity whose appeal lies in its soft, caressing light and velvety rendering of cloth, flesh, and plants.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St John the Baptist (Youth with Ram)

DESCRIPTION: The figure is identifiable as St John only virtue of the symbols of Christ displayed in the painting: the ram (sacrificial victim), and the grape-leaves (from whose red juice, akin to the blood of Christ, springs life); otherwise the iconographical subject (the simple, immediately apparent image) appears as a nude youth with an ironic, if not allusive, expression.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St John the Baptist (Youth with Ram)

DESCRIPTION: Its cultivated content and its destination for an aristocratic patron are underscored by the artist's explicit use of a great figurative source of the past: Michelangelo's Ignudi from the Sistine Ceiling.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St John the Baptist (Youth with Ram)

DESCRIPTION: But whereas Michelangelo created abstract and ideal figures with cold lights and a merely theoretical plasticism, Caravaggio models his figure on the careful observation of nature, achieving an image of perfect realism
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St John the Baptist (Youth with Ram)

DESCRIPTION: The Crucifixion of St Peter in the church of Santa Maria del Popolo is one of two paintings in the Cerasi Chapel.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Crucifixion of Saint Peter

DESCRIPTION: Three shady characters, their faces hidden or turned away, are pulling, dragging and pushing the cross to which Peter has been nailed by the feet with his head down.Caravaggio's St Peter is not a heroic martyr, nor a Herculean hero in the manner of Michelangelo, but an old man suffering pain and in fear of death.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Crucifixion of Saint Peter

DESCRIPTION: The scene, set on some stony field, is grim.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Crucifixion of Saint Peter

DESCRIPTION: The dark, impenetrable background draws the spectator's gaze back again to the sharply illuminated figures who remind us, through the banal ugliness of their actions and movements - note the yellow rear and filthy feet of the lower figure - that the death of the apostle was not a heroic drama, but a wretched and humiliating execution
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Crucifixion of Saint Peter

DESCRIPTION: The founder of the Franciscan Order was the first person to experience the miracle of stigmatization of his own body.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: In other words, he was marked out by Christ's wounds.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: Here he is reduced to the ideal state of penance in the wilderness - a state equally valid for saints and pious people.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: Caravaggio shows no sign of reinterpreting the story unconventionally.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: His rather traditional approach may derive from the fact that the composition is probably a commission from the papal family.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: They owned the township known as Carpineto, from where an almost identical second version, stored at present in the Palazzo Venezia, Rome, originated.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: Stylistically, the painting is very closely related to the Brera Supper in Emmaus, which was probably painted in Latium.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: St Francis in Meditation

DESCRIPTION: From the fiefs of the Colonna family Caravaggio took refuge in Naples, in 1606.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: There he began to work again with his usual, astounding speed.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Early in January 1607 he was paid for the immense altarpiece commissioned to him by the Pio Monte di Misericordia (where it may still be seen today).
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows the Seven Acts of Mercy.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: It is very complicated in its organization.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Caravaggio actually had to add a series of figures (two angels and the Madonna and Child, the latter painted later) in the upper part of the painting, which make the composition of the picture the most complex, perhaps, in any of his works.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Caravaggio did not paint exemplary episodes intended to stir the viewer to religious piety through the illustrative emphasis of gestures and feelings.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Rather, he entrusted the educational effectiveness of his works to the evidence of things in themselves, in the conviction that nothing should be added above and beyond what is already contained in the intrinsic eloquence of the various poses.The seven acts of mercy represented on the painting are the following.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: On the right appear the (1) burial of the dead and the episode of the so-called Carita Romana (Cimon's daughter giving her father suck in prison), which contains at once the two charitable acts of (2) visiting prisoners and (3) feeding the hungry.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: (4) Dressing the naked appears in the foreground, symbolized by St.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Martin and the beggar.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Next to this scene, the host and St.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: James of Compostela allude to the (5) offering of hospitality to pilgrims.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: (6) Relieving the thirsty is represented by Samson drinking from the ox jaw.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: The youth on the ground behind the beggar of St.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: Martin may also represent the merciful gesture of (7) caring for the sick.We readily apprehend the artist's power of synthesis, which concentrates a conceptual content that is potentially quite dispersive, in the model behavior of a few figures.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: The large painting was widely copied and studied by seventeenth-century Neapolitan painters, who drew ideas and formal devices from it
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: The Seven Acts of Mercy

DESCRIPTION: On his way back to Rome Caravaggio returned to Naples.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: This harsh late work has none of the beauty of some of the late Sicilian pictures, such as the altarpiece stolen from the Oratory of San Lorenzo in Palermo, and it may reflect the assault Caravaggio endured in the Osteria del Cerriglio in the city.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: A sense of the tired mood of one aware of the pointlessness of a ruthless vendetta pervades the painting.The Baptist has been executed for denouncing Salome's mother Herodias over her illicit marriage with Herod.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: Caravaggio uses the device of planting two heads - Salome's and her maid's (or her mother's) - so close together that they seem to grow out of one body as the contrasting stages of youth and age.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: This had been a trait of Leonardo's, and the way that the head of St John is presented to the spectator recalls a picture by Leonardo's pupil Luini, whose Salome also looks away from her victim.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The executioner takes no joy in what he has been commanded to do.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: He feels only a stunned emotion in keeping with the sombre tones that Caravaggio adopts.You can view other depictions of Salome with the Head of John the Baptist.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: Alof de Wignacourt (1547-1622) was the Grand Master of the Knights of Malta and the patron of Caravaggio during his stay on Malta in 1607-1608
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Portrait of Alof de Wignacourt with His Page

DESCRIPTION: The attribution of this still-life to Caravaggio is doubtful.From a thematic point of view, large scale still-lifes in the Galleria Borghese are similar to outstanding early works by Caravaggio, but they lack the brilliance and the concentration on individual objects.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Still-Life with Flowers and Fruit

DESCRIPTION: This painting and another are usually attributed to Caravaggio.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Still-Life with Flowers and Fruit

DESCRIPTION: Because it is rather unconvincing to attribute such work to Caravaggio, some scholars distinguish this Caravaggesque painter of still-lifes from the master by naming him - after a splendid example of the genre - the Painter of the Still-Life in the Wadsworth Athenaeum, Hartford.
AUTHOR: CARAVAGGIO
TITLE: Still-Life with Flowers and Fruit

DESCRIPTION: The painting affords a view of the Serenissima's most characteristic quay: the Molo, with the columns of San Marco and San Todaro (or Teodoro) framing the entrance to the city.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: On the left stands the Ducal Palace, rendered in minute detail.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: The steep perspective in which the building is captured continues into the background along the Riva degli Schiavoni.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: Cast in contrasting light and truncated by the upper border of the image, the column of San Todaro dominates the scene.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: Between it and the column of San Marco the mast of a schooner appears in the background; it marks the central axis of the composition.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: Together with the large schooner on the right, the column of San Todaro to some extent counterbalances the buildings which occupy the left side.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: There is much activity both on the water and in the Square, where most of the figures are gathered in small groups.This view of the Molo and the Ducal Palace towards the east is highly unusual.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: Instead of depicting the Palace frontally, Carlevaris turned a quarter circle so that we look down the façade of the building towards the Riva degli Schiavoni, a composition he also used in four later works.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: The vantage-point in all these works is from the loggia of the Library, directly opposite the Ducal Palace.Although the architecture dominates the composition, the artist paid close attention to the human figures.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: Drawn or painted studies for several of the macchiette have survived.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: Scenes of people and situations drawn from everyday life were introduced to Italy in the first half of the seventeenth century by Dutch painters active in Rome.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: In the course of the century the so-called Bamboccianti cast such everyday scenes with growing frequency against a — sometimes identifiable — urban background.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: One of these painters was Johannes Lingelbach, whose work seems to have inspired Carlevaris's vedute.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: The Venetian artist is thought to have spent some time in Rome, where he could have become familiar with Lingelbach's work.Carlevaris's town views are also deeply rooted in the Venetian tradition of depicting historic or festive events.
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: His View of the Molo with the Ducal Palace, however, does not document a procession, reception or other festivity; rather, it subordinates the human figures to a portrayal of one part of the city in meticulous, topographically correct detail from an unorthodox point of view
AUTHOR: CARLEVARIS, Luca
TITLE: The Molo with the Ducal Palace

DESCRIPTION: The panels depicting St John the Baptist, the Crucifixion, St Peter, and St Francis (now in various museums) once belonged to a single altarpiece, which was a polyptych that consisted of ten panels arranged in two registers.
AUTHOR: CARNEVALE, Fra
TITLE: The Crucifixion
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and oil on wood, 103 x 67 cm

DESCRIPTION: The original location of the polyptych is not known, it comes perhaps from Loreto or from its environment.
AUTHOR: CARNEVALE, Fra
TITLE: The Crucifixion
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and oil on wood, 103 x 67 cm

DESCRIPTION: The panels show the influence of Domenico Veneziano
AUTHOR: CARNEVALE, Fra

TECHNIQUE: Tempera and oil on wood, 103 x 67 cm

DESCRIPTION: The panels depicting St John the Baptist, the Crucifixion, St Peter, and St Francis (now in various museums) once belonged to a single altarpiece, which was a polyptych that consisted of ten panels arranged in two registers.
