DESCRIPTION: The painter was influenced by Manet.
AUTHOR: CAROLUS-DURAN
TITLE: After the Swimming

DESCRIPTION: Like Manet in the Nymph Surprised he placed a sitting nude by a stream, and as in Manet's Dejeuner sur l'herbe, nudes and a figure in modern dress are present in a rural setting
AUTHOR: CAROLUS-DURAN
TITLE: After the Swimming

DESCRIPTION: Caron, who was Catherine de Medicis' official artist and whose paintings often seem to echo the royal fêtes, shows here the Emperor Augustus on his knees in front of the Sibyl, who gestures towards the Virgin and Child in the heavens.
AUTHOR: CARON, Antoine
TITLE: Augustus and the Sibyl

DESCRIPTION: The architectural setting, reminiscent of theatre decor, shows the Seine and possibly certain monuments of Paris modified by the artist's imagination on the right-hand side
AUTHOR: CARON, Antoine
TITLE: Augustus and the Sibyl

DESCRIPTION: Canvas No.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: 6 of the series of nine large paintings "Stories from the Life of St Ursula".The same colour tone and mood as in the Apotheosis, but used in a much more self-assured perspective composition, appears again in the Meeting between Pope Cyriacus and the Pilgrims.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: Scholars do not agree on the dating of this canvas and suggestions go from 1491, the same year as the Apotheosis of St Ursula, to 1493, the year of the Martyrdom of the Pilgrims and the Funeral of St Ursula.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: Even the question of the identification of the character in red standing next to Pope Cyriacus as Ermolao Barbaro, an eminent Humanist and the Venetian ambassador to the Vatican who died in 1493 after having fallen out of grace in Venice, is used in different ways by the advocates of the various chronological theories.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: The style of the canvas would appear to suggest a more mature period than the Pilgrims' Arrival in Cologne canvas, which dates from 1490.The scene of the meeting takes place in the bright afternoon light: to the left, the retinue of virgins is shown approaching along the path, while the English Prince and Ursula, in the centre, kneel in front of Pope Cyriacus; and to the right the procession of bishops, prelates and dignitaries unfolds in the bright, sunlit meadow outside the walls of Rome.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: Each figure projects its own shadow to emphasize the hour of the day in which the historic meeting is taking place; like a brilliant colour prism it revolves slowly in an atmosphere of absolute enchantment.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: The calculated stage-like arrangement of the characters is echoed in the setting of the eight standards, the white mitres, the regular geometric shapes of the huge construction of Castel Sant'Angelo.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: Not even the tiniest of details is lost on this enormous stage: the lavish ornamentation of the damask copes, or the group of clarion players standing out against the sky on the castle's bastions, or the ivy clinging to the walls
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Pilgrims Meet the Pope

DESCRIPTION: The painting is one of a series on the Life of the Virgin for the Scuola degli Albanesi, near S. Maurizio (Venice).
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: After the suppression of the Scuola in the late eighteenth century, this canvas and The Presentation of the Virgin went to the Brera; The Birth of the Virgin to the Accademia Carrara, Bergamo, The Annunciation and The Death of the Virgin to the Ca' d'Oro and The Visitation to the Museo Correr, Venice.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The entire cycle was completed in the early sixteenth century, with the help of considerable shop work
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: The Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Episode No.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: 4 of the series of seven paintings "Episodes from the Life of Sts Jerome, George and Triphun".St George and the Dragon is set in a wide open space, unlike anything Carpaccio had ever done before.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: The whole of the foreground is taken up by St George on his horse and the monstrous animal, wounded and dying, arranged along a diagonal line that goes from the praying princess to the tip of the  dragon's curved tail.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: On the ground, baked by the sun, we can see the remains of the dragon's victims and vipers, lizards, toads and vultures, each realistically portrayed.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: To the left, from the terraces of the fairytale palaces, the inhabitants of Selene watch the outcome of this extraordinary tournament
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the last works entirely by Carpaccio.
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: Crucifixion and Apotheosis of the Ten Thousand Martyrs

DESCRIPTION: The painting divides critics: some see it as little more than a virtuoso exercise, while other praise it for its great breadth and spectacular effects
AUTHOR: CARPACCIO, Vittore
TITLE: Crucifixion and Apotheosis of the Ten Thousand Martyrs

DESCRIPTION: In this painting, attributed to Girolamo da Carpi, echoes of Bosch's surreal world are evident
AUTHOR: CARPI, Girolamo da
TITLE: Landscape with Magicians

DESCRIPTION: The Villa Caldogno is the result of one of Palladio's early projects.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: Its construction began in 1542, at the behest of Losco Caldogno, an aristocrat and silk merchant from Vicenza, who had inherited an agricultural complex and fields in Caldogno the year before.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: Construction of the building and the decoration of the interiors extended over a long period of time, brought to completion only in 1570.The fresco decoration of the loggia, the Central Hall, and two other rooms (Room of Scipio and Room of Sofonisba) was completed by Giovanni Antonio Fasolo and Giovanni Battista Zelotti by 1570.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: In 1646, the interior distribution of the space was modified and a new small room (camerino), connecting the Room of Scipio and the Room of Sofonisba, was frescoed by the young Venetian painter Giulio Carpioni.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: These frescoes illustrate scenes from Guarino Guarini's Pastor Fido (The Faithful Shepherd).
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: The room was partly frescoed earlier by an unidentified sixteenth-century painter with some episodes taken from Torquato Tasso's Aminta.Carpioni's paintings in the camerino unfold in three compartments on the walls, each containing an episode from the poem; the compartments are embellished along the side edges with refined, colourful floral festoons.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: The scenes depict: The Coronation of the Nymph Amaryllis, Winner of the Kissing Competition; The Pursuit of Corsica by a Satyr; and the Wounding of Dorinda, Mistaken by the Shepherd Silvio for One of His Prey.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: In the corners of the room, as a connective element, are two unusual, extremely lively candelabra.
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: Completing the cycle, above the two doors are the scenes Cupid Taming the Lion and The Struggle between Erote and Anterote
AUTHOR: CARPIONI, Giulio
TITLE: View of the Pastor Fido camerino

DESCRIPTION: This altarpiece in a chapel in Santa Caterina dei Funari, Rome was commissioned by Gabriele Bombasi, a member of the Farnese entourage.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: St Margaret

DESCRIPTION: The figure of the saint was taken directly from The Madonna of St Luke (now in the Louvre) which Annibale Carracci had painted for the cathedral in Reggio Emilia in 1592.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: St Margaret

DESCRIPTION: The figure was copied by Lucio Massari (1569-1633), a pupil of Carracci, and Annibale carried out the finishing touches
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: St Margaret

DESCRIPTION: During his years in Rome, Annibale was an enthusiastic exponent of a cleansed classical art.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Rest on Flight into Egypt

DESCRIPTION: He paid tribute to it in the amazing ceiling that he spent the last years of his life painting in the Palazzo Farnese.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Rest on Flight into Egypt

DESCRIPTION: On this, and also on the large landscape lunettes in the Galleria Doria Pamphilj, Annibale was helped by young assistants, nearly all from Emilia, who subsequently established the classical style there that proved to be so successful.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Rest on Flight into Egypt

DESCRIPTION: Annibale Carracci's reputation as an "academic artist" and the fact that for over three centuries he has been regarded as a paradigm of classical style, has meant that for too long we have overlooked his no less fascinating handling of nature, evident in his Landscape with the Flight into Egypt.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Rest on Flight into Egypt

DESCRIPTION: But the melancholy which can be glimpsed in that landscape, whose symmetry almost anticipates Poussin's, overwhelmed Annibale as a man and he stopped painting toward the end of his life.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Rest on Flight into Egypt

DESCRIPTION: Fortunately, his true place in art has been recognized by recent critical works
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Rest on Flight into Egypt

DESCRIPTION: In 1597 Cardinal Odoardo Farnese commissioned Annibale Carracci's great masterpiece, the ceiling of the Galleria Farnese in the Palazzo Farnese, the most splendid and influential ceiling decoration in Rome since that of the Sistine Chapel.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: The Galleria Farnese

DESCRIPTION: Annibale's brother Agostino assisted him on at least two of the scenes until they quarrelled and Agostino left Rome.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: The Galleria Farnese

DESCRIPTION: In contrast to the earlier interpretation which saw them as a Neoplatonic allegory of the victory of Celestial Love over physical passion, in recent years Annibale's frescoes have generally been regarded as a witty and joyous celebration of the classical gods in love.During the 1570s and 1580s fresco cycles with mythological subjects had been relatively unfashionable in Rome, since the climate of the Counter Reformation favoured religious decoration, even in secular buildings such as palaces and villas.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: The Galleria Farnese

DESCRIPTION: It may be a measure of the Catholic Church's confidence in winning the battle for souls that it could increasingly tolerate such overtly erotic decoration, even in a cardinal's palace, albeit in what was probably one of the more private rooms.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: The Galleria Farnese

DESCRIPTION: Besides celebrating love's power to conquer, it is likely that the frescoes were intended to complement the antique statues, some of the finest in one of Rome's most magnificent collection of antiquities, which were displayed there
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: The Galleria Farnese

DESCRIPTION: The fresco depicts the scene when the jealous Cyclops Polyphemus hurls a rock at Acis, the beloved of the sea nymph Galatea.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Annibale
TITLE: Polyphemus and Acis

DESCRIPTION: Lodovico Carracci derived his Baroque type of composition from certain pictures by Titian, adding to these a celestial plane, by which the upper part of the picture is filled with great beauty.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Bargellini Madonna

DESCRIPTION: The Renaissance 'Sacra conversazione', in which all the people were motionless, has become a living conversation, in which men and saints are admitted in familiar terms into the presence of the sacred figures
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Bargellini Madonna

DESCRIPTION: This scene is part of the frescoed frieze painted in 1588-91 by the Carracci in the salone on the piano nobile of the Palazzo Magnani in Bologna.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The frieze depicts in 15 scenes the stories of the founding of Rome.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The iconographical program of the frieze precisely follows the story of "Parallel Lives" by Plutarch.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: Each scene is accompanied by a motto written on a scroll beneath each box.One of the most famous of all Roman myths, is the story of Romulus and Remus, the twins who were suckled by a she-wolf.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The twin brothers were purported to be sons of the Rhea Silvia and Mars, the god of war.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: Because of a prophecy that they would overthrow their murderous uncle, they were abandoned at birth and put into a basket that was then placed into the River Tiber.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The basket ran aground and the twins were discovered by a female wolf.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The wolf nursed the babies for a short time before they were found by a shepherd.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The shepherd then brought up the twins.When Romulus and Remus became adults, they decided to found a city where the wolf had found them.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The brothers quarrelled over where the site should be and Remus was killed by his brother.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: This left Romulus the sole founder of the new city and he gave his name to it – Rome.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The date given for the founding of Rome is 753 BC.Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf is the first scene of the cycle.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: It was executed by Lodovico Carracci.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The motto beneath the scene reads: "LAESI NON NECATI ALIMVR" (Wounded, not killed, we are fed)
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: Romulus and Remus Suckled by the Wolf

DESCRIPTION: The scene depicted, popular in the Counter Reformation, is taken from the Gospel of Saint Mark (Chapter 14, verse 72), when Saint Peter laments his betrayal of Christ.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: St Peter in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: Lodovico's presentation of the narrative discretely includes all the relevant context of the story, without distracting the viewer from the magnificent figure of Peter in the foreground.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: St Peter in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: In the background we see the palace of  the High Priest, with Christ being brought before him on the arcaded upper story, and the servants warming themselves by a fire on the ground arcade, where Peter had recently been with them.
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: St Peter in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: In the left foreground the Cross is being prepared
AUTHOR: CARRACCI, Lodovico
TITLE: St Peter in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: The artist painted in Toledo and Madrid.
AUTHOR: CARRE?O DE MIRANDA, Juan
TITLE: Duke of Pastrana

DESCRIPTION: Charles II, successor to Philip IV, viewed him with favour, and in 1669 he was made painter to the King.
AUTHOR: CARRE?O DE MIRANDA, Juan
TITLE: Duke of Pastrana

DESCRIPTION: Although his religious paintings are of unusual quality, his main interest was painting portraits, the finest being that of the Duke Pastrana, now in the Prado.This mature portrait by Carreño, the impact of the dark and imposing, pyramidal figure of the Duke is counterbalanced by very delicate and melancholic coloring.
AUTHOR: CARRE?O DE MIRANDA, Juan
TITLE: Duke of Pastrana

DESCRIPTION: Carreño's work here recalls the portraiture of Van Dyck in England
AUTHOR: CARRE?O DE MIRANDA, Juan
TITLE: Duke of Pastrana

DESCRIPTION: A sister-in-law of Giovanni Antonio Pellegrini, Rosalba Carriera achieves the same airy lightness of touch as her relative in her portraits.
AUTHOR: CARRIERA, Rosalba
TITLE: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family

DESCRIPTION: These were done in pastel and in them she explored the finest shadings of her subjects' characters, the most fleeting of their moods.
AUTHOR: CARRIERA, Rosalba
TITLE: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family

DESCRIPTION: Thus, without falling either into the dangers of the encomiastic portrait or of the documentary, Rosalba matches the immediacy of pastel technique to the freshness of her psychological and social penetration of her subjects, offering an unrivalled picture of the society of her time.
AUTHOR: CARRIERA, Rosalba
TITLE: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family

DESCRIPTION: In the Elderly Lady the mature beauty of the noblewoman and her serene good-natured existence are conveyed with incomparable skill.
AUTHOR: CARRIERA, Rosalba
TITLE: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family

DESCRIPTION: No less typical of her work is the portrait of Cardinal Melchior de Polignac with its superb rendering of the physical features of the subject, catching immediately the wilful character of the prelate.The artist uses her pastels with consummate skill in conveying the fresh innocence of the Young Lady of the Le Blond Family
AUTHOR: CARRIERA, Rosalba
TITLE: Young Lady of the Le Blond Family

DESCRIPTION: Carrier-Belleuse's portraits of women are few, and for them he often worked in a neo-Rococo mode, participating in the eighteenth-century revival that began and flourished in the mid-nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: CARRIER-BELLEUSE, Albert-Ernest
TITLE: Girl in a Straw Bonnet

DESCRIPTION: The identity of the sitter of the present bust is unknown.
AUTHOR: CARRIER-BELLEUSE, Albert-Ernest
TITLE: Girl in a Straw Bonnet

DESCRIPTION: The women Carrier-Belleuse portrayed were generally actresses or singers, wives or daughters of friends, and high society ladies, whose identities were discreetly concealed
AUTHOR: CARRIER-BELLEUSE, Albert-Ernest
TITLE: Girl in a Straw Bonnet

DESCRIPTION: In this painting Carus also shows the figures from behind, so that the viewer experiences the boat trip.
AUTHOR: CARUS, Carl Gustav
TITLE: A Gondola on the Elbe near Dresden

DESCRIPTION: At the same time the boat is framed like a vista from the window, creating a picture within a picture.. This was an effect that Friedrich used in many of his interiors where he shows a view out of a window.
AUTHOR: CARUS, Carl Gustav
TITLE: A Gondola on the Elbe near Dresden

DESCRIPTION: Although Cassatt was never married and had no children of her own, she had a remarkable ability to portray the special love between mother and child.
AUTHOR: CASSATT, Mary
TITLE: Caress Maternelle

DESCRIPTION: She was likely inspired to explore this theme by images of the Madonna and Child from the Italian Renaissance
AUTHOR: CASSATT, Mary
TITLE: Caress Maternelle

DESCRIPTION: Cassatt preferred to paint friends and acquaintances.
AUTHOR: CASSATT, Mary
TITLE: Susan on a Balcony Holding a Dog

DESCRIPTION: Her sister Lydia posed frequently.
AUTHOR: CASSATT, Mary
TITLE: Susan on a Balcony Holding a Dog

DESCRIPTION: After Lydia died in 1882, Susan - probably a cousin of Cassatt's housekeeper, Mathilde Vallet - made continual appearances, posing for no fewer than nine pictures up to 1883, the last and most mature of which was Susan on a Balcony Holding a Dog
AUTHOR: CASSATT, Mary
TITLE: Susan on a Balcony Holding a Dog

DESCRIPTION: The painting portrays the nobleman Francesco Falier dressed as procuratore da Mar.
AUTHOR: CASTELLI, Bernardino
TITLE: Portrait of the Nobleman Francesco Falier

DESCRIPTION: It is signed by the Venetian portraitist Bernardino Castelli and probably painted in 1786, the year Falier was elected to the high office of which he displays the insignia
AUTHOR: CASTELLI, Bernardino
TITLE: Portrait of the Nobleman Francesco Falier

DESCRIPTION: In the 1650s Castello developed a scheme of a simulated opening on the ceiling with symmetrical architectural framing elements incorporating additional figures and motifs.
AUTHOR: CASTELLO, Valerio
TITLE: Triumph of the Balbi

DESCRIPTION: On the ceiling in the Palazzo Reale (formerly Palazzo Balbi Durazzo), showing the Triumph of the Balbi, he worked together with his pupil, Giovanni Maria Mariani
AUTHOR: CASTELLO, Valerio
TITLE: Triumph of the Balbi

DESCRIPTION: The story of a great flood occurs in the mythology of many races.
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: The Greek version (Met.
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: 1:348-415) tells of Deucalion, son of Prometheus, who, like Noah, escaped the destruction that overtook the rest of mankind by building an ark in which he floated for nine days with his wife Pyrrha.
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: After the waters had subsided they were advised by an oracle to veil their heads and 'throw the bones of your great mother behind you', which they took to mean the rocks of Mother Earth.
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: They did as they were bid, the rocks which Deucalion threw turning into men and Pyrrha's into women.
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: Thus a new human race was created.In the painting Pyrrha and Deucalion are shown in the act of casting the rocks.
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: On the ground rocks change into men and women who scramble to their feet
AUTHOR: CASTIGLIONE, Giovanni Benedetto
TITLE: Pyrrha and Deucalion

DESCRIPTION: This painting is typical of those northern painters whose art was transformed by the Italian experience.The picture shows figures in the garden of the Villa Doria Pamphilj in Rome, with a view of the old church of San Pancrazio.
AUTHOR: CATEL, Franz Ludwig
TITLE: Garden of the Villa Doria Pamphili in Rome

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows the influence of both Johan Christian Dahl's more naturalist approach to landscape painting, and the continuing legacy of the French painters of the generation following Valenciennes.The Villa Doria Pamphili was one of several Roman properties of the Doria Pamphili Landi family, including a splendid palace in the Corso, which housed one of the greatest art collections in Italy, another in the Piazza Navona, and the great park and palace of the Villa Doria Pamphili
AUTHOR: CATEL, Franz Ludwig
TITLE: Garden of the Villa Doria Pamphili in Rome

DESCRIPTION: This painting Catena, a pupil of Giorgione, represents a type of devotional image in which Christ bearing the cross is removed from Passion scenes involving a large number of figures
AUTHOR: CATENA, Vincenzo
TITLE: Christ Carrying the Cross

DESCRIPTION: Giangiorgio Trissino (1478-1550) was a poet and architect, one of the first patron of Andrea Palladio
AUTHOR: CATENA, Vincenzo
TITLE: Giangiorgio Trissino

DESCRIPTION: Not until 1900, during restoration work in the church, did large sections of the old fresco decoration come to light again.
AUTHOR: CAVALLINI, Pietro
TITLE: Jacob's Dream (fragment)

DESCRIPTION: The middle register of a depiction of the Last Judgment on the west wall of the basilica, fragments of the fresco of the Annunciation on the north wall, and two scenes from the story of Jacob on the south wall were uncovered.
AUTHOR: CAVALLINI, Pietro
TITLE: Jacob's Dream (fragment)

DESCRIPTION: It is assumed that there were cycles of the Old and New Testament, respectively, on facing walls of the nave.The fragment of Jacob's Dream is on the south wall of the nave
AUTHOR: CAVALLINI, Pietro
TITLE: Jacob's Dream (fragment)

DESCRIPTION: This painting was probably painted around 1617 by Bartolomeo Cavarozzi, one of Caravaggio's most successful and accomplished followers.
AUTHOR: CAVAROZZI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Sacrifice of Isaac

DESCRIPTION: Although it was catalogued and exhibited in the Barbara Piasecka Johnson Collection, Lawrenceville as the work of Caravaggio, in 2014 it was sold by the Collection with the attribution to Cavarozzi
AUTHOR: CAVAROZZI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Sacrifice of Isaac

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the south wall of the Salone Terreno (Room of Giovanni da San Giovanni) on the ground floor of the Palazzo Pitti.The Palazzo Pitti in Florence, purchased from the Pitti family by the wife of Duke CosimoI de' Medici in 1549 and renovated and expanded by Bartolommeo Ammanati, served as a residence of royal proportions for roughly 350 years.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: It was occupied by the dynasties of the Medici, the Habsburgs, and finally the Savoyards, and subjected to constant adaptations and alterations.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: Intensive use by ruling families resulted in the lavish decoration of all floors.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: Fresco painters from three centuries  contributed to the fixed decor of the public rooms and living quarters.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: Of its numerous apartments two suites of rooms stand out because of their decoration, function and size.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: These took their present form under Grand Duke Ferdinando II de' Medici (1610-1670), and for the most part they were spared later encroachments owing to their high-quality frescoes.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: These are the reception rooms in the left (north) wing used by Ferdinando II.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: The rooms on the cooler ground floor, directly connected with the Boboli Gardens by way of a loggia and a terrace, served him as a summer apartment (Appartamento d'Estate); his winter quarters (Appartamento d'Inverno), reached by way of a large staircase and capable of being heated, lie directly above these on the piano nobile.Several different painters worked on the decoration of the large hall on the ground floor (Salone Terreno).
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: Its virtuoso wealth of forms, the scenographic bravura of its architectural painting, and its strikingly original programmatic concept, makes the room an outstanding example of seventeenth-century Florentine painting, standing as it does between tradition and modernism.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: The east wall of the Salone and the ceiling was painted by Giovanni da San Giovanni in 1635-36, the south wall by Cecco Bravo in 1638, the west wall by Ottavio Vannini in 1639-41, and the north wall by Francesco Furini in 1640-42.The wall paintings deal with Lorenzo de' Medici and the return of the Golden Age under his rule.
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: Cecco Bravo's frescoes present Lorenzo, who is always shown in fifteenth-century costume, as protector of the Muses and Apollo and as a bringer of peace
AUTHOR: CECCO BRAVO
TITLE: View of the south wall

DESCRIPTION: The four panels in Avignon showing the standing Saints Peter, John the Baptist, Bartholomew and Nicholas probably formed the side panels of an altarpiece which had in the centre the Virgin and Child Enthroned (signed and dated 1386, now in the Portland Art Museum, Portland, Oregon)
AUTHOR: CECCO DI PIETRO
TITLE: St John the Baptist
TECHNIQUE: Poplar panel, gold ground, 92 x 30 cm

DESCRIPTION: Four panels representing full-length saints - Sts Peter, Simon, Rainerius and a bishop saint - have formed part of a larger altarpiece complex flanking a central panel
AUTHOR: CECCO DI PIETRO
TITLE: A Bishop Saint
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, gold ground, 92 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: Francesco di Ser Cenni was one of the greatest popularizers of late Gothic painting style in Florence.
AUTHOR: CENNI di Francesco di Ser Cenni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: This panel, preserved in good condition, shows the influence of the style of Agnolo Gaddi
AUTHOR: CENNI di Francesco di Ser Cenni
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: This painting shows the influence of Van Dyck, both the colours and the composition is close to the Flemish Baroque painting.
AUTHOR: CEREZO, Mateo the Younger
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: However, its pathos and sentimentality relate it to contemporary Spanish religious painting
AUTHOR: CEREZO, Mateo the Younger
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: A 1692 Chigi inventory lists two paintings, the Rural Scene (see at Angeluccio) and the Figures in a Tree-lined Avenue and indicates that they are the product of a collaboration between Angeluccio, who painted the landscape, and Michelangelo Cerquozzi, who painted the figures.Though Miel and van Bloemen also painted figures for Angeluccio's landscapes, the majority of his collaborations were with Michelangelo Cerquozzi.
AUTHOR: CERQUOZZI, Michelangelo
TITLE: Figures in a Tree-lined Avenue

DESCRIPTION: Angeluccio seems to have furnished background landscapes for his fellow "Bamboccianti" much as Viviano Codazzi executed architectural backgrounds for them.
AUTHOR: CERQUOZZI, Michelangelo
TITLE: Figures in a Tree-lined Avenue

DESCRIPTION: A hypothesis has even been advanced that the nickname "Angeluccio" is derived from the closeness of this artist to "Michele Angelo" Cerquozzi.
AUTHOR: CERQUOZZI, Michelangelo
TITLE: Figures in a Tree-lined Avenue

DESCRIPTION: The fruits of this collaboration entered into numerous important Roman collections in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries, the inventories of which either report the pictures as "by Angeluccio with figures by Cerquozzi", or as landscapes by Angeluccio alone
AUTHOR: CERQUOZZI, Michelangelo
TITLE: Figures in a Tree-lined Avenue

DESCRIPTION: Ovid (Metamorphoses 14:130-153) tells how the Sibyl of Cumae, in southern Italy, was loved by Apollo.He bribed her by offering to prolong her life for as many years as there were grains in a heap of dust, in return for her embraces.
AUTHOR: CERRINI, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Apollo and the Cumaean Sibyl

DESCRIPTION: She refused him and although he kept his word, he denied her perpetual youth, so she was commanded to centuries as a wizened crone.In the painting the Sibyl, a young woman is shown standing before the sitting Apollo holding out her cupped hand which contains the heap of dust
AUTHOR: CERRINI, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Apollo and the Cumaean Sibyl

DESCRIPTION: This painting belongs to the Padernello cycle (a series of about twelve paintings executed for the castle of Padernello).
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Little Beggar Girl and Woman Spinning

DESCRIPTION: It represents two full-length, life-size figures, whose precise relationship is unclear.
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Little Beggar Girl and Woman Spinning

DESCRIPTION: The sharp, crude realism of the figures is contrasted with the almost evanescent quality of the background, which is painted in a summary manner with swift, fluid brushstrokes
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Little Beggar Girl and Woman Spinning

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts a group of young women in full length, modestly dressed and seated on simple wicker chairs, who are making pillow lace in a bare room without windows or furnishings.
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Women Working on Pillow Lace (The Sewing School)

DESCRIPTION: The "sewing school," a widespread theme in genre painting of the period, was most likely developed as such by the Danish artist Bernhard Keil (1624-1687), known as Monsù Bernardo, who was active in northern Italy and who repeatedly treated the subject as an allegory of the senses of touch and sight
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Women Working on Pillow Lace (The Sewing School)

DESCRIPTION: This still-life with herring, lobster, turbot, red mullet, oysters, gurnard, lemon, chicory root, carrots, onions, terracotta pot and ladle, and straw flask, was executed during the artist's stay in Venice, from about 1736 to 1742.
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Connections with Venetian painting are evident in the soft, quivering brushwork and the sumptuous, refined sense of colour, enhanced by the bright orange tonalities of the lobster, the brilliant red of the mullet, and the golden yellow of the lemon
AUTHOR: CERUTI, Giacomo
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Prospero Farinaccio was the lawyer of the painter.
AUTHOR: CESARI, Giuseppe
TITLE: Portrait of Prospero Farinaccio

DESCRIPTION: Cesari rarely executed portraits, this portrait was painted in recognition of the part that the lawyer had played  in securing the painter's release from imprisonment after the sequestration of his property and collection of pictures in 1607 by Cardinal Scipione Borghese
AUTHOR: CESARI, Giuseppe
TITLE: Portrait of Prospero Farinaccio

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a fragment, originally conceived as a large scale altarpiece with full length figures.
AUTHOR: CESARI, Giuseppe
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts John the Baptist, Mary Magdalen and Anne

DESCRIPTION: It is a work from Cesari's early maturity
AUTHOR: CESARI, Giuseppe
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts John the Baptist, Mary Magdalen and Anne

DESCRIPTION: The painting, built up using effective light-dark and red-green contrasts, shows Cézanne's friend from his youth, Émile Zola, author of the Les Rougon-Macquart.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Paul Alexis Reading to Zola

DESCRIPTION: The other figure is Zola's secretary Paul Alexis, a journalist, writer and friend of Cézanne from his time in Aix
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Paul Alexis Reading to Zola

DESCRIPTION: Every object in this painting, with its rhythmic horizontal and vertical construction, forms an integral part of the rigorous structure and yet also exists in its own right.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: The Black Clock

DESCRIPTION: There is a stark contrast between the organic opening of the seashell and the cold marble of the clock
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: The Black Clock

DESCRIPTION: Cázanne used his visits to Zola's summer house in Médan to paint in the open air in the surrounding area, including Auvers, Pontoise, and Bennecourt
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Château de Médan

DESCRIPTION: Cézanne depicts himself here as an extremely withdrawn, distrustful personality.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Self-Portrait on Rose Background

DESCRIPTION: Based on this self-portrait, Rilke described the artist he admired so much as "humble and colossal", "meek and larger than life"
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Self-Portrait on Rose Background

DESCRIPTION: Cézanne's main work was done in landscapes.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire and the Viaduct of the Arc River Valley

DESCRIPTION: He painted the river valleys of the Ile-de-France and, above all, his beloved hard, bright, sunbaked Provence.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire and the Viaduct of the Arc River Valley

DESCRIPTION: Over the course of decades he never tired of walking the hills in order to paint the majestic profile of Mont Sainte-Victoire, often with the valley of the Arc in the foreground and the impressive intrusion of a lengthy new railway viaduct
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire and the Viaduct of the Arc River Valley

DESCRIPTION: Although spots of paint are still used to represent areas of foliage or building, the Sainte-Victoire paintings from the latter part of Cézanne's life are increasingly abstract.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire Seen from Les Lauves

DESCRIPTION: The sky seems to merge with the foreground, particularly on the left-hand side; the three-dimensionality of landscape before Cézanne seems to have disappeared
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire Seen from Les Lauves

DESCRIPTION: Cézanne has built up this composition using individual spots of light and dark colour which create the impression of landscape only when they are juxtaposed.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire Seen from Les Lauves

DESCRIPTION: The sky contains the same green as the ground, and the spots of white unpainted canvas create an open feeling.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire Seen from Les Lauves

DESCRIPTION: These white areas emphasize the two-dimensional nature of the surface
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: Mont Sainte-Victoire Seen from Les Lauves

DESCRIPTION: In 1902, Cézanne bought a plot of land on the Chemin des Lauves, on an otherwise undeveloped hillside to the north of Aix, and had a two-storey house built with a large studio, some five metres high, on the first floor.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: The Gardener

DESCRIPTION: He used the studio early in the morning and in the late afternoon.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: The Gardener

DESCRIPTION: When it became too hot, he would paint watercolours on the terrace, which was surrounded by bushes and small trees and had a magnificent view of the town of Aix.
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: The Gardener

DESCRIPTION: From time to time, local agricultural workers or his gardener Vallier would sit for him, for example for this painting
AUTHOR: CÉZANNE, Paul
TITLE: The Gardener

DESCRIPTION: Other candidates for the identity of the sitter are Mary Stuart (Mary, Queen of Scots) and Marie Touchet, mistress to Charles IX.This is the classic portrayal of a Royal mistress in her official role, cool, beautiful, aloof, bejewelled even in her bath, accompanied by the strappings of her state: fine rooms, a noble child in the arms of its leering, accomplice-nurse, the sly Love-child stealing the fruits, the flower of passion in her hand.Regarding the several influences, Titian's influence has been cited.
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: A Lady in Her Bath

DESCRIPTION: The motif of the servant in the background performing a domestic chore is seen as deriving from the Venus of Urbino.
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: A Lady in Her Bath

DESCRIPTION: The painting also shows affinities to the highly polished surfaces and icy eroticism of Bronzino.
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: A Lady in Her Bath

DESCRIPTION: The pose of the woman in the bathtub was derived from a composition by Leonardo, known as the Monna Vanna (now lost
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: A Lady in Her Bath

DESCRIPTION: Claude Gouffier (1501-1570) distinguished himself as a captain of Pavia, where he was captured along with the king.
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: Portrait of Claude Gouffier

DESCRIPTION: In 1536 he was again taken prisoner, this time in Provence by the troops of Emperor Charles V. François I  named him grand equerry of France.
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: Portrait of Claude Gouffier

DESCRIPTION: Responsible for organizing the royal jousts so dear to Henri II, he was a skilled, subtle, and prudent courtier.
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: Portrait of Claude Gouffier

DESCRIPTION: His family at the Château d'Orion had an art collection which included paintings, drawings, books of hours.This portrait shows Gouffier at the very end of his career as grand equerry
AUTHOR: CLOUET, François
TITLE: Portrait of Claude Gouffier

AUTHOR: COLLIER, Edwart

DESCRIPTION: Inscribed and dated lower right: vanitas/vanitaum/et omnia/vanitas/1665

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the ceiling decoration in the Salone delle Guardie in the Palazzo Ducale in SassuoloThe Salone was transformed into a bombastic, theatrical glorification of the house of Este by the quadratura painters Angelo Michele Colonna and Agostino Mitelli.
AUTHOR: COLONNA, Angelo Michele
TITLE: Glorification of Este Patronage

DESCRIPTION: Coats of arms, painted fabrics, trophies, and simulated statues against the walls serve as a prelude to the ceiling painting in which Apollo and the nine Muses celebrate the Este as patrons of the various arts, documented in inscriptions accompanying the goddesses
AUTHOR: COLONNA, Angelo Michele
TITLE: Glorification of Este Patronage

DESCRIPTION: Andrea Commodi was an Italian painter of the early-Baroque period.
AUTHOR: COMMODI, Andrea
TITLE: Young Woman in the Kitchen

DESCRIPTION: Born in Florence, but mostly active in Rome, he was a pupil of the painter Cigoli.
AUTHOR: COMMODI, Andrea
TITLE: Young Woman in the Kitchen

DESCRIPTION: He painted frescoes in the sacristy of San Carlo ai Catinari and a Fall of the Angels now in the Galleria Palatina (Palazzo Pitti) in Florence.
AUTHOR: COMMODI, Andrea
TITLE: Young Woman in the Kitchen

DESCRIPTION: One of his pupils was a juvenile Pietro da Cortona who moved to Rome and became one of the towering figures of the Italian Baroque.
AUTHOR: COMMODI, Andrea
TITLE: Young Woman in the Kitchen

DESCRIPTION: Another pupil was Giovanni Battista Stefaneschi (1582-1659)
AUTHOR: COMMODI, Andrea
TITLE: Young Woman in the Kitchen

DESCRIPTION: Constable's rural realism belongs to the tradition of the composed landscape - created in the studio after studies in oil done from nature.
AUTHOR: CONSTABLE, John
TITLE: Helmingham Dell

DESCRIPTION: Helmington Dell is the sketch of a motif repeated by the artist in two finished pictures
AUTHOR: CONSTABLE, John
TITLE: Helmingham Dell

DESCRIPTION: For some of his large canvases Constable painted full-size oil sketches, The Leaping Horse being an example.
AUTHOR: CONSTABLE, John
TITLE: The Leaping Horse

DESCRIPTION: Here he has tried to freeze a sudden action - the leap of a barge horse over a cattle barrier on the Stour towpath.
AUTHOR: CONSTABLE, John
TITLE: The Leaping Horse

DESCRIPTION: But to the modern observer his own description of the picture, written shortly before it was ready for the 1825 Academy exhibition - 'calm & exhilarating, fresh & blowing' - applies more happily to the sketch; the greatest sufferer in the finished canvas is the sky, which has lost its bubbling clouds
AUTHOR: CONSTABLE, John
TITLE: The Leaping Horse

DESCRIPTION: However, compared with other existing portraits of this couple, this identification is doubtful

DESCRIPTION: The Haarlem government commissioned this painting to decorate a guesthouse for the Orange family and other dignitaries.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: The painting's reference to the beginnings of the Trojan War presented an impressive reminder that even trivial discord causes devastating wars.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: This was a topical message in Haarlem, which had suffered debilitating defeat in a Spanish siege of 1573.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: The work also showcased Haarlem's patronage of sophisticated international history painting.In this painting, depicting events leading up to the Trojan War, Cornelis van Haarlem represented the assembled gods as naked muscle-men and soft-skinned women, in endlessly varied poses.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: Their idealized, heroic bodies befit their immortality and the ominous event they witness.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: These figures were clearly based on drawings after the nude which Cornelis could have made in the small academy in Haarlem.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: His grand style would have reminded knowledgeable viewers of the history painting of the Italian Renaissance, specifically of Michelangelo and his followers, and of the praise for idealized nudity and difficult poses in sophisticated art theory
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: The Wedding of Peleus and Thetis

DESCRIPTION: When Jesus was born and King Herod heard that the infant was the King of the Jews, he ordered that all boy children in Bethlehem under two years of age should be put to death.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: Meanwhile, however, Mary and Joseph had fled to safety with their baby.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: The senseless slaughter of the innocents is an example of ruthless tyranny.
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: The painting was probably commissioned on behalf of Prince Maurits, whose task as commander-in-chief of the army was to rid the Netherlands of Spanish tyranny.A second version of this subject was made one year later for the city of Haarlem
AUTHOR: CORNELIS VAN HAARLEM
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: The sitter of this portrait is Jan Gerritz.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob

DESCRIPTION: van Egmond van de Dijenborgh, elected Burgomaster of Alkmaar.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob

TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: This self-portrait by the Amsterdam painter Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen tells us important facts about his life.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The note with the date 1533 and the house mark between an I and an A appear to announce that Iacobus Amstelodamensis, or Jacob of Amsterdam, painted this portrait of himself in 1533.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: It is known from the archives that Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen, the person behind the name Jacob of Amsterdam, must have died before 18 October 1533, the date of a document stating that his wife was a widow.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: That and the date on the Self-Portrait appear to be conclusive evidence that the artist did indeed die that year.However, it has been suggested that he was dead by 1532, when one of his houses was sold.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: So 1533 or 1532 - it is not known for sure.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: On top of that, there are doubts about when the Self-portrait was actually executed.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: It is very close in style to the paintings that Jacob Cornelisz made around 1525, and he is not known to have made any more after 1526.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: It is possible that the date was added later, in the year of his death, and that we are looking at a Van Oostsanen who is younger than he appeared in 1533.There is another panel in which the same man is seated before an easel, painting the portrait of an older woman.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: It is by Dirck Jacobsz, the couple's son, who traced the head in the Rijksmuseum Self-Portrait and used it for the man by the easel.
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: He then added his mother's likeness, creating an anachronistic scene: a portrait of his father as he probably looked before 1533, and one of his mother as she appeared around 1550
AUTHOR: CORNELISZ VAN OOSTSANEN, Jacob
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: Basically it is oriented to Michelangelo's fresco in the Sistine Chapel, but is easily half as big again, so it is now the largest fresco in the world.

DESCRIPTION: It proved fatal for Cornelius.
AUTHOR: CORNELIUS, Peter
TITLE: The Last Judgment

DESCRIPTION: The individual elements simply would not resolve into a unified composition.

DESCRIPTION: Cornelius was overwhelmed with criticism as soon as the painting was finished, and there were acrimonious disputes with King Ludwig I of Bavaria.

AUTHOR: CORONA, Leonardo

DESCRIPTION: From his second Italian journey in 1834 Corot brought back landscapes permeated by an astonishing luminosity, in particular those of Volterra and Venice.

DESCRIPTION: The figures in his late works appear to dissolve into nature.

TITLE: Peasant Woman Pasturing a Cow by the Edge of a Forest

DESCRIPTION: Here, the turn of the woman's body is presented so precisely that the entire landscape seems to be contained within her backward glance
AUTHOR: COROT, Jean-Baptiste Camille
TITLE: Peasant Woman Pasturing a Cow by the Edge of a Forest

DESCRIPTION: Toward the end of his life Corot revived the theme of the painter's studio: a model posing, or a gathering of connoisseurs or artists.
AUTHOR: COROT, Jean-Baptiste Camille
TITLE: Corot's Studio

DESCRIPTION: In a few instances he depicted a young girl seated in front of one of his own pictures, contemplative, or lost in reverie
AUTHOR: COROT, Jean-Baptiste Camille
TITLE: Corot's Studio

AUTHOR: COROT, Jean-Baptiste Camille

DESCRIPTION: The painting was probably cut down slightly on the sides and top, painted originally for a local church at the same time that he was working on the frescoes in the Cathedral.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: It can be considered as the companion of the Nativity (The Night) in Dresden.Considered his masterpiece among the altarpieces, the composition is built up as a remote variation of the pyramidal arrangements favoured by Leonardo, broken by the dominating verticality of St Jerome on the left.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: The sacra conversazione is transformed into an informal and incidental narrative that takes place in a landscape.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: A makeshift red canopy has been constructed in the foreground, where his figures are massed on a compact, constricted plane.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: Their poses are particularly hard to reconstruct because they are either figures covered by draperies that effectively hide their structure, or are in intricate unnatural positions.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: As Correggio grew older, he began to take liberties with the conventions regarding the proportion of figures.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: Saint Jerome on the left, accompanied by his identifying lion, occupies almost the entire height of the painting, assuming a dominant role even in relation to the Madonna and Child.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: His thick, muscular right leg is strikingly long in comparison to his upper body and rather smallish head.The pictorial effects derive from a masterly application of the oil paint, confident and elegant colour, and idealized, refined faces
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO
TITLE: Madonna and Child with Sts Jerome and Mary Magdalen (The Day)

DESCRIPTION: The two allegories, Allegory of Virtues and Allegory of Vices, were painted to complete the decoration of Isabella d'Este's studiolo in the Palazzo Ducale of Mantua.
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO

DESCRIPTION: These are some of the most enigmatic works of Correggio, their subject is difficult to decipher
AUTHOR: CORREGGIO

DESCRIPTION: This painting (and another in the same private collection) are illuminating examples of the type of decorative flower pieces in series in which De la Corte specialised.
AUTHOR: CORTE, Gabriel de la
TITLE: Grotesques with Flowers

DESCRIPTION: The complete series is likely to have comprised a number of other pictures of the same type.
AUTHOR: CORTE, Gabriel de la
TITLE: Grotesques with Flowers

DESCRIPTION: These pictures are trompe l'oeil works that depict fictive carved stone or stucco-work grotesques of scrolling vegetable ornament with intertwining flower garlands.
AUTHOR: CORTE, Gabriel de la
TITLE: Grotesques with Flowers

DESCRIPTION: It is unlikely that these grotesques existed as such and they were most probably copied from 16th or 17th-century ornamental prints.While the grotesques are repeated in each picture, the floral arrangements vary and offer a delightful interplay between the natural-looking flowers and the stylised vegetable ornaments.
AUTHOR: CORTE, Gabriel de la
TITLE: Grotesques with Flowers

DESCRIPTION: The repetition of the grotesque decorations and the downward-looking angle of the cherubs gaze in the paintings suggest that these pictures were intended to make up a frieze on the upper part of the wall in a private residence of the time.
AUTHOR: CORTE, Gabriel de la
TITLE: Grotesques with Flowers

TITLE: Battle Scene with a Roman Army Besieging a Large City

DESCRIPTION: The battle represented here is not yet identified.
AUTHOR: CORTE, Juan de la

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows a view of the Stanza della Stufa with the Age of Iron (left) and the Age of Gold and Age of Silver (right).Of the numerous apartments in the Palazzo Pitti, two suites of rooms stand out because of their decoration, function and size.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: View of the Stanza della Stufa

DESCRIPTION: These took their present form under Grand Duke Ferdinando II de' Medici (1610-1670), and for the most part they were spared later encroachments owing to their high-quality frescoes.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: View of the Stanza della Stufa

DESCRIPTION: These are the reception rooms in the left (north) wing used by Ferdinando II.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: View of the Stanza della Stufa

DESCRIPTION: The rooms on the cooler ground floor, directly connected with the Boboli Gardens by way of a loggia and a terrace, served him as a summer apartment (Appartamento d'Estate); his winter quarters (Appartamento d'Inverno), reached by way of a large staircase and capable of being heated, lie directly above these on the piano nobile.In the winter quarters Pietro da Cortona decorated the Stanza della Stufa, and the Rooms of the Planets (Sala di Venere; Sala di Giove; Sala di Marte; Sala di Apollo) between 1637 and 1661.The Stanza della Stufa is a smaller room on the piano nobile that was one of the grand duke's private chambers.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: View of the Stanza della Stufa

DESCRIPTION: It took its name from its heated floor ("stufa" means heater).

TITLE: View of the Stanza della Stufa

DESCRIPTION: Cortona painted here the Age of Gold and the Age of Silver on the north wall in 1637.

DESCRIPTION: The Sacchetti family commissioned this painting in the 1620s when Pietro da Cortona was just making his name in Roman circles.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da

DESCRIPTION: They thus became his first patrons and introduced him to the world of aristocratic commissions.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: The Rape of the Sabine Women

DESCRIPTION: During the first two decades of the century, Caravaggio's naturalistic style had been rivaled by the Carracci cousins' academic style of classicism.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: The Rape of the Sabine Women

DESCRIPTION: Each school had its own followers and some attempts had been made to bring the two together.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: The Rape of the Sabine Women

DESCRIPTION: The arrival of Pietro da Cortona, at the same time as Bernini erupted onto the scene as the preferred sculptor and architect of the Barberini pope Urban VIII, were together sufficient to transform art in Rome and to create a true Baroque style.Pietro da Cortona's painting stands out for its open theatricality, lively gestures, richness of colour, and brushwork, as well as its diffused light.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: The Rape of the Sabine Women

DESCRIPTION: The Sabine women being lifted into the air deliberately derive from Bernini's works, such as Apollo and Daphne, as if to underline the bond between the two artists.
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: The Rape of the Sabine Women

DESCRIPTION: There is little real violence in his treatment of this scene from Roman legend, merely a splendidly theatrical display of half-clothed bodies
AUTHOR: CORTONA, Pietro da
TITLE: The Rape of the Sabine Women

DESCRIPTION: As indicated in the romances and the books of sermons, a swaying walk was one of the ways of expressing worldly elegance for women of this Gothic world from the fourteenth century; but here this Gothic mannerism meets and contributes to another kind - the 'Mannerism' of art history.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Venus Standing in a Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Mannerist painters and sculptors, whether Italian, German, or French, all admired what Italian aestheticians called 'la linea serpentina', which seemed to them the most beautiful of all forms.The Venus is clad only in a provocatively transparent veil; in some paintings this is a subsequent addition, but here it is original.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Venus Standing in a Landscape

DESCRIPTION: The better to set off the ivory whiteness of her body, Cranach has shown it silhouetted against a sombre background of foliage.

TITLE: Venus Standing in a Landscape

DESCRIPTION: The landscape conveys in a few strokes an intense impression of the Germanic conception of nature.

TITLE: Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: Human beings dream of being young again, of leaving the worn outer shell and exchanging it for a new one.

DESCRIPTION: The notion of the cleansing power of the elements, especially of water, is as old as humankind itself.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder

DESCRIPTION: The centre of the scene is a pool filled with water.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: Some steps lead down to the pool, which is surrounded by a fantastic landscape far from civilisation.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: People have undertaken arduous journeys to reach this solitary spot and bathe in the miraculous waters.In the left half of the picture wrinkled and frail old women are brought up on carts and stretchers.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: They are undressed and examined by a doctor before stepping into the water where the gradual process of rejuvenation takes place.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: Their wrinkles and old sallow skin disappear, their flesh becomes rosy and smooth, and they turn into young girls.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: As they emerge from the water they are welcomed by a cavalier who shows them to a tent where they receive new clothes.

TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: Old peasant women are transformed into young ladies of the court who indulge in the carefree pleasures of life.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: The jollifications at the festive table, the dancing, music and lovemaking, all take place in a lush flowering landscape.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: These are the realms of eternal youth, to which the hardships of old age, set in a barren rocky landscape on the left side of the picture, form a stark contrast.The fountain spouting water from the spring into the pool bears the statues of Venus and Cupid - evidence that this is actually a fountain of love rather than youth, and that the power of love is the true source of immortality
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: The Fountain of Youth

DESCRIPTION: Johannes Spiessheimer (Cuspinian) was a scholar in the court of the Emperor Maximilian I, himself a writer, who made Vienna, through its chancellery and university, the leading humanist city in Germany.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: Cranach painted the double portrait of the Viennese humanist Dr.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: Cuspinian and his wife Anna, daughter of an official of the Emperor on the occasion of their marriage.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: Cranach composed these portraits as a pair.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: This is apparent in the continuity of the landscape behind the elegantly dressed couple.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: The trees at the edges of the painting, on the left and right of the figures, are placed so that their branches form an arch, imparting an air of grandeur to the sitters.The background was evidently composed with a distinct purpose in mind: nothing here is arbitrary.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: The landscape is full of erudite symbolism, probably devised by Cuspinian himself.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: The various images disguise hieroglyphic allusions to the cabbala.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: However, it would be quite unsatisfactory merely to decipher the landscape background symbol by symbol without seeing its significance as a whole.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: Beyond a system of occult signs, the landscape allows a generous framework for the couple's understanding of themselves, providing a medium for the new cult of sensitivity and awareness of nature which some humanists were propagating in literary form through the Classical topos of the pleasance, or pleasure-park
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Johannes Cuspinian

DESCRIPTION: The painting can be dated around 1520, the date 1517 in the top left corner is a later addition.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Martin Luther as an Augustinian Monk in a Doctoral Hat
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on wood, 40 x 27 cm

DESCRIPTION: The underdrawing of the portrait is extremely detailed, suggesting that it was drawn directly from the subject during a portrait sitting
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Martin Luther as an Augustinian Monk in a Doctoral Hat
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on wood, 40 x 27 cm

DESCRIPTION: The painting has a companion piece depicting the Portrait of a Clean-Shaven Young Man.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 59 x 41 cm

DESCRIPTION: Both half-length figures are placed close to the picture surface against a bright green background.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 59 x 41 cm

DESCRIPTION: The close attachment of the two people is suggested in their dress: they wear similar caps, his adorned with stitching, hers with a round agrafe.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 59 x 41 cm

DESCRIPTION: The freshness  of the observation and the finesse of its realisation recall Netherlandish portraits of the period, such as those of Joos van Cleve and Quentin Massys, for example
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 59 x 41 cm

DESCRIPTION: John the Steadfast (1468—1532) was a member of the Ernestine line of the House of Wettin.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: During the lifetime of his brother, Elector Frederick the Wise, he became involved in the business of government.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: After his brother's death in 1525, John the Steadfast inherited the position of Elector and became Cranach's new master, in which role he proved no less benevolent than Frederick the Wise.One of Cranach's main duties as court painter consisted in portraying the Saxon princes as well as their families and allies.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: The portraits were not only intended as documentation of the line of descent for royal ancestral galleries, but also as gifts.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: The mutual exchange of portraits was a court custom, with the result that we know what John the Steadfast looked like from a number of paintings by Cranach.The present half-length portrait shows John the Steadfast in semi-profile at the age of 58.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: His arms are elided on the left and right edges of the painting, but the work's narrow format lends the portrait an expression of monumental immediacy.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: Moreover, the sitter stands out by virtue of the signet ring on his left hand, the chain around his neck bearing several rings and a small cross, and above all the rich embroidery on his shirt collar and the precious fur trim on his gown.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: The garland of carnations in his hair, traditionally worn at weddings, indicates that the portrait might have been painted on the occasion of the betrothal of the sitter's son, John Frederick the Magnanimous, to Sibylle of Cloves in 1526, and that the Elector is depicted here as the father of the groom
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Elector John the Steadfast of Saxony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 57 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: Margaret of Austria was one of the most significant female figures of the sixteenth century, and won the respect of his contemporaries by the conduct of her life and office (as the Governess-General and regent of the Netherlands.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Margaret of Austria
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 50 x 35 cm

DESCRIPTION: Her court painter Bernaert van Orley painted several official portraits of Margaret.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Margaret of Austria
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 50 x 35 cm

DESCRIPTION: Cranach's painting is based on van Orley, his source was, however, not one of the official portraits but a chalk drawing now in Berlin.The painter depicts the sitter in a white hood in the Netherlandish style.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Margaret of Austria
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 50 x 35 cm

DESCRIPTION: The Governess of the Netherlands had adopted this form of dress in a modest acknowledgement of her widowhood
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of Margaret of Austria
TECHNIQUE: Oil and tempera on red beechwood, 50 x 35 cm

DESCRIPTION: This painting was executed by the workshop of Lucas Cranach.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: Cranach's productive workshop follows the master's example in presenting us with this bizarre and highly characterized portrait of a lady, achieved with a sinuous and undulating line.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: The punctilious attention to detail expressed in the tiny decorations of the dress, the tight curly hair and the effervescent hat  tells us that this is a fine example of German artistic workmanship
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Elder

DESCRIPTION: This depiction by Lucas Cranach the Younger of the founders of the human race was part of a tradition in the Cranach workshop that spanned many decades.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Adam and Eve
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: Lucas Cranach the Elder had produced a number of variants from 1509 onwards.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Adam and Eve
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: Apart from small-sized versions on panel, we know of life-size pairs of paintings also by Lucas Cranach the Elder.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Adam and Eve
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: Albrecht Dürer's first independent formulations of this theme in 1504 and 1507 were certainly the inspiration for Cranach's work on the subject.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Adam and Eve
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: But unlike Dürer, Cranach was less interested in Antiquity and classical proportions, and operated rather within north Alpine traditions that were strongly influenced by Burgundian-Dutch forms.Cranach's fundamental principle of varying individual motifs is illustrated in his depictions of Adam and Eve.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Adam and Eve
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: Not only the posture and the vocabulary of gestures, but also the positioning of the fig-leaves, the background design and the representations of the animals can be found in either similar or identical form in the various versions that came from the Cranach workshop.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Adam and Eve
TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: The method of combining individual components to produce a striking overall impression gives a special quality to the Cranachs' works, which are never mere copies of previous designs

TECHNIQUE: Oil on lime wood panel, 171 x 63 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: Philipp Melanchthon (1497-1560) was a German reformer, collaborator with Martin Luther, the first systematic theologian of the Protestant Reformation, intellectual leader of the Lutheran Reformation, and an influential designer of educational systems.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 63 x 49 cm

DESCRIPTION: He stands next to Luther and Calvin as a reformer, theologian, and molder of Protestantism.Melanchthon had his portrait painted on numerous occasions, but he only sat to four artists: Albrecht Dürer (in an engraving of 1526); Hans Holbein the Younger (whose portrait of circa 1535 is in the Niedersächsisches Landesmuseums, Hannover); and both Lucas Cranach the Elder and his son Lucas Cranach the Younger.Cranach the Younger painted several portraits of Melanchthon, probably from the mid 1540s onwards.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 63 x 49 cm

DESCRIPTION: The earliest would seem to be that dated 1544, in Östra Ryd, Sweden, and the last painted from life is that signed and dated 1559 in the Städel Museum, Frankfurt am Main, finished just one year before Melanchthon's death at the age of 63.
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 63 x 49 cm

DESCRIPTION: Such was the demand for portraits of Luther and Melanchthon that several posthumous works were produced by Cranach the Younger and his studio
AUTHOR: CRANACH, Lucas the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Philipp Melanchthon
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 63 x 49 cm

AUTHOR: CRIVELLI, Vittore

AUTHOR: CRIVELLI, Vittore
TITLE: Madonna with the Child

AUTHOR: CRIVELLI, Vittore

DESCRIPTION: This painting is as much a tree portrait as a landscape study, as the sensitivity and naturalism of the painting imbues the subject with a great deal of character.
AUTHOR: CROME, John
TITLE: Wooded Landscape with an Oak

DESCRIPTION: John Crome, along with John Constable, was one of the earliest English artists to represent identifiable species of trees, rather than generalised forms.
AUTHOR: CROME, John
TITLE: Wooded Landscape with an Oak

DESCRIPTION: His works, renowned for their originality and vision, were inspired by direct observation of the natural world combined with a comprehensive study of Old Masters.
AUTHOR: CROME, John
TITLE: Wooded Landscape with an Oak

DESCRIPTION: Cuyp's earliest dated landscapes of 1639 are astonishingly eclectic, but by 1641 he was painting panoramic views of the Dutch countryside in the monochromatic mode of van Goyen.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: The young Cuyp, however, favoured a distinct yellow tonality as against van Goyen greyish and brown hues.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: More important for Cuyp's subsequent development was the impact of Dutch landscapists who brought an Italianate style from Rome back to Holland; Cuyp himself never travelled to the south.Since very few of Cuyp's landscapes are dated, and none is dated after 1645, it is difficult to say precisely when the characteristic golden light, reminiscent of the Campagna the artist never saw, replaces the earlier paler one, and when mountain ranges, herds of cattle, and figures conspicuously set off against a sky begin to play an important role in his compositions.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: But by 1645 distinct traces of the style of Cornelis Poelenburgh, a member of the first generation of Italianate painters, and Jan Both, the leading artist of the following generation of Italianate landscapists, are evident.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: Jan Both became Cuyp's principal source of inspiration.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: The River-bank with Cows shows how rapidly he assimilated Both's motifs and sun-drenched light.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: From this time onward golden sunlight becomes the all-pervading element in Cuyp's paintings.
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: It spreads warmth and beauty over the Dutch countryside, where sturdy animals - most often cows - take place of human heroes
AUTHOR: CUYP, Aelbert
TITLE: River-bank with Cows

DESCRIPTION: The angular figure of the Saviour is standing in the middle isolated from everything and everybody.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar

DESCRIPTION: He is raising up his hands  as if praying or preaching.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
