DESCRIPTION: The group of the twelve  apostles are looking out of the picture.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Dr.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Rezsõ Pertorini, author of the Csontváry pathogaph, grouped them as people shouting, "Crucify him," as if they were a choir in a Greek tragedy.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Faces are suggestive, those of the Saviour and Moses are expressive.The picture condenses events.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Moses is standing with stone tablets on the left.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: The silhouette of a town can be seen in the background, it is Jerusalem.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: On the right, there is a slim tree with a block of stone at its foot with two black figures tumbling on it.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Behind the tree, there is a modern church which is lit: it can be approached on a steep slope.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Next to it, there are three columns with winged sculptures and a domed building on the left.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: A group of people are approaching the church.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: The picture has a complicated and symbolic message, in fact, the painter attempted to sum up the history of christianity.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: He portrayed the Old Testament on the left and the New Testament on the right: the former  being represented by Moses and the tables of the Testament, and the New Testament by Jesus' sermon, payer, and desciples, the tree symbolizing the cross, and the mourners with a stone suggesting a grave.There are symbolic objects and scenes on both sides.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: The  background stretches out to the distance.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Thus, the painter emphasizes the main characters.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: The composition is balanced.
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: The connection between time and space, and the suggestivity of tools with expressive power are in  harmony with one another
AUTHOR: CSONTVÁRY KOSZTKA, Tivadar
TITLE: Praying Saviour

DESCRIPTION: Moritz Michael Daffinger was one of Vienna's most successful portraitists in the early nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: DAFFINGER, Moritz Michael
TITLE: Miniature of Elise Wolf

DESCRIPTION: He started his career at the Vienna porcelain factory, and later his domain became the portrait miniature.
AUTHOR: DAFFINGER, Moritz Michael
TITLE: Miniature of Elise Wolf

DESCRIPTION: He portrayed the actors of Vienna, painted guest portraits for the albums of his wife, and became acquainted with Grillparzer who introduced him into Schubert's circle.
AUTHOR: DAFFINGER, Moritz Michael
TITLE: Miniature of Elise Wolf

DESCRIPTION: After working as a decorative painter in his home town of Bergen, Norway, Dahl studied landscape painting at the Copenhagen Academy from 1811 to 1818.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: Here he was impressed by the work of Jens Juel and Christoffer Wilhelm Eckersberg, but the crucial influence came with a study of the seventeenth-century Dutch masters of landscape.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: One of them, Allaert Everdingen, had visited Norway and subsequently developed a type of "Nordic landscape" based on his impressions.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: This style was later taken up by the Norwegian national movement in the nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: Alongside the "Italian landscape," the "Nordic landscape" also became established on the Continent early in the century.Stimulated by his first extensive travels through Norway in 1826, Dahl supplemented his previous range of motifs - waterfalls, moving clouds, and windswept trees - with depictions of the bare plateaus of the high mountain regions and their cloud formations, becoming an innovator in Norwegian as well as German landscape painting.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: In 1818, he settled at Dresden, where he associated with Caspar David Friedrich and Carl Gustav Carus.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: In 1824, like Friedrich, he was appointed professor at the Dresden Academy.
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

DESCRIPTION: Dresden and its environs began to feature frequently in his compositions, in which the sky often occupied the larger part of the canvas
AUTHOR: DAHL, Johan Christian Clausen
TITLE: Cloud Study with Horizon

AUTHOR: DALSGAARD, Christen

DESCRIPTION: A group of people are gathered around a table, listening to a missionary's message.
AUTHOR: DALSGAARD, Christen
TITLE: Mormons Visit a Country Carpenter

DESCRIPTION: Light filters in through a small window and an open door.
AUTHOR: DALSGAARD, Christen
TITLE: Mormons Visit a Country Carpenter

DESCRIPTION: It is a study of contemporary daily life, carefully depicting the interior and costumes of the people in detail
AUTHOR: DALSGAARD, Christen
TITLE: Mormons Visit a Country Carpenter

DESCRIPTION: After attending the drawing school of the Royal Dublin Society and spending a brief period in London, Danby settled around 1813 for two decades in Bristol, in whose environs he painted the small, exquisite landscapes on which his fame today largely rests.
AUTHOR: DANBY, Francis
TITLE: Scene from the Apocalypse

DESCRIPTION: Forced to leave England in 1829 due to financial problems and a marital scandal, Danby established himself in Paris and Geneva, where he remained until 1840.
AUTHOR: DANBY, Francis
TITLE: Scene from the Apocalypse

DESCRIPTION: His oils, ink drawings, and watercolours, focussing on lyrically romantic landscapes, represents one of the most significant contributions made by any artist to nineteenth-century British landscape painting.
AUTHOR: DANBY, Francis
TITLE: Scene from the Apocalypse

DESCRIPTION: He also concerned himself with religious themes, treated in a visionary manner.The present painting is presumably one of four depicting scenes from the Apocalypse.
AUTHOR: DANBY, Francis
TITLE: Scene from the Apocalypse

DESCRIPTION: In a Romantic nocturnal landscape evoking the infinity of the cosmos appears a vision of the giant angel described in Chapter 10 of the Apocalypse, descending in a cloud from heaven with a rainbow over his head and legs like columns of fire.
AUTHOR: DANBY, Francis
TITLE: Scene from the Apocalypse

DESCRIPTION: The natural scene in which the visionary apparition is set evinces a coloration and sophisticated painterly handling that explain Danby's rank as one of the finest British landscapists of the nineteenth century
AUTHOR: DANBY, Francis
TITLE: Scene from the Apocalypse

DESCRIPTION: This image of objective scientific representation was consistent with Medici interests
AUTHOR: DANDINI, Cesare
TITLE: Two Hanged Teals

DESCRIPTION: The sitter of this three-quarter length portrait is probably Anne, eldest daughter of Sir Jacob de Bouverie, 1st Viscount Folkestone
AUTHOR: DANDRIDGE, Bartholomew

DESCRIPTION: Konrad Graf (1782-1851) was one of Vienna's most outstanding piano-manufacturers of the early nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: DANHAUSER, Josef Franz
TITLE: Portrait of the Piano-Manufcturer Konrad Graf

DESCRIPTION: He owned a veritable collection of paintings and was patron of contemporary artists like Josef Danhauser, from whom he commissioned his portrait in 1840.
AUTHOR: DANHAUSER, Josef Franz
TITLE: Portrait of the Piano-Manufcturer Konrad Graf

DESCRIPTION: Robert Campin, who is generally identified as the Master of Flémalle, had a workshop in Tournai from 1406 at the latest, and, as we know from several documents, it received many commissions from the city, various institutions, and private individuals.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: According to a document (which is a copy of old records of the painters' guild, dating from around 1482, that is to say some 50 years later) a certain Jacques Daret was an "apprentice" in the workshop at about the same time as Rogier van der Weyden; he joined it on 12 April 1427 and became a master on 18 October 1432.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: We do know, however, that Daret had already been working with Campin for over ten years, so he must have learned his trade as a painter long before 1427; the description "apprenticeship" cannot therefore be correct for him at this period.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: We may assume that both Daret and Van der Weyden completed their real apprenticeship earlier and they must have worked together in Campin's workshop around 1430 as trained painters.Four paintings executed by Campin's pupil Jacques Daret in 1434-35 for Jean du Clercq, abbot of St.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: Vaast in Arras, are extant and are unusually well documented.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: They originally ornamented the wings of an altar shrine decorated with alabaster sculptures.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: In these panels Daret shows himself a capable if not particularly innovative or sensitive artist, very closely related to Rogier and in particular to the Master of Flémalle.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: Daret's Visitation of Mary is so similar to Rogier's painting of the same subject (Museum der Bildende Künste, Leipzig)), which is certainly later, that we have to assume they had a common model.
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: And Daret follows one picture from the "Flémalle group" so closely, the Nativity now in Dijon Museum, that it can almost be called a free copy.This kind of painting, which now appears mediocre in comparison with the works of masters such as Rogier van der Weyden, was still so new and unusual in its time that a chronicler tells us how the donor, Jean de Clercq, seen here kneeling on the left with his abbot's insignia, proudly showed this altarpiece wing to the participants in the peace conference negotiating the Treaty of Arras in 1435
AUTHOR: DARET, Jacques
TITLE: Visitation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 57 x 52 cm

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a typical example of the artist's late period, when he was travelling in his floating studio along the rivers Oise and Seine
AUTHOR: DAUBIGNY, Charles-François
TITLE: River Bank

DESCRIPTION: This is an incisive work with the emphasis on the lighting.
AUTHOR: DAUMIER, Honoré
TITLE: The Drama

DESCRIPTION: Daumier used the same subject in an 1864 lithograph
AUTHOR: DAUMIER, Honoré
TITLE: The Drama

DESCRIPTION: This type of Pietà, whether or not accompanied by other holy women, appears more than once in Gerard David's oeuvre and was adopted on various occasions by painters of his circle such as Adriaan Isenbrant or Ambrosius Benson.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: A model drawing may have existed in David's studio or perhaps there was another prototype by his hand which is now lost.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: On closer examination David seems here to have built on both Hugo van der Goes and Hans Memling.The composition of the scene is a kind of reprise of Memling's Reins triptych (Memlingmuseum, Bruges).
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: Here too, the scene is set in front of a landscape with on the left buildings intended to represent Jerusalem and on the right a group of rocks which serves as a repoussoir.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The tomb of Joseph of Arimathea, which he placed at Christ's disposal, has been hewn out of the rocks here.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: Wearing a turban and exotic clothing he stands in profile before the tombstone, while Nicodemus enters the tomb.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: With Memling it is a Roman sarcophagus which stands in front of the rock and which is being opened by Joseph and Nicodemus.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The composition itself, with the body held almost upright under the armpits and the head nodding to one side, derives from the right wing of Hugo van der Goes' Lamentation diptych (Kunsthistorisches Museum, Vienna).
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The figure of the Virgin placed parallel along Christ's body with her arm diagonally across it is an adaptation in reverse of the Virgin's posture in Van der Goes.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The same is probably also the case with the position of the squatting Mary Magdalene.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The St John, with his right knee and foot in frontal view, is also borrowed from Memling's Reins triptych.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The spire in the landscape is probably intended to suggest Bruges' Our Lady's Church
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Lamentation
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39,4 x 31,7 cm

DESCRIPTION: The left wing of the diptych depicts the Virgin and Child in the Church, while the right wing the donor Antonio Siciliano and St Anthony.The diptych was commissioned by Antonio Siciliano who served as chamberlain and secretary to Massimiliano Sforza, the Duke of Milan.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: In 1513 he was dispatched to Margaret of Austria in Mechelen on a diplomatic mission.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is assumed that Siciliano commissioned the painting from Gossart, who about 1513 worked at Margaret's court in Mechelen.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: However, the authorship of the diptych is debated, especially that of the donor (right) wing.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: Several alternative suggestions were proposed, the authorship being connected to the Antwerp Mannerists or to the artists contributing to the Grimani Breviary.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: Presently the right wing is attributed to Jan Gossart.The left panel is attributed to Gerard David.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: This attribution is supported by recent technical examination.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: More than any other Bruges painter, David inherited Jan van Eyck's legacy.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: The left panel of the diptych is an adaptation of van Eyck's Madonna in the Church.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: David made adjustments to the earlier model: he centred the Virgin in a wider view of the nave, added a third arch to the choir screen, and closed off the composition at the right with a series of columns matching those of the bays opposite
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: The Doria-Pamphili Diptych (left wing)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 22 cm

DESCRIPTION: Gerard David interpreted with great originality the theme of Rest during the Flight to Egypt.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Rest during the Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin and Child are placed in the centre in a landscape.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Rest during the Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: A tiny depiction of the Holy Family on its way to Egypt can be seen in the background on the right.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Rest during the Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The influence of Renaissance art, especially Leonardo, is clearly visible, notably in the use of sfumato and the atmospheric variations of the background
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Rest during the Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The work of Gerard David, another foreigner drawn to the wealthy city of Bruges, offers a final summary of the technical and spiritual tradition of the fifteenth century.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: David was born in Oudewater in Holland, but worked mostly in Bruges between 1484 and 1523, where, in a manner of speaking, he became Memling's successor.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: Two of his masterpieces, The Judgment of Cambyses (1498) and the Triptych of Jan des Trompes, belong to the Groeninge Museum in Bruges.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: In both works, Memling's flawless precision and cool smoothness are combined with the anatomical realism and seriousness of Van der Goes.The triptych with the Baptism of Christ, even though it was probably done after the Judgment of Cambyses, still breathes the quiet, ethereal atmosphere so characteristic of the Flemish Primitives.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: It is also one of the period's most remarkable artistic evocations of landscape and flora.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: It was commissioned by Jan des Trompes, a leading civil servant in Bruges, who appears in the painting with his first and second wives (front and rear of the right wing).
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: His third wife donated it to the Chapel of the Vierschaar tribunal in Saint Basil's Church after his death
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jan Des Trompes
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 129,7 x 96,6 cm (central panel), 132 x 43 cm (each wings)

DESCRIPTION: The Baptism of Christ forms the central section of a triptych commissioned by the treasurer of the city of Bruges, Jean Trompes.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: The wings show the donor's family and patron saints on the inside, and the Virgin and Child and the donor's first wife with St Elizabeth on the outside.Nowhere does the artist demonstrate more clearly both his talents and his limitations.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: The present scene contains virtually no action.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: The kneeling figures of John the Baptist and the angel dressed in a sumptuous cope reveal a mutual correspondence in their approximate symmetry and subtly differentiated positions.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: The panel's central axis is strongly emphasized by the figure of Christ, the dove of the Holy Ghost and the apparition of God the Father.In David's paintings the landscape forming the background to religious scenes takes on the motionless and precious look of something whose serenity opposes it to the tragedy of what is happening in the picture.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: One has only to look at the forest in the background of the Baptism of Christ, with its huge ivy-covered trunks, the strong rhythm of its escarpments and its foliage standing out against the blue of the distance.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: The still life of flowers in the foreground is characterized by a dazzling wealth of minute detail.This altarpiece was at one time considered one of the best works of Memling.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: The study of its wing panels was rightly recommended to landscape painters as the work of a marvellous painter of foliage
AUTHOR: DAVID, Gerard
TITLE: Triptych of Jean Des Trompes (central)

DESCRIPTION: David discovered the dramatically lit and forceful canvases of Caravaggio and his followers, and his full-length male nude and semi-nude studies such as Hector of 1778 and Patroclus of 1780 show how he had begun to use light and shadow to give weight and density to his figures
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Patroclus

DESCRIPTION: If little else were known of David, the self-portrait that he painted in May 1791 certainly looks the image of a Romantic.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: Painted rapidly, with a spontaneous touch, it shows an excited, even wild young man, with freely curling hair, eyes aglow with almost visionary zeal.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: He is looking slightly dishevelled and with a piercing gaze, very different from the normally relaxed pose of his sitters and perhaps an indication of the internal conflicts that eventually led him to become a fully committed Republican
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: When David was released from the Luxembourg prison at the end of December 1794, he became ill and so requested permission from the Convention to visit his wife's sister and her husband, Emilie and Pierre Sériziat, at their country house in Saint Ouen, near Tournan-en-Brie, about 32 km (20 miles) east of Paris.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son

DESCRIPTION: This visit was cut short by the accusations of May 1795 and arrest, but he returned there, accompanied by a guard, to recuperate after his second and final release in August.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son

DESCRIPTION: He then painted the portraits of his hosts.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son

DESCRIPTION: Madame Sériziat is shown in an interior setting with her young son, having just returned from a walk.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son

DESCRIPTION: Her cheeks are ruddy and she carries a recently picked bunch of wild flowers which are painted in a lively but meticulous manner.These two portraits were testaments of friendship and, by showing them at the 1795 Salon, he could prove that he was still able to paint after his ordeals
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Emilie Sériziat and her Son

DESCRIPTION: While Pope Pius VII remained in Paris after the consecration, David also painted his portrait and thereby joined an illustrious band of past artists - Raphael, Titian and Velázquez - as the painter of a pontiff.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Pius VII

DESCRIPTION: David broke with protocol by sitting down while he worked, as previously tradition had dictated that the humble artist should kneel to paint the Pope.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Pius VII

DESCRIPTION: David, though, did appreciate the honour bestowed upon him and apparently put on fine clothes and wore a sword as he worked.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Pius VII

DESCRIPTION: He responded warmly to the venerable old pontiff and was both delighted and moved by the benediction that he received from the hand of Pius
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Pius VII

DESCRIPTION: David's first history painting in exile was an extremely original and disturbing interpretation of the late antique myth of Cupid and Psyche.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: It was painted for the wealthy Italian patron and connoisseur Count Giovanni Battista Sommariva and, although planned in Paris, it was only finished in Brussels in 1817.As related by the Roman writer Lucius Apuleius in The Golden Ass (late second century AD), Cupid, the god of love, fell in love with the beautiful Psyche and brought her to his palace, where he visited her every night without ever letting her see his face.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: But curiosity got the better of her, and one night Psyche looked at Cupid while he was asleep.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Unfortunately a drop of hot oil fell from her lamp and awakened him, whereupon he abandoned her and the palace disappeared.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: From then on Psyche was condemned to wander the earth and perform impossible tasks in the vain hope of winning her lover back.Many other artists saw the lovers as innocent, tender and poetic, but David deliberately drew attention to the sexual aspect of the relationship.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Normally Cupid was shown as a beautiful young man, but David depicted him as a grinning adolescent who seems proud of his recent conquest.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: A great contrast is set up between Cupid's coarse ruddy features and awkward angular limbs, and the pale, smooth and languid beauty of the sleeping Psyche.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Unusually for David, the colours are bright and intense; in Brussels he looked at the colours used by Flemish Renaissance artists such as Jan van Eyck.
AUTHOR: DAVID, Jacques-Louis
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Beside portraiture, Degas's early work was also centred on historical themes drawn from religious tradition or mythology.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Young Spartans Exercising

DESCRIPTION: Between 1860 and 1865 he painted five historical paintings, for which there are several sketches and versions: Young Spartans Exercising, Semiramis Founding a City, Alexander and Bucephalus, Jephthah's Daughter, and The Sufferings of the City of New Orleans, the latter being his first entry at the Salon.These paintings are very original and unlike any historical painting in the nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Young Spartans Exercising

DESCRIPTION: They conformed to the rules of classicist composition, but they were also  innovative because of the freshness of his figures and the warm colours of his landscapes.The Young Spartans Exercising was reworked several times, and numerous related drawings and studies survive
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Young Spartans Exercising

DESCRIPTION: Degas's family were related to the Italian aristocracy, among them Baroness Bellelli and Duchess Morbilli.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Hilaire de Gas

DESCRIPTION: In 1856 he traveled for the first time to Italy, where he intended to make the acquaintance of his Italian relatives.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Hilaire de Gas

DESCRIPTION: This journey, which was followed by another in 1858 and several more in 1859, was Degas's real education.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Hilaire de Gas

DESCRIPTION: In Italy, Degas preferred the Quattrocento painters and the exponents of Florentine Mannerism.The people Degas depicted in that time were almost all members of his family, especially his sisters and brothers, and himself.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Hilaire de Gas

DESCRIPTION: His early portraits achieve their culmination in his group portrait The Bellelli Family.The present painting represents Hilaire de Gas, the painter's grandfather
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Hilaire de Gas

DESCRIPTION: Degas produced many portraits between 1865 and 1870, too, the major ones of which were Thérèse de Gas, Double Portrait, The Collector, Madame Hertel, Duke and Duchess of Morbilli, Jacques Joseph (James) Tissot, Mademoiselle Dihau at the Piano, Madame Camus at the Piano, Portrait of Hortense Valpinçon as a Child.Conventional as they may be, these portraits highlight both what is characteristic and what is casual in the personality and deportment of the sitter
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Collector

DESCRIPTION: Many of Degas's drawings and studies of movement after 1860 are inspired by race-course scenes.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Parade
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on canvas, 46 x 81 cm

DESCRIPTION: His paintings of horse races reflect how much he was influenced by the works of famous painters such as Théodore Géricault and Ernst Meissonier.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Parade
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on canvas, 46 x 81 cm

DESCRIPTION: He was similarly influenced by Japanese woodblock prints.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Parade
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on canvas, 46 x 81 cm

DESCRIPTION: The asymmetry of this composition derives from Oriental art
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Parade
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on canvas, 46 x 81 cm

DESCRIPTION: Horse racing, a sport of English origin, became popular on the Continent at the end of the eighteenth century, and soon inspired such painters as Carle Vernet and Théodore Géricault, who were both influenced by English artists.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: It attracted the interest of later painters, too.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: Manet emphasized the elegance of these occasions, while Degas preferred to observe the horses in motion.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: He focused on the movements of man and animal.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: His first sketches of racecourses date back to the beginning of the 1860s.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: At first he was interested  in the jockeys, but he also turned a keen eye on the spectators.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: This led to the At the Races in the Countryside.Degas never tires of the theme of the racecourse.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: On September 27, 1881, the newspaper "Le Globe" started publishing Major Muybridge's photographs of a galloping horse, and Degas used them for his sketches.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: The photographs showed that traditional English prints were inaccurate when depicting galloping horses with their front legs outstretched.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: This is how Degas painted the horses racing in the background of At the Races in the Countryside of 1869.Degas exhibited this moderately colourful work at the first Impressionist exhibition in 1874.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: The race itself is in the background, the foreground is occupied by a family scene centred on a baby, with the nurse, mother, father and even the dog atop the box.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: The family is the Valpinçon family: the driver of the carriage is Degas's friend Paul Valpinçon, who is shown with his wife, a wet nurse, and in the nurse's lap, the couple's son, Henri.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: The people in the carriage are caught in their fashionable elegance
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: At the Races in the Countryside

DESCRIPTION: Degas produced many portraits between 1865 and 1870, too, the major ones of which were Thérèse de Gas, Double Portrait, The Collector, Madame Hertel, Duke and Duchess of Morbilli, Jacques Joseph (James) Tissot, Mademoiselle Dihau at the Piano, Madame Camus at the Piano, Portrait of Hortense Valpinçon as a Child.Conventional as they may be, these portraits highlight both what is characteristic and what is casual in the personality and deportment of the sitter
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Portrait of Hortense Valpinçon as a Child

DESCRIPTION: The portrait of Estelle Musson, the artist's first cousin, was painted during Degas's 1872-1873 visit to New Orleans.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston

DESCRIPTION: Not long after marrying René de Gas, Estelle had gone blind.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston

DESCRIPTION: Degas shows her gaze by passing us, a vacant gaze bent upon vacancy.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston

DESCRIPTION: It is a discreet and simple portrait of one woman's solitude and isolation
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: Madame René de Gas, née Estelle Muston

DESCRIPTION: From 1870 Degas increasingly painted ballet subjects.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: First he painted a series of ballet rehearsal pictures.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier shows ten ballerinas being examined in the great hall.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: The white-clad Louis François Mérante, instructor at the opera house, is giving orders which the dancers have to follow.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: Those who are not busy exercising are watching the ballerina currently being examined with close attention.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: The work is organized around the polarity of group and single figure.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: The scene, remarkable for the rigour of its composition, has a distinctive energy centre in the vacant chair at the fore
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Foyer of the Opera at Rue Le Peletier

DESCRIPTION: From 1870 Degas increasingly painted ballet subjects.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Dance Class

DESCRIPTION: In these paintings he explored the subject's potential through variations on the theme.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Dance Class

DESCRIPTION: In The Dance Class he has grouped some twenty girls and one or two mothers too, watching or comforting their daughters.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Dance Class

DESCRIPTION: Dominating the scene (and painted in as an afterthought) is instructor Jules Perrot, with the huge stick he used to beat out a rhythm.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Dance Class

DESCRIPTION: This trial session under the famed teacher is taking place in the rehearsal rooms of the old opera house in Rue Peletier, which has long since burned down
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar
TITLE: The Dance Class

DESCRIPTION: Horse racing, a sport imported from England, was a novelty at that time.
AUTHOR: DEGAS, Edgar

DESCRIPTION: The first of Delacroix's paintings to achieve true notoriety, Dante and Virgil in Hell or The Barque of Dante, exemplifies a duality that pervaded his entire career.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: The shared influence of Michelangelo and Rubens is manifest here, but there is also a savour of the revolution so thunderously proclaimed by his friend and elder, Theodore Géricault, in his immortal painting, The Raft of the Medusa (1819).The Barque of Dante was submitted to the Salon in 1822, and makes clear acknowledgement of its debt to Géricault's The Raft of the Medusa.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: Indeed, the influence of that painting can be traced for many years afterwards in Delacroix's work, for example, in his Christ on the Lake of Gennesaret (1854) or The Shipwreck of Don Juan (1840).
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: The 'stage-setting' of The Barque of Dante looks forward to Baudelaire's pronouncement that Delacroix is an 'essentially literary' painter.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: But Delacroix had something much more important to leam from the Raft.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: In expressing the predicament of the shipwrecked everywhere in the world, Géricault had laid the foundations of an aesthetic revolution.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: The Raft of the Medusa marks the first appearance in painting of 'the ugly' and thereby proclaims its scrupulous respect for the truth, however repulsive the truth might be.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: This concern for truth is integral to the Romantic temperament.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Barque of Dante

DESCRIPTION: Delacroix's experience of English artists is reflected here, alongside the influence of Venetian painting and the works of Rubens.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: A Mortally Wounded Brigand Quenches his Thirst

DESCRIPTION: A critic remarked: "The colour of this piece is as beautiful as some landscape imagined by Byron as the setting for the bloodstained body of one of the tyrants of Missolonghi.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: A Mortally Wounded Brigand Quenches his Thirst

DESCRIPTION: Delacroix's grandest pictures have never left their country of origin.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Only in Paris can we fully appreciate the bold reconciliation of beauty with cruelty, sensuality with control, fantasy with observation, modernity with tradition that characterises the art of this influential painter.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: 'As Byron signifies Romantic poetry, so Romantic French art means above all Delacroix.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Like Byron he achieved his flamboyant artistic effects through intense intellectual application and a firm grasp of technique.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Pupil of an academic artist, he was essentially self-taught through the study of the great Renaissance and seventeenth-century colourists in the Louvre.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: He was fascinated by the vibrant brushwork of the Venetians and their Flemish heir Rubens, imitating their capacity to simulate brilliant daylight even in the shadows, their use of colour instead of line as the primary structural element.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: It was precisely these effects which, as employed by Constable in the Hay-Wain exhibited at the Paris Salon in 1824, caused a sensation and further exacerbated Delacroix's fashionable Anglomania.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: In 1825, having sold his picture of the Massacre of Chios to the French State, he set out for London with two English friends, the watercolourists Richard Bonington and Thales Fielding.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: They visited galleries and the theatre and read English poets.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Delacroix met other English artists, including Thomas Lawrence.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Appropriately for a painting in an English collection, the lifesize likeness of Louis-Auguste Schwiter, painted after Delacroix's return to Paris, is an essay in the portrait style of Lawrence.Schwiter, a lifelong friend of Delacroix, was himself a painter.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: He is presented here, however, as a gentleman, dressed in elegant black and hat in hand, standing on what appears to be the terrace of a great country house, as if waiting to be admitted.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: The blue Chinese vase with its heavily paint-textured flowers contrasts with the red lining of his hat.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Like the trumpet vine clippings on the paving, these touches of colour serve to relate the foreground to the brooding sunset landscape (said to have been painted in part by Paul Huet, another artist friend), thus counteracting the isolation of Schwiter's monochrome silhouette.The portrait is lit from the right, a reversal of the more usual illumination from the left, highlighting the left side of the sitter's face and perhaps helping to account for the curiously tentative impression he gives, despite his firm stance in the centre of the picture and his direct gaze.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: The unemphatic 'modern' pose, with its hint of English-style reserve, and the free 'unfinished' brushwork made this full-length portrait, at once so formal and so unconventional, unacceptable to the judges of the 1827 Paris Salon exhibition, and it was rejected.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: Delacroix later reworked the painting, finally completing it in 1830
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Louis-Auguste Schwiter

DESCRIPTION: The capture of Algiers in 1830 had given France the Sultan of Morocco as a neighbour.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: Louis Philippe's government decided to send him an ambassador extraordinary, the Comte de Mornay; the latter wished to take an official artist with him and chose Eugene Delacroix.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: The mission left Toulon on 11 January 1832, landed at Tangiers on the 25 January, travelled through a part of Morocco, and returned via Oran and Algiers.During his visit to this country, Delacroix witnessed spectacles belonging to a noble and primitive way of life which provided material for his art until he died; but he had not been allowed to enter the jealously guarded harems of the Moslems.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: It was the chief harbour engineer at Algiers who persuaded one of the port officials, a former reis or owner of privateers, to allow Delacroix into his own harem.In these few hours Delacroix did several watercolour sketches, some of which are in the Louvre.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: Using them as a basis, he painted a large picture on his return, and exhibited it in the 1834 salon.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: He wanted to show the dark tones of flesh and the subdued colours in the warm half-light of the harem.In 1849 he painted another smaller version of the same subject, now in the Musée de Montpellier.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: Here the colours are softer and the atmosphere more intimate; it has a note of nostalgia absent from the 1834 Salon picture, which is still full of his first impressions, and which already foreshadows Renoir.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: The latter artist was well aware of this relationship; in 1872 he painted a large picture inspired by Delacroix's canvas and called Les Parisiennes habillées en Algériennes (Tokyo Museum).
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: He had already done an Odalisque and exhibited it in the 1870 Salon.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: (Chester Dale Collection, New York.)
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Women of Algiers

DESCRIPTION: The Combat of the Giaour and the Pasha, which Delacroix repeated in various versions, illustrates the conflict in Byron's poem, in which the Christian Giaour, an outcast Venetian warrior, is about to slay the Turk Hassan to avenge his mistress, Leila, who had fled from the Turk's harem.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Combat of the Giaour and the Pasha

DESCRIPTION: On being recaptured, she was flung into the sea, her punishment for infidelity
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Combat of the Giaour and the Pasha

DESCRIPTION: The reign of Louis-Philippe saw a return to the great tradition of French religious painting.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne

AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne

AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Christ on the Cross (sketch)

DESCRIPTION: Delacroix's treatment of subjects from fashionable works frequently raised critical hackles, and he was assailed in the name of good taste, the Beautiful, and the Ideal.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Abduction of Rebecca

DESCRIPTION: A notable victim of such disparagement was the scene drawn from Scott's Ivanhoe.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Abduction of Rebecca

DESCRIPTION: The version of the The Abduction of Rebecca, now in the Louvre, was exhibited at the 1859 Salon, and shows Rebecca carried off by Sir Brian de Bois-Guilbert, while in the background flames engulf Torquilstone Castle
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: The Abduction of Rebecca

DESCRIPTION: Géricault had inspired in Delacroix his fascination with horses, the emblematic beasts of Romantic painting.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

DESCRIPTION: But his love of horses was fully satisfied only in Morocco.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

DESCRIPTION: Thereafter the Arab horses that he had seen and drawn during his voyage constituted a kind of repertoire.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

DESCRIPTION: For one of his last paintings, Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable, he drew on a scene that he had witnessed in Tangier, when the horses of Mornay and the English Consul were fighting.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

DESCRIPTION: No anatomical studies lie behind this painting.
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

DESCRIPTION: Once again, it is the violence of the combat that he portrays; the power and energy of the animals, an effect emphasised by the strong contrasts of light and shade
AUTHOR: DELACROIX, Eug?ne
TITLE: Arab Horses Fighting in a Stable

DESCRIPTION: Delaroche's early work consists mainly of subjects from the Old Testament, while later he chose subjects from French and English history.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

DESCRIPTION: He was one of the most popular painters of his time, his paintings satisfied the need for education through art and the demand for sensibility.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

DESCRIPTION: Both his carefully researched interiors and costumes and the theatrical content made his paintings so popular.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

DESCRIPTION: In The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England the cultivation of material actually distracts attention from the real subject.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

DESCRIPTION: But this was in keeping with contemporary taste for decorative history painting, which had gone to extremes in its meticulous attention to detail in the objects, furniture, and costumes.The painting was exhibited at the Salon of 1827/28
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Death of Elizabeth I, Queen of England

DESCRIPTION: Two once famous pictures by Delaroche in the Wallace Collection illustrate the contrasting last days of the two great French Cardinals, Mazarin eager for wealth, Richelieu thirsting for revenge
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The State Barge of Cardinal Richelieu on the Rhone

DESCRIPTION: Anglomania was in fashion in France in the 1820s and 1830s.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: Interest in British history, fuelled by the novels of Sir Walter Scott, was further stimulated by parallels drawn between recent events in France and the turbulent accounts of Tudors, Stuarts and the Civil War.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: The pictorial representation of British history may have been pioneered in Britain, but it was the Frenchman Paul Delaroche who gained a European reputation with the grand scenes drawn from it which he exhibited at the annual Paris Salon between 1825 and 1835.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: Popularised through mass-produced engravings, these set pieces, combining ostentatious antiquarianism with the pseudo-realism of bourgeois melodrama, in turn influenced the painters of national history in mid-Victorian Britain.The painting depicts the last moments on 12 February 1554 in the life of the seventeen-year old Jane Grey, a great granddaughter of Henry VII who was proclaimed Queen of England upon the death of young King Edward VI, a Protestant like herself.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: She reigned for nine days in 1553, but, through the machinations of the partisans of Henry VIII's Catholic daughter, Mary Tudor, she was convicted of high treason and sentenced to death in the Tower of London.Delaroche, who based the painting on a sixteenth-century Protestant martyrology, has falsified the historical account the better to appeal to his contemporaries.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: Lady Jane Grey, a humanist-educated young married woman, was in fact executed out of doors.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: Attended by two gentlewomen, probably no less stoical than she, she resolutely made her own way to the block.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: She could not have worn a white satin dress of nineteenth-century cut with a whalebone corset, and her hair would have been tucked up, not streaming down over her shoulders.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: But a painting cannot be judged by the criteria of historical accuracy.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: Much more applicable to this particular picture are the standards of popular melodrama and tableau vivant.As on a stage, the heroine gropes her way towards the audience, gently guided by the elderly Constable of the Tower whose massive, dark, male presence acts as a foil to her own.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: A spotlight trained on her from above complements the dim stage lighting, reflecting from her immaculate dress and the straw which spills over into the front row of the stalls.
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

DESCRIPTION: The emotions of each actor are carefully delineated and distinguished, and we are left in no doubt as to the character of each even of the lady in the background who turns her back on the terrible sight
AUTHOR: DELAROCHE, Paul
TITLE: The Execution of Lady Jane Grey

AUTHOR: DEVIS, Arthur
TITLE: Portrait of Lord Robert Kerr

DESCRIPTION: The present canvas is one of his earliest known signed and dated portraits

TITLE: Portrait of Lord Robert Kerr

DESCRIPTION: The aesthetically conservative principle of tables arranged strictly parallel to the horizontal edges of the painting was followed by Nicolaes Gillis and Floris Claesz van Dijck.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: (Predecessors were probably family paintings such as Marten van Heemskerck's.)
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: Their still-lifes are classified as 'ontbijtjes' (breakfast still-lifes).
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: Onbijt(je) was a light meal which could be taken at any time of the day.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: Strictly speaking, most of the paintings by Gillis and van Dijck are dessert still-lifes, developed at roughly the time by Osias Beert and Clara Peeters.All these artists show a table with a table runner and a carefully ironed, white damask tablecloth whose creases, regardless of the laws of perspective, run in parallel lines towards the back of the painting.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: A relatively high viewpoint was also chosen, apparently to afford a good overall survey of the objects, which are arranged side by side, or in a circle, hardly ever touching or overlapping.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: The precious drinking vessels and pieces of textile show very clearly that the arrangement is that of a privileged household.In accordance with etiquette, fruit, pies, nuts and confectionery were served as a dessert.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: Cheese, which had a central role in Gillis's and van Dijck's art, was also part of the dessert.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: Gillis and van Dijck build up pyramids of hard cheese in two or three layers: at the bottom there is half a large cheese with a rich, yellow hue, indicating that it is still very young, while on the top the cheeses are smaller and more brownish, almost grey in colour, showing that they are older and more mature.
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table

DESCRIPTION: The irregular traces of cuts with a knife - the only piece of cutlery on the table - are rendered extremely well
AUTHOR: DIJCK, Floris Claesz van
TITLE: Laid Table
