DESCRIPTION: He gazes upward at the Holy Spirit and above him God the Father.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: The Holy Family with God the Father and the Holy Spirit

DESCRIPTION: The combination of the figures, therefore, void of other extraneous saints, represents the "Celestial" and "Terrestrial" Trinities together.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: The Holy Family with God the Father and the Holy Spirit

DESCRIPTION: Dolci was a painter of intense religiosity.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: His work was much sought after internationally during his own lifetime and his reputation reached its apogee during the eighteenth century, particularly in England.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The meticulous finish, careful elaboration of detail and concentration of expression, especially in those compositions with single figures, are the hallmarks of a style that proved to be influential even in the late eighteenth century in the work, for example, of Jean-Baptiste Greuze.The biblical source for the painting is Matthew 14:6-11 or Mark 6:21-8, where the daughter of Herodias danced for her stepfather, Herod, on his birthday.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: As a reward he promised her anything she wanted and, prompted by her mother, she chose the head of Saint John the Baptist, which she then carried to Herodias on a silver charger.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The daughter subsequently became known in literature as Salome, and the theme was memorably treated in the nineteenth century by Richard Strauss and Oscar Wilde amongst others.Dolci painted several versions of Salome.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: According to Baldinucci, the original version was painted, probably during the 1660s, for the Marchese Rinuccini in Florence and it proved to be the artists most popular work, known through two other variants of good quality (Dresden, Staatliche Kunstsammlungen and Glasgow, City Museum and Art Gallery), which in turn spawned numerous copies.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: Of the three versions recorded by Baldinucci, the present painting is the second, which was acquired by Sir John Finch (1626—82) who gave it to Charles II.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: Finch was the English Resident at the court of the Grand Duke Ferdinand II in Florence from 1665 to 1670.You can view other depictions of Salome with the Head of John the Baptist.
AUTHOR: DOLCI, Carlo
TITLE: Salome with the Head of St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows a view from the Giudecca facing east with the church of the Chiesa delle Zitelle
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINI, Apollonio
TITLE: View from the Giudecca, Venice

DESCRIPTION: This view of Venice shows the Grand Canal with the church of San Geremia and the entrance to the Cannaregio
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINI, Apollonio
TITLE: View of the Grand Canal, Venice

DESCRIPTION: There was a famous competition between Domenichino and Guido Reni in the Oratorio di Sant'Andrea.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Flogging of St Andrew

DESCRIPTION: There Domenichino depicted the martyrdom of St Andrew, Reni the apostle proceeding to the execution site.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Flogging of St Andrew

DESCRIPTION: Domenichino's fresco earned Domenichino the praise of his master Annibale Carracci
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Flogging of St Andrew

DESCRIPTION: Vincenzo Giustiniani (1564-1637) was one of the most brilliant, and knowledgeable lovers of art in early seventeenth-century Rome.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Scenes of Diana

DESCRIPTION: He assembled a renowned collection of roughly 1.800 works of classical sculpture and 600 paintings, among them eleven of Caravaggio's most important works.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Scenes of Diana

DESCRIPTION: He purchased a villa at Bassano Romano in 1595 which was then thoroughly remodeled and enlarged.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Scenes of Diana

DESCRIPTION: The artists who painted there between 1595 and 1604 all worked in the Mannerist style.The north wing of the enlarged palace was erected in 1607-09 and the painted decoration was accomplished in 1609-10.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Scenes of Diana

DESCRIPTION: There are three rooms in the north wing, the Sala della Felicità Eterna (painted by Paolo Guidotti in 1610), the Sala di Diana (painted by Domenichino in 1609) and the Galleria (painted by Francesco Albani and assistants in 1609-10).In the Sala di Diana, Domenichino concentrated his pictures on the ceiling, fitting them into a geometrical system patterned after the Galleria Farnese.
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Scenes of Diana

DESCRIPTION: The pictures depict scenes of the moon goddess Diana
AUTHOR: DOMENICHINO
TITLE: Scenes of Diana

DESCRIPTION: This fresco is located in the 5th bay on the west wall of the Pellegrinaio in the Spedale di Santa Maria della Scala.
AUTHOR: DOMENICO DI BARTOLO
TITLE: Caring for the Sick

DESCRIPTION: The Pellegrinaio, situated on the ground floor of the hospital, is a fourteenth-century room which took the form of a long vaulted hall.In the four scenes on the west wall, painted by Domenico di Bartolo, we find large numbers of figures gathered in a stagelike foreground and engaged in the various good works assigned to the hospital by statute in 1305.
AUTHOR: DOMENICO DI BARTOLO
TITLE: Caring for the Sick

DESCRIPTION: The settings for these depictions of everyday work of the hospital may reproduce actual spaces within the complex.
AUTHOR: DOMENICO DI BARTOLO
TITLE: Caring for the Sick

DESCRIPTION: For all their realism, the scenes are highly idealised.In the Caring for the Sick Domenico combines specific portraiture with a sensitive treatment of the nude figure.
AUTHOR: DOMENICO DI BARTOLO
TITLE: Caring for the Sick

DESCRIPTION: The unidealized bodies of the sick man being placed in bed and the wounded man being washed rank among the most naturalistic figures in Quattrocento painting
AUTHOR: DOMENICO DI BARTOLO
TITLE: Caring for the Sick

DESCRIPTION: Doré is best known today for his book illustrations, but he himself was most committed to his work as a painter.
AUTHOR: DORÉ, Gustave
TITLE: Gorge

DESCRIPTION: In 1873-74 he visited Scotland, which inspired him to produce a number of landscapes, including this depiction of a steep gorge.
AUTHOR: DORÉ, Gustave
TITLE: Gorge

DESCRIPTION: This is a typical example of late Romanticism, a grandiose panoramic mountain landscape, its vast scale indicated by the tiny trees and animals on the slopes
AUTHOR: DORÉ, Gustave
TITLE: Gorge

DESCRIPTION: The altarpiece of St.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: George church in Sopron is one of those rare Baroque compositions which are not a simple devotional picture or a copy of one, but a so-called picture in picture.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: This type of composition, apart from intensifying the pictorial effect, always refers to some important aspects of the history of devotion of the central picture.In the middle of this altarpieces, in an elegant Louis XIV.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: style golden frame set out whit laurel festoons and bows of ribbons, is shown the image of the Virgin of Genazzano, at that time famous all over the world, with her special appellation written in a banderole: Maria von guten, Rath, Mother of Good Advice (Aurenhammer 1956.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: 110-111).The prototype of the Eleousa-type devotional picture was an Albanian Treccento fresco from the church of Skutari, delivered from the Turkish invaders in 1467 the Augustinian hermits in Genazzano near Roma.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: Its veneration spread by means of copies made for other churches of the order, and won popularity through the pious brotherhoods founded for its honour.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: The cult of the Mother of Good Advice - obviously because of its anti-Islamic aspects - was encouraged by Pope Innocent XI, so in the 17th and 18th centuries it flourished not only within the order but throughout the whole Catholic Church.In Hungary the altarpieces representing the Mother of Good Advice sometimes also show the angels who, according to the legend, flew with the devotional picture and brought it to its place.The representation of this scene may come from a copperplate of Sebestyén Zeller, an engraver in Pozsony.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: In Sopron, however, the substitution of this usual environment for an allegorical natural landscape transmits an entirely original, thus far unknown  meaning of the iconography of the picture.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: The tree struck by lightning and the shattered ancient idol with lire, in his hand had already lost much of their topicallity at the time as symbols for the enemies of the pervious centuries (pagans, Turks, the Reformation).
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: The literary products of the Enlightenment which spread even by way of leaflets, engendered a grave spiritual crisis, disrupting even the traditional unity of the clergy.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: The verse of psalm written in front of the flashing thunderbolts at the two sides of the picture: Verstummen müssen - falsche Lettzen, Ps.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: (Let the lying lips be put to silence, Psalm 31, 18) gives us a very perceptible rendering of the mood of the belivers confused in their traditional religiosity.
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: With the dark clouds in the background Dorffmaister presents us with a picturesque and inventive representation of the shock that befell the faith before omnipotence of reason, and makes us feel the atmosphere of the crisis caused in many contemporaries by awareness of helplessness.It is in this stormy, almost pre-Romantic landscape in this "mirror of the soul" that the gentle look of the Mother of Good Advice and that of the Child on her breast might have been an "apology" of orientation and inner satisfaction for everybody having recourse to her
AUTHOR: DORFFMEISTER, István
TITLE: The Mother of Good Advice

DESCRIPTION: The core element around which the rooms of the Zenobio palace are organized is the large double-story main hall (ballroom) complete with an orchestra balcony, and embellished with complex stucco work created by Abbondio Stazio sometime later than the frescoes.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: Decoration of the ballroom

DESCRIPTION: Twelve personifications of the Arts and Sciences, among them the nine Muses, sit on imaginary stools along the cornice that circles the walls of the room.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: Decoration of the ballroom

DESCRIPTION: The ceiling opens wide, exploding into an ornate projecting cornice that rests on large, bulging corbels.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: Decoration of the ballroom

DESCRIPTION: The large elliptical opening frames a view of the sky containing an allegorical depiction of Aurora.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: Decoration of the ballroom

DESCRIPTION: The entire ceiling is punctuated by displays of flowers and fruit.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: Decoration of the ballroom

DESCRIPTION: There are vases brimming with flowers in the corners of the room
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: Decoration of the ballroom

DESCRIPTION: The ceiling opens wide, exploding into an ornate projecting cornice that rests on large, bulging corbels.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: View of the ballroom ceiling

DESCRIPTION: The large elliptical opening frames a view of the sky containing an allegorical depiction of Aurora.
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: View of the ballroom ceiling

DESCRIPTION: The entire ceiling is punctuated by displays of flowers and fruit.The allegorical Aurora Preceding the Chariot of Apollo, represented in the ceiling oval, is the culmination of a vast iconographic program that once also adorned the other rooms of the palace (stripped of their decorations during the nineteenth century
AUTHOR: DORIGNY, Louis
TITLE: View of the ballroom ceiling

DESCRIPTION: Dossi executed this painting to Alfonso d'Este in Ferrara.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Jupiter, Mercury and the Virtue

DESCRIPTION: The picture represents Jupiter painting butterflies while Mercury refuses the Virtue asking for an audience.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Jupiter, Mercury and the Virtue

DESCRIPTION: The official painter of the Este court, Dossi painted the family portraits, filled castles with paintings and frescoed villas.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: This routine, which for other painters might have seemed mortifying, did nothing to extinguish the vivacious and brilliant vein of the artist.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: Dossi is always consistent.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: He flushes the flesh tones of his characters with orangy, reddish colours, he places them in risqué situations, with bare-chested women in convivial surroundings and almost obscene merrymaking men with such highly characterized faces that they are almost caricatures.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: The faces of the women and that of the faun are drawn directly from a cultured classical tradition which is inserted into the Mannerist context.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: The other characters, emerging from a humid, obscure background, are anything but stereotypes: healthy faces reddened by feasting, grimaces, a variety of attitudes.
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: The only note of light - quite unreal - which stands out from the prevalently ruddy tones, falls directly onto the breasts of the woman holding a bowl of fruit
AUTHOR: DOSSI, Dosso
TITLE: Witchcraft (Allegory of Hercules)

DESCRIPTION: Originally, this panel formed the shutters of the box protecting the Dropsical Woman
AUTHOR: DOU, Gerrit
TITLE: The Silver Ewer

DESCRIPTION: This painting belongs to a group of night scenes painted in the 1650s and 1660s by Dou.
AUTHOR: DOU, Gerrit
TITLE: An Evening School

DESCRIPTION: Here the candlelight allows the artist to demonstrate his skill in handling highlights and shadows, and to contrast the features of the old man and the young girl
AUTHOR: DOU, Gerrit
TITLE: An Evening School

DESCRIPTION: This panel depicts a young girl at a window ledge with a cat and a mouse-trap, a hung duck and a pewter ewer beside her.Dou's genre paintings are often imbued with subtle emblematic meanings which would certainly not have been lost on his public.
AUTHOR: DOU, Gerrit
TITLE: Young Girl at a Window Ledge

DESCRIPTION: In 17th-century paintings, and in particular in Dou's own work, certain everyday objects took on other meanings and were therefore chosen by the artist for a specific reason: a set of scales, for example, could allude to the virtues of moderation and temperance; an empty bird-cage was a conventional symbol of immorality; and the open mouse-trap and lascivious expression of the cat in this painting could equally have carried some erotic overtones
AUTHOR: DOU, Gerrit
TITLE: Young Girl at a Window Ledge

DESCRIPTION: Dou popularized the the compositional device of a figure engaged at some occupation at a window
AUTHOR: DOU, Gerrit
TITLE: Young Woman at the Window with a Bunch of Grapes

DESCRIPTION: Although Drouais made his career primarily as a society portrait painter in the tradition of Largillière and Nattier, his portraits 'déguisés' were very different from theirs.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: The Children of the Duc de Bouillon

DESCRIPTION: Instead of court ladies depicted in the guise of antique goddesses, Drouais chose to depict his ladies and gentlemen (and especially their children) in pastoral guises (say, of shepherds and shepherdesses) or as members of different, perhaps less fortunate classes such as harvest workers or Savoyards.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: The Children of the Duc de Bouillon

DESCRIPTION: The present portrait depicts the two sons of the Duc de Bouillon dressed as Montagnards.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: The Children of the Duc de Bouillon

DESCRIPTION: One holds a marmot with a ribbon and the other plays a hurdy-gurdy, both activities associated exclusively with the people of the mountains especially in Savoy and in North Italy.The painting is signed lower centre: Drouais le fils 1756
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: The Children of the Duc de Bouillon

DESCRIPTION: Jeanne Bécu, comtesse du Barry (1743-1793), was the mistress of Louis XV.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: She was the natural daughter of a poor woman of Vaucouleurs.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Placed in a convent in Paris at an early age, she received a very slight education, learning little but the catechism and drawing; and at the age of sixteen entered a milliner's shop in the rue St Honoré.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Subsequently she lived as a courtesan under the name of Mlle Lange.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Her great personal charms led the adventurer Jean, comte du Barry, to take her into his house in order to make it more attractive to the dupes whose money he won by gambling.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Her success surpassing his expectations, his hopes took a higher flight, and through Lebel, valet de chambre of Louis XV, and the duc de Richelieu, he succeeded in installing her as mistress of the king.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: In order to present her at court it was necessary to find a title for her, and as Count Jean du Barry was married, his brother Guillaume offered himself as nominal husband.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: The comtesse du Barry was presented at court on the 22nd of April 1769, and became official mistress of the king.Her influence over the monarch was absolute until his death in 1774 when an order of his successor banished her to the abbey of Pont-aux-Dames, near Meaux, but, the queen interceding for her, the king in the following year gave her permission to reside at Luciennes with a pension.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Here she led a retired life with the comte de Cosse-Brissac, and was visited there by Benjamin Franklin and the emperor Joseph II, among many other distinguished men.Having gone to England in 1792 to endeavour to raise money on her jewels, she was on her return accused before the Revolutionary Tribunal of having dissipated the treasures of the state, conspired against the republic, and worn, in London, "mourning for the tyrant."
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: She was condemned to death by guillotine on the 8th of December 1793, and beheaded the same evening.By the time the comtesse du Barry had arrived at Versailles, Drouais had completed posthumously the last portrait of Madame de Pompadour, a sumptuous affair that surely qualifies as his masterpiece.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: It was fitting that the new royal paramour would choose as her official portraitist an artist who could immortalize her predecessor with such refinement and elegance.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: She commissioned him to paint for both the château and the pavilion of Luciennes a series of delightful pictures.
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: During the comtesse du Barry's years at court, Drouais created five distinct portraits of her, as well as additional copies of the five images
AUTHOR: DROUAIS, François-Hubert
TITLE: Jeanne Bécu, Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: In Greek mythology, Hyanthe and Clymene are the two daughters of a king of Crete who rescued Francus, the Trojan ancestor of the Franks, when he was shipwrecked.
AUTHOR: DUBREUIL, Toussaint
TITLE: Hyanthe and Clymene Offering a Sacrifice to Venus

DESCRIPTION: Dubreuil's painting belonged to a group of about sixty paintings that Henri IV commissioned between 1594 and 1602 for the Château Neuf of Saint-Germain-en-Laye
AUTHOR: DUBREUIL, Toussaint
TITLE: Hyanthe and Clymene Offering a Sacrifice to Venus

DESCRIPTION: This scene is on one of the front crowning panels of the Maestà.In the burial scene the background of deeply indented rocks with small leafy trees evokes the valley of Jehoshaphat where the burial took place.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Burial of the Virgin (panel 8)

DESCRIPTION: The disciples, grouped quietly round the tomb in attitudes of tender affection, show their heartfelt participation in the sad event, particularly the person on the left who is lifting his hand to his mouth in grief.The composition is strongly reminiscent of the scene depicting Christ's entombment
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Burial of the Virgin (panel 8)

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows one of the 26 narrative scenes from the Stories of the Passion on the reverse side of the Maestà.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Way to Calvary (scene 19)

DESCRIPTION: It is situated in the upper row on the left side above the scene of Pilate Washing his Hands.The scene on the Way to Calvary, as Duccio represents it, has the specific purpose of acting as an intermediary between past and future events.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Way to Calvary (scene 19)

DESCRIPTION: On the one hand, the slender, erect figure of Christ, with his hands still tied, refers the onlooker to the various stages of the trial.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Way to Calvary (scene 19)

DESCRIPTION: On the other hand, the direction in which all the characters are moving (to the right, towards the panel with the Crucifixion) and the cross borne by Simon of Cyrene, allude to the terrible conclusion
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Way to Calvary (scene 19)

DESCRIPTION: Painted with the 'Master of the Badia at Isola'.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Madonna and Child (no. 593)

DESCRIPTION: With regard to this anonymous master it is worth recording that in all probability he was at the beginning in such close relations with Duccio as to lend credibility to the opinion that Duccio's hand can be detected in some of his early works.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Madonna and Child (no. 593)

DESCRIPTION: As an example can be cited the very beautiful Madonna no.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Madonna and Child (no. 593)

DESCRIPTION: 593 in the Pinacoteca of Siena whose face is really so close to Duccio's Crevole Madonna that it could easily be attributed to him and dated to that period
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Madonna and Child (no. 593)

DESCRIPTION: The painting is a portable triptych of a type that was fairly widely produced in Italy during the early fourteenth century, essentially for private worship.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: For the purposes of travel the wings would have closed inwards covering the centre panels and lying flush with the raised spandrel above the inner moulding.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The backs of the wings were most probably painted with imitation marble or porphyry, perhaps with decorative motifs, as opposed to narrative scenes.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The creation of a work of art of this kind was due to a combination of craftsmanship and painterly skills.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: Some of the finest surviving examples are Florentine or Sienese in origin.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The triptych in the Royal Collection is comparable with examples in the National Gallery in London, the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, the Pinacoteca in Siena, and the Fogg Art Museum in Cambridge, Massachusetts, all of which, according to varying degrees of attribution, are associated with Duccio or his workshop.The exact attribution of the present triptych is unsettled owing to the multiplicity of hands at work not only in Duccio's workshop as a whole, but even on the surface of individual paintings.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The centre panel in particular is of a quality worthy of Duccio himself.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The same might almost be said of the lower scenes in each of the wings, certainly in their design even if the actual execution reveals evidence of assistants (for example, the gold decoration on the cloth of honour behind Christ and the Virgin Enthroned, lower right).
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The inconsistencies apparent in the architecture of Annunciation (top left) or the design of the two thrones are not unknown in Duccio's own work, as revealed in the Maestà of 1308-11 (Siena, Museo dell'Opera del Duomo) with which this triptych is comparable in date or possibly slightly earlier.The iconography of the panels is also significant.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: Paradoxically, the inner religious consistency is derived from the unusual combination of scenes, especially the pairing of enthroned figures in the lower sections of the wings.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The enthronement of the Virgin twice (lower left and lower right), for instance, suggests a temporal sequence before and after Christ's death as represented in the centre.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The Annunciation (top left) is comparable with the relevant scene (now in the National Gallery, London) from the Maestà, whereas both Saint Francis receiving the Stigmata (top right) and Christ and the Virgin Enthroned (lower right) recall frescoes in the Upper Church of St Francis, Assisi (the former in the nave from the Life of Saint Francis and the latter, earlier in date and by Cimabue, in the transept).
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: These connotations and the treatment of the crucifixion in a devotional, as opposed to a narrative sense, imply a Franciscan origin for this triptych.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The quantity of blood depicted in the central scene (some of it removed in an earlier restoration) is an unusual feature in a work on this scale.Probably before it became part of the Royal Collection the triptych had been dismantled and put in a heavy gothic frame, which was removed when it was cleaned in 1930.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Panel, 44,9 x 31,4 cm (centre); 44,8 x 16,9 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: After this the triptych was displayed in a shadow box with a simpler frame.
AUTHOR: DUCCIO di Buoninsegna
TITLE: Triptych

DESCRIPTION: During the second quarter of the 17th century a group of artists began to specialize in painting the life of soldiers.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: Scenes of plunder and battle were depicted but the ancient battle of sexes, where the field of action was a room in an inn or a barrack, and in which the outcome of the struggle is not much in doubt, was more frequently represented.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: Other popular subjects were soldiers drinking, smoking and gambling at cards or tric-trac, activities that contemporary predicants and moralists condemned as vices that endanger salvation.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: But it is doubtful if the painters of these scenes and their clients viewed them as pictorial reminders of the perils of sin and the inexorable need to lead a virtuous life.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: Pictures of the life of off-duty soldiers were called by the Dutch 'cortegaardjes' a corruption of the French term 'corps de garde'.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: The better ones show little movement or overt action.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: Painters of them had a special feeling for tonal values and their pictures take on a certain still-life quality.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: In their half-dark interiors the light glitters over uniforms, and a fine subdued play of colours, mostly broken and harmonized by delicate half-tones, betrays the Dutch gift for intimate pictorial qualities and a subtle rendering of textures.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: Some even anticipate the achievement of the high society painters of the following generation, when well-to-do burghers rather than soldiers and their friends became the favoured subject of genre painters.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: Specialists in this category worked in Amsterdam, Utrecht, Delft, but seldom in Haarlem.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: The leading ones in Amsterdam were Willem Duyster and Pieter Codde.What sets Duyster's rare pictures apart from those made by his contemporaries is his distinct chiaroscuro and the refinement of his colours.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: He was also better able than any of them to convey the fascinating visual drama which can take place  when people do little more than confront each other.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.
TITLE: Soldiers beside a Fireplace

DESCRIPTION: It is difficult to think of a painter of his time who surpasses his penetrating characterization of the personalities of the men gathered round a fireplace in the modest nocturnal scene in the Soldiers beside a Fireplace in the Philadelphia museum.
AUTHOR: DUYSTER, Willem Cornelisz.

DESCRIPTION: (Versions are also in the Hermitage, and in Düsseldorf.)

DESCRIPTION: The careful, fastidious representation of these meaningful details creates a powerful foundation for the setting of the head: vigorous, strong features, the pronounced nose and the strong-willed mouth, the furrowed eyebrows, as if from a sudden start or fright that makes him direct his gaze off to the side behind him.

AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Portrait of Oswolt Krel
TECHNIQUE: Oil on panel, 50 x 39 cm (central), 50 x 16 cm (each side panel)

DESCRIPTION: To the energetic expression of the face corresponds the nervous look of his left hand clutching his cloak and that of the contraction of the knotted fingers of the right hand that leans on an invisible window sill.Colour, form, and proportion heighten the expression of supreme resolution, an expression that is the result of a serious psychological study that Dürer conducted on the merchant, who was the same age as the artist and who was later to become the mayor of Lindau, his native city.The two side panels that represent two "sylvan men" are wings to the portrait.

DESCRIPTION: At the same time as the Feast of the Rose Garlands, Dürer was working on the painting of Christ among the Doctors.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: The theme derives from the Gospel of St Luke (Luke 2, 41-52).On the bookmark at the bottom left of the panel, Dürer has recorded that this picture was `the work of five days', a pointed reference to his inscription on The Altarpiece of the Rose Garlands, the work of five months.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Christ among the Doctors is not only a smaller panel, but the brushwork is much more spontaneous and the paint is applied with broad and fluid strokes.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Despite Dürer's statement about five days, he based it on a number of careful studies, including one of Christ's gesticulating fingers.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Although not present on the original painting, two early copies of the panel have the word `Romae' added to the inscription on the bookmark and this suggests that Dürer visited Rome late in 1506.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: It may also be significant that the original painting was in Rome's Galleria Barberini until its acquisition by Baron Heinrich von Thyssen-Bornemisza in 1935.The story recorded in the panel is of Christ's visit to Solomon's Temple in Jerusalem, where he debated with the learned Jewish doctors (or scribes).
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: According to the Bible, this was the first occasion on which Christ taught.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Dürer's daring composition does not use the conventional temple setting which he earlier used in the lower left panel of The Seven Sorrows of the Virgin.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht

DESCRIPTION: Instead he gives a close-up view of the faces of six doctors crowding round the young Jesus.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: The elderly doctors, caricatured faces which may well have been influenced by Leonardo da Vinci, argue with Christ by quoting from the Scriptures and gesticulating.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Christ, a sober boy of 12, quietly gestures with his fingers to make a point.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Dürer contrasts Christ's youthful hands with the gnarled fingers of the ugly old man with the white cap and a gap-toothed grin
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: Christ Among the Doctors

DESCRIPTION: Dürer's monogram and the date are visible in the upper part of the two canvases, which are part of a series of twelve heads of apostles which the artist planned, though never completed.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: The Apostles Philip and James
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas, 45 x 38 and 46 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: The two heads are constructed with an incisive and meticulous line, a reflection of Dürer's troubled search for moral austerity.
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: The Apostles Philip and James
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas, 45 x 38 and 46 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: We may recall that this was a particularly delicate time in German history, shortly before the emergence of Martin Luther and the Reformation.The two saints inspire a diffuse sense of solemn veneration, in the passionate, severe eyes, the embittered curve of the mouths, and the overabundant beards, depicted as heavy, noble masses of coiling hair
AUTHOR: DÜRER, Albrecht
TITLE: The Apostles Philip and James
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas, 45 x 38 and 46 x 37 cm

DESCRIPTION: During his extended stay in Italy from 1621 to 1627, spending the majority of his time in Genoa, Van Dyck made his mark as a portraitist, and numbered many important families from the upper strata of Genoese society among his clients.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of a Man in Armour with Red Scarf

AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of a Man in Armour with Red Scarf

DESCRIPTION: It is also possible that the painting is not a portrait but an allegory
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of a Man in Armour with Red Scarf

DESCRIPTION: Cardinal Guido Bentivoglio (1579-1644), an Italian cardinal, statesman and historian, commissioned this portrait of himself.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Cardinal Guido Bentivoglio

DESCRIPTION: As papal nuncio, he had work for peace between the Catholics and the Protestants in Flanders, and the Catholics and the French Protestants (the Huguenots) in France.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Cardinal Guido Bentivoglio

DESCRIPTION: Van Dyck, refining the robust style of his master, Rubens, specialized in long, sensitive fingers and the lush treatment of fabrics - note the sitter's moiré robe
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Cardinal Guido Bentivoglio

DESCRIPTION: This likeness of the king on horseback takes as its point of departure the archetypal image on the obverse of all the Great Seals of England: the sovereign as warrior.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: King Charles is wearing Greenwich-made armour and holding a commander's baton.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: A page carries his helmet.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: In keeping with the imperial claim of the inscription (in Latin on the tablet tied to the tree in this portrait: CAROLUS REX MAGNAE BRITANIAE - Charles King of Great Britain), the pose and woodland setting echo Titian's equestrian portrait of the Emperor Charles V at Muhlberg.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: (Titian's painting itself recalled the famous Roman bronze of the Emperor Marcus Aurelius on horseback.)
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: Over his armour Charles wears a gold locket bearing the image of Saint George and the Dragon, the so-called Lesser George.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: He wore it constantly; it contained a portrait of his wife, and was with him the day he died.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: Here, however, it identifies him with the Order of the Garter of which Saint George was patron.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: As Garter Sovereign he is riding, like Charles V, at the head of his chivalrous knights in defence of the faith.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: In a profound sense the portrait is a visual assertion of Charles's claim to Divine Kingship.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: Albeit high above our heads - the horizon line ensures that our viewpoint is roughly at the level of his stirrup - his face is undistorted by foreshortening.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: Van Dyck's three-quarter view refines his features, and he bestrides his horse with a remote air of noble contemplation
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Charles I on Horseback

DESCRIPTION: The sitter of this portrait is the young Prince Charles Louis (1617-1680), the nephew of King Charles I. The excellent portrait was painted directly from the life in London a few months before the death of van Dyck
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Prince Charles Louis, Elector Palatine

DESCRIPTION: The Genoese noblewoman is shown on the terrace of her palace.

AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Marchesa Elena Grimaldi Cattaneo

DESCRIPTION: The Genoese nobility, wealthy from the trade of its powerful merchant marine, had many ties with members of the Spanish court and adopted many customs from them, including the sumptuous but sober fabrics of courtly dress.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Marchesa Elena Grimaldi Cattaneo

DESCRIPTION: Van Dyck, in these portraits of his Genoese period, has immortalized the dignity and splendid scale of living of his patrons
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Marchesa Elena Grimaldi Cattaneo

AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Margaret of Lorraine, Duchess of Orléans

DESCRIPTION: Rubens, Van Dyck and Jordaens, often named in the same breath, are the most prominent artists of the Flemish Baroque.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: The trio dominated artistic life in the Southern Netherlands throughout the 17th century.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: All three made an enormous contribution to the fame of the city of Antwerp, but it is Rubens who bears the greatest authority, because he was the most versatile and talented.The youngest of the three great masters was Anthony van Dyck.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: He worked with Rubens for a time in his youth, after which he spent most of his career in England and Italy.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: He was even more admired in England than in his own country, and he had a significant influence upon English painting.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: Van Dyck's oeuvre, less varied than that of Rubens, consists mainly of brilliant portraits.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: His sensitive personality and restless temperament were brought to bear in penetrating psychological studies of members of leading families, the nobility and royalty.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

DESCRIPTION: His sober Portrait of Marten Pepijn shows the artist as an energetic man of fifty-eight years, depicted in a black jerkin with a refined pleated collar.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist Marten Pepijn

AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Self-Portrait at the Age of Sixteen

DESCRIPTION: During his trip to Italy and in particular when he was living in Genoa, Anthony van Dyck painted many portraits of members of patrician families.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: These were strongly influenced by those that Peter Paul Rubens had produced for the same families almost two decades earlier.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: From these Van Dyck borrowed the structures and the chromatic oppositions between the dark, court clothing and the bright ruffs, embroideries and jewels.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: The painting in the Brussels museum is a good example of this type of official representation.Porzia Imperiale and her daughter Maria Francesca belonged to a family of Genoese bankers.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: On 5 August 1610 the mother married Bartolomeo Imperiale, probably a distant cousin.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: Born in around 1586, she must have been between 35 and 40 when Anthony van Dyck stayed in Genoa.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: Maria Francesca's date of birth is not known, but the inscription Virtute gaudet (she rejoices in virtue) on the virginal, exalting the young girl's honour, shows that she was of marriageable age.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: Women occupied a special place in the Republic of Genoa.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: It is therefore not surprising to see them associated with Virtue, a quality with heroic connotations that is more generally ascribed to men.Porzia Imperiale, seated here, is dressed in a black gown, its severity softened by an imposing ruff, a double chain, engraved buttons and lace-edged cuffs.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: In her left hand she carries a closed fan, whilst her right hand rests on the arm of the chair.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: Her daughter wears a light-coloured gown with silvery reflections, decorated with gilded braid and a ruff, its moiré reflections very finely balancing the dark mass of her mother's gown.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: Porzia Imperiale's determined face contrasts with Maria Francesca's gentle and innocent looks.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: The background architectural details and the heavy red drapery confer a monumental aspect to the painting, further accentuated by the way in which the figures literally dominate the spectator, who views them from a low-angle position.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: The subtlety with which Van Dyck renders the different dark nuances is proof of an uncommon skill
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Portrait of Porzia Imperiale and Her Daughter

DESCRIPTION: Early in 1639 the two Stuart brothers, cousins of King Charles I and younger sons of the third Duke of Lennox, set off on a three-year tour of the Continent.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: They must have posed for Van Dyck just before their departure.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: Since his arrival at the court, the artist had developed a new portrait type: the double portrait recording friendship, often, but not necessarily, between relatives.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: The two brothers are shown as if poised on the point of departure, waiting perhaps for servants to bring up their carriage.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: Both were to die a few years later in the Civil War, and hindsight gives the image an added valedictory poignancy.Van Dyck's compositional skill is surpassed only by his matchless ability to depict satin, lace and meltingly-soft kid leather.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: But these carefully described effects are somehow not local: the whole surface of the canvas is brought alive with a flickering touch.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: The costumes, so fashionably similar, are beautifully contrasted - receding warm gold and brown on Lord John, cooler and advancing silver and blue on Lord Bernard - so that the two brothers, complementing each other in apparel, seem to form one shimmering, indivisible whole
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Lord John and Lord Bernard Stuart

DESCRIPTION: St Ambrose, the fearsome fourth-century Archbishop of Milan, is said to have refused Theodosius entry into the cathedral because of the emperor's vengeful massacre of the inhabitants of Thessalonica.

DESCRIPTION: Theodosius impetuously thrusts his face upwards towards the saint.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Emperor Theodosius Forbidden by St Ambrose To Enter Milan Cathedral

DESCRIPTION: Ambrose's sturdy vigour has been transferred to the crozier as if the priest who holds it for the saint were ready to bring it crashing down on the emperor.This painting is a free copy by Van Dyck of a large painting now in Vienna executed in Rubens's studio.
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Emperor Theodosius Forbidden by St Ambrose To Enter Milan Cathedral

DESCRIPTION: The finely drawn profile to the right of St Ambrose has been identified as a portrait of Nicolaas Rockocx, the friend for whom Rubens painted Samson and Delilah
AUTHOR: DYCK, Sir Anthony van
TITLE: Emperor Theodosius Forbidden by St Ambrose To Enter Milan Cathedral

DESCRIPTION: The cross as the focal point of the "gloria del paradiso" is revered by the saints and the elect of the heavenly realm who surround the cross on banks of clouds.

AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam

AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam

DESCRIPTION: In the foreground, there is a disputation between St Sebastian and Pope Gregory, St Jerome, St Ambrose and St Augustine, with the first Christian martyrs St Stephen and St Laurence.
AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam
TITLE: Glorification of the Cross

DESCRIPTION: The cross, clutched by a kneeling female figure who is probably an embodiment of Faith, is surrounded by angels bearing the instruments of the Passion, above which we can make out the Evangelists and Apostles.
AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam
TITLE: Glorification of the Cross

DESCRIPTION: At the head of a procession of angels streaming into the dazzling light of the background, which is flooded with an overwhelming brightness, we can see the Coronation of the Virgin.Elsheimer's unique art is evident in the astonishing illusion of remarkable breadth and depth achieved by this small panel painting.
AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam
TITLE: Glorification of the Cross

DESCRIPTION: Here, space is no longer simply a problem of continuously reduced scale, but also one of simultaneous graduation of colour and the distribution of light and darkness.
AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam
TITLE: Glorification of the Cross

DESCRIPTION: This creates interlocking areas of colour and light which, though perceived by the eye, nevertheless take on the quality of a vision.
AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam
TITLE: Glorification of the Cross

DESCRIPTION: This painting, originally part of a triptych, is widely regarded as Elsheimer's greatest masterpiece
AUTHOR: ELSHEIMER, Adam

DESCRIPTION: 's work in 1904, and shortly afterwards the Rijksmuseum was able to acquire a second, less well-preserved panel from the same altarpiece: Christ in the House of Martha and Mary.The events depicted in the two panels are not found in the Bible but in the popular late-medieval Meditationes vitae Christi.

DESCRIPTION: Both scenes precede the Arrest of Christ.

DESCRIPTION: In the conversation with his mother and Mary Magdalen, Christ refused to abandon his planned visit to Jerusalem during the Jewish Passover, and foretold his impending death.The second panel shows Christ taking leave of his mother, immediately before he and his disciples set off for Jerusalem.
AUTHOR: ENGEBRECHTSZ., Cornelis
TITLE: Christ Taking Leave of his Mother

DESCRIPTION: Movingly he embraces the kneeling Virgin amidst the sorrowful Marys and the apostles.
AUTHOR: ENGEBRECHTSZ., Cornelis
TITLE: Christ Taking Leave of his Mother

DESCRIPTION: Some of the disciples are descending into the valley on the right, with the city gate and walls of Jerusalem in the distance.The attribution of the panels to Engelbrechtsz., based partly on the correspondences in style, colouring and manner of execution with the Crucifixion triptych in Leiden, was recently confirmed by an examination of the two underdrawings using infrared reflectography.
AUTHOR: ENGEBRECHTSZ., Cornelis
TITLE: Christ Taking Leave of his Mother

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a fine example of the artist's more mature work.
AUTHOR: ENGEBRECHTSZ., Cornelis

DESCRIPTION: The poses and gestures in the figure group highlight the emotional nature of the leave-taking.
AUTHOR: ENGEBRECHTSZ., Cornelis
TITLE: Christ Taking Leave of his Mother

DESCRIPTION: The landscape and city in the background are painted in a surprisingly lively way.
AUTHOR: ENGEBRECHTSZ., Cornelis

DESCRIPTION: The steely, blue-white shapes of the mountains and rock formations contrast with the warm, bright colouring of the figures in the foreground.

DESCRIPTION: The attention paid to ornamental details, which was relatively slight by the standards of the day, and the broad manner of painting, which fades to the sketchy in the background, are typical of the work of Engelbrechtsz.

AUTHOR: ERIKSEN, Vigilius
TITLE: Portrait of Catherine II before a Mirror
