DESCRIPTION: The Cross in the Mountains (The Tetschen Altar) brought Friedrich to the attention of a wider public.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: Probably at no other point in his life did Friedrich enjoy more profound appreciation and greater admiration than in the years around 1810.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: Two landscapes in particular were responsible for thrusting Friedrich into the limelight.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: In 1810 they were exhibited as pendants at the Academy exhibition in Berlin, where they were purchased by the Prussian king Frederick William III.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: These two paintings were The Monk by the Sea and the Abbey in the Oakwood.The Abbey in the Oakwood is an expression of grief at the loss of a great past.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: The artist has chosen to depict an architectural ruin; it may testify to the sublimity of the past, but it is a monument in a graveyard.The Napoleonic invasion of Germany and the consequent War of Liberation had added a patriotic dimension to Friedrich's subjects of north German ecclesiastical buildings in ruins or, in imagination, raised again.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: While the essential message of the Abbey in the Oak-wood of 1810 is the passing of the earthly life, its fog-bound ruin and blasted, leafless trees inevitably evoked the contemporary state of Germany.The painting was exhibited with its companion picture, the Monk by the Sea.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: This suggests the hope of resurrection in its bright sky, in contrast to the dark clouds that loom above the figure on his Baltic shore
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Abbey in the Oakwood

DESCRIPTION: Friedrich's people are often portrayed in a rapt contemplation of the mysteries of their own passion as reflected by water's moon-struck rise and fall, extended by the passage of time and tide.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Two Men by the Sea

DESCRIPTION: His seascapes combine intimacy and grandeur in unprecedented fashion.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Two Men by the Sea

DESCRIPTION: In the surreal Two Men by the Sea, each viewer is the other's clone
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Two Men by the Sea

DESCRIPTION: This view probably combines elements of Bohemia's low-lying mountains with quotations from the coastal landscape of the island of Rügen.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: View of the Baltic

DESCRIPTION: Friedrich's native town becomes a symbol of longing for a better world.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Meadows near Greifswald

DESCRIPTION: The prancing horses, the geese and the pond reflecting the sky reinforce the sense of idyll
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Meadows near Greifswald

DESCRIPTION: A symbolic and heavy sadness lies over the Graveyard under Snow.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Graveyard under Snow

DESCRIPTION: We are now looking from inside the cemetery across the grave to the open gate, which is surrounded by a latticework of bare branches.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Graveyard under Snow

DESCRIPTION: The stormy sky is dead and empty.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Graveyard under Snow

DESCRIPTION: The open grave in the foreground has prompted much speculation.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Graveyard under Snow

DESCRIPTION: Some have suggested that it is intended as the future resting-place of the artist
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: Graveyard under Snow

DESCRIPTION: This painting, depicting an area of pastureland crossed by tree-lined avenues just outside Dresden, portrayed in masterly fashion from an alienating angle, is an example of Friedrich's final phase of full mastery.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Grosse Gehege near Dresden

DESCRIPTION: He uses an exquisite palette to evoke a particularly solemn evening mood and thereby lends a rhythmic impulse to the foreground with rivulets of water glinting in the sunset.
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Grosse Gehege near Dresden

DESCRIPTION: With the richness of its palette, the beauty of its composition and its sonorous atmosphere, this impressive painting is a true masterpiece in the history of European landscape painting
AUTHOR: FRIEDRICH, Caspar David
TITLE: The Grosse Gehege near Dresden

DESCRIPTION: This work of Froment's maturity, which is indeed an epitome of his whole oeuvre, was commissioned by King René of Provence.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: This central panel of the triptych represents Moses before the Burning Bush; the figures kneeling in prayer on the wing are the donor and his wife, Jeanne de Laval, accompanied by saints (not reproduced here).
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: In this work the painter has abandoned the occasional crudities of The Raising of Lazarus; only in the countenance of Moses are there reminiscences of the more rigid portraiture of the earlier altarpiece.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: Moses is struck with astonishment at the vision before him and the appearance of the angel.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: The vision occupies the upper centre of the picture: amidst a great circle of flaming rose bushes the Madonna appears in a richly draped mantle, holding the Child.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: Christ holds a mirror in his hand, in which both of them are reflected.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: The picture contains a number of emblematical representations.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: The combination of a number of unusual elements side by side is characteristic of mediaeval symbolism.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: It is evidence of the extraordinary cult of the Virgin in the Middle Ages that it is she who appears before Moses, and not God, as in the Old Testament
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: The Burning Bush

DESCRIPTION: This is the only other authentic work of Froment beside The Burning Bush.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 175 x 134 cm (central), 175 x 66 cm (each side wing)

DESCRIPTION: The central panel depicts The Raising of Lazarus, the other scenes on the side panels are Magdalen Anoints the Feet of Christ (right wing), Martha at the Feet of Christ (left wing), The Donors (outer face of right wing), The Madonna and Child (outer face of left wing).The tradition that the triptych was painted for Cosimo il Vecchio is rendered improbable by the fact that the donor is in clerical dress.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 175 x 134 cm (central), 175 x 66 cm (each side wing)

DESCRIPTION: The painting of the exterior faces, which bears the signature, is of a quality superior to that of the interior ones.
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 175 x 134 cm (central), 175 x 66 cm (each side wing)

DESCRIPTION: It is assumed that the man looking out of the picture at the upper left corner of the central panel is a self-portrait
AUTHOR: FROMENT, Nicolas
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, 175 x 134 cm (central), 175 x 66 cm (each side wing)

DESCRIPTION: Fuseli was the second son of the Zurich portraitist and author Johann Caspar Fussli.
AUTHOR: FUSELI, John Henry
TITLE: Lady Macbeth

DESCRIPTION: His early contact with the teachings of Johann Jakob Bodmer familiarized him with the figures of world literature, which were to remain a major source of inspiration throughout his career.
AUTHOR: FUSELI, John Henry
TITLE: Lady Macbeth

DESCRIPTION: Ordained in 1761 as a pastor in the Zwinglian Reformed Church, he left Zurich two years later for political reasons, traveling by way of Berlin to London, where he settled.
AUTHOR: FUSELI, John Henry
TITLE: Lady Macbeth

DESCRIPTION: Initially Fuseli made his living by writing, while engaged in illustrating the works of his favourite authors, particularly William Shakespeare.The painting represents a scene from Shakespeare's Macbeth.
AUTHOR: FUSELI, John Henry
TITLE: Lady Macbeth

DESCRIPTION: It shows Lady Macbeth as a a sleep-walker in the corridor of a fortress.
AUTHOR: FUSELI, John Henry
TITLE: Lady Macbeth

DESCRIPTION: The terrified eyes of Lady Macbeth, by now lost between reality and nightmare, clutch at the viewer, almost as though trying to capture him and carry him off into her own unknown dimension
AUTHOR: FUSELI, John Henry
TITLE: Lady Macbeth

DESCRIPTION: The monkey in this sumptuous still-life is an allusion to sensual pleasure
AUTHOR: FYT, Jan
TITLE: Still-Life with Fruit and Monkey

DESCRIPTION: This is the centre panel of an altarpiece.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 184 x 94 cm

DESCRIPTION: Two panels depicting four standing saints (Sts Peter, James, Bartholomew, and Anthony Abbot) in Museo Nazionale di San Matteo, Pisa, are suggested to be on the right-hand side, other parts are not identified.The composition of the centre panel follows that of Giotto's Coronation of the Virgin in the Baroncelli Chapel of half century earlier.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 184 x 94 cm

DESCRIPTION: Nothing appears to have occurred between 1330 and 1380 to render Giotto's prototype out of date: the latter painting reveals no startling new approach.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 184 x 94 cm

DESCRIPTION: Only the proportions have been elongated in accordance with Gothic ideal of elegance; otherwise the design has been followed faithfully.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 184 x 94 cm

DESCRIPTION: Where the differences lie is in nuances of colour, and it is these nuances that reveal a Florentine tradition and its development
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 184 x 94 cm

DESCRIPTION: This altarpiece was executed perhaps for the Manetti Chapel in Santa Maria del Carmine, Florence, which was frescoed by Spinello Aretino.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Virgin and Child with Saints

DESCRIPTION: The represented saints in the altarpiece are Sts John the Baptist, Anthony Abbot, Catherine and Mary Magdalen
AUTHOR: GADDI, Agnolo
TITLE: Virgin and Child with Saints

DESCRIPTION: This scene at bottom left on the east wall, shows presents an imposing architectural backdrop.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Presentation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Three tall platforms provide a foundation for the temple, which is depicted as a three-aisle basilica, flanked by loggias.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Presentation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The stairway on which Mary turns backward is given an equivalent amount of space.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Presentation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Her path is followed attentively not only by her parents and the high priest waitng at the temple entrance, but also by a number of citizens.This painting was admired in Taddeo's time and it was imitated in contemporary painting
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Presentation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This scene, at bottom right on the east wall, has a festive and cheerful character.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The main action is not in the foreground but rather in the middle ground within the crowd of people that surrounds the ceremony.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The scene is defined in the rear by a wall, but beyond the wall a luxurious garden is suggested
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Taddeo Gaddi was Giotto's most important student, belonging to his workshop for twenty-four years.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Last Supper, Tree of Life and Four Miracle Scenes

DESCRIPTION: He produced a number of frescoes in Florence and Pisa, besides numerous panel paintings, but until his death in 1366 he was mainly active in Santa Croce, the Franciscan monastery in Florence, and his house and workshop were nearby.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Last Supper, Tree of Life and Four Miracle Scenes

DESCRIPTION: His late works, from around 1360, include the fresco of the Crucifixion in the sacristy and the ensemble of paintings grouped around a Tree of Life (Arbor vitae) in the refectory of Santa Croce.The picture shows the interior of the refectory in Santa Croce in Florence.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Last Supper, Tree of Life and Four Miracle Scenes

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes were commissioned by the woman in the garments of a Franciscan tertiary kneeling at the foot of the cross, behind St Francis.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Last Supper, Tree of Life and Four Miracle Scenes

DESCRIPTION: At the right are the Priest at his Easter Meal Receiving Word of St Benedict's Hunger in the Wilderness, and the Magdalen Washing the Feet of Christ.
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Last Supper, Tree of Life and Four Miracle Scenes

DESCRIPTION: At the left are the Stigmatisation of St Francis and St Louis of Toulouse Feeding the Poor and Sick of Toulouse
AUTHOR: GADDI, Taddeo
TITLE: Last Supper, Tree of Life and Four Miracle Scenes

DESCRIPTION: This charming picture belongs to Gainsborough's early period, when he was working in London and Suffolk.
AUTHOR: GAINSBOROUGH, Thomas
TITLE: Conversation in a Park

DESCRIPTION: The theme of the conversation in a park evokes Watteau and his school; it denotes a French influence, which played a considerable part in the formation of the artist - he was in fact a pupil of the French engraver Gravelot at the St Martins Lane Academy.
AUTHOR: GAINSBOROUGH, Thomas
TITLE: Conversation in a Park

DESCRIPTION: This picture has been thought to represent Thomas Sandby and his wife.
AUTHOR: GAINSBOROUGH, Thomas
TITLE: Conversation in a Park

DESCRIPTION: At the Watson sale in 1832, it was described as depicting the artist and his wife.
AUTHOR: GAINSBOROUGH, Thomas
TITLE: Conversation in a Park

DESCRIPTION: The painter's marriage took place in 1746; a very similar work, Mr and Mrs Andrews, is dated 1748.The open-air portrait is a familiar theme in the English school, whereas in eighteenth-century France the portrait is usually in an interior.
AUTHOR: GAINSBOROUGH, Thomas
TITLE: Conversation in a Park

DESCRIPTION: The evocation of nature by the English portrait painters is on the whole conventional; it is quite another matter with Gainsborough, however, who has treated the landscape for its own sake
AUTHOR: GAINSBOROUGH, Thomas
TITLE: Conversation in a Park

DESCRIPTION: This painting was exhibited at the Salon of 1725.
AUTHOR: GALLOCHE, Louis
TITLE: Diana and Actaeon

DESCRIPTION: Two later versions of the subject by the painter are known
AUTHOR: GALLOCHE, Louis
TITLE: Diana and Actaeon

DESCRIPTION: This study of a bearded man, head and shoulders, was probably made with the intention to use it in some multi-figural composition
AUTHOR: GANDOLFI, Gaetano
TITLE: Study of a Bearded Man

DESCRIPTION: This is a preparatory sketch (bozzetto) for the altarpiece of the same subject in the Oratory of the Blessed Virgin of the Nativity and Saint Giustina at Villa Tanari, Bazzano
AUTHOR: GANDOLFI, Gaetano
TITLE: St Giustina and the Guardian Angel Commending the Soul of an Infant to the Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the lunette fresco in the Tesoro Vecchio in the Certosa di San Martino.Gargiulo worked for the Carthusians in Naples over a period of more than twenty years.
AUTHOR: GARGIULO, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and Aaron Collecting Alms for the Building of the Temple

DESCRIPTION: He painted the lunette in the so-called Tesoro Vecchio, whose subject, Moses and Aaron Collecting Alms for the Building of the Temple, reflects the function of the room.
AUTHOR: GARGIULO, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and Aaron Collecting Alms for the Building of the Temple

DESCRIPTION: In this lunette Gargiulo already presents the compositional and stylistic features that would characterize his paintings in the lay brothers' choir in the Certosa
AUTHOR: GARGIULO, Domenico
TITLE: Moses and Aaron Collecting Alms for the Building of the Temple

DESCRIPTION: In this painting Garofalo used some of the leading motifs of Raphael's School of Athens.There is a variant of the painting attributed to the Master of the Twelve Apostles in the Pinacoteca Capitolina in Rome
AUTHOR: GAROFALO
TITLE: Christ and the Adulteress

DESCRIPTION: This painting is illusionistic in its theatrical sense of sudden confrontation.
AUTHOR: GÄRTNER, Eduard
TITLE: Staircase in the Berlin Palace

DESCRIPTION: Guardsmen march in the distance while a servant and her little girl as seen in the foreground of Andreas Schlüter's designed Baroque palace, destroyed in World War II
AUTHOR: GÄRTNER, Eduard
TITLE: Staircase in the Berlin Palace

DESCRIPTION: This old-fashioned view of a mostly old-fashioned Berlin quarter with its eighteenth-century shops is painted in the Dutch mode
AUTHOR: GÄRTNER, Eduard
TITLE: Klosterstrasse

DESCRIPTION: This view of the Königsbrücke shows the theaterlike pavilions still under construction
AUTHOR: GÄRTNER, Eduard
TITLE: Königsbrücke and Königskolonnade

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the result of a collaboration between a figure painter influenced by Carlo Maratti and a northern European still-life painter in the circle of Abraham Brueghel.
AUTHOR: GARZI, Luigi
TITLE: Allegory of Autumn

DESCRIPTION: The figures, painted prior to the still-life, are attributed to Luigi Garzi, while the voluptuous still-life of fruits and flowers to Franz Werner von Tamm, who was in Rome from 1685 and remained in Italy until 1701
AUTHOR: GARZI, Luigi
TITLE: Allegory of Autumn

DESCRIPTION: By 1883, and as a direct result of the collapse of the stock market the previous year, Gauguin's finances were in disarray, and he began to consider a change in career.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel

DESCRIPTION: This painting demonstrates an attempt to align himself with the landscape Impressionist painters, perhaps from a desire to make money from the sale of his works, and is in marked contrast to the more laboured works produced while he could still consider himself an amateur.The subject of a snowy landscape was a typical Impressionist device to enable the artist to study the effects of colour reflections on a white surface and was particularly favoured by Sisley.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel

DESCRIPTION: However, the handling in the sky and the foliage is more reminiscent of the work of Monet from this period.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel

DESCRIPTION: The spontaneity of the brushwork and the subject matter would suggest that the canvas was painted out of doors, but there is a small related sketch without the two foreground figures, probably done in front of the motif, which presumably forms the basis for this more finished, studio painting.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel

DESCRIPTION: This means that the two women were added later, and demonstrates that even at this date Gauguin did not feel tied to working solely from nature, and had already begun to use the subject of two conversing women which was to recur in his mature work
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: The Garden in Winter, Rue Carcel

DESCRIPTION: From November 1884 to June 1885 Gauguin lived in Copenhagen with his wife and family, and it was there that he painted this self-portrait.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Gauguin at His Easel

DESCRIPTION: His letters to friends in Paris chronicle what was for him a difficult period - he missed the cultural life of Paris, disliked the Danes, his wife's family in particular, and the harsh climate meant that he could do little work in the open air.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Gauguin at His Easel

DESCRIPTION: Increasingly he was forced to work indoors, without a model, and his subject matter betrays these constraints.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Gauguin at His Easel

DESCRIPTION: His work became increasingly premeditated.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Gauguin at His Easel

DESCRIPTION: However, in the execution, particularly in the flickering brushwork, this painting is still close to the work of his Impressionist years.Gauguin's rather romantic characterization of the solitary figure labouring in a garret establishes the tenor of much later self-portraits, in which he depicted himself as artistic martyr, culminating in the series of works of 1889 in which he increasingly identified with Christ
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Gauguin at His Easel

DESCRIPTION: Gauguin met Charles Laval (1862-1894) at Pont-Aven in the summer of 1886 and the younger artist became his pupil.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval

DESCRIPTION: The two were to journey to Panama and Martinique together the following year.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval

DESCRIPTION: Gauguin's role as mentor is alluded to in the way in which Laval gazes fixedly at the ceramic pot which was made by Gauguin in the winter of 1886-87, when he worked in Paris with the ceramicist Chaplet.The still-life with its piled up fruits, treated with tight diagonal brushstrokes and laid out on a white cloth, is reminiscent of Cézanne's painting Still-Life with Compotier which Gauguin owned at this date.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval

DESCRIPTION: At the same time, the oddly truncated head in the foreground is a homage to Degas, who had exhibited with Gauguin at the final Impressionist exhibition that year
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Still-Life with Portrait of Laval

DESCRIPTION: Things sacred are present in the background of Gauguin's portraits, which he wanted to put in expressive harmony with the faces, according to the Symbolist doctrine which inspired also Van Gogh.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Self-Portrait with Yellow Christ

DESCRIPTION: In 1889, he placed The Yellow Christ in the background of his self-portrait
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Self-Portrait with Yellow Christ

DESCRIPTION: Gauguin's Tahitian paintings celebrate the lushness and mysterious splendour of his new environment.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)

DESCRIPTION: At the same time they are seldom correct pictures of Tahitian life, from an anthropological standpoint, but rather feature recastings and recombinations of objects and persons taken out of their normal settings, as was the case with several of his paintings done in Brittany.The most important paintings executed during Gauguin's first stay in Tahiti are the Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary) and The Spectre Watches over Her (Manao Tupapau).
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)

DESCRIPTION: In Ia Orana Maria Gauguin places the Christian story into a setting where both the figures and the vegetation are Polynesian.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)

DESCRIPTION: A Tahitian woman, her young son, and two women standing nearby are shown in the obvious attitudes of the Virgin and Child with attendant saints or worshiping angels.Once again Gauguin has returned to the theme of the effect of profound religious faith on an apparently simple people, which had preoccupied him in some of his most important Breton works.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)

DESCRIPTION: The apparently effortless fusion of Christian iconography with Tahitian subject matter is in fact carefully contrived, with the poses of the background figures lifted from the relief carving on the Javanese temple of Borobudur, photographs of which Gauguin had taken with him to Tahiti
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Ia Orana Maria (Hail Mary)

DESCRIPTION: In 1889 Gauguin had painted a pair of works entitled Women Bathing (Life and Death) and Woman in the Waves (Ondine).
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)

DESCRIPTION: The latter (in the Cleveland Museum of Art) depicts a naked woman, seen from behind, cast adrift in the waves, and in Fatata te miti he has reused the same subject, setting her within a Tahitian genre scene.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)

DESCRIPTION: In Ondine, Gauguin had treated the myth of the water-sprite who can only become human after having a child fathered by a man.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)

DESCRIPTION: Once again, he has explored the theme of the joy of sexual union as an essentially liberating activity, hinted at in the alternative title for The Loss of Virginity: The Awakening of Spring.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)

DESCRIPTION: In Fatata te miti the sexual abandonment is seen as part of the natural rhythm of Polynesian life (the two women do not appear perturbed at the presence of the fisherman in the background of the work), a notion that was integral to the highly popular Marriage of Loti, which Gauguin had read before visiting Tahiti and which was calculated to appeal to a Parisian audience
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: By the Sea (Fatata te Miti)

DESCRIPTION: The Moon and the Earth is Gauguin's depiction of an ancient Polynesian myth, in which Hina, the female spirit of the Moon, implores Fatou, the male spirit of the Earth, to grant humans eternal life.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)

DESCRIPTION: It is a request Fatou resolutely denies.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)

DESCRIPTION: The painting was included in the exhibition that Gauguin organized at Durand-Ruel's gallery in Paris in November 1893.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)

DESCRIPTION: The works exhibited were his most recent: a few sculptures, three paintings from Brittany and 41 from Tahiti.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)

DESCRIPTION: In the end, only 11 paintings were sold and the artist Degas bought Hina te Fatou
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Hina te Fatou (The Moon and the Earth)

DESCRIPTION: This work was probably produced at the beginning of 1894, when Gauguin painted another snowscape, Paris in the Snow (Amsterdam, Rijksmuseum Van Gogh).
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Breton Village in the Snow

DESCRIPTION: During his two years in Paris he painted far fewer works than before - large amounts of his time were taken up with organizing his show at Durand-Ruel's and on a number of literary projects.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Breton Village in the Snow

DESCRIPTION: Consequently, what little he did paint was not new in either subject or treatment.
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Breton Village in the Snow

DESCRIPTION: This landscape is remarkably similar to those that he had produced during his Impressionist period - the small brush-strokes are quite different from the broad sweeps of colour that characterized his Tahitian works
AUTHOR: GAUGUIN, Paul
TITLE: Breton Village in the Snow

DESCRIPTION: The artist interprets the subject in a fantastic and worldly way: the sparkling colours of the luxurious robes dominates the scene
AUTHOR: GEERTGEN tot Sint Jans
TITLE: The Tree of Jesse

DESCRIPTION: The portrait of Gérard de Lairesse, a fellow painter, was painted when he was 24 years old.
AUTHOR: GELDER, Aert de
TITLE: Portrait of Gérard de Lairesse

DESCRIPTION: The fashionably dressed man sits sin front of a table, holding some papers in his hand.
AUTHOR: GELDER, Aert de
TITLE: Portrait of Gérard de Lairesse

DESCRIPTION: There is nothing to indicate that this man is an artist.
AUTHOR: GELDER, Aert de
TITLE: Portrait of Gérard de Lairesse

DESCRIPTION: The painter made no attempt to flatter his model, he portrayed him with his outward imperfections.Formerly the painting was attributed to Rembrandt
AUTHOR: GELDER, Aert de
TITLE: Portrait of Gérard de Lairesse

DESCRIPTION: The artist, a pupil of Rembrandt, is holding in his hands Rembrandt's etching, "The 100 Guilder Print".
AUTHOR: GELDER, Aert de
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: It is generally accepted as his self-portrait and as his homage to his teacher, but even if we ignore the fact that this portrait does not show a cross-eyed man - we are told that de Gelder bore his affliction with good humour - the evidence for this identification is flimsy
AUTHOR: GELDER, Aert de
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The monogram of the artist and age of the sitter (28) is inscribed upper left
AUTHOR: GELDORP, Gortzius
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: One of the right side panels of the polyptych represents St George
AUTHOR: GENTILE DA FABRIANO
TITLE: Quaratesi Polyptych: St George

DESCRIPTION: This panel is part of the predella of the Quaratesi polyptych.It appears that Gentile felt freer to experiment in the minor scenes of a predella than in the main panel of an altarpiece.
AUTHOR: GENTILE DA FABRIANO
TITLE: Quaratesi Polyptych: Miracle of the Pilgrims at St Nicholas's Tomb

DESCRIPTION: In this case he shows the interior of a church, which itself was quite a difficult task, with a rather convincing treatment of the space
AUTHOR: GENTILE DA FABRIANO
TITLE: Quaratesi Polyptych: Miracle of the Pilgrims at St Nicholas's Tomb

DESCRIPTION: This grisly subject was enduringly popular.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Artemisia
TITLE: Judith and Her Maidservant

DESCRIPTION: Once upon a time in Florence, the subject stood for the city's proud republicanism.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Artemisia
TITLE: Judith and Her Maidservant

DESCRIPTION: By the time Gentileschi made this work, probably for Cosimo II de' Medici, Florence was a grand duchy and the Baroque, with all its monumental and realistic cruelty, held sway
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Artemisia
TITLE: Judith and Her Maidservant

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts the appearance of an angel to Valerianus and Cecilia, a young couple who had been converted to Christianity.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Cecilia had taken a vow of chastity and had persuaded her husband to do likewise.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Valerianus had suspected her of secretly being in love with his f riend Tiburtius but the angelic apparition allays his doubts while also heralding their approaching martyrdom.The composition - showing the three sumptuously dressed saints as they express with dignity their astonishment over the apparition of the angel - incorporates the main elements of Gentileschi's art.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: It represents a high point of his maturity, ranking with the Madonna of the Rosei family and the Annunciation in Turin.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: The disciplined, orderly construction has a Neoclassical stamp that derives from the artist's Tuscan background.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: The handling of the light shows the fundamental influence of Caravaggio, while the refinement of the surfaces in the gleaming satin and damask draperies and the soft warmth of the velvets are inspired by Bronzino.Typical of Gentileschi are the arrested gestures standing out against the opaque shadow of the austere interior; the figure of Tibertius, silhouetted against the light as he cautiously peers at the angel; the system of curves formed by the wings, the body and the long palm branch of the angel in flight; and the outstretched arms of St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Cecilia and St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Valerianus.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: The structural elements of the composition are striking: the link between Tibertius' hand and the angel's foot; the alignment of the palm branch and the organ pipes, and the wreath of flowers, St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Cecilia's hand and St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Valerianus' knee; and the parallels formed by the figures of St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Valerianus and St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Cecilia, the organ pipes and the door frame, the keyboard and the dais.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Every element is brought into complex play in this highly articulated composition, from the tips of the wings and the palm branch to the edge of the red mantle, St.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: Valerianus' foot and the velvet cushion.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Sts Cecilia, Valerianus and Tiburtius

DESCRIPTION: The story of Cupid and Psyche is not a myth but a late antique fairy tale, by Lucius Apuleius (2nd century AD) in the Metamorphoses, or Golden Ass.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Psyche was a maiden so beautiful that she aroused even Venus' envy.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Cupid, sent by the goddess to arouse Psyche's love in some worthless being, fell in love with her himself.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: Cupid and Psyche

DESCRIPTION: Orazio Gentileschi's brooding image of David contemplating the head of Goliath reflects a new type of meditative image introduced at the beginning of the seventeenth century by Caravaggio.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: Traditionally David was shown either as an uncompromised biblical hero slaying Goliath or as a triumphant youth displaying the giant's decapitated head.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: In Caravaggio's David with the Head of Goliath (Galleria Borghese, Rome), which was likely to have been sent from Naples around 1609 as a gift for Cardinal Scipione Borghese, the adolescent hero gazes tenderly at his victim's head, creating a strong, almost erotic, bond.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: Orazio's David does not interact with Goliath's head, rather he stands beside it lost in a moment of deep introspection, evoking a pensive atmosphere similar to the mood generated in Caravaggio's St John the Baptist.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: Like the St John, David's body is pushed towards the picture plane and set off against a background of dense, dark foliage.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: This verdant background is strikingly different from the one in Orazio's small copper version (Gemäldegalerie, Berlin), in which David is framed by a rocky cliff.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: The difference has led some critics to suggest that Agostino Tassi was responsible for the landscape in the Spada picture, but there is no conclusive proof to substantiate this.Unlike the Berlin copper, where David is seen full-length, in the Spada version his body is cropped just below the knee and Goliath's head is turned upwards towards the viewer.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: It has been suggested that the Spada canvas was cut down at the bottom.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: However, technical evidence shows that instead it was extended on all four sides.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: Thus the picture would have focused more directly on the contemplative and melancholic David and the head of Goliath would have appeared to rest on the edge of the frame.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: A copy of the Berlin composition (Quadreria Arcivescovile, Milan) was paired with a version of Artemisia Gentileschi's Judith Beheading Holofernes , but there is no evidence to indicate that two pictures of such contrasting moods were originally conceived as pendants.
AUTHOR: GENTILESCHI, Orazio
TITLE: David Contemplating the Head of Goliath

DESCRIPTION: This is a case where a comparison will give a good idea of how differently the same subject was handled by Jacques-Louis David and one of his numerous pupils.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: David started the portrait of Madame Récamier in 1800 which was never finished.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: (However, incidentally, this portrait helped a contemporary item of furniture to become known under her name.)
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: When the master learned that the lady had also commissioned his pupil Gérard to paint her, he is said to have refused any further service.In David's portrait, noble simplicity, expressed by the simple dress and the Spartan decoration, is also eloquent in the open face.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: This might well appear more to the modern viewer than Gérard's version, which was judged to be more representative and flattering at the time.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: And comparisons with portraits of Madame Récamier by other artists suggest that Gérard had achieved a better likeness than David.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: The Spartan severity of David's composition, the Neoclassical sparseness of the arrangement, the cool handling of the room, the distanced pose, with the lady turning her shoulder to the viewer, were all elements with which Neoclassicism had operated for long enough.Gérard, by contrast, sets the lady in a noble park loggia, where she seems to be inviting to conversation.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: Her low-cut bodice is seductive, the red curtain flatters the subject and gives the flesh a rosy tint.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: Where David gave the beautiful woman a rather severe touch around the mouth, Gérard embellishes her features with the hint of a gentle smile, making her look younger.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: By contrast, David's portrait in the antique manner looks rather forced.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: Perhaps these were the reasons why his painting was never finished.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: Madame Récamier gave Gérard's portrait of her to her admirer Prince Augustus of Prussia, a nephew of Frederick II, who had met the French beauty at the salon of Madame de Staël. For state reasons a marriage was impossible, but in the painting Madame Récamier was ever present in the palace which Schinkel furnished for the Prince in 1817.After the death of the Prince the portrait was returned to Madame Récamier
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Madame Récamier

DESCRIPTION: In 1819 Madame Récamier received as a gift from Prince Augustus of Prussia a picture by Gérard, an affecting realization of Madame de Staël as Corinne, set like Sappho on the wild shore of Cape Miseno and pausing in her recitation of an ode when interrupted by her infatuated admirer, Lord Nelvil.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Corinne at Cape Miseno

DESCRIPTION: Corinne looks up heavenwards in her confusion
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, François
TITLE: Corinne at Cape Miseno

DESCRIPTION: Gérard specialized in domestic genre scenes, often depicting an idealized vision of the lives of bourgeois and upper class women.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, Marguerite
TITLE: Lady Reading in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: Usually depicted in intimate settings, her subjects enjoy lives of leisure with their families or engage in elegant pastimes.
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, Marguerite
TITLE: Lady Reading in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: Her meticulous style derived from her study of the works of Dutch 17th-century masters such as Gabriel Metsu and Caspar Netscher
AUTHOR: GÉRARD, Marguerite
TITLE: Lady Reading in an Interior

DESCRIPTION: Géricault painted five studies of this theme for large painting which was never realized.
AUTHOR: GÉRICAULT, Théodore
TITLE: Riderless Horse Races

DESCRIPTION: Two versions depicts the subject as a contemporary scene, to other three (one of them in the Louvre) as antique.In this composition created in Rome, the power of man struggling against beast is expressed through the study of antiquity and the forms of Michelangelo
AUTHOR: GÉRICAULT, Théodore
TITLE: Riderless Horse Races

DESCRIPTION: Géricault seems to have felt something like an inner mission when he chose the most pitiable creatures in society for his subjects.
AUTHOR: GÉRICAULT, Théodore
TITLE: A Madwoman and Compulsive Gambler

DESCRIPTION: In his studies of neurotics, he made shattering documentations, like this painting.
AUTHOR: GÉRICAULT, Théodore
TITLE: A Madwoman and Compulsive Gambler

DESCRIPTION: The composition of this painting is clearly related to a work by Luca Giordano depicting the Sleeping Venus with Cupid and a Satyr in the Museo di Capodimonte, Naples.
AUTHOR: GHERARDINI, Alessandro
TITLE: Jupiter and Antiope

DESCRIPTION: Given the great popularity of Giordano's work in Florence, it is conceivable that Gherardini knew the composition of Venus with Cupid and a Satyr through other versions or drawings, and presented it in his own idiom
AUTHOR: GHERARDINI, Alessandro
TITLE: Jupiter and Antiope

DESCRIPTION: The small dimensions of the panel suggest that it was painted for private devotion.
AUTHOR: GHERARDUCCI, Don Silvestro dei
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: This half-length depiction of the married sea gods whose love is symbolized by the Cupid and the shells that accompany them was originally described in Wallraf's collection as 'Italian'.
AUTHOR: GHEYN, Jacob de II
TITLE: Neptune and Amphitrite

DESCRIPTION: He was deceived probably by the decorative elegance of its colour and line, and by the type of the double half-length, which originated in Italy
AUTHOR: GHEYN, Jacob de II
TITLE: Neptune and Amphitrite

DESCRIPTION: Between November 1475 and April 1476 Domenico Ghirlandaio and his brother Davide received payments for painting half-figure bust portraits of ancient philosophers and Church fathers, together with inscription ribbons, in the Biblioteca Latina at the Vatican Palace.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Davide
TITLE: Aristotle and Diogenes

DESCRIPTION: These paintings were rediscovered in 1967
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Davide
TITLE: Aristotle and Diogenes

DESCRIPTION: "... He did a chapel in Santissima Trinita for Francesco Sassetti with stories of St Francis, an admirable work, remarkable for its grace, finish and delicacy" (Vasari).Francesco Sassetti had gained his wealth as a partner in the French branches of the Medici bank in Avignon and Lyon.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: He also spent over ten years representing the Medici bank in Genoa and occasionally in Geneva.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: But he was not always successful later on in his role as the chairman of the bank, and in 1484 was replaced by Giovanni Tornabuoni.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: By the end of the 1470s, Sassetti had already acquired the rights of patronage to a small side chapel, the second to the right of the choir in the Florentine church of Santissima Trinita.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: It was probable at this time that Ghirlandaio was commissioned to paint the chapel, which he decorated with frescoes between 1482 and 1485.The donor and his wife had themselves portrayed as life-sized figures kneeling in prayer at the side of the altarpiece the Adoration of the Shepherds.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: The donors are adoring the Christ Child, just like the shepherds in the panel painting.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: An incomplete inscription under their portraits names the day on which the chapel was consecrated, 25 December 1485, hence also the date by which it would have been completed.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: This year corresponds with the complete inscription on the altarpiece.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: In the Sassetti Chapel the artist combined secular, religious, and classical themes to produce a unique masterpiece.In the scenes from the life of Saint Francis of Assisi, Ghirlandaio incorporated portraits of contemporaries and views of Florence: he recreated religious events to the Florence of his day.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: In contrast to the newly built Saint Fina Chapel, the Sassetti Chapel was old and in the Gothic style.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: On each of its three walls Ghirlandaio painted two scenes from the life of Saint Francis, completed by a seventh fresco in the tympanum over the arched entrance to the chapel.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: At the crown of the entrance arch, the Sassetti coat of arms is surrounded by a garland of fruit, a sculptural work made of terracotta.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: The fresco in the tympanum above shows a sibyl prophesying Christ's dominion over the world to Emperor Augustus.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: The fresco idealizes the classical period as the precursor to the Christian age, and this provides a link with the chapel's high point, the altarpiece, which depicts the birth of Christ.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: The grisaille figure of David outside the chapel can also be interpreted in this way.On the two side walls of the chapel are the black marble sarcophagi of Francesco Sassetti and his wife Nera Corsi, set into niches with round arches.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: Here the sculptural decorations are dominated by classical motifs; the sculptor Giuliano da Sangallo is sometimes identified as the artist.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: The tomb niches are framed by grisaille frescoes, in which Ghirlandaio cites motifs from classical coins.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: Above each are two monumental frescoes by Ghirlandaio, which clearly owe a debt to traditional images.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: There are still echoes of the pictorial order established by Giotto in Assisi over 160 years earlier.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: Ghirlandaio studied Giotto's frescoes in the Bardi Chapel, dating from about 1325, in the Franciscan church of Santa Croce in Florence, and made direct use of them
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: View of the Sassetti Chapel

DESCRIPTION: "In two pictures on either side he painted Francesco Sassetti kneeling, and Madonna Nera, his wife and her children, the latter being in the scene above where the boy is raised to life, with some beautiful maidens of the same family" (Vasari).The two donors are in prayer on either side of the altar, as if they are taking part in the Adoration of the Shepherds depicted on the altarpiece.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Portrait of the Donor Nera Corsi Sassetti

DESCRIPTION: Linking the frescoes and the central panel painting in this way, Ghirlandaio creates what is almost a triptych.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Portrait of the Donor Nera Corsi Sassetti

DESCRIPTION: Astonishingly enough, the wife, Nera Corsi Sassetti, is occupying the traditionally more distinguished position on the right of the religious scene.At the base is the painted inscription: A.D.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Portrait of the Donor Nera Corsi Sassetti

DESCRIPTION: MCCCCLXXX.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Portrait of the Donor Nera Corsi Sassetti

DESCRIPTION: XV decembris.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Portrait of the Donor Nera Corsi Sassetti

DESCRIPTION: This could be the initial date of the work whose conclusion is in the great altarpiece with the Nativity, dated 1485
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Portrait of the Donor Nera Corsi Sassetti

DESCRIPTION: The official prestige value of the upper picture on the main chapel wall (the Confirmation of the Rule) is clear.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: In contrast, the fresco beneath it, directly above the altarpiece, is devoted to the Sassetti family's private history.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: In 1478, the year of the Pazzi plot, their son Teodoro died; but a few months later Nera Corsi Sassetti gave birth to a second son.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: As they felt him to be a gift from God, they made yet another change in the plans for the altar wall in their mortuary chapel.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: Ghirlandaio had to abandon his design for a scene showing the appearance of Saint Francis in Arles, for which preliminary drawings still exist, and paint the Resurrection of the Boy.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: This was how the Sassetti intended to express their gratitude for their new-bon son Teodoro II.The events in the Resurrection of the Boy are taking place just outside the church of Santissima Trinita at the Ponte Santissima Trinita.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: "... In it he represented the Ponte Santissima Trinita (the old one, by Taddeo Gaddi; the present one was built by Ammannati almost a hundred years later) with the palace of the Spini, the first scene showing the appearance of St Francis in the air to raise a child of that family... and other figures who are marvelling and rejoicing at the miracle, affording no little pleasure to the rest of us.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Resurrection of the Boy

DESCRIPTION: Among them are portraits of Agnolo Acciaioli, Palla Strozzi..." (Vasari).While playing, a boy falls out of the windows of the Palazzo Spini.

AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico

DESCRIPTION: This composition was so successful that other artists frequently repeated it.

DESCRIPTION: Ghirlandaio himself appears in the scene, dressed as a shepherd.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico

DESCRIPTION: He is even allowed to come closer to the Christ Child than the donors, who appear in frescoes to the right and left, praying outside the confines of the panel.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: His left hand, with which he is pointing to the Christ Child, is finely drawn and is superbly modelled in three dimensions.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: With his right hand, his painting hand, he is pointing to his chest, as he does in a later fresco in the Tornabuoni Chapel.

TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: As Ghirlandaio is pointing both at the child and the garlands on the Roman marble sarcophagus, it is possible that the gesture is saying: "This holy child was painted for you by me, the garland-maker Ghirlandaio.

DESCRIPTION: "The classical sarcophagus in the picture is not just a manger for the ox and ass.

AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico

DESCRIPTION: In his Adoration of the Shepherds, Ghirlandaio combines this reference to the Roman classical age with knowledge of Flemish art and turns them into an integrated whole.An historic event that took place a few years before this work was painted clearly left its mark behind on Ghirlandaio's work.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: An altarpiece ordered by Tommaso Portinari from Hugo van der Goes in Bruges reached Florence in May 1483.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: Florentine artists saw van der Goes' Adoration of the Shepherds as a shining comet showing new ways of painting.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: In Ghirlandaio's altarpiece, the shepherds pushing their way into the picture from the right, with their harsh, life-like features, are drawn directly from this Flemish model.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Shepherds

DESCRIPTION: Ghirlandaio's landscape in the background also displays features from north of the Alps

DESCRIPTION: The narration of the story of Mary on the left wall of the chapel starts at the bottom at the entrance to the chapel with the Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple.In the centre of the loggia with broad round arches and built on a cross-shaped ground plan, a high priest is receiving sacrificial lambs at the altar where a fire is burning.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: As the old Joachim does not yet have any descendants, he is not allowed to take part in the sacrificial rite, and is sent away.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: Symmetrical groups of Florentine citizens frame this biblical scene, and in the group on the right, the artist has depicted himself and some members of his family.This episode follows the traditional lines of composition.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: Of significance here is the architecture, which the artist obviously felt was more important than the events.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: In the upper half of the painting it takes up more space than the figures, who occupy only the bottom part of the picture.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: The most important figures - and not only the biblical ones - are standing at the front edge of the picture.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: All the other scenes follow this basic principle.In the background, Ghirlandaio's depiction of the widely spaced loggia and its medallions is a direct quotation of the Spedale degli Innocenti, the foundling hospital in Florence designed by Brunelleschi.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: Interestingly enough, there is a repetition of this façade, constructed shortly after Ghirlandaio's frescoes were painted, that can be seen when leaving the church of Santa Maria Novella at the other end of the piazza by the Spedale di San Paolo (built 1489 -1498).Above the portraits are two palaces whose lines run parallel with those of the temple.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: Comparable buildings, with rusticated lower stories and open upper stories, largely characterize the appearance of Florence to this day.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: This was one way in which Ghirlandaio repeatedly brought the city into his paintings.Contemporaries of the artist and clients are present as spectators and witnesses of the expulsion of Joachim, and because of their fashionable clothing and shoes and their vain hairstyles they differ conspicuously from the biblical participants.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: It is thought that the noblemen on the left include the client's son, Lorenzo Tornabuoni, and his friend Piero, the son of Lorenzo de' Medici.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: In the group at the right Ghirlandaio depicts famous contemporary artists (including himself) who can be identified from the description of Vasari as Alesso Baldovinetti, Bastiano Mainardi, Davide and Domenico Ghirlandaio.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Expulsion of Joachim from the Temple

DESCRIPTION: At the height of the Presentation of the Virgin and the Marriage of Mary - above the corner of the chapel and connecting with the rear wall next to the Gothic window - there is the narrow fresco the Annunciation.Again Ghirlandaio has moved the scene of this biblical event to Tuscany and his own era.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: He was able to find the traditional Renaissance form of a painted window with a view of a landscape in many Florentine palaces.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: They can still be seen today in Florence, examples being the palaces of the Medici, Ruccelai and Strozzi families.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The angel is derived from the Annunciation painted by the young Leonardo da Vinci between 1472 and 1475, now on view in the Galleria degli Uffizi.In contrast to Leonardo's horizontal format, in Ghirlandaio's fresco in the predetermined vertical format his Virgin may be depicted facing the observer in an equally frontal view, but she is standing upright.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: She is therefore reminiscent of the beautiful picture on the same theme by Lorenzo di Credi, an artist who was also taught by Verrocchio together with Leonardo and Ghirlandaio
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: In the Gothic vaults of the Tornabuoni Chapel the four Evangelists are floating on clouds.St John the Evangelist is writing down God's words, which are being conveyed to him by his symbolic animal, the eagle, on a piece of paper
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: St John the Evangelist

AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The date is confirmed by Roman numerals: MCCCCLXXXVII.Such tondos were particularly popular as decorative items in private rooms, and their circular form required a particularly skillful composition.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: In the centre the childlike Mary is enthroned with her child.

TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The kings' large retinues are lined up right to the ruin, and only behind the Madonna is there a circle of empty space.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: In other words the composition is influenced by the form of the panel.On the left is a lovely group of four soldiers with helmets and lances, looking in various directions.

TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The soldiers have four horses that are also looking in different directions.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Their pendant on the right, further back, is a group of four other soldiers in magnificent contemporary armor.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The horses in front of the ruin are also very successful, and in them Ghirlandaio showed that he was also capable of depicting animals with strong foreshortening and from various angles.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The contrast between the magnificent gray stallion and the darker gray ass is surely intentional.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Above these animals the observer's gaze wanders through the open arched architecture of the classical ruin out into the far distance.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: There, painted in an atmospheric paleness, is a city surrounded by water and reminiscent of Venice.The composition of this Adoration contains allusions to the unique panel created in 1481 by Leonardo da Vinci, now in the Galleria degli Uffizi.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Though Leonardo never completed this work, it had an enormous influence on the artists of his age.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Ghirlandaio adopted the pyramidal composition of the main figures, with Mary at the top.
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The circular empty space behind Mary in the tondo might also have been inspired by Leonardo's picture.A replica of this tondo, in smaller dimensions and entirely the work of Domenico's shop, is to be found in the Galleria Palatina at Palazzo Pitti in Florence
AUTHOR: GHIRLANDAIO, Domenico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

TITLE: The Dead Christ and the Adoration of the Infant Jesus
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on wood, 39 x 29 cm

TITLE: The Dead Christ and the Adoration of the Infant Jesus
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on wood, 39 x 29 cm

DESCRIPTION: They also have their arms crossed like Christ, a gesture that expresses resignation for the unavoidable divine sacrifice.In the lower sector, the infant Jesus is lying on the ground, barely covered by a transparent cloth; his small body emits strong rays of light.
AUTHOR: GHISSI, Francescuccio
TITLE: The Dead Christ and the Adoration of the Infant Jesus
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on wood, 39 x 29 cm

AUTHOR: GIANI, Felice

DESCRIPTION: It was decided that a new sovereign's residence was required for Napoleon and the viceroy, Eugène de Beauharnais.
AUTHOR: GIANI, Felice
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: Once the idea of converting the Palazzo Ducale had been abandoned, the notion was mooted to use the Procuratie Nuove and the Libreria Marciana for this purpose.Apart from Giuseppe Borsato, there were also a number of famous non-Venetians involved in decorating the royal palace.
AUTHOR: GIANI, Felice
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: Felice Giani was given the task of painting the new apartment for the viceroy made out of the Libreria Marciana.
AUTHOR: GIANI, Felice
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: His figures, full of self-confidence enlivened by quick-witted elements set against the whimsical ornamental scheme by Gaetano Bertolani, contain references to Herculaneum and neo-Renaissance motifs.The picture shows the ceiling decoration for the viceroy's apartment in the former Libreria Marciana
AUTHOR: GIANI, Felice

DESCRIPTION: The story is recounted in the Book of Tobit.

DESCRIPTION: Tobias was sent by his father Tobit to Media to recover a sum of money he had hidden there earlier.
AUTHOR: GIAQUINTO, Corrado
TITLE: Tobias and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: Archangel Raphael, sent by God to help Tobit and his family, asked Tobit (who did not recognize the angel) whether he may escort his son on his journey and, in company with Tobias' faithful hound, they departed together.
AUTHOR: GIAQUINTO, Corrado
TITLE: Tobias and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: They reached the Tigris, where Tobias was attacked by a gigantic fish.
AUTHOR: GIAQUINTO, Corrado
TITLE: Tobias and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: The archangel ordered him to capture it and had him remove and conserve its gall, heart and liver.
AUTHOR: GIAQUINTO, Corrado
TITLE: Tobias and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: The innards proved to be a medicine which he can use to restore his father's sight
AUTHOR: GIAQUINTO, Corrado
TITLE: Tobias and the Angel

AUTHOR: GIJSBRECHTS, Cornelis Norbertus
TITLE: Still-Life with Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The subject is taken from Virgil's Aeneid (1:314-371).
AUTHOR: GIMIGNANI, Giacinto

DESCRIPTION: The goddess Venus, the mother of Aeneas, appeared to him twice, first in the midst of burning Troy to bid him be on his way.
AUTHOR: GIMIGNANI, Giacinto
TITLE: Venus Appearing to Aeneas and Achates

DESCRIPTION: Later, when the Troyan were washed ashore near Carthage after the storm at sea, Aeneas and his friend Achates set out to explore Venus appeared once more, this time with bow and quiver disguised as a huntress, to direct them to Dido's palace.This painting depicts the moment in which Venus appears to the Trojan warriors disguised as a huntress and directs them to Queen Dido's palace
AUTHOR: GIMIGNANI, Giacinto
TITLE: Venus Appearing to Aeneas and Achates

AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: Marriage of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The companion-piece of this painting, The Rape of Europa, is also in the Hermitage
AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: The Triumph of Galatea

DESCRIPTION: This composition is a combination of a mythological subject and a genre scene
AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: The Forge of Vulcan

DESCRIPTION: The new treasury (Tesoro Nuovo) was built on the north side of the monastery.
AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: Aaron's Sacrifice, and the Destruction of the Band of Korah

DESCRIPTION: Its painted decoration, completed in 1704 by the elderly Luca Giordano, constituted the last phase of the decoration of the charterhouse.Giordano painted Judith in Triumph over Holofernes on the cupola vault.
AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: Aaron's Sacrifice, and the Destruction of the Band of Korah

DESCRIPTION: The figure that appears to dominate the vault is the heroic Judith triumphantly displaying the head of Holofernes to the people of Israel.
AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: Aaron's Sacrifice, and the Destruction of the Band of Korah

DESCRIPTION: The lunettes contains scenes from the Old Testament, among them Aaron's Sacrifice, and the Destruction of the Band of Korah above the entrance, and the Erection of the Brazen Serpent above the altar
AUTHOR: GIORDANO, Luca
TITLE: Aaron's Sacrifice, and the Destruction of the Band of Korah

DESCRIPTION: Through the open window the Riva degli Schiavoni and the Campanile (bell tower) of he St Mark's Basilica can be seen.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: The Reading Madonna

DESCRIPTION: The campanile is represented with a temporary flat-roofed bell-chamber, which was in place from 1489 to 1511.The attribution to Giorgione is not universally accepted, some scholars attribute the painting to a painter close to Giorgione
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: The Reading Madonna

DESCRIPTION: Giorgione exploited the new style evolved in Venice through sensual subject matter.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: The Sleeping Venus is a case in point.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: The reclining figure was originally accompanied by a small figure of Cupid, but this figure was painted over in 1843.Giorgione placed the Venus across the whole width of the painting.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: She stretches one arm behind her head, making a long, continuous slope of body whose gentle curves echo the hills of the landscape behind and suggest some form of connection between the female depicted and nature.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: Painted at just the moment when Venice was defending its claims on the terra firma, it may, therefore, be possible to read Venus (Venere) as Venice (Venezia).Venus's sensuality is heightened by her red lips and by the deep red velvet and white satin drapery upon which her creamy body lies.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: Significantly, she is asleep, so the issue of decorum is bypassed.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: Her sleep implies dreaming and transport of the figure to another world.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: Thus the painting may be interpreted as a poetic evocation of a classical idyll.Several works of great beauty associated with Giorgione involve the collaboration of another distinctive master.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: In the Sleeping Venus a significant share has been assumed for Titian, especially in the landscape, where on the right a cupid has been painted out.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: The outstretched figure, stocky in proportions, is usually considered to be by Giorgione.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: The drawing is only approximative, with the outlines blurred to produce a gradual transition between the barely modeled flesh and the surrounding surface.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: But the edges are nonetheless legible, and they form a flattened lozenge-shaped, pale, collage-like form lying close to the picture plane, a device favoured over juxtapositions of darks and lights to conjure up an illusion of three-dimensionality.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: Giorgione fully exploited the sensuous potential of both the medium and the subject.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: There is a decidedly erotic air to the totally unselfconscious young woman whose pale flesh is contrasted to the silky cloth.If compared with Titian's Venus of Urbino the differences between the two become clear since Titian has taken over the pose and the figural type almost verbatim from Giorgione; they are differences of temperament and personality more than of time passed.
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: If the Sleeping Venus was actually completed by Titian, as is frequently assumed, the overall effect remains tightly connected with Giorgione's style, and one might also suppose that it falls chronologically near the end of his short career, for we should assume that it was left unfinished at his death
AUTHOR: GIORGIONE
TITLE: Sleeping Venus

DESCRIPTION: The focus of this subsidiary pictorial program, which was probably inspired by Bonaventura's interpretation of St Francis as the angel of the sixth seal, is the Apocalyptic Christ in the capstone of the crossing vault, from whose mouth two swords emerge and whose head, with sweeping white hair, bears a crown.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Apocalyptic Christ

DESCRIPTION: In his right hand he holds the book of divine wisdom with seven seals, toward which the Lamb of God is approaching from the side; in his right hand he is raising a double-bit key.Above Christ, the Lamb of God (at left), and the Arc of the Covenant (at right) are depicted
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Apocalyptic Christ

AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: The Chapel viewed from the entrance

DESCRIPTION: Above the dado level of painted marble Giotto articulates the walls using broad ornamental bands and narrower, horizontal strips.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: The Chapel viewed from the entrance

DESCRIPTION: In so doing it becomes clear how he harmonizes the painted divisions with the existing architecture - to which the row of windows along one side belongs
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: The Chapel viewed from the entrance

DESCRIPTION: The elderly Joachim is denied entry to the temple, as he has remained childless.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 1 Scenes from the Life of Joachim: 1. Rejection of Joachim's Sacrifice

DESCRIPTION: The architecture reinforces the priest's gesture of rejection, to which the saint replies with a saddened look.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 1 Scenes from the Life of Joachim: 1. Rejection of Joachim's Sacrifice

DESCRIPTION: The sheep, as a sacrificial animal that has become superfluous, has a particularly touching effect.The rejection of Joachim's sacrifice and his expulsion from the Temple occurred because of his childlessness.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 1 Scenes from the Life of Joachim: 1. Rejection of Joachim's Sacrifice

DESCRIPTION: Here we are dealing with a true opening picture: the closed architecture of the temple introduces the first idea of solidity, while Joachim's dual movement brings this scene to a close, on the one hand, and on the other paves the way for the rest of the series, which finds a premature conclusion in the last picture of this register, the Meeting at the Golden Gate.The action is also driven forward by the repetition of buildings.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 1 Scenes from the Life of Joachim: 1. Rejection of Joachim's Sacrifice

DESCRIPTION: Thus the temple of the opening picture reappears in the fresco Presentation of Christ at the Temple
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 1 Scenes from the Life of Joachim: 1. Rejection of Joachim's Sacrifice

DESCRIPTION: In the upper section of the lunette above the chancel arch God the Father enthroned is painted, while the sides of the lunette are occupied by the scene of the Annunciation.The border between painted and real space appears to have been breached in Giotto's frescoes.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This characterizes the representation of God the Father at the top of the triumphal arch wall above the entrance to the choir.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The heavens have opened and ranks of angels surround God the Father on his throne.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Amongst the angels, who move elegantly, the depiction of God, with his delicately shimmering, bright robes and his hieratic face, gives the impression of his belonging to a different sphere.This particular effect is also the result of a different painting technique: God the Father is not painted as a fresco on the wall, but in tempera on a wooden panel.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This "door" was presumably opened during the mystery plays performed to celebrate the Feast of the Annunciation, in order that the dove of Annunciation could fly out.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The representation of the Annunciation directly below it is an indication of this.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: In a magnificent way, Giotto here combines the real architecture of the church interior with feigned, painted architectural elements to create a meaningful unity.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: To the right and left of the arch, the angel and Mary kneel in their respective buildings.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: It is only through the connecting architecture that tension is maintained within the depiction of the Annunciation, even over this great, daring distance and separation of figures, and that God the Father — at the top of the triumphal arch — is also included in the action.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: As far as form and content were concerned, Giotto was even here entering new territory
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 13 God Sends Gabriel to the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The Annunciation takes place in the lower section of the fresco on the lunette above the chancel arch, in the two spandrels flanking the chancel arch.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 14 Annunciation: The Angel Gabriel Sent by God

DESCRIPTION: Mary and the Angel of the Annunciation kneel in a narrow building to the left and right of the triumphal arch.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 14 Annunciation: The Angel Gabriel Sent by God

DESCRIPTION: Its jutting balconies are so aligned perspectively that they absorb the real architecture that lies between them, and the triumphal arch thus seems to convey the angel's greeting
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: No. 14 Annunciation: The Angel Gabriel Sent by God
