DESCRIPTION: This Crucifix  (now in the Museo Civico) was painted by Giotto for the Arena Chapel in Padua.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix (front)

DESCRIPTION: It displays a striking similarity to the frescoed Crucifixion in the right transept of the Lower Church of San Francesco at Assisi.Represented on the recto is the Christus patiens, that is, with his eyes closed and in a state of abandon on the arms of the cross.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix (front)

DESCRIPTION: On the extremities of the cross are: above, God the Father; on the left, the Virgin; on the right, St John; and on the foot of the cross, the skull symbolizing Golgotha
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix (front)

DESCRIPTION: The crucifix was first attributed to Giotto by Lorenzo Ghiberti, who in his Commentaries quoted other works of the master in the altars of the church of Ognissanti, like the Virgin of Ognissanti and the Dormitio Virginis.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on fir panel, 468 x 375 cm

DESCRIPTION: Originally it was probably located on the presbytery, dominating the nave and the faithful, near the Virgin of Ognissanti.In poor condition, it was kept in a room adjacent to the basilica and attributed to an artist close to Giotto and possessing great pictorial capacities.The work was restored from 2005 onwards by Opificio delle pietre dura from Florence and was attributed to Giotto himself, for a date which is around 1315.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on fir panel, 468 x 375 cm

DESCRIPTION: On November 6, 2010, the crucifix was reinstalled inside the left transept, enhanced by proper illumination.Intended for the procession, it is in conformity with the monumental representations of Christ in the cross of the time, namely: the Christ on the cross is in the suffering position; the body falling; the belly prominent on its perizonium; the head leaning forward touching the shoulder; the prominent ribs; the bloody wounds; the superimposed feet.The crucifix has small panels with scenes on the ends of the cross: the Virgin Mary on the left clothed in blue, St John on the right, hands clasped, and on top the titulus in red is surmounted by a blessing Christ accompanied by the Book.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on fir panel, 468 x 375 cm

DESCRIPTION: The background contains patterned gold behind the body of Christ.The cleaning and retouching of the blackened cross has revealed individual brush strokes and the bright colour of the lapis lazuli used by the artist.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on fir panel, 468 x 375 cm

DESCRIPTION: This expensive pigment now dominates the background of the work.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on fir panel, 468 x 375 cm

DESCRIPTION: Infrared photography and X-rays studies unearthed clear proof of the authorship of Giotto
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on fir panel, 468 x 375 cm

AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone

DESCRIPTION: In the rows at the front kneeling angels make music, in those at the back the looks and gestures of those present are oriented towards the central event.Both the highly packed hosts of angels praising the Virgin and the huge figures in the central panel indicate that considerable assistance was needed for this work.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Baroncelli Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: Giotto no longer worked with a few individual assistants, but now had a well-organized studio.
AUTHOR: GIOTTO di Bondone
TITLE: Baroncelli Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: We are beginning to identify a number of Giotto's own relations and well-known artists

TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 154 x 43 cm

DESCRIPTION: The main panels with which the upper register has been framed since 1925 represent the Madonna and Child with angels, flanked by, on the left, Sts Augustine and Catherine of Alexandria and, on the right, Sts Appolonia and Nicholas of Tolentino.St Jerome is the most moving of the figural panels in the upper register.
AUTHOR: GIOVANNI ANGELO D'ANTONIO

TITLE: St Jerome

AUTHOR: GIOVANNI ANGELO D'ANTONIO
TITLE: St Jerome
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 154 x 43 cm

DESCRIPTION: Staring at the text through gilded pince-nez, his brows knitted in concentration, he reads aloud, his mouth half open, revealing white teeth.The panels forming the upper register come from the Benedictine abbey in Gualdo Tadino, which must have been the original location of the altarpiece to which they belonged
AUTHOR: GIOVANNI ANGELO D'ANTONIO
TITLE: St Jerome
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 154 x 43 cm

DESCRIPTION: Girodet was Jacques-Louis David's favourite pupil.
AUTHOR: GIRODET DE ROUCY-TRIOSON, Anne-Louis
TITLE: Mademoiselle Lange as Venus

DESCRIPTION: The sense of the mysterious and poetic that he shows in many of his works is what many call the Romantic spirit, although it was already latent in Neoclassicism.
AUTHOR: GIRODET DE ROUCY-TRIOSON, Anne-Louis
TITLE: Mademoiselle Lange as Venus

DESCRIPTION: Girodet sensed the coming direction in an early stage, although he had been trained to be a Neoclassicist by David.Girodet depicted the actress Mademoiselle Lange as Venus, standing on her couch, her face turned from the viewer.
AUTHOR: GIRODET DE ROUCY-TRIOSON, Anne-Louis
TITLE: Mademoiselle Lange as Venus

DESCRIPTION: In the mirror that Cupid is holding up to her, the painter, who delighted in hidden references, has shown only one ear.
AUTHOR: GIRODET DE ROUCY-TRIOSON, Anne-Louis
TITLE: Mademoiselle Lange as Venus

DESCRIPTION: When the actress expressed her annoyance at the painting, Girodet painted her again, this time in mythological form, Mademoiselle Lange as Danaë.The toilet of Venus is a timeless theme of sensuous seduction.
AUTHOR: GIRODET DE ROUCY-TRIOSON, Anne-Louis
TITLE: Mademoiselle Lange as Venus

DESCRIPTION: You can view other depictions of Venus at Her Toilet in the Web Gallery of Art

DESCRIPTION: The Camerino dei Cesari (Chamber of the Caesars) was perhaps the most famous room in Federico Gonzaga's apartment in the Palazzo Ducale.
AUTHOR: GIULIO ROMANO
TITLE: Emperor Alexander

DESCRIPTION: Giulio Romano designed the complex decoration of this room, which centred on frescoed scenes of classical subjects on the vault, now only partially preserved; the series of stuccoed niches around the upper part of the wall, which contained bronze statues, and the famous series of eleven Roman emperors painted by Titian between 1536 and 1540.
AUTHOR: GIULIO ROMANO
TITLE: Emperor Alexander

DESCRIPTION: Wooden panels inserted into a framework beneath them illustrates scenes from the lives of Caesars and ancient knights and were painted by Giulio's pupils
AUTHOR: GIULIO ROMANO

DESCRIPTION: The naked, athletic St John the Baptist sits on a stony outcrop of a grotto-like rock formation that forms a dark background for his brilliantly lit figure.
AUTHOR: GIULIO ROMANO
TITLE: St John the Baptist in the Wilderness

DESCRIPTION: The spring rising close by can be read as a symbol of baptism
AUTHOR: GIULIO ROMANO
TITLE: St John the Baptist in the Wilderness

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the scenes from the life of Christ, which are depicted on the north wall
AUTHOR: GIUSTO de' Menabuoi
TITLE: The Wedding at Cana

DESCRIPTION: Gleyre handled Oriental themes as well as his antique Neoclassical subjects.
AUTHOR: GLEYRE, Charles-Gabriel
TITLE: The Queen of Sheba

DESCRIPTION: Numerous watercolours document his travels and depict ruined Egyptian temples.
AUTHOR: GLEYRE, Charles-Gabriel
TITLE: The Queen of Sheba

DESCRIPTION: In adventurous compilations of oriental components he succeeded in intensifying the fairy-tale element into historic imaginative depictions, as in the Queen of Sheba, which is fantastic and theatrical in both colouring and scenery
AUTHOR: GLEYRE, Charles-Gabriel
TITLE: The Queen of Sheba

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows the view of Port Glasgow and Greenock on the Firth of Clyde, the Argyll Hills beyond
AUTHOR: GLOVER, John
TITLE: View of Port Glasgow

DESCRIPTION: Glover had a house at Blowick Farm near Patterdale, at the foot of Ullswater Lake, and spent much of his time in the Lake District.
AUTHOR: GLOVER, John
TITLE: View of Keswick, in the Lake District, Cumberland

DESCRIPTION: He was so fond of the region that, when in Tasmania, where he settled from 1831, he reminiscently named his house Patterdale
AUTHOR: GLOVER, John
TITLE: View of Keswick, in the Lake District, Cumberland

DESCRIPTION: The major painting of Van der Goes's third period (between around 1478 and 1482) and very likely one of the last works he painted is the Death of the Virgin.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The panel is almost square in shape.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The scene is set in a totally enclosed room.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The apostles are grouped around Mary's bed.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin's fine blue robe contrast with the purple sheets that cover the bed.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Her livid gray face is framed by the immaculate whiteness of her wimple, and of the cushion on which her head rests.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Her hands are joined, her fingers look quite bony.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Her eyes have lost their lustre.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: She looks up one last time towards the heavens, where her Son appears to her in His glory with arms outstretched, to display the wounds in his hands.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: He is dressed in a blue robe and a large red cloak held up by two angels.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The picture represents the moment at which life has already gently slipped away, but death has not yet completed its work.The painter uses the apostles to ring the changes on the different varieties of grief, and their profound sadness contrasts with the detachment of the Virgin herself.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Their clothes have been creased into countless shifting folds which cut across one another at right angles.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Van der Goes is revealed as a penetrating analyst of religious feeling, of grief and devotion, and of the agitation they can cause.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This work, like all those he painted during his last period, represents the eruption of sacred experience into a profane world.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The artist achieves this through an abundant use of colours which strike the viewer as unreal, as if they were themselves transfigured.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: In this way, Van der Goes seeks to identify his painting with the mystery of transcendence itself.To this end too, the gestures of his figures are emphatic.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: He uses techniques or the progressive reduction of pictorial space and the transformation of figures, which he paints half-length, not full length
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: The Death of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Soberly painted in monochrome, the panels are entirely occupied by the Archangel Gabriel and the Virgin of the Annunciation.
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: Portinari Triptych (closed)

DESCRIPTION: The enormous figures are portrayed under a series of perspectively receding arches and in an extremely bare, linear setting, enriched only by the copious folds of the robes surrounding the figures
AUTHOR: GOES, Hugo van der
TITLE: Portinari Triptych (closed)

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 19, JH 409.Unlike some earlier paintings which he did back in The Hague, in this painting van Gogh scarcely attempts any solidarity with the farming people's arduous labours.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Two Peasant Women in the Peat Field

DESCRIPTION: The massive blocks of colour that serve as the women's silhouettes have a self-referential in the more or less decorative way that the two figures appear in sequential rapport
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Two Peasant Women in the Peat Field

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 34, JH 459.The the tower of the old ruined village church standing alone in the middle of the field appeared in the earliest works which van Gogh painted in Nuenen.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Old Tower of Nuenen with a Ploughman

DESCRIPTION: He was greatly attracted to this sturdy ruin, which he could see from the house and which he painted and drew on many occasions
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Old Tower of Nuenen with a Ploughman

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 30, JH 479.In Nuenen between January and August 1884, van Gogh depicted the figure of the weaver working at the loom in several pen drawings, watercolours and oil paintings.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Weaver, Seen from the Front

DESCRIPTION: In this small village of Northern-Brabant, to where his parents moved in September 1882, more than four hundred people took up weaving, an activity of domestic industry during the winter months, when agricultural labour was suspended.The chronology of the series could be determined by the development in representing the loom.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Weaver, Seen from the Front

DESCRIPTION: As time went by, van Gogh depicted the loom with more and more precision, abandoning the anecdotal elements and concentrating on the work process and on the machine itself
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Weaver, Seen from the Front

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 185, JH 484.Van Gogh lived in Nuenen between December 1883 and November 1885, first in the house of his father who was the pastor of the Nuenen parish.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on panel, 25 x 57 cm

DESCRIPTION: He made drawings and oil paintings of the parental gardens as well as the street façade and the garden façade of the parsonage.From the garden of the parsonage there was a good view of the tower of the old ruined village church.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on panel, 25 x 57 cm

DESCRIPTION: This old tower standing alone in the middle of the field appeared in the earliest works which van Gogh painted in Nuenen.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on panel, 25 x 57 cm

DESCRIPTION: He was greatly attracted to this sturdy ruin, which he could see from the house and which he painted and drew on many occasions
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Parsonage Garden at Nuenen in Spring
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper on panel, 25 x 57 cm

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 25, JH 521.Van Gogh painted this detached view of the village church, which was the place of his father's spiritual ministry, for his parents, and he chose the Sunday churchgoing as his subject
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Chapel at Nuenen with Churchgoers

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 158, JH 792.Van Gogh showed, in several drawings and paintings, women absorbed in work in the solitude of their homes.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 29 x 40 cm

DESCRIPTION: Sewing, spooling thread, peeling potatoes, shelling beans and preparing food were among the most frequently depicted subjects.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 29 x 40 cm

DESCRIPTION: During the day, light shone into the dark rooms through the windows, whereas lamp- or firelight illuminated the models in the evening.In the present painting the woman sitting to the right of the fire is peeling a potato.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 29 x 40 cm

DESCRIPTION: A kettle is boiling over the fire, hanging from a chain barely visible in the curling smoke.Van Gogh's Nuenen interiors of peasant women engaged in their work convey a certain timelessness and reflect the influence of 17th-century Dutch genre painting
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Peasant Woman by the Fireplace
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 29 x 40 cm

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 212, JH 999.This painting is in many ways the key Antwerp picture by van Gogh.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Skull with Burning Cigarette

DESCRIPTION: He was mocking the procedure in drawing classes, where a skeleton invariably served as the basis of anatomical studies.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Skull with Burning Cigarette

DESCRIPTION: The lifelessness of the skeleton represented the very opposite of what van Gogh wanted a picture to express.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Skull with Burning Cigarette

DESCRIPTION: With the burning cigarette jammed in its teeth, the skeleton, though still nothing but dead bones, has acquired a grotesquely funny hint of life
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Skull with Burning Cigarette

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 278, JH 1103
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Vase with Poppies, Cornflowers, Peonies and Chrysanthemums

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 213, JH 1247.Van Gogh arrived in Paris in March 1886.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: Although he was able to see a considerable amount of contemporary French painting by the Impressionists and their followers - Seurat's Sunday Afternoon on the Island of the Grande Jatte was exhibited twice in 1886 - he took little notice for at least a year.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: As a letter written to an English artist he had met in Antwerp reveals, he continued with what he had been doing in Antwerp.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: He enrolled again in an atelier, where he could draw and paint the nude from plaster casts and live models.Since he could ill afford to hire models, he painted large numbers of still-lifes of flowers in order to study the colour theory of Hals and Delacroix.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: He wrote that he was 'trying to render intense colour and not a grey harmony'.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: The present painting indicates to what extent he had accomplished this aim.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: It also demonstrates the now varied ways in which he applied his paint: dashes in the background to break up the blue field of the wall, directional brushstrokes on the table, impasto highlights on the metal vase.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: The plant itself is virtually drawn in colour; each leaf is a separate stroke and the heads of the flowers are depicted with more voluptuous and solid sweeps of paint
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Fritillaries in a Copper Vase

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 313, JH 1251.This picture shows an inviting restaurant in Asnières.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: Van Gogh's unique facility for communicating his feelings directly by means of his brushwork is already in evidence.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: The light and the associated atmospheric effects have become the actual subject of the picture, very much in the spirit of the Impressionists.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: Although still restrained, the painting is defined in terms of colour by contrasting complementary colours: blue and orange, red and green.By the middle of 1887 a dramatic change of style has occurred in van Gogh's work.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: Using these characteristically 'impressionist' motifs of a restaurant on the outskirts of Paris, van Gogh seems to have been willing to experiment with Impressionist techniques as well.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: However, the painting lacks a sense of substance and conviction, which reflects his difficulty in feeling himself as part of the world he is portraying.In the two years van Gogh spent in Paris he tried to assimilate French Impressionism, only to find that a new generation of painters were questioning its premises regarding both subject-matter and style.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: His flirtation with Impressionist subject-matter was brief; encounters with the Neo-Impressionists led him to believe that Paris could no longer be the subject of modern French painting
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Restaurant de la Sir?ne at Asni?res

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 363, JH 1351.The sitter in this portrait was the colour-merchant Tanguy, a Breton peasant who had settled in Paris and ran a small paint shop in the Rue Clauzel, much frequented by vanguard artists.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: His shop had become a kind of gallery of their paintings, for Tanguy would take paintings on deposit as credit for the painting materials he supplied.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: Van Gogh painted two portraits of Père Tanguy in the autumn and early winter of 1887, both against a background composed of Japanese colour woodcuts which he had begun to collect, firstly in Antwerp and then more avidly in Paris.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: Tanguy is placed massively in the centre of the canvas, facing the spectator.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: But the Paris merchant is presented not against an urban or even French setting, but in an imaginary context composed of Japanese seasonal scenes and costumed figures.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: Although this choice of background indicates van Gogh's evident preoccupation with Japanese prints - he also made individual copies of selected prints at this date - the painting does not indicate any profound influence of Japanese graphic styles or perspectival devices upon his work.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: But it is important to note that the motifs represented in the prints anticipate those that van Gogh would shortly resume when he left Paris and moved once again into a more rural setting - seasonal landscapes and portraits of regional types in costume.In his portraits of ordinary people van Gogh emphasized their sadness, dignity and kindness.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: The Portrait of Père Tanguy is a good example
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Portrait of P?re Tanguy

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 392, JH 1361.In February 1888 van Gogh left for Arles in southern France where he wanted to paint orchards in blossom.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Blossoming Almond Branch in a Glass

DESCRIPTION: As a matter of fact, the south welcomed him with snow.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Blossoming Almond Branch in a Glass

DESCRIPTION: Unperturbed, he broke a budding twig off a tree and put it in a glass of water, waiting for blossoms
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Blossoming Almond Branch in a Glass

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 412 JH 1440.Van Gogh's production in Arles fell into a number of series, one of which comprised landscape paintings on the theme of the seasons.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: The original idea for a seasonal series, in which each season would be represented by a pair of complementary colours, had been put forward in Nuenen in 1884.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: On arrival in Arles in March 1888 van Gogh began to paint a series of canvases of blossoming orchards in pinks and greens entitled Spring.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: In June he painted Summer in blue and orange, represented by the harvest on the plain of La Crau, which lay between Arles and the ruined monastery of Montmajour.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: The painting is a pendant of the Haystacks in Provence (F 425).
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: It was an important work for van Gogh; he made two preliminary drawings of the motif and when the painting was finished he made two further drawings after it.In the painting, the viewpoint is high and thus the great plain is laid out beneath us, receding more gradually to the distant towers of Montmajour and the hills beyond.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: Van Gogh often described the plain of La Crau in his letters, saying that apart from differences of colour it reminded him constantly of Holland, but not of modern Holland.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: In this landscape he saw the landscape paintings of the seventeenth-century artists Ruisdael and De Koninck, who were both famous for their panoramic landscapes
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Harvest at La Crau (The Blue Cart)

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 422, JH 1470.The plain of La Crau spreads to the southeast of Arles.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Sower

DESCRIPTION: It is as flat as van Gogh's native country.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Sower

DESCRIPTION: La Crau is surrounded on all sides by hills.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Sower

DESCRIPTION: These offered van Gogh an opportunity to escape the flatland, to withdraw to a greater distance from where he commanded a panoramic view of the whole region.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Sower

DESCRIPTION: The figure of sower is depicted on the broad plain of La Crau.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Sower

DESCRIPTION: This painting follows van Gogh's depictions of the harvest, just as in reality the sower does his sowing only when the reaping has been completed and the fields are fallow.The figure of the sower is quoted from an early drawing by van Gogh in which he was copying Millet
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: The Sower

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 455, JH 1668.This painting is a copy with minor variations of the original Vase with Twelve Sunflowers (F 456) made a few months befor
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Sunflowers

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 604, JH 1656.This cheerful still-life was painted shortly after van Gogh left the hospital in Arles which he had entered after his first major attack of psychomotor epilepsy on 25 December 1888.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: The objects depicted have both an allegorical and a more personal significance.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: The lighted candle, used in the painting of Gauguin's chair, derives from the emblematic tradition of still-life and signifies light and life; its opposite, the snuffed-out candle, was used in memento mori still-life and van Gogh had included it in a still-life with books which he painted after his father's death in 1885 (Amsterdam, Rijksmuseum Vincent van Gogh).
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: The optimistic note sounded by the candle flame is underlined by the presence of the sprouting onions, taken from his Yellow Chair (a 'self-portrait').
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: On the other hand, van Gogh has added his pipe and tobacco and an empty bottle, possibly once containing absinthe, all of which endangered his health.Modern research has intriguingly shown that absinthe itself can cause epileptic fits.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: Van Gogh had consumed this poisonous beverage in some quantity during the months in Arles, and many of his subsequent fits coincide with occasions on which he had access to it.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: The drawing board on which most of these objects are placed indicates van Gogh's resumption of work.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: He informed his brother that he was painting still-lifes to ease himself back into painting after his hospitalization.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

DESCRIPTION: However, the colours used in this painting are more tempered and less intense, more controlled and less arbitrary than those he had been using both in the summer of 1888 and under the aegis of Gauguin in the autumn preceding his attack
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Still-Life with Drawing Board and Onions

AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van

AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 807, JH 1980

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 541, JH 1893.Working from the large-format portrait drawing that Gauguin left in Arles at the end of December 1888, van Gogh returned to the subject of the Arlésienne in January 1890, simultaneously drawing on his reinterpretation of Madame Ginoux with Books of 1888 (F 488).
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: L'Arlésienne (Madame Ginoux)

DESCRIPTION: As yet untitled in the painting of that year, the books accompanying Madame Ginoux in subsequent variant all bear the same two titles: Harriet Beecher-Stove's Uncle Tom's Cabin and Charles Dickens's A Christmas Carol.Four of the five original variants of the portrait survived, they are in the Rijksmuseum Kröller-Müller, Otterlo, in the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Moderna e Contemporanea, Rome, in the Museu de Arte, São Paulo, and in a private collection

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue numbers: F 522, JH 1356.Shortly before he left Paris and moved to Provence in late February 1888, van Gogh painted this final self-portrait.

AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van

DESCRIPTION: He stands before his easel, holding his palette in a pose intentionally reminiscent of a self-portrait by Rembrandt which was then in the Louvre and well known to van Gogh.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

DESCRIPTION: Perhaps the painting should be read as a kind of manifesto of the new orientation in his conception of himself as an artist and of his work - the intention to remove himself from the city and its bourgeois lifestyle, and the desire to be seen in a Dutch rather than a French tradition.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

DESCRIPTION: The painting also betrays a growing confidence in himself as an artist: he appears with the insignia of his profession.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

DESCRIPTION: Greater assurance is also evident in the handling.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

DESCRIPTION: The earlier extreme experimentation with pure or broken colour and a textured and structuring brushwork has given way to a more controlled and coherent treatment.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

DESCRIPTION: In the pose he has used, van Gogh evokes Rembrandt; but the painterly treatment and coloration remind us of another seventeenth-century Dutch artist - Frans Hals.
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

DESCRIPTION: The lessons van Gogh had learnt in Antwerp, explored in greater depth throughout the Paris period, are now successfully integrated into his work to produce a distinctive style
AUTHOR: GOGH, Vincent van
TITLE: Self-Portrait in front of the Easel

AUTHOR: GOYA Y LUCIENTES, Francisco de
TITLE: The Fall (La Caída)

DESCRIPTION: La Caída is described in Goya's account for the paintings submitted on 12 May 1787: 'an excursion in hilly country, with a woman in a faint after a fall from an ass; she is assisted by an abbot and another man who support her in their arms; two other women mounted on asses [and] expressing emotion and another figure of a servant form the main group and others who had fallen behind are seen in the distance, and a landscape to correspond.
AUTHOR: GOYA Y LUCIENTES, Francisco de
TITLE: The Fall (La Caída)

DESCRIPTION: 'Though on a smaller scale, this series of decorative paintings is similar in style and character to the tapestry cartoons; but unlike the tapestry cartoons it includes some scenes, such as La Caída, which appear to represent actual occurrences.

DESCRIPTION: The tonal style in Dutch landscape painting of the 1630s continued well into the 1640s, while still developing, especially in the hands of Jan van Goyen.
AUTHOR: GOYEN, Jan van
TITLE: Windmill by a River

DESCRIPTION: The direction in which van Goyen took landscape reveals a considered logic; as tonal painting was a realistic attempt to capture an atmosphere, its consequence was, in the end, to paint the sky over the flat, low land.
AUTHOR: GOYEN, Jan van
TITLE: Windmill by a River

DESCRIPTION: Thus, in his "Windmill by a River", the real subject is the moving skies.Everything is subordinated to the high sky, a sky that seems to take on the colour of the vast land stretching to a low, distant horizon: a brownish-green with tinges of blue.
AUTHOR: GOYEN, Jan van
TITLE: Windmill by a River

DESCRIPTION: Only the sky contains more grey - the clouds - and is more transparent in its pictorial treatment.
AUTHOR: GOYEN, Jan van
TITLE: Windmill by a River

DESCRIPTION: Dunes in the foreground, caught in a splash of sunlight, introduce the distance - suggesting a high viewpoint that gives the view naturalness.
AUTHOR: GOYEN, Jan van
TITLE: Windmill by a River

DESCRIPTION: The windmill, painted in the greyish-brown colour of the sky, is a discreet spatial reference point
AUTHOR: GOYEN, Jan van
TITLE: Windmill by a River

DESCRIPTION: In his late paintings Van Goyen was interested in capturing in his paintings the states of weather, and the effects of clouds in response to meteorological conditions.

DESCRIPTION: The concentrically painted clouds create the impression of a circular vault
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo

TITLE: St Nicholas of Bari (on the pillar)

DESCRIPTION: He is holding three golden balls in his hand, which according to the so-called legend of the virgins he gave to three impoverished girls so that they would have a dowry befitting their station and would not be disgraced
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Nicholas of Bari (on the pillar)

DESCRIPTION: The eight saints standing in niches on the fronts and sides of the choir pillars are important elements in the design.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo

AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: Tobias and the Fish

DESCRIPTION: This little panel was part of a predella from an altarpiece of the Madonna, Angels and Saints, which was commissioned by the Confraternity of the Purification of the Virgin, in Florence.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Dominic Reuscitates Napoleone Orsini

DESCRIPTION: On October 23, 1461, the contract for the painting was drawn up.

DESCRIPTION: It is a remarkable document in the number and precision of its stipulations and instructions.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Dominic Reuscitates Napoleone Orsini

DESCRIPTION: The painter was asked to use Fra Angelico's altarpiece at San Marco as a model and to execute the entire work by his own hand, with the greatest care.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Dominic Reuscitates Napoleone Orsini

DESCRIPTION: One clause stated that "...the said painting must go beyond all the good painting done up to now by the said Benozzo, or at least should be comparable in quality..."The artist scrupulously observed the conditions of the contract.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Dominic Reuscitates Napoleone Orsini

DESCRIPTION: His composition is clearly articulated, with the initial episode of the narrative placed in the middle ground.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Dominic Reuscitates Napoleone Orsini

DESCRIPTION: The culminating moment of the miracle is brought forward toward the spectator by the figures of the women and the monks, who are following the silent dialogue between the saint and the resuscitated child
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: St Dominic Reuscitates Napoleone Orsini

DESCRIPTION: In the centre of the Shrine of the Madonna della Tosse the Madonna breast feeding the Child is depicted.

DESCRIPTION: She is surrounded by St Peter with the keys and a book, St Catherine with a broken wheel, St Margaret with a cross, and St Paul with a sword and book.
AUTHOR: GOZZOLI, Benozzo
TITLE: Maria Lactans

DESCRIPTION: In order to create the impression of a real altarpiece, several angels are holding a curtain around the altar painting.

DESCRIPTION: At the bottom edge of the picture, as if placed there quite by chance, Benozzo has painted a small pointed panel painting showing the face of Christ

TITLE: Maria Lactans

TITLE: Portrait of a Lady

DESCRIPTION: In the painting she is seated full length, dressed in a yellow and blue dress with a red cloak, playing an english guitar from a music score
AUTHOR: GRASSI, Józef
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady

DESCRIPTION: De Grebber's full length composition featuring the Baptism of Christ concentrates exclusively on the story's principal protagonists, eliminating the febrile animation and artifice, the squirming and twisted gestures, even the ancillary witnesses and much of the setting, present in earlier depictions of the subject by Romanist or Mannerist artists.
AUTHOR: GREBBER, Pieter de
TITLE: Baptism of Christ

DESCRIPTION: This composition focuses on Christ and St John and confers on them a monumental, classical repose
AUTHOR: GREBBER, Pieter de
TITLE: Baptism of Christ

DESCRIPTION: The format, colour, and contrasts of light within this painting suggest that de Grebber was influenced by the intimate and solemn portraits painted by Rembrandt and Lievens in the 1620s.The painter reused an old panel that once depicted the expulsion of Adam and Eve from the Garden of Eden.
AUTHOR: GREBBER, Pieter de
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: Details of the work underneath remain faintly visible to the naked eye
AUTHOR: GREBBER, Pieter de
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: This unsigned painting evinces a similar technique as the signed ("by the hand of Domenikos") Modena Triptych, which is a key reference work for the early paintings of El Greco.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: In the Last Supper the perspective space is still quite simply structured.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: The figures have little corporeal volume and seem more to hover than actually to sit at the long table
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: Painted for the attic of the High Altarpiece of Santo Domingo el Antiguo, Toledo, to go above the Assumption.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: Probably painted 1577-78, following the Assumption.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: It was El Greco's first commission upon his arrival in Toleedo in 1577.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: It gained great fame in Toledo, which was artistically rather archaic and provincial, and established a successful career for El Greco in the town.Here the reference is to Rome, rather than to Venice, and specifically to Michelangelo, developing the motif of the Pietà.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: The general scheme of the composition of the Trinity, however, refers to Dürer's engraving of the same subject.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: The composition continues that of the Assumption below, slowing down the upward movement which finally comes to rest in the supported shoulders of Christ.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: Form is more in evidence here than in the Assumption, especially in the Michelangelesque motif of the naked Christ (for which the artist probably drew inspiration from Michelangelo's  Pietà for Vittoria Colonna), and it is only later that he treats his figures with the same freedom as draperies.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: Here the suggestion of weight in the supported Dead Christ is appropriate.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: The stress on the dead body of Christ, together with the clamorous mannerist colors and the rather loose composition of the figures, produces a feverish pathos.El Greco was not to repeat this subject
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Trinity

DESCRIPTION: After a short period of study in Greece, El Greco, one of the most renowned figure in Spanish art, went to Venice in the middle of the sixteenth century, where he worked in Titian's workshop, and where he became familiar with the art of Paolo Veronese, Jacopo Bassano and Tintoretto, as well as works by representatives of the North Italian Mannerist school.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: Later, in Rome, he was strongly influenced by the work of Michelangelo.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: By the time he had settled in Toledo around 1576, his art was fully developed.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: Like most of the painters coming from Italy, he was anxious to enter the service of King Philip II, but the Greek painter's immediacy of passion, ecstatic style, disturbing colours and visionary conceptions did not please the king's academic Italian taste.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: He was, however, appreciated by the religious orders and the aristocratic patrons of Toledo.The penitent Magdalen must have been painted at the beginning of his years in Toledo because the strong influence of paintings on the same theme by Titian can be observed.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: The ideal of beauty is still Titian's half-figure pictures of women, but the inner tension of the whole composition and the relation between man and nature already indicate the beginning of Mannerism.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: The arrangement of the fingers of the right hand is a characteristic feature of El Greco's painting.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: It is assumed by some critics that the sitter of the painting was Jerónima de las Cuevas, the mistress of the artist
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Mary Magdalen in Penitence

DESCRIPTION: This formerly unknown signed painting was found during an inventory of the artworks in 1966 in Poland.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Ecstasy of St Francis

DESCRIPTION: El Greco painted many representations of St Francis, all showing him in meditation, receiving the stigmata or experiencing a vision.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El

DESCRIPTION: Devotion to St Francis was highly developed in Spain, and in El Greco's time there were in Toledo alone ten Franciscan religious institutions.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Francis Receiving the Stigmata

DESCRIPTION: Many ordinary Toledans were members of the Third Order of Saint Francis, established so that lay people could participate in the spiritual life of the Franciscans.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Francis Receiving the Stigmata

DESCRIPTION: (El Greco himself was a lay Franciscan.)
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Francis Receiving the Stigmata

DESCRIPTION: This serves to explain the success of El Greco's images of the saint.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Francis Receiving the Stigmata

DESCRIPTION: Painted for the high altar of the Colegio de Doña Maria, Madrid.

TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: The retable no longer exists, and the paintings are dispersed.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: The subjects of the paintings of the retable are not recorded, but it is assumed that they illustrated the Life of Christ.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: For reasons of size, style, and subject matter, the following paintings probably came from the retable: the Annunciation, the widest painting, in the centre (the church was dedicated to the Virgin of the Annunciation); the Adoration of the Shepherds and the Baptism of Christ, two paintings of the same size, on the left and right of the Annunciation; the Crucifixion above the Annunciation; and the Resurrection and Pentecost, another pair of identical size, flanking the Crucifixion (the whole forming a retable of a type known in the Escorial).
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: Such an arrangement gives a chronological sequence to the events of the Life of Christ.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: The payment of 6000 ducados (for the paintings and retable) indicate a large commission.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: Small versions, probably models, exist for the three paintings more generally accepted as belonging to the retable, the Annunciation, the Adoration of the Shepherds and the Baptism of Christ.Probably originally on the right of the retable of the Colegio de Doña María, balancing the Adoration of the Shepherds, and painted at the same time.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: A small version, possibly the model for the large painting, is in the Galleria Corsini, Rome.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: A later development of this subject, only treated once before, in the Modena Triptych, is the painting for the Hospital de San Juan Bautista, Toledo, probably completed after his death by Jorge Manuel.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: The pose of the Christ is related to that of the Saint Sebastian of c.

DESCRIPTION: The bipartite composition can be related to the Burial of the Count of Orgaz, the portraits giving place to the range of angels.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: The splendid ecstatic figure of the angel, between the Baptist and Christ, is one of a number of such symbols that he began to introduce into his painting.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: If his figures - the actual participants in the action - become increasingly dematerialised, these new symbols appear as emotions materialised in gesture and colour
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Baptism

DESCRIPTION: This painting was made for the Capilla de San José (Chapel of Saint Joseph) in Toledo, originally it was placed on the left-hand side of the high altar.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Martin and the Beggar

DESCRIPTION: The paintings for the high altar (still in place) were the Saint Joseph and the Christ Child, and above, the Coronation of the Virgin; and, for the side altars, the Saint Martin and the Beggar and the Virgin and Child with Saints were placed.Clad in gold damascened armour with a ruff typical of fashionable Toledan dress in El Greco's day, St Martin is shown astride a white horse as he prepares to cut his bright green cloak in half in order to share it with the beggar who stands on the left.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Martin and the Beggar

DESCRIPTION: Below, a distant and freely painted view of Toledo shows the Alcántara bridge and the river Tagus.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Martin and the Beggar

DESCRIPTION: The gleaming whiteness of the horse and the shining gold-damascene work on Martin's armour contrast with the darkening sky behind.The painting is from the Widener Collection.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Martin and the Beggar

DESCRIPTION: There is a nearly identical smaller version of the subject also in the National Gallery of Art, Washington, from the Mellon Collection
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Martin and the Beggar

DESCRIPTION: The dragon in the goblet held by the figure on the left is from a legend of John the Evangelist, the turbulent heavens behind him express divine inspiration.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Sts John and Francis

DESCRIPTION: Against a serene sky, Francis displays his wounded hands - the saint is said to have miraculously received the stigmata of Christ on the Cross
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Sts John and Francis

DESCRIPTION: There are many versions of The Agony in the Garden painted by El Greco and his workshop, it was one of his most successful inventions.

DESCRIPTION: He painted the subject both as a horizontal and as a vertical composition.

TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The version in Andújar is probably the prime version of the vertical type.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: There are other vertical versions in Cuenca, Spain, in Budapest and in Buenos Aires.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: In collaboration with his son Jorge Manuel in 1603-07, El Greco executed an extensive programme of pictures for the Hospital de la Caridad in Illescas: a Madonna of Charity, a Coronation of the Virgin, an Annunciation, and a Nativity.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: Under a separate contract a further picture was made, of St Ildefonso, who was particularly important for Toledo.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: The painting is in the side altar on the left of the main chapel of the church, balancing the Virgin of Charity.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: Its original place in the church is not known.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: The painting is not mentioned in the incomplete documentation for the decoration of the chapel, and if, as is probable, it was not painted at the same time, it cannot date much before June 1603, the date of the contract, and was more likely painted soon after the conclusion of litigation in August 1607.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: In its present position, it makes a grand pair to the Virgin of Charity, and is one of the most splendid of his 'portraits' of Saints.It is difficult, and perhaps not proper, to separate his portraits of Saints from his actual portraits.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: In both he employs all his means of spiritual or psychological expression.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: The legend is that Saint Ildefonso, the first Bishop of Toledo, presented an image of the Virgin of the Mantle to a foundation of his in Illescas.

TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: The Saint is portrayed before the same image, as he wrote his dissertation on the Purity of the Virgin.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: The state of inspiration is brilliantly expressed.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: There is an infinite distinction in expression between the hand poised with the pen in this 'portrait' and the similar motif in the portrait of his son.In his depiction of St Ildefonso, El Greco anticipated a Baroque motif, that of the learned churchman.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: As if receiving inspiration, the saint is seated at a desk covered with an array of utensils that is unusually detailed for the artist.There is a smaller replica of the picture in the National Gallery of Art in Washington.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: It belonged once to the painter Jean François Millet, and later to Edgar Degas
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: St Ildefonso

DESCRIPTION: There are many versions of The Agony in the Garden painted by El Greco and his workshop, it was one of his most successful inventions.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: He painted the subject both as a horizontal and as a vertical composition.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The version in the Budapest museum is a good example of the vertical type.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: There are other vertical versions in Andújar, in Cuenca and in Buenos Aires.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The intervention of El Greco's workshop can be assumed in all these paintings.In his religious compositions and portraits El Greco frequently repeated themes from his major works, with slight alterations, to meet different commissions.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: He broke away from the Renaissance tradition and ceased to depict reality and nature.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: In order to convey mystic emotions and to imbue his work with passion he distorted and elongated the forms and used stridently blazing colours to express the transcendental.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The Agony in the Garden is such mystic interpretation representative of El Greco's late years and mature style.The painting depicts the last night of Christ on the Mount of Olives.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: In the foreground the tired pupils are sleeping, their unnaturally rigid robes refer to the wax models which the aged master used.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: Above them Christ is kneeling while an angel appears.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The scene is a grassy clearing which looks like to be a lighted stage.

TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: In the background the soldiers are gathering
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: The Agony in the Garden

DESCRIPTION: The identity of the sitter was only established in 1988, despite the fact that the portrait must record a prominent figure.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: A Prelate

DESCRIPTION: He was identified with Francisco de Pisa (c.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: A Prelate

DESCRIPTION: 1537-1616), Professor of Holy Scripture at Toledo University, the author of a major history of Toledo and a prominent figure in ecclesiastical affairs in the city.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: A Prelate

DESCRIPTION: The identification rests on the striking resemblance between his features and those of a documented miniature of Francisco de Pisa in a private collection, that was, at one time, ascribed to El Greco himself.The open book displayed on the table is identified by lettering on its pages as BOSIUS CANONICI, presumably an edition or commentary on the corpus of canon law.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: A Prelate

DESCRIPTION: The author of the text is probably Francesco Bossi or Bosio (1500/10-1584), who specialized in law.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: A Prelate

DESCRIPTION: In Rome Bossi was closely associated with Carlo Borromeo, one of the key figures of the Catholic reform
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: A Prelate

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed 'doménikos theotokópoulos epoiei'.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Gentleman

DESCRIPTION: The attribution to El Greco is universally accepted by critics
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Gentleman

DESCRIPTION: El Greco painted several views of Toledo.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: View and Plan of Toledo

DESCRIPTION: Seen beneath mountainous clouds the city stirred his imagination and in this painting, as in others, the representation includes an element of fantasy and is not strictly accurate.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: View and Plan of Toledo

DESCRIPTION: In the El Greco Museum there is a painting in which a young man is seen holding up a map of the city.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: View and Plan of Toledo

DESCRIPTION: The map partially corrects the view of the city in which, to improve the composition as the inscription tells us, El Greco gave the Hospital of Don Juan Tavera a central place in the picture; transferring it from its actual setting so that the façade could be shown without blocking out the other important buildings.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: View and Plan of Toledo

DESCRIPTION: In the upper part of the picture there is a scene in which the Virgin presents a vestment to St Ildefonso.
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: View and Plan of Toledo

DESCRIPTION: The landscape is painted in brownish-green and blue tints, and the mythological and religious elements are minimal; with his pictures of Toledo El Greco created the Spanish landscape, a branch of art which was nevertheless neglected until the emergence of Velázquez.It is sometimes supposed that the young man is a portrait of El Greco's son, who was, however, at least thirty years old at that time
AUTHOR: GRECO, El
TITLE: View and Plan of Toledo

DESCRIPTION: Born to humble beginnings as the daughter of a seamstress, the Comtesse du Barry (1746-1793), née Marie Jeanne Bécu, rose to become one of the most famous figures in the court of Louis XV.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Portrait of the Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Her influence was born out of her legendary powers of seduction, which she used to gain the title of Maîtresse-en-titre (chief mistress of the King of France), the last to fill the position in the court of Louis XV.Madame du Barry's support for the arts was also legendary, and she came to amass one of the great collections in France in the 18th century.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Portrait of the Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: She had her portrait painted by some of the leading artists of the day, including Louise Élisabeth Vigée-Lebrun, François-Hubert Drouais, and Jean-Baptiste Greuze
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Portrait of the Comtesse du Barry

DESCRIPTION: Greuze was also a portrait painter, occasionally revealing the influence of Rembrandt in his use of light
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Portrait of Joseph, Model at Art Academy

DESCRIPTION: Greuze was in his late 50s when he conceived of this portrait of himself.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: It was a difficult period for him personally, because his notoriously difficult marriage was finally coming apart, but at the same time he was painting some of his most important genre pictures.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: In these he created scenes from contemporary life that combined an unblinkered view of the world around him with a style derived from the grand manner of the traditional historical painter.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: His penetrating insight into his subjects' motivation and personality is also evident in the portraits and self-portraits of which he made many at this time.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: This painting by Greuze is frankly Poussin-like.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Septimius Severus and Caracalla

DESCRIPTION: The artist wished to be recognized as a history painter; he chose an obscure subject to illustrate:  Septimius Severus Roman emperor (146-211) reproaches his son, Caracalla for trying to assasinate him.
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Septimius Severus and Caracalla

DESCRIPTION: Varied emotions are at work within it: from Caracalla's angry shame to the surprise of the chamberlain, Castor, at the emperor's recklessly heroic gesture which is at once a challenge and a rebuke
AUTHOR: GREUZE, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Septimius Severus and Caracalla

DESCRIPTION: Abel Grimmer was a follower of Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: His series of the Four Seasons is an interesting reproduction of Bruegel's series.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: Abel Grimmer continued the themes of Pieter Bruegel the Elder and evoked the four seasons in many of his paintings.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: He copied the subjects produced by Bruegel while adding his own mark: a stylisation of the forms and the introduction of powerful colours.The present panel of Summer is an interpretation of the famous drawing by Pieter Bruegel the Elder.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: This drawing inspired numerous artists including his son, Pieter Brueghel the Younger.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: Not all refer to the drawing itself, but rather to the engraving of it made by Pieter Cock around 1570.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: Engraving flourished in Antwerp in the 16th century and was an excellent means of distribution.
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: Hence, artists were familiar with the works of their contemporaries.There are other versions of this painting by Abel Grimmer
AUTHOR: GRIMMER, Abel
TITLE: Summer

DESCRIPTION: The painting has a companion-piece in the same private collection
AUTHOR: GRUND, Norbert
TITLE: Landscape with Pedestrians

DESCRIPTION: Grünewald's earliest datable work is the Mocking of Christ, a colourful, vehemently expressive painting demonstrating his ability to create dazzling light effects.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Mocking of Christ
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 109 x 73,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts Christ blindfolded and being beaten by a band of grotesque men.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Mocking of Christ
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 109 x 73,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: The figures are thick-bodied, soft, and fleshy, done in a manner suggestive of the Italian High Renaissance.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Mocking of Christ
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 109 x 73,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: Elements of the work also show Grünewald's assimilation of Dürer, specifically his Apocalypse series.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Mocking of Christ
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 109 x 73,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: Different from High Renaissance idealism and humanism, however, are Grünewald's uses of figural distortion to portray violence and tragedy, thin fluttering drapery, highly contrasting areas of light and shadow, and unusually stark and iridescent colour.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Mocking of Christ
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 109 x 73,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is these elements, already in evidence in this early work, that Grünewald was to develop into the masterful, individualistic style most fully realized in his Isenheim Altarpiece
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Mocking of Christ
TECHNIQUE: Oil on pine panel, 109 x 73,5 cm

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the left wing of the second view of the Isenheim Altarpiece
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: The Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The third view with wings opened again discloses on either side of the carved innermost shrine two panels, Sts Paul and Anthony in the Desert and a Temptation of St Anthony.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: Isenheim Altarpiece (third view)

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the left and right wings of the third view of the Isenheim Altarpiece
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: Visit of St Anthony to St Paul and Temptation of St Anthony

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the panels of the two-part altarpiece originally in the church at Tauberbischofsheim.
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: Carrying the Cross

DESCRIPTION: The Carrying the Cross was seen from the direction of the choir while the other part, the Crucifixion, from the nave
AUTHOR: GRÜNEWALD, Matthias
TITLE: Carrying the Cross

DESCRIPTION: Girolamo Godi, organizer of a Vicenzan literary salon and friend of Pietro Bembo and Alvise Cornaro, engaged Gualtiero around 1550 to decorate the villa.
AUTHOR: GUALTIERO PADOVANO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices

DESCRIPTION: In addition to the loggia, the decoration of four rooms in the right wing of the villa can be ascribed to Gualtiero: the Hall of the Gods or the Putto, the Hall of the Triumphs, the Hall of the Caesars, and the Hall of the Sacrifices.
AUTHOR: GUALTIERO PADOVANO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices

DESCRIPTION: Gualtiero's sudden death in 1552 prevented him from completing the work which was taken over by Battista Zelotti and Battista del Moro, who created the frescoes in the other rooms.In the Hall of the Sacrifices allegorical figures ornament the walls.
AUTHOR: GUALTIERO PADOVANO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices

DESCRIPTION: The figure with elongated limbs shows the influence of Parmigianino
AUTHOR: GUALTIERO PADOVANO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Sacrifices

DESCRIPTION: The decoration of the Music Room is divided into two parts, one dedicated to the world of allegories, the other to the real world.
AUTHOR: GUARANA, Jacopo
TITLE: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte

DESCRIPTION: Apollo, the god of music, dominates the fresco on the back wall of the Room, which is splendidly laid out by Agostino Mengozzi Colonna in a manner that recalls the scheme employed by the elder Mengozzi Colonna to frame Tiepolo's The Banquet of Cleopatra in the Palazzo Labia.
AUTHOR: GUARANA, Jacopo
TITLE: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte

DESCRIPTION: Apollo personally directs the orchestra of young girls (the "putte") seated in his right.
AUTHOR: GUARANA, Jacopo
TITLE: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte

DESCRIPTION: Next to him, dressed in yellow, Pasquale Anfossi (1727-1797), the opera composer who was then in charge of the Ospedaletto, conducts the chorus, holding a rolled-up musical score
AUTHOR: GUARANA, Jacopo
TITLE: Apollo Conducting the Orchestra of Putte

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes in this airy portego were completed by Jacopo Guarana at the end of 1772; the chandeliers are from Murano
AUTHOR: GUARANA, Jacopo
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: This view is dominated by the great marble bulk of the Church of Gesuati built in the 18th century
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: The Giudecca Canal with the Zattere

DESCRIPTION: This painting belongs to a series of four (originally six) vedute designed after Canaletto's "Capricci ed altre Vedute ideate."

DESCRIPTION: Guardi's original contribution to this series was the addition of staffage figures which breathe life into the views of Venice

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts the audience granted by the Doge to the ambassadors in the Sala del Collegio of the Doge's Palace in Venice

DESCRIPTION: It seems likely that these pictures had been painted for Doge Alvise Mocenigo himself

DESCRIPTION: Francesco Guardi was a collaborator of Gianantonio, from whom he learned the craft of painting, but he introduced into his older brothers art his own profoundly meditative personality.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: This fact is evinced by the essential differences to be discerned in the works the "workshop" produced.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: This picture, unanimously attributed by researchers to Francesco, is, in all likelihood, the fragment of a larger composition.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: The whole scene is summarized in the slow and calm movement of the gondoliere in the foreground, whereas the scenery of the lagoon virtually disintegrates in the mother-of-pearl atmosphere, which is lightened here and there by some rare flashes in the background.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: The lonely gondola is seen in the lagoon at the Fondamente Nuove, in front of the islands of San Cristoforo and San Michele.The emotional intensity of the painting is condensed into this brief recording of the moment, as if it were a "phrase in music", for example in Vivaldi's or Albinoni's compositions of the same theme.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: The smooth lagoon and the "adagio continuo" are parallel motifs of picture and music.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: The scenery becomes dissolved in musicality, as musicality disintegrates "in sorrowful weeping" (Goethe).The mournful character of the black gondola is both a forecast and a conscious experience of the future destiny of the world of lagoons — a world enclosed within its own modest boundaries.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: This is a world which has disappeared, because it was linked to a declining civilization.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: The argument was not continued, and it has not been taken up again; the other lagoon painters, such as the members of the Burano school, could not disguise the emptiness — not only of form but also of content.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: Gondola in the Lagoon

DESCRIPTION: The division between quay and water and the human activity around the market stalls and gondolas make up the theme of this view of the Molo.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: The quay, which is provided with steps and jetties for mooring boats, creates a striking line in the composition running almost at a right angle to the lower edge of the image and leads the eye toward a vanishing point just below the middle of the painting.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: Depicted at the right is the column of Todaro beyond which the buildings along the Molo continue with the Library, the Zecca and the State Grain Storage Houses all the way to the Fonteghetto della Farina near the entrance of the Grand Canal.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: A market with simple stalls and awnings occupies the Fondaco del Grano.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: To the left of the entrance of the Grand Canal can be seen the Punta della Dogana and Santa Maria della Salute and in the distance, to the extreme left, the Redentore.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: The composition is closed off at this end by a fishing boat which counterbalances the column of Todaro.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: As several corrections by the painter, visible to the naked eye reveal, Guardi modified the strong perspective of the buildings at the right and moved the Salute closer to the centre of the composition.The view of the Molo in the direction of the entrance to the Grand Canal was a subject frequently depicted in Venetian vedute painting.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: Initially the view functioned primarily as a setting for festive entries in the Doges' Palace, such as in Luca Carlevaris's Reception of Cardinal Cesar d'Estrees (Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam).
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: Later the view of the Molo was usually shown without the Doges' Palace and without any kind of festivity.For this painting, Guardi undoubtedly drew inspiration from a work by Canaletto (c.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: 1740, private collection) which he may have known through a print by Antonio Visentini from 1742.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: Not only did Guardi rely on this for his composition, he also borrowed several details from Canaletto such as the little stalls on the Molo and the gondolas floating on the water.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: However, a comparison with this source makes it clear that Guardi, despite the strong perspectival arrangement of this composition, neither subjected the cityscape to a strict perspectival system nor strove for an exact, detailed rendering of the architecture.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: For the loosely, vigorously painted figures on the Molo, Guardi more likely found an example in the work of the Genoese painter, Alessandro Magnasco.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: Furthermore, Guardi's painting is not even half the size of the one by Canaletto.Guardi's small painting and its pendant, a view of the Piazzetta in the direction of San Giorgio Maggiore (also in the Galleria Franchetti, Venice), no longer satisfied the presumably more representative function of Canaletto's painting, but were purchased instead by an individual client who was as interested in the well-known Venetian cityscapes as in Guardi's painterly rendering of them.As with many of Francesco Guardi's paintings, the dating of this work is problematic.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: It no longer displays the strong stylistic dependence on Canaletto which is characteristic of his earliest cityscapes, nor the brown tonality of his work from the 1760s.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: The shimmering effects of light and colour, especially in the wall surfaces of the buildings, and the nervous treatment of the sky and the figures on the Molo are characteristic of Guardi's extremely individualistic, transparent style in the last two decades of his career.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: Therefore, dating this painting to the second half of the 1770s seems plausible
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Molo towards the Santa Maria della Salute

DESCRIPTION: This mature work by the artist depicts the Piazza San Marco looking towards the Basilica and the Campanile.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Piazza San Marco, Looking East

DESCRIPTION: It was one of Guardi's most popular compositions
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Piazza San Marco, Looking East

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a view of the Campo San Zanipolo with the loggia temporarily erected outside the Scuola di San Marco for the benediction of Pope Pius VI on 19 May 1782.In May 1782, Pope Pius VI visited the city of Venice.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice

DESCRIPTION: The ceremonies and festivities on that occasion were recorded by Francesco Guardi in a series of four paintings.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice

DESCRIPTION: The city council commissioned Guardi to make four paintings representing the following subjects: the arrival of the pontiff near San Giorgio in Alga, the papal mass in SS Giovanni e Paolo, the papal audience and the blessing of the people on Campo SS Giovanni e Paolo.On the occasion of the Pope Pius VI blessing the crowd a temporary wooden loggia, designed by Antonio Codognato, was erected on the façade of the Scuola di San Marco.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice

DESCRIPTION: Once the Pope had finished his blessing the crowds were allowed to mount the loggia and the existence of at least three variants of this subject, including the present one, attest to the popularity of the composition
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the Campo San Zanipolo in Venice

DESCRIPTION: Two views of the Canal Grande by Francesco Guardi are taken from the top section of the waterway.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco

DESCRIPTION: One looks towards the right bank with the dominating dome of San Simone Piccolo, the other looks in the opposite direction to the church Santa Lucia on the left bank which was pulled down to be replaced by the railway station
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco
TITLE: The Canal Grande with San Simeone Piccolo

DESCRIPTION: Two views of the Canal Grande by Francesco Guardi are taken from the top section of the waterway.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco

DESCRIPTION: One looks towards the right bank with the dominating dome of San Simone Piccolo, the other looks in the opposite direction to the church Santa Lucia on the left bank which was pulled down to be replaced by the railway station
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Francesco

DESCRIPTION: This painting belongs to a series of twelve pieces in the Budapest museum.
AUTHOR: GUARDI, Giacomo
