DESCRIPTION: Although he painted views of Paris at all hours of the day, he excelled at painting at the margins of daylight, or when cloudy skies or misty rain create a cool atmosphere through which sparkle electric lights and sunny reflections
AUTHOR: LOIR, Luigi
TITLE: Carousel at the Porte Dorée

DESCRIPTION: Loiseau was a self-taught painter who experimented with pointillism around 1884.
AUTHOR: LOISEAU, Gustave
TITLE: Banks of the Seine

DESCRIPTION: He sojourned in Pont-Aven, and then, on his many travels, painted landscapes, mainly featuring rivers and the coast.
AUTHOR: LOISEAU, Gustave
TITLE: Banks of the Seine

DESCRIPTION: He was dubbed "the historian of the Seine" because he was adept at what Impressionism was best suited to: recording and celebrating shifting conditions of light and the changes made in the landscape by human hand
AUTHOR: LOISEAU, Gustave
TITLE: Banks of the Seine

DESCRIPTION: This is an early work by Lambert Lombard, probably dating from just before his celebrated altarpiece panels for the Saint-Denis retable done circa 1533.The central panel of the triptych represents the Adoration of the Magi, the left inner wing the Adoration of the Shepherds, while the right inner wing the Massacre of the Innocents.
AUTHOR: LOMBARD, Lambert
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 110 x 76 cm (central), 110 x 32 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: On the outer wings (not shown) the Theological Virtues are depicted
AUTHOR: LOMBARD, Lambert
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 110 x 76 cm (central), 110 x 32 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The monument to Generosa Orsini and his son Maffeo Zen (d.
AUTHOR: LOMBARDO, Pietro
TITLE: Monument to Generosa Orsini

DESCRIPTION: 1498) is located in the left transept of the Frari's Basilica.
AUTHOR: LOMBARDO, Pietro
TITLE: Monument to Generosa Orsini

DESCRIPTION: The simple and elegant urn is attributed to Pietro Lombardo, although others believe it to be by Antonio of Verona
AUTHOR: LOMBARDO, Pietro
TITLE: Monument to Generosa Orsini

DESCRIPTION: The professionalism of the doctor is brutally exposed through the open book of human anatomy on the table alongside parts of a human skeleton
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Alessandro
TITLE: Portrait of Dr. Pietro Pellegrini

DESCRIPTION: Pietro Longhi was first a pupil of Balestra and then of Crespi whose art was the source of his realism, which expressed a sober and sincere inner world, and a delight in detailed and fresh narrative.
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: He conveyed his realism with wit and ease, whereas the immediacy with which he approached the landscape enriched his painting with a unique quality.
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: Up to a certain point these elements can be discerned in pre-revolution French painting (Watteau, Chardin, Boucher and Lancret), whose influence also made itself felt in Pietro Longhi's realism.
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: Only here and there did grotesque features appear in his art; he saw his figures with the eye of a sage and a gentle and witty impertinence is to be found in many of the scenes he depicted.Pietro Longhi became, by means of his genre-painting, one of the most faithful chroniclers of his age, and one who conjured up a regrettably vanished civilization.
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: It should be borne in mind, however, that his connection with Goldoni and the teachings of Emilia encouraged him, through the observation of reality, to perform a kind of analysis of "social depths"; he did not want to cause an upheaval but only wanted to point out — perhaps tendentiously — the ineptitude of a declining class of society.
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: Although he did not pass sentence, he allowed his opinion to be known, being fully aware that changes were imminent.
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: Sometimes he would ironically represent certain dandies, abbots and virgins
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: Il Ridotto

DESCRIPTION: After devoting his efforts to historical painting, from the 1730s he concentrated on portraying the society of his day with a subtle vein of irony
AUTHOR: LONGHI, Pietro
TITLE: The Confession

DESCRIPTION: The sitter can be identified by the inscription at the bottom of the painting.
AUTHOR: LÓPEZ Y PORTA?A, Vicente
TITLE: Portrait of Don Juan Francisco Ximénez del Rio, Archbishop of Valencia

DESCRIPTION: López painted two other similar portraits of the archbishop, both commissioned in 1800, one for the Real Hospital in Valencia, another for the Cathedral in Segovia.
AUTHOR: LÓPEZ Y PORTA?A, Vicente
TITLE: Portrait of Don Juan Francisco Ximénez del Rio, Archbishop of Valencia

DESCRIPTION: The portrait in Bilbao shows the influence of Mengs
AUTHOR: LÓPEZ Y PORTA?A, Vicente
TITLE: Portrait of Don Juan Francisco Ximénez del Rio, Archbishop of Valencia

DESCRIPTION: The panel (and another also in the Uffizi) came from the church of St Procolo in Florence where it was recorded by Vasari.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Ambrogio
TITLE: Scenes of the Life of St Nicholas

DESCRIPTION: Presumably it was painted as side wing of a triptych which had a figure of St Nicholas in the central panel (which has disappeared) during the second visit of Ambrogio to Florence between 1327 and 1332, or later.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Ambrogio
TITLE: Scenes of the Life of St Nicholas

DESCRIPTION: Another possibility is that the panels made up a tabernacle door.The upper scene represents the resurrection of the dead child.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Ambrogio
TITLE: Scenes of the Life of St Nicholas

DESCRIPTION: In the lower scene Nicholas, as bishop of Myra saves the town from famine by miraculously drying and multiplying the sacks of wheat which had fallen into the sea
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Ambrogio
TITLE: Scenes of the Life of St Nicholas

DESCRIPTION: This small panel was originally part of an altarpiece dedicated to St Crescentius.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Ambrogio
TITLE: St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: This altarpiece was one of four commissioned by the cathedral in Siena as part of a grand decoration scheme to celebrate the city's patron saints and the Virgin Mary
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Ambrogio
TITLE: St John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows one of the scenes from the life of Christ painted by Pietro Lorenzetti on the vault of the south arm of the western transept of the Lower Church.In this scene the painter makes skillful use of the obstacle represented by the arch on the wall to produce a scene split into two levels.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Washing of the Feet

DESCRIPTION: The lively dialog between Christ and the apostle conveys a sense of movement that embrace all the other figures
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Washing of the Feet

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows one of the scenes from the life of Christ painted by Pietro Lorenzetti on the vault of the south arm of the western transept of the Lower Church.This scene has the tragic cadence of a procession of Flagellants, like the ones used to travel along the roads of Umbria on Good Friday, accompanied by the singing of lauds and marching to the rhythm of their scourges
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Road to Calvary

DESCRIPTION: This painting formed a panel of the predella of the dismembered altarpiece in the Carmelite church San Niccolò al Carmine in Siena.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Predella panel: The Approval of the New Carmelite Habit by Pope Honorius IV

DESCRIPTION: The five scenes in the predella depict events in the history of the Carmelite Order: The Annunciation to Sobac, Hermits at the Fountain of Elijah, St Albert Presents the Rule to the Carmelites, The Pope Issues a Bull to a Carmelite Delegation, and The Approval of the New Carmelite Habit by Pope Honorius IV.The long central predella and the next two scenes represent the modern documented history of the Carmelite Order.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Predella panel: The Approval of the New Carmelite Habit by Pope Honorius IV

DESCRIPTION: Some time between 1206 and 1214, Albert, Patriarch of Jerusalem, traveled to Mount Carmel an presented the hermits with a Rule.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Predella panel: The Approval of the New Carmelite Habit by Pope Honorius IV

DESCRIPTION: The Rule was accepted by Pope Honorius III in 1226 with a papal bull.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Predella panel: The Approval of the New Carmelite Habit by Pope Honorius IV

DESCRIPTION: A further papal dispensation allowed for the alteration of the Carmelite habit, exchanging the black and white horizontally striped outer cape for a simple white one
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Predella panel: The Approval of the New Carmelite Habit by Pope Honorius IV

DESCRIPTION: This altarpiece was painted for the church of San Francesco in Pistoia, where remained until 1799, to be transferred in the Uffizi Gallery.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Madonna Enthroned with Angels

DESCRIPTION: Among the latest work of Pietro Lorenzetti, the picture shows the tender motif of the silent colloquy that binds Mother and Child, which is characteristic of the style of other contemporary masters, as Giotto or the sculptor Giovanni Pisano.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Madonna Enthroned with Angels

DESCRIPTION: The predella paintings, described by Vasari, are lost.The painting was restored several times since the 18th century, originally it was higher.
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Madonna Enthroned with Angels

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed and dated on the step of the throne: PETRUS LAURENTII DE SENIS ME PINXIT ANNO DOMINI MCCCXL
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Madonna Enthroned with Angels

DESCRIPTION: This fragment, perhaps representing St Elizabeth of Hungary, came from San Francesco, Siena, almost certainly from the Chapter House
AUTHOR: LORENZETTI, Pietro
TITLE: Crowned Female Figure
TECHNIQUE: Fresco withareas of secco, 42 x 36 cm

DESCRIPTION: The Madonna and Christ Child appear in a window, and the child is standing on the balustrade below it.
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: She is holding a pomegranate that has been cut open out to him, and the boy has taken some of it, for he is showing Mary red pearls of fruit that he is holding in his clumsy child's hand.
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: Mary appears melancholy, as if she knows about the future Passion of her son, symbolized by the pomegranate.This is one of the first Florentine panel paintings known today to have been produced with a paint medium containing oil for colour pigments.
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: This technique first appeared in northern painting in the first half of the 15th century and rapidly spread there.
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: Italian developed the technique later.
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: The panel is very small by Italian standards, yet not at all an unusual format in Flemish painting.
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: The Christ Child as well, with his fat, tummy overlong torso and skinny little arms, refutes the widespread generally more rounded Florentine type of depiction.This Madonna is modeled after one by Leonardo; in fact, the painting was formerly thought to be an early work by Leonardo
AUTHOR: LORENZO DI CREDI
TITLE: Madonna and Child with a Pomegranate

DESCRIPTION: This narrow predella panel was among other widely scattered panels of the high altar of the Florentine monastic church of San Gaggio (also known as Santa Caterina al Monte).
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: Christ and the apostles are fitted within a boxlike space.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: Judas is spaced "below the salt," at the far side of the table from Christ and John, as witness to the latter's despair upon learning of the impending betrayal
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: This panel formed part of a predella, which included a Visitation (Courtauld Galleries, London), a Nativity (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York), an Adoration of the Magi (Courtauld Galleries, London), and a Flight into Egypt (Lindenau-Museum, Altenburg).The oblong frame, with a semicircle on every corner and angular projections between them, divides the picture into three parts and Lorenzo Monaco made good use of the possibilities offered by the unusual shape of the frame.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: He placed the Virgin and her Child-isolated from the other figures-into the central, widest part.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin is riding the ass side-saddle, as though she were sitting on a throne, and she is turned towards us.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: To indicate the direction of her course, her body is a little bent backwards.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The oblique line of her body suggests a straight line between the upper point of the frame and the bottom inward angle on the right, and this diagonal axis is further stressed by the ass's foreleg, stepping forwards, which, continuing the same line, eventually ends in the semicircle.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: A similar connection between the composition and the frame can be observed in the hindmost leg of the ass and the bottom left semicircle.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The oblique line of the leg is a reflected image of the axis which was mentioned previously.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The horizontal line of the animal's body links the figures of the Virgin and Joseph, and, at the same time, it separates the Holy Family from the women accompanying them.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The palm branches in the hands of the woman in a green cloak, and the drapery falling downwards from her arm, practically creates a line between the top and the bottom angular indentations of the frame.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: (According to some apocryphal gospels the fleeing Holy Family was nourished by the fruits of a palm-tree bending towards them.)
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The background, too, separates the left-hand side of the picture from the rest: the escorts proceed among bare, grey rocks, while the Holy Family move through woods: the foliage magically illuminates the semi-darkness.Whilst the two female figures are moving forwards, Joseph, at the head of the small group, has stopped and looks back.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: By this the painting representing progress in one direction becomes enclosed and symmetrical.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: This geometrically constructed composition with its strict rhythm by Lorenzo Monaco shows, as do all his works, that even while pursuing the best trecento traditions of Florentine art, an artist could adjust himself to the International Gothic style.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: Counterparts of the two women, with the long, even and soft folds of their draperies, or of the Virgin's graceful, aristocratic figure, could be found anywhere in the art of the period.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: On the other hand, the vigorous and definite personality of Joseph can be imagined only in Florentine art, which had old, democratic traditions.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: In vain would we try to find this image in the representations of Joseph as the humble old man in Northern art
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Flight into Egypt
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on poplar, 24 x 39 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: There are four panels in the Metropolitan Museum in New York representing Old Testament patriarchs, which are among the finest works of Lorenzo Monaco, who, at the time the panels were painted, was the leading master in Florence.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: Abraham

DESCRIPTION: The four patriarchs (Abraham, Noah, Moses, and David) are each portrayed seated on a cut stone bench or chest set on a fictive marble dais, which is alternately pink with a strip of green in the foreground (Noah and David) or green with a strip of violet in the foreground (Abraham and Moses).Abraham wears a pink tunic with green shadows, a violet cloak with pink highlights, and a white shawl draped over his shoulders.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: Abraham

DESCRIPTION: He holds a silver sword and a firebrand in his right hand and lays his left on the head of his son, Isaac, kneeling in profile before him, dressed in an orange tunic over a gray robe.The function of these four paintings, possibly as flanking elements of an altarpiece, has been debated
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: Abraham

DESCRIPTION: From the high altar of the church of Santa Maria degli Angeli, where Lorenzo was a monk.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Signed and dated.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The Scenes of the Life of St Benedict in the predella, with their fairy tale charm, are to be reckoned among the highest achievements of the master.Lorenzo's elegant style reached maturity in this very large altarpiece.In this painting the edges of the figures' garments have an animation quite independent of the actual movement of the figures.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Although the composition of the painting is quite conventional, the figures display a new fluidity in their poses and in the movements of their drapery which is suggestive of the International Style then being employed in sculpture by Ghiberti and Niccolò Lamberti.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Surface patterns vie for attention with the volumes of the figures; even the superimposition of figures tends to read as pattern.
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Brilliant, light-toned colour and the lavish use of gold and expensive ultramarine blue pigment would have made the painting a strong focal point in the church and would also have testified to its importance and to the donor's extraordinary generosity
AUTHOR: LORENZO Monaco
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Lorenzo Veneziano fulfilled countless commissions in Venice and its vicinity that display a handsome fusion of Byzantine and later pictorial currents.
AUTHOR: LORENZO VENEZIANO
TITLE: Conversion of Paul

DESCRIPTION: His commissions included that for an altarpiece which was later dismembered.
AUTHOR: LORENZO VENEZIANO
TITLE: Conversion of Paul

DESCRIPTION: The central panel depicting Christ Giving the Keys to St Peter is now in the Museo Correr, Venice, the side panels were destroyed in Berlin in 1945.
AUTHOR: LORENZO VENEZIANO
TITLE: Conversion of Paul

DESCRIPTION: The five predella panels survived, they comprise the Conversion of Paul; the Calling of the Apostles Peter and Andrew; the Christ Rescuing Peter from Drowning; the Apostle Peter Preaching; the Crucifixion of Peter
AUTHOR: LORENZO VENEZIANO
TITLE: Conversion of Paul

DESCRIPTION: These full-length saints would originally have formed part of a polyptych, standing alongside other martyred saints to surround a larger central panel depicting the Madonna and Child
AUTHOR: LORENZO VENEZIANO
TITLE: St Catherine of Alexandria and St Sigismund of Burgundy
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, gold ground, 99 x 33 cm (each)

DESCRIPTION: Hendrick van Vliet passed on aspects of the Delft style of architectural painting to his Delft followers.
AUTHOR: LORME, Anthonie de
TITLE: Interior of the St Laurenskerk in Rotterdam

DESCRIPTION: However, reflections of the style also can be seen in interiors by Anthonie de Lorme, one of the last practitioners of the subject.
AUTHOR: LORME, Anthonie de
TITLE: Interior of the St Laurenskerk in Rotterdam

DESCRIPTION: In his work Saenredam's example is also of importance
AUTHOR: LORME, Anthonie de
TITLE: Interior of the St Laurenskerk in Rotterdam

DESCRIPTION: It is hypothesized that the painting depicts the Greek sculptor and royal portraitist, Praxiteles, contemplating the bust of Alexander the Great.
AUTHOR: LOTH, Johann Karl
TITLE: Portrait of an Old Man with Bust

DESCRIPTION: The elderly man with a distinctive white beard and large hands, can be identified in numerous other works by Loth, including his Mercury and Argus in the National Gallery, London
AUTHOR: LOTH, Johann Karl
TITLE: Portrait of an Old Man with Bust

DESCRIPTION: A fine youthful work but partially repainted.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Head of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: It was done under the influence of Dürer and Jacopo de' Barbari.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Head of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: It is small, but life-size.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Head of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: Even in this work from his earliest period, the sitter's fully frontal posture is characteristic of Lotto's portraits, and so is the lively sense of personality that emerges from the close-up.In the 18th-century inventories the painting appeared as the portrait of Raphael, executed by Leonardo da Vinci, an assumption based on the soft, atmospheric modeling, the intense psychological penetration, and the traditional iconography of Raphael, who had always been seen as a delicate, elegant and refined youth.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Head of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: Recent X-rays, however, have revealed a previous portrait, completely different the one executed
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Head of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: This panel is the lower right panel of the Recanati Altarpiece
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Recanati Polyptych: Sts Peter Martyr and Vitus

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the three predella paintings of the altarpiece Lotto painted for the Dominican church of Santo Stefano in Bergamo between 1513 and 1516.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: The central panel is now in the church of San Bartolomeo in Bergamo
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: In this nocturnal portrait the pale moonlight laps the edges of the clouds and just barely mists the shores.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of Lucina Brembati

DESCRIPTION: Plump and self-confident, the Bergamasque noblewoman stands out with vibrating luminosity against the dark background.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of Lucina Brembati

DESCRIPTION: In this portrait Lotto mixes various features, namely the sense of belonging to the peaceful life of Bergamo, the ability to depict the sitters extremely vividly and the fondness for plays on words.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of Lucina Brembati

DESCRIPTION: In fact, the lady's name is concealed in a rebus: in the moon (luna in Italian) on the left the letters CI appear, thus form Lu-ci-na
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of Lucina Brembati

DESCRIPTION: The Angel and the Virgin of the Annunciation are the two upper panels of the polyptych executed by Lotto for the small village Ponteranica in a valley north of Bergamo.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Angel Annunciating

DESCRIPTION: The other panels were probably partly completed by assistants, while the protagonists of the Annunciation are among the most fascinating images of Lotto's maturity.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Angel Annunciating

DESCRIPTION: Lotto, who was very fond of the theme of the announcement that Mary was to give birth to the son of God, presented the episode in various ways.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Angel Annunciating

DESCRIPTION: Here the evocation of the iridescent, almost incorporeal angel confers a dream-like fascination on the event, which is, however, placed on a plane of worldly normality by the Virgin's gesture and expression.The angel in the upper left compartment of the polyptych is one of the most lyric creations of Lotto
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Angel Annunciating

DESCRIPTION: According to Roman legend, Lucretia, who was the wife of Lucius Tarquinius Collatinus, was raped by the son of the Roman king - a dishonour which subsequently resulted in her suicide.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: The event is supposed to have precipitated the collapse of the Etruscan royal line (510 BC) and thus to have led to the founding of the Roman Republic.In the 16th and 17th century Lucretia was frequently portrayed as a symbol of purity.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: Lotto presents us with the three-quarter view of a woman dressed in fine, richly trimmed clothes.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: Turned slightly away from the viewer, in her left hand she holds a drawing of the naked Lucretia about to stab herself in the heart.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: An inscription in Latin on the sheet on the table reads: "Following Lucretia's example, no dishonoured woman should continue to live".In the exquisiteness of its palette, the painting ranks amongst Lotto's greatest works.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: While the subject's face follows on from the tradition of Giorgione, the contrast between her brightly lit shoulders and the richly gradated reds and greens of her dress is worthy of a Titian.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: The costly pendant suspended from the gold chain, its precious stones refracting the light, is virtually without equal in 16th-century Venetian painting
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady as Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: Like the panel representing St Christopher (in the same museum), this panel was a side wing of a polyptych
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: This painting is a variation on the traditional Venetian pictorial type representing the Virgin and Child with saints in a landscape.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Holy Family with Angels

DESCRIPTION: The idyllic group comprises the Virgin and the Christ child, Joseph (at the left), the child John the Baptist, his mother Elizabeth (the Virgin's elder sister) and his father Zacharias (at the right).
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Holy Family with Angels

DESCRIPTION: It was painted in the Marches, probably for a local patron, but for some reason it remained in Lotto's possession.
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Holy Family with Angels

DESCRIPTION: He left the painting to the religious community in Loreto after his death
AUTHOR: LOTTO, Lorenzo
TITLE: Holy Family with Angels

DESCRIPTION: Painting nudes was one of the favourite genres of Károly Lotz, especially during the 1890s he painted several nudes.
AUTHOR: LOTZ, Károly
TITLE: Bathing Woman

DESCRIPTION: His female nudes are generally very sensuous, with natural beauty radiating from their gestures.
AUTHOR: LOTZ, Károly
TITLE: Bathing Woman

DESCRIPTION: This particular nude is a little abstract; her posture, the cape over the shoulder, and the black stone vessel are reminiscent of the cool grace of Ingres's nudes
AUTHOR: LOTZ, Károly
TITLE: Bathing Woman

DESCRIPTION: The harbour was a favourite subject of the French Impressionists, whose technique Luce adopts here.
AUTHOR: LUCE, Maximilien
TITLE: The Port of Rotterdam

DESCRIPTION: The modernist element here consists of the choice of an industrial scene
AUTHOR: LUCE, Maximilien
TITLE: The Port of Rotterdam

DESCRIPTION: The church of San Maurizio is divided into two sectors, one open for the public, and another for the nuns.
AUTHOR: LUINI, Bernardino
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Maurice

DESCRIPTION: The dividing wall is decorated by Bernardino Luini's frescoes which include the Martyrdom of St Maurice
AUTHOR: LUINI, Bernardino
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Maurice

DESCRIPTION: This youthful work by the artist originally showed a full-length figure, and once formed part of a larger altarpiece from which three other survive
AUTHOR: LUINI, Bernardino
TITLE: A Female Martyr

DESCRIPTION: Pyrrhus, son of Achilles, took Andromache, wife of Hector, as part of his spoils from the Trojan War and had three sons by her.
AUTHOR: LUND, Johan Ludwig Gebhard
TITLE: Pyrrhus and Andromache at Hector's Tomb

DESCRIPTION: One of these sons became king of Epirus after Pyrrhus' death.Pyrrhus and Andromache are characters in the tragedy "Andromaque" written in 1667 by Jean Racine (1639-1699), a French dramatist, one of the three great playwrights of 17th-century France (along with Molière and Corneille), and an important literary figure in the Western tradition.
AUTHOR: LUND, Johan Ludwig Gebhard
TITLE: Pyrrhus and Andromache at Hector's Tomb

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows a view from Kitnas on Roskilde Fjord, Zeeland.
AUTHOR: LUNDBYE, Johan Thomas
TITLE: A Danish Coast

DESCRIPTION: When the painter decided to depict a Danish coastline in an unusually monumental format, the scene was to represent the quintessential characteristic of the Danish countryside: the extensive coastlines.
AUTHOR: LUNDBYE, Johan Thomas
TITLE: A Danish Coast

DESCRIPTION: The scene does not, in fact, depict a single, specific site, the main motif is based on cliffs that the artist saw and sketched at the Roskilde Fjord.
AUTHOR: LUNDBYE, Johan Thomas
TITLE: A Danish Coast

DESCRIPTION: He adapted these cliffs, making them rather more monumental, and combined them with scenes from elsewhere
AUTHOR: LUNDBYE, Johan Thomas
TITLE: A Danish Coast

DESCRIPTION: In this painting the signature tells us that the study was created on Vejrhoj, a landmark within the artist's autobiographical landscape: his grandparents lived in the nearby town of Kalundborg, where he himself was born, and the place became a recurring motif in his pictures
AUTHOR: LUNDBYE, Johan Thomas
TITLE: Kolas Wood, Vejrhoj
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper laid down on canvas, 24 x 33 cm

DESCRIPTION: Three very similar paintings attributed to the British-Dutch painter Simon Luttichuijs show a number of etchings and paintings of old people by or after Rembrandt and especially Jan Lievens.
AUTHOR: LUTTICHUIJS, Simon
TITLE: Still Life with a Skull

DESCRIPTION: Two facing paintings resemble the old man and woman called Rembrandt's father and mother.
AUTHOR: LUTTICHUIJS, Simon
TITLE: Still Life with a Skull

DESCRIPTION: However, the iconography of Luttichuijs's paintings, with their emphasis on mortality, the images seem merely to refer old age as such, not to specific individuals
AUTHOR: LUTTICHUIJS, Simon
TITLE: Still Life with a Skull

DESCRIPTION: This painting shows a still-life of roses, peonies and passion flowers in a glass vase on a stone ledge with a ladybird and a butterfly
AUTHOR: LUYCKX, Christiaen
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: L'Église des Saints Innocents (Church of the Holy Innocents) was located in the cemetery of the same name on the rue Saint-Denis in Paris In 1786, a Parliamentary public health order decreed that the cemetery and church be destroyed to make way for a marketplace.
AUTHOR: MACHY, Pierre-Antoine de
TITLE: Demolition of L'Église des Saints Innocents, Paris

DESCRIPTION: De Machy painted numerous paintings and drawings of the church both before and during its destruction, the present painting is probably one of the three which were exhibited in the Salon of 1787
AUTHOR: MACHY, Pierre-Antoine de
TITLE: Demolition of L'Église des Saints Innocents, Paris

DESCRIPTION: The represented saints are John the Baptist, James, Jerome and Ugone
AUTHOR: MACRINO D'ALBA
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints and Angels

DESCRIPTION: From the mid-nineteenth century onwards, Hungarian painters began to paint historical scenes as well as landscapes, portraits and genre paintings.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: It was not merely a fashion in Hungary to follow the current Romantic Movement that originated in Paris, or the "historism" of the Munich and Vienna Academies; it went much deeper than that.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: At the defeat of the fight for independence, the nation escaped into its history.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: Along with Hungarian poets and writers, the painters recalled the glorious events of the past, searching for ideals of patriotism and heroism that had not been crushed by despotism.Viktor Madarász gained the first international appreciation for Hungarian painting when his picture, "The Bewailing of László Hunyadi" won the State Grand Prix at the 1861 Paris Salon Exhibition.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: This rather romantic historical painting of the Hunyadi tragedy epitomizes the national grief of the 1850s, and fans the fire of revenge.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: The dead body of the heroic László Hunyadi, son of the great János Hunyadi, lies in Buda Castle Chapel.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: King László V, fearing for throne, had lured the popular young Hunyadi to his place with a promise of safe passage.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: Then he seized him and had him beheaded in the market place at Buda on March 16, 1457.
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: At the feet of body, his mother, Erzsébet Szilágyi, and his bride, Mária Gara, kneel in grief
AUTHOR: MADARÁSZ, Viktor
TITLE: László Hunyadi on the Bier

DESCRIPTION: The range of Mae's domestic subjects is large.
AUTHOR: MAES, Nicolaes
TITLE: The Lacemaker

DESCRIPTION: They show women praying, spinning, sewing, making lace, preparing food, or teaching children - all virtuous activities related to the centrality and sanctity of the home in Dutch society
AUTHOR: MAES, Nicolaes
TITLE: The Lacemaker

DESCRIPTION: This portrait and its companion piece depict a married couple.
AUTHOR: MAES, Nicolaes
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: The portraits demonstrate that from the 1660s, Maes was influenced by the French style of portraiture, characterized by a refined and distant air
AUTHOR: MAES, Nicolaes
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: Inspired by Piazzetta's style in its pictorial expression, the work takes up the Cinquecento modular structure and pays particular homage to the work of Savoldo.
AUTHOR: MAGGIOTTO, Domenico
TITLE: Boy with Flute

DESCRIPTION: The companion-piece of the painting (Three Camaldolese Monks in Meditative Prayer) is also in the Rijksmuseum
AUTHOR: MAGNASCO, Alessandro
TITLE: Three Camaldolese Monks in Ecstatic Prayer

DESCRIPTION: The Genoese Alessandro Magnasco was taught by his father Stefano and a little known Milanese painter, Filippo Abbiati, and began by painting in a conventional seventeenth-century style.
AUTHOR: MAGNASCO, Alessandro
TITLE: The Observant Friars in the Refectory

DESCRIPTION: During his stay in Florence at the beginning of the eighteenth century, however, he became acquainted with the work of Salvator Rosa and the etchings of Callot, and under their influence developed a content and style of his own.
AUTHOR: MAGNASCO, Alessandro
TITLE: The Observant Friars in the Refectory

DESCRIPTION: His themes were bizarre, different from anything to be seen in Genoa, Milan, or indeed anywhere in Italy; nor did his manner of painting resemble that of any other artist in Italy.
AUTHOR: MAGNASCO, Alessandro
TITLE: The Observant Friars in the Refectory

DESCRIPTION: He depicted imaginary scenes, capriccios in many of which monks are seen in strange settings or tiny figures in stormy landscapes.
AUTHOR: MAGNASCO, Alessandro
TITLE: The Observant Friars in the Refectory

DESCRIPTION: In his paintings, which are usually small, the figures are oddly elongated, the strokes of the brush vibrating and restless; indeed, everything seems to be in flickering movement.The number of people depicted in this painting and the richness of the decorations lead us to think that this may have been the General Chapter of the Franciscan Order
AUTHOR: MAGNASCO, Alessandro
TITLE: The Observant Friars in the Refectory

DESCRIPTION: Fra Domenico Strambi was a scholarly Augustinian monk, who was Benozzo Gozzoli's patron when he painted the main choir chapel in Sant'Agostino in San Gimignano.
AUTHOR: MAINARDI, Bastiano
TITLE: Tomb Monument to Fra Domenico Strambi

DESCRIPTION: In 1487, Bastiano Mainardi, a native of San Gimignano who was a pupil of Domenico Ghirlandaio, painted on the north wall of the church (to the left  of the choir) a depiction of St Gemignanus seated on his bishop's throne.
AUTHOR: MAINARDI, Bastiano
TITLE: Tomb Monument to Fra Domenico Strambi

DESCRIPTION: Three local notables kneel before the city's patron saint.
AUTHOR: MAINARDI, Bastiano
TITLE: Tomb Monument to Fra Domenico Strambi

DESCRIPTION: Below this scene there is a painted monument, with an inscription explaining that Strambi is buried here.
AUTHOR: MAINARDI, Bastiano
TITLE: Tomb Monument to Fra Domenico Strambi

DESCRIPTION: It shows the deceased laid out atop a sarcophagus in an imaginary niche
AUTHOR: MAINARDI, Bastiano
TITLE: Tomb Monument to Fra Domenico Strambi

DESCRIPTION: Vladimir Yegorovich Makovsky's subject bears heavily on a traditional Russian subject.
AUTHOR: MAKOVSKY, Vladimir Yegorovich
TITLE: Gypsy Girl

DESCRIPTION: Gypsy Girl defies the tradition of Romanticism and neo-Classicism, which dominated Russian art in the first half of the nineteenth century.
AUTHOR: MAKOVSKY, Vladimir Yegorovich
TITLE: Gypsy Girl

DESCRIPTION: As a founding member of Peredvizhniki, or ‘The Wanderers', a group of artists who aimed to bring art into life, like their contemporaries in literature and in music, such as Feodor Dostoyevsky and Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakoff, respectively, Makovsky's painting is a strong response to Russia's traditional Slavic heritage.
AUTHOR: MAKOVSKY, Vladimir Yegorovich
TITLE: Gypsy Girl

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed upper right in Cyrillic: 'V.
AUTHOR: MAKOVSKY, Vladimir Yegorovich
TITLE: Gypsy Girl

DESCRIPTION: Makovsky'
AUTHOR: MAKOVSKY, Vladimir Yegorovich
TITLE: Gypsy Girl

DESCRIPTION: The sitter of the portrait is Sebastian Andorfer (1469-1537), a top mining official of Schwaz in Tirol.
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Sebastian Andorfer

DESCRIPTION: His father held a prominent position in the mining administration at Schwaz, serving as 'Silberbrenner' (refiner of silver) from 1470 to 1499.
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Sebastian Andorfer

DESCRIPTION: Sebastian assumed the post in 1499 and occupied it until his death in 1537.A variant of the portrait exists, also dated 1517, in which Andorfer is depicted bearded.
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Sebastian Andorfer

DESCRIPTION: The two portraits may exemplify the practice, which can be observed in contemporary medals, of recording a change in appearance for eternity.
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Sebastian Andorfer

DESCRIPTION: However, no known biographical events correspond with the 1517 date of the portraits.
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Sebastian Andorfer

DESCRIPTION: Furthermore, technical investigations suggest that the execution of the beardless portrait preceded the bearded one.The two Andorfer portraits stand as the earliest securely dated works in Maler's oeuvre
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Sebastian Andorfer

DESCRIPTION: This is the companion-piece of the Portrait of Moritz Welzer von Eberstein, the sitter's husband
AUTHOR: MALER, Hans
TITLE: Portrait of Maria Welzer, née Tänzel

DESCRIPTION: In the first half of the seventeenth century, Jan Mayen Island and Spitsbergen were used as whaling bases by the Noordse Compagnie (Dutch Northern Company).
AUTHOR: MAN, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Whale-oil Factory on Jan Mayen Island

DESCRIPTION: This painting shows the company settlement on Jan Mayen Island, with the snow-clad peak known as Beerenberg in the background.
AUTHOR: MAN, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Whale-oil Factory on Jan Mayen Island

DESCRIPTION: In the foreground we can see the whale-oil factory in operation.
AUTHOR: MAN, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Whale-oil Factory on Jan Mayen Island

DESCRIPTION: On the left, a whale is being 'flensed'.
AUTHOR: MAN, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Whale-oil Factory on Jan Mayen Island

DESCRIPTION: On the right, the strips of blubber are being chopped up on wooden tables and boiled in huge vats.
AUTHOR: MAN, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Whale-oil Factory on Jan Mayen Island

DESCRIPTION: The resulting whale-oil was used for a number of different purposes
AUTHOR: MAN, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Whale-oil Factory on Jan Mayen Island

DESCRIPTION: This canvas was the most vociferously decried painting of the 1865 Salon.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Olympia

DESCRIPTION: In fact, Manet has painted it in 1863 but had apparently not dared submit it in 1864.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Olympia

DESCRIPTION: Olympia is another painting packed with allusions to past masterpieces, notably Titian's Venus of Urbino and Goya's Naked Maja.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Olympia

DESCRIPTION: This whole tradition, from the odalisque to the black slave, continues (particularly with Ingres) throughout the nineteenth century, but what was surprising here was the absence of any exoticism, of either period or location, and the portrayal of a modern prostitute.The painting of the period was not at all averse to flowers, and Courbet, Fantin-Latour, and Manet all painted many pictures with flowers in them.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Olympia

DESCRIPTION: Among the best known bunches (this time wrapped in florist's paper, like those that later Degas placed in the hands of his dancers as they took their bow) is the one being presented by a black servant to Olympia
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Olympia

DESCRIPTION: In the fertile years that followed his Déjeuner and Olympia, Manet experimented very widely.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama"

DESCRIPTION: Sometimes he focused on giving form to colour and movement in works like the Bullfight, at others he was inspired by contemporary events, such as the Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama" off Cherbourg.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama"

DESCRIPTION: This episode of the American War of Independence made a considerable impression on public opinion.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama"

DESCRIPTION: The work testified to Manet's modernity, but was also an attempt to renew the theme of naval combat traditional in Dutch painting.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama"

DESCRIPTION: It is, in fact, a battle between colour and light, where the blacks and the few dots of red enhance the tumultuous green of the waves
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Battle of the "Kearsarge" and the "Alabama"

DESCRIPTION: Manet detested the countryside, and found landscapes futile unless animated by some justificatory event.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The World Fair of 1867 in Paris

DESCRIPTION: When he painted a view of the Trocadéro, it was on the occasion of the World Fair
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The World Fair of 1867 in Paris

DESCRIPTION: Following Monet, Bazille, Boudin and Jongkind, who worked at Honfleur on the coast, Manet too began to take an interest in harbour scenes and ships at sea
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Departure of the Folkestone Boat

DESCRIPTION: The 1870s were rich in female models for Manet: the Brunette with Bare Breasts, the Blonde with Bare Breasts and the Sultana testify to it
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Brunette with Bare Breasts

DESCRIPTION: Manet returned several times to painting Berthe Morisot's languishing face and languishing attitudes.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Berthe Morisot with a Bunch of Violets

DESCRIPTION: He clearly sought something more than the merely pictorial in this strange young woman, who was always dressed soberly in Manet's favourite colours, black and white
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Berthe Morisot with a Bunch of Violets

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the product of Manet's 1872 trip to Holland, when the impact of Frans Hals was a great revelation.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: On the Beach

DESCRIPTION: It was Hals, more then the Impressionists, who converted Manet to painting rapidly.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: On the Beach

DESCRIPTION: He now put his "black" period behind him and embarked upon plein-air.Madame Manet poses on the beach, and the intense black of her bonnet with its long strings defines the harmonies of the entire painting
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: On the Beach

DESCRIPTION: This painting depicts an unconventional young woman on the background of a fashionable café.This picture belongs to Manet's "Naturalist" series of paintings.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Plum Brandy

DESCRIPTION: He depicts a prostitute, lost in melancholy daydreams.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Plum Brandy

DESCRIPTION: She neither lights her cigarette nor touches her brandy-soaked plum.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Plum Brandy

DESCRIPTION: This painting was the first of Manet's many café scenes, which followed by At the Café, the Corner of a Café-Concert, and his absolute masterpiece, the Bar in the Folies-Bergère
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: The Plum Brandy

DESCRIPTION: The present portrait shows the image of a modern Parisian woman who performed the rituals of fashion obligatory before appearing in public.
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Woman in Riding Costume

DESCRIPTION: The painting is unfinished, and thus the sketchy effect is due to the stage of completion which it had reached and was not intended as the final result
AUTHOR: MANET, Edouard
TITLE: Woman in Riding Costume

DESCRIPTION: This work is an autograph variant of the painting in the church of Saint Eustache in Paris which originally hung in the church of San Luigi dei Francesi in Rome.
AUTHOR: MANETTI, Rutilio
TITLE: The Ecstasy of the Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: Another variant is in the Pitti Palace in Florence
AUTHOR: MANETTI, Rutilio
TITLE: The Ecstasy of the Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: Manfredi created a series of theatrically lit compositions in which bawdy figures crowd around a table gambling, drinking and making music.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: In his Denial of St Peter the tavern scene is transformed into a religious narrative in which the soldiers' game of dice is given more prominence than Peter's betrayal.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The religious event is thus cast within the context of secular life
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: In the 1620s in Roman circles, a definite change came about in the subject matter of musical paintings.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Tavern Scene with a Lute Player

DESCRIPTION: The representation of figures playing musical instruments in 'cultivated' domestic interiors (the direct descendants of Caravaggio's Lute Player and Musicians) disappeared.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Tavern Scene with a Lute Player

DESCRIPTION: Within the space of a very few years they were replaced by large numbers of representations of concerts in public places and 'popular' locations.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Tavern Scene with a Lute Player

DESCRIPTION: One of the earlier examples of this new trend is Bartolomeo Manfredi's Tavern Scene with a Lute Player.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Tavern Scene with a Lute Player

DESCRIPTION: One characteristic of the painting, besides the presence of the lute player in a non-musical context (he simply accompanies a scene in which people are eating and drinking), is the absence of a musical score, an attribute of 'cultivated' musical painting.
AUTHOR: MANFREDI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Tavern Scene with a Lute Player

DESCRIPTION: The Confraternity of the Scuola Grande di San Giovanni Evangelista in Venice called upon the most respected Venetian painters of the period, including  Pietro Perugino, Vittore Carpaccio, Gentile Bellini, Giovanni Mansueti, Lazzaro Bastiani and Benedetto Diana to paint nine canvases for the Great Hall of their headquarters showing the Miracles of the Holy Cross, the story of the miracles performed by the fragment of wood from the Cross on which Jesus was crucified.
AUTHOR: MANSUETI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo

DESCRIPTION: This fragment had been donated to the brotherhood in 1369 by Philip de Mezières, Chancellor of the Kingdom of Cyprus and Jerusalem, and had soon become an object of great veneration and the symbol of the Scuola, one of the most important and wealthy Venetian confraternities.The canvas painted by Perugino has been lost, but the eight surviving paintings executed between 1496 and 1501, contain depictions of some of the most famous parts of Venice.
AUTHOR: MANSUETI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo

DESCRIPTION: Since the imposing series of pictures (known as 'teleri') are all in the Accademia now it is easy to compare them.The subject of this 'telero' is the miraculous healing in 1414 of the little daughter of Benvegnudo.
AUTHOR: MANSUETI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo

DESCRIPTION: Having been paralysed ever since birth, she gained the use of her limbs after touching the three candles which her father had placed on the relic of the Holy Cross.
AUTHOR: MANSUETI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo

DESCRIPTION: The interior of the richly decorated and furnished room and the animation of the watching crowd are described with inventorial precision
AUTHOR: MANSUETI, Giovanni
TITLE: The Miraculous Healing of the Daughter of Benvegnudo of San Polo

DESCRIPTION: This photograph was taken before the chapel was destroyed on 11 March 1944.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Christopher (scene 5)

DESCRIPTION: Today only fragments of the lower wall area remain.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Christopher (scene 5)

DESCRIPTION: The right-hand wall of the chapel was dedicated to St Christopher.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Christopher (scene 5)

DESCRIPTION: From the upper left to the lower right the scenes were St Christopher before the King (scene 1); the Confrontation with the Devil (scene 2); St Christopher Carrying Christ across the River (scene 3); St Christopher and the Soldiers of the King of Samos in Lycia (scene 4); the Martyrdom of St Christopher (scene 5); the Removal of his Body (scene 6).The composition of the whole wall was Mantegna's work, but only the two bottom pictures (scenes 5 and 6) were painted by him
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Christopher (scene 5)

DESCRIPTION: A prodigy, Andrea Mantegna established his reputation when he was barely 20 years old.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: The Adoration of the Shepherds
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 40 x 56 cm

DESCRIPTION: This painting is an early work, but already his highly individual style is evident.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: The Adoration of the Shepherds
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 40 x 56 cm

DESCRIPTION: The hard, precise drawing, the astonishing clarity of even the smallest details in the distant landscape, and the refined, pure colour are typical of his work, as are the intensely serious expressions of the figures.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: The Adoration of the Shepherds
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 40 x 56 cm

DESCRIPTION: The Adoration seems to have been painted for Borso d'Este, ruler of Ferrara, and the coarse realism of the shepherds probably reflects Flemish paintings collected by the Este.In this scene the realistic portrayal of the two shepherds in ragged clothing betrays Flemish influence.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: The Adoration of the Shepherds
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 40 x 56 cm

DESCRIPTION: Mantegna was able to study the work of Rogier van der Weyden at the Ferrara court
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: The Adoration of the Shepherds
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on canvas transferred from wood, 40 x 56 cm

DESCRIPTION: St Euphemia has been placed in a stone arch decorated with garlands of fruit and leaves.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Euphemia

DESCRIPTION: She has been portrayed in the immediate foreground, bringing her close to the viewer.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Euphemia

DESCRIPTION: With her direct gaze, the life-size figure, accompanied by a lion, is open to dialogue with the viewer standing in front of her.St Euphemia was subjected to various forms of torture during the persecution of Christians under Emperor Diocletian.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Euphemia

DESCRIPTION: These are symbolized by a sword that has pierced her side and the lion biting her arm.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Euphemia

DESCRIPTION: The painting was damaged by fire in the late 18th century, so that the detail of the folds of her robe are no longer apparent
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Euphemia

DESCRIPTION: In 15th-century Italian art, portrayals of St Sebastian offered the opportunity of depicting an idealized nude figure in a classical setting.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Mantegna tied the saint to the column of a triumphal arch both to emphasize his heroism and at the same time to stress the precise historic setting.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: The triumphal arch stands in a courtyard closed off by a wall.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Debris from statues and a fragment of bacchanalian relief lie around, indicating the fall of the pagans and the victory of Christianity.A bearded horseman can be seen in the cloud to the left.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Images in the cloud like this, already described in classical art theory and adopted by Alberti and Leonardo da Vinci, were ascribed to the genius of nature, which could stimulate artists and inspire them to improve on nature with their creations.The vertical inscription at the right side of the saint is the signature of Mantegna in Greek
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Mantegna painted monumental likenesses that combine the particularity of Eyckian physiognomy with the authority of ancient Roman busts.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan

DESCRIPTION: The portrait of Cardinal Trevisan suggests a statue come to life, a bust animated by light washing over its forceful features.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan

DESCRIPTION: This portrait is one of the landmarks of Italian portraiture.Cardinal Trevisan was a rich, powerful, and cultured figure who proved his military prowess in the Battle of Anghiari on June 29, 1440, between Milan and the Italian League, where he lead the papal troupes.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan

DESCRIPTION: He became cardinal in the same year
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Cardinal Ludovico Trevisan

DESCRIPTION: The central part represents the Madonna and Child Enthroned (212 x 125 cm), the left part shows Saints Peter and Paul, Saint John the Evangelist and Saint Zeno, while the right part Saints Benedict, Lawrence, Gregory and Saint John the Baptist (235 x 135 cm each).
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: The predella paintings are copies, the originals are in the Musée du Louvre and in the Musée des Beaux-Arts of Tours.Despite the framing elements that divide them, the three main panels of the San Zeno Altarpiece form an unified picture space.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: The central section depicts the Madonna holding her Child and surrounded by music-making angels, seated on a marble throne decorated with Roman-inspired reliefs.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: The naturalistic trompe l'oeil garlands, seemingly affixed to the top of the picture, create a rapport with the garlands held by the putti in the marble relief at the top of the throne.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: The borderline between the real world and the invented world here breaks down completely
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: The central section of the San Zeno Altarpiece depicts the Madonna holding her Child and surrounded by music-making angels, seated on a marble throne decorated with Roman-inspired reliefs.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych (central panel)

DESCRIPTION: The naturalistic trompe l'oeil garlands, seemingly affixed to the top of the picture, create a rapport with the garlands held by the putti in the marble relief at the top of the throne.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych (central panel)

DESCRIPTION: The borderline between the real world and the invented world here breaks down completely
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: San Zeno Polyptych (central panel)

DESCRIPTION: The space of the room with a square plan (8,1 x 8,1 m) is essentially a cube, and in it Mantegna has created a monumental architectural reality by means of ribs on the ceiling connecting with pilasters on the walls, which are in turn supported by a marble socle.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: In the centre of the ceiling is the much-admired oculus, opening onto a painted sky.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: The interplay of levels of reality elaborates ideas already set forth in his art.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: Only the corbels are actually stone, the highly worked ribs, the garlands that encircle the eight busts of emperors supported by putti, and the ensembles in decorative lozenges are painted to simulate marble so convincingly that even the modern viewer is sometimes fooled.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: In the triangular spaces at the edges of the ceiling are twelve mythological scenes of Orpheus, Orion, and Hercules with backgrounds of simulated mosaics, a device that Raphael was to use in the ceiling of the Stanza della Segnatura.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: Only two of the walls have figurative narrations: the north wall with a scene that is usually called the Court and the west wall, divided into three scenes, Servants with Horse and Dogs, the Inscription with Putti, and the Meeting.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: The remaining two walls are painted with imitation leather draperies that encroach upon the other sides as well to create the fiction that there were curtains before all four walls and on two sides they had been opened up to reveal the events depicted.The central subject of the frescoes is Ludovico III Gonzaga, his wife, his children, and his court.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: A closed letter held by Cardinal Francesco Gonzaga in the Meeting seems to be the same one, now opened, that Ludovico, seated majestically, holds in the Court, and must be considered important for understanding the paintings.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: The style of the frescoes is similar to Mantegna's previous works.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: The compositions are dominated by the narrative elements, with the figures set frieze-like, close to the picture plane within a narrow spatial shelf in front of a landscape or architectural setting
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: View of the west and north walls

DESCRIPTION: The detail of the west wall shows a grotesque self-portrai of the artist.Hidden in the foliate decor of one of the room's painted pilasters, right next to the painted plaque above the door containing the painter's dedication of the work, is a face that has been commonly identified as the artist's self-portrait.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Grotesque Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: Its resemblance to the bronze portrait bust from roughly 1490 in the church of Sant'Andrea in Mantua, is unmistakable, even though this painted likeness does not wear the arrogant and somewhat surly expression that his contemporaries tell us was characteristic of the artist
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Grotesque Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The tent-like vaulting of the Camera degli Sposi contains: in the centre the trompe-l'oeil oculus; in the diamond-shaped compartments eight busts of emperors in medallions; in the side vaults scenes from the myths of Orpheus, Arion, and Hercules.Although painted first, the painting of the ceiling, done in grisaille and imitation gold mosaics, is meant to be the logical continuation of the vertical arrangements of the space.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling decoration
TECHNIQUE: Walnut oil on plaster and fresco

DESCRIPTION: It represents a tent-like roof with pointed vaults above the walls; the painting makes it appear higher than it actually is.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling decoration
TECHNIQUE: Walnut oil on plaster and fresco

DESCRIPTION: Broad groins ornamented with meanders rise up from the painted basket capitals, dividing the ceiling into eight lozenge-shaped fields drawn to sharp points at the bottom, like spandrels.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling decoration
TECHNIQUE: Walnut oil on plaster and fresco

DESCRIPTION: Each lozenge contains a round medallion in which depicted are the first eight Roman emperors.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling decoration
TECHNIQUE: Walnut oil on plaster and fresco

DESCRIPTION: The twelve triangular vaults above the lunettes contain scenes from classical myth and legend, all backed by gold mosaics.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling decoration
TECHNIQUE: Walnut oil on plaster and fresco

DESCRIPTION: First comes three scenes from the Orpheus myth, then three relating to Arion, and finally six depictions of some of the labours of Hercules
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling decoration
TECHNIQUE: Walnut oil on plaster and fresco

DESCRIPTION: One the most remarkable portions of the decoration of the Camera degli Sposi is the fictive oculus, or opening to the sky, located on the room's low ceiling.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling Oculus

DESCRIPTION: Created with sharp foreshortenings, the oculus is ringed with figures looking down on the room below; a potted plant is precariously perched on its wooden support, seemingly ready to fall at any moment.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling Oculus

DESCRIPTION: It is a brilliant tour de force that invariably engages the spectator, who must join in the game by standing directly beneath the circular trellis.The magnificent details of the ceiling and some of the busts and scenes stand among the most convincing trompe l'oeil passages of the entire Italian Renaissance
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling Oculus

DESCRIPTION: Once owned by King Charles I of England, this painting illustrates an episode from the Old Testament which relates how the Israelite Judith by guile killed the Assyrian general Holofernes and thus saved her beleaguered city.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Judith

DESCRIPTION: Painted with minute detail, Judith and her handmaiden finish their deed with tragic calm.Among Mantegna's works there are several representations of Judith that, without exception, show a comparatively peaceful scene in which Judith is placing the severed head of Holofernes in a bag.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Judith

DESCRIPTION: During the Baroque, in contrast, the dramatic central moment of the action was preferred, as Judith, often with great effort, decapitates Holofernes.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Judith

DESCRIPTION: The Madonna of Victory was commissioned by Francesco II Gonzaga To celebrate his victory over the French at Fornovo on 6 July 1495.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Madonna of Victory

DESCRIPTION: On the first anniversary of the battle the altarpiece was installed with great ceremony over the high altar in the chapel of Santa Maria della Vittoria in Mantua.By the end of the 15th century, large single paintings  were being used as altarpieces, a form that reached its apogee in the works of Titian and Veronese.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Madonna of Victory

DESCRIPTION: The stiffly hierarchical composition of the traditional Sacra Conversazione was also discarded.Mantegna's Mary is turning slightly away from the central axis, which runs from the Tree of Knowledge on the throne pedestal up through the Christ Child to the branch of coral hanging on a chain.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Madonna of Victory

DESCRIPTION: Mary and the idealized, over life-size figures of the saints Michael and George form a majestic group.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Madonna of Victory

DESCRIPTION: Francesco II Gonzaga is depicted kneeling to the left, blessed by the Virgin
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Madonna of Victory

DESCRIPTION: Between 1490 and 1506, the year he died, Mantegna painted several devotional paintings in which the main figures are represented as reliefs standing out against a mostly dark background.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Inspired by reliefs on classical tombs, these figures are shown partially hidden behind stone balustrades or a frame.The subject of Adoration of the Magi was one of the most popular in all fifteenth-century art, especially for the opportunities it presented for the display of rich costumes and accessories, and of numerous subordinate figures with horses and other animals in an extensive landscape.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Mantegna, however, restricts his composition to just six figures - with the three magi on the right converging on the three members of the Holy Family on the left - which he shows in half-length, and hence, too, in powerfully expressive close-up.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Four decades earlier, when still working as a young man in Padua, Mantegna had introduced this type of half-length devotional narrative into Italian painting with his Presentation in the Temple.It was suggested that this painting was executed for Isabella d'Este, the consort of Marquis Francesco Gonzaga
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: This scene shows Julius Caesar in the triumphal chariot.
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Triumphs of Caesar (scene 9)

DESCRIPTION: The triumph of the emperor, who sits like a god in his triumphal chariot, is heralded and lauded - as shown by the presence of putti, which appear only in this painting, the laurel wreath with which Caesar is about to be crowned, the sculptures of conquered warriors on the triumphal arch, and the images of the gods
AUTHOR: MANTEGNA, Andrea
TITLE: Triumphs of Caesar (scene 9)

DESCRIPTION: The flower garland was executed by Mario Nuzzi, nicknamed Mario dei Fiori (1603-1673).
AUTHOR: MARATTI, Carlo
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi (in Garland)

DESCRIPTION: He painted the flowers on several other paintings by Maratti, too
AUTHOR: MARATTI, Carlo
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi (in Garland)

DESCRIPTION: Apart from demonstrating the favours granted by important Roman patrons, Maratti's portraits are also perhaps the most lively and penetrating part of his work.
AUTHOR: MARATTI, Carlo
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Clement IX

DESCRIPTION: He took pains to capture the exact physiognomy of his sitters in whom he sometimes seemed to uncover an incurable feeling of melancholy hiding just below the surface.
AUTHOR: MARATTI, Carlo
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Clement IX

DESCRIPTION: Here his admiration for Raphael's portraits is evident, but he has added a more stylish air to suit the tastes of the high Baroque.The painting was executed shortly before the death of the Pope who was on the throne from 1667 to 1669.
AUTHOR: MARATTI, Carlo
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Clement IX

DESCRIPTION: It is signed on the paper sheet on the table
AUTHOR: MARATTI, Carlo
TITLE: Portrait of Pope Clement IX

DESCRIPTION: Although officially considered a third member of the so-called German Romanists, Hans von Marées, long resident in Italy, moved far from the dramatic narrative of Böcklin or the ponderous perspective of Feuerbach.
AUTHOR: MARÉES, Hans von
TITLE: The Oarsmen

DESCRIPTION: The Berlin-trained von Marées was Germany's major prophet of Modernism, filling a critical role as that nation's Puvis de Chavannes, the French master who was thirteen years his senior.
AUTHOR: MARÉES, Hans von
TITLE: The Oarsmen

DESCRIPTION: Like Puvis de Chavannes, von Marées followed the Nazarene and Pre-Raphalite revival of wall painting.
AUTHOR: MARÉES, Hans von
TITLE: The Oarsmen

DESCRIPTION: His major commission was the 1873 murals for the Library of the German Marine Zoological Station on Naples.The Oarsmen is a powerful study for one of the largest Library fresco, located on the north wall
AUTHOR: MARÉES, Hans von
TITLE: The Oarsmen

DESCRIPTION: The staffage (the small figures animating the scene) in this fine veduta is ascribed to Giovanni Antonio Guardi
AUTHOR: MARIESCHI, Michele
TITLE: The Grand Canal with the Palazzo Labia and Entry to the Cannareggio

DESCRIPTION: The painting represents a capriccio of an imagined cityscape with Saint Mark's Basilica and ruins on the banks of a river.
AUTHOR: MARIESCHI, Michele
TITLE: Capriccio of a Riverside Town

DESCRIPTION: This imagined riverside town is typical of the spirited and picturesque landscapes created early in the career of Michele Marieschi.
AUTHOR: MARIESCHI, Michele
TITLE: Capriccio of a Riverside Town

DESCRIPTION: The artist includes celebrated and instantly recognizable edifices, such as Venice's Saint Mark's Basilica here, and places them side by side with fantasy buildings and crumbling ruins.
AUTHOR: MARIESCHI, Michele
TITLE: Capriccio of a Riverside Town

DESCRIPTION: The artist is not bound by rules of perspective: the ruined columns and the tower overgrown with greenery are painted to a completely different scale than the houses directly opposite them on the other side of the river at right.
AUTHOR: MARIESCHI, Michele
TITLE: Capriccio of a Riverside Town

DESCRIPTION: They dwarf the figures beneath them, who cross the bridge between the two sides
AUTHOR: MARIESCHI, Michele
TITLE: Capriccio of a Riverside Town

DESCRIPTION: The pendant of the painting representing Salome with the head of the Baptist is also in the Budapest museum.
AUTHOR: MARINARI, Onorio
TITLE: Judith with the Head of Holofernes

DESCRIPTION: The two paintings mark a perceptive continuation of the style of Carlo Dolci, Marinari's teacher and cousin, but interpreted in a luminist vein reminiscent of Pietro da Cortona
AUTHOR: MARINARI, Onorio
TITLE: Judith with the Head of Holofernes

DESCRIPTION: Markó often interrupted his stay in Italy for the sake of paying a visit to Hungary.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: This work, made in 1853, is considered a rarity, because, except for a few works during the earliest period of his career, he never painted Hungarian landscapes.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: Although his art can largely be classified as late neo-classicist, this time Markó chose a romantic motif.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: He depicted the Puszta, the region of the country which is still thought to be the most special and the most interesting, with a sweep-pole well, its mandatory symbol.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: A rainbow glows in the stormy sky.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: One is reminded of the anxiety felt before a storm by the ponderous, dark clouds.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: Besides the subject of the painting, its style also shows the traits of romanticism, with special regards to its composition which is built on the contrast between light and dark.
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Elder
TITLE: The Puszta

DESCRIPTION: This signed and dated picture is a characteristic Italianate landscape by Markó, close in style to his father's works, although the handling here is a little freer
AUTHOR: MARKÓ, Károly the Younger
TITLE: Landscape with a Traveller on a Path

DESCRIPTION: This portrait of Benjamin Franklin was commissioned by Robert Alexander, of the firm of William Alexander & Sons, Edinburgh.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, David
TITLE: Portrait of Benjamin Franklin
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 127 x 101 cm

DESCRIPTION: The beribboned document held by Franklin in the portrait is not a treaty or an Act of Parliament, but one of Alexander's deeds.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, David
TITLE: Portrait of Benjamin Franklin
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 127 x 101 cm

DESCRIPTION: The other books and pamphlets suggest the learned evidence brought in support of a wise man's decision.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, David
TITLE: Portrait of Benjamin Franklin
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 127 x 101 cm

DESCRIPTION: The bust of Isaac Newton, whose gaze is directed toward Franklin, invokes the greatest English voice of Reason
AUTHOR: MARTIN, David
TITLE: Portrait of Benjamin Franklin
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas on panel, 127 x 101 cm

DESCRIPTION: In the 1820s Martin produced a series of paintings depicting scenes of disaster, set in infinite, visionary spaces and full of theatrical, nightmarish lighting effects.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, John
TITLE: Pandemonium

DESCRIPTION: Their basic mood largely derived from the artist's familiarity with John Milton's epic poem Paradise Lost and with the biblical Apocalypse.The Pandemonium of 1841 goes back to a passage in the first book of Milton's Paradise Lost, in which "Pandemonium, the palace of Satan, rises suddenly built out of the deep."
AUTHOR: MARTIN, John
TITLE: Pandemonium

DESCRIPTION: In a diagonal perspective characteristic of Martin, a gigantic building complex extends along the waterfront.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, John
TITLE: Pandemonium

DESCRIPTION: This recalls fantastic reconstructions of cities of antiquity.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, John
TITLE: Pandemonium

DESCRIPTION: Martin's Satan, whose invocatory figure stands on a rocky outcrop in the right foreground, has the look of an ancient Greek hero.
AUTHOR: MARTIN, John
TITLE: Pandemonium

DESCRIPTION: Like Achilles outside Troy, he appears with shield and feathered helmet, but commanding an army not of besiegers but of demons and damned souls in their Cyclopean city
AUTHOR: MARTIN, John
TITLE: Pandemonium

DESCRIPTION: The artist seems to have represented here a young girl from the Tuscan countryside and has ennobled her aspect by dressing her in a white mantle with traces of light blue, yellow-lined and edged with a gold ribbon.
AUTHOR: MARTINO DI BARTOLOMMEO
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: He made her face graceful by putting on her head a very light, impalpable white veil
AUTHOR: MARTINO DI BARTOLOMMEO
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This panel shows a battle scene between Dutch cavalry and Spanish infantry
AUTHOR: MARTSZEN, Jan the Younger
TITLE: Battle Scene

DESCRIPTION: Masaccio's frescoes for the Brancacci Chapel in Florence's Santa Maria del Carmine  mark a milestone in the history of wall painting.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Frescoes in the Cappella Brancacci (left view)

DESCRIPTION: They enhance Giottesque traditions of naturalism with new vitality, not merely on their formal properties of space and volume, but also in the psychological intensity that permeates the narrative.The following frescoes can be seen in this view:Expulsion from the Garden (Masaccio)Tribute Money (Masaccio)St Peter Preaching (Masolino)St Peter Healing the Sick with his Shadow (Masaccio)Raising of the Son of Theophilus and St Peter Enthroned (Masaccio and Filippino Lippi)St Paul Visiting St Peter in Prison (Filippino Lippi
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Frescoes in the Cappella Brancacci (left view)

DESCRIPTION: On February 19th 1426 Masaccio agreed to paint an altarpiece for a chapel in the church of the Carmine in Pisa for the sum of 80 florins.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: On December 26th of that year the work must have been already completed since payment for it is recorded on this date.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: Vasari gave a detailed description of the work which was the basis for art critics for the attempt at reconstruction and for the recovery and identification of the work which was dismantled and dispersed in the 18th century.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: Only eleven pieces have so far come to light and they are not sufficient to enable a reliable reconstruction of the whole work.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: The Crucifixion is one of the eleven panels (one of the top panels) connected with the Pisa Polyptych.As in the main panel, the Gothic arch determines the pictorial frame, the upward stress of which Masaccio modifies in his composition.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: To counter the vertical trust imposed by the arch, Masaccio creates a strong horizontal effect with the rather exaggerated extension of the arms of Christ on the cross.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: Although Masaccio still uses the gilt background for his representation, the atmospheric effects remain hauntingly convincing.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Crucifixion

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the central predella panel of the Pisa Altarpiece, directly beneath the enthroned Madonna and Child.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi
