DESCRIPTION: Compared to Gentile da Fabriano's painting of the same subject done in Florence just a few years before, Masaccio's treatment is entirely new.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: Besides offering lifelike portraits of the patron and his nephew in contemporary dress at the middle right, he has given the entire scene a convincing atmosphere which surrounds the figures and the landscape.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: In the distance, the atmosphere breaks down the clarity of the forms resulting in an effect which is referred to as aerial perspective
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The painting is in a poor state of conservation, the colours have altered dramatically.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Profile of a Man

DESCRIPTION: However, the portrait has an extraordinary presence.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Profile of a Man

DESCRIPTION: The face, defined by its sharp contour, is modeled like sculpture.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Profile of a Man

DESCRIPTION: The three-dimensional effect of the mazzocchio (the turban) is emphasized by being cut at the right edge of the picture.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Profile of a Man

DESCRIPTION: The portrait can be compared with various portraits by Masaccio in the Brancacci Chapel in the church of Santa Maria del Carmine, Florence, especially the bystanders in the scene of St Peter preaching.
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Profile of a Man

DESCRIPTION: This comparison points to a date about 1426-27, making this panel the earliest surviving independent portrait in fifteenth-century Florence
AUTHOR: MASACCIO
TITLE: Profile of a Man

DESCRIPTION: The St Sylvester cycle begins in the lunette on the left (north) wall with Constantine's refusal to bathe in the blood of the innocents to cure himself of leprosy
AUTHOR: MASO DI BANCO
TITLE: Emperor Constantine Refuses to Bathe in the Blood of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: This fresco is located behind the smaller tomb on the north wall of the Bardi di Vernio Chapel  in Santa Croce, Florence.
AUTHOR: MASO DI BANCO
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: This tomb (the arcosolium, an arched recess used as a place of entombment) was for the female members of the patron family.
AUTHOR: MASO DI BANCO
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: The front wall with prophets was painted by Maso di Banco, the interior of the niche is attributed to Taddeo Gaddi
AUTHOR: MASO DI BANCO
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: This landscape is constructed similarly to the landscape background in the Baptism of Christ fresco of the Baptistery in Castiglione Olona
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Landscape with Mountains

DESCRIPTION: The images of the four evangelists with their respective symbols in the radiating compartments of the vaulting complement the iconographic program of the fresco cycle.
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Vaulting of the Baptistery

DESCRIPTION: In conformity with the iconographic tradition linking John the Evangelist and John the Baptist, John the Evangelist is given the compartment that opens downward the altar space.
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Vaulting of the Baptistery

DESCRIPTION: On the capstone of the vault the Lamb of God is painted
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Vaulting of the Baptistery

DESCRIPTION: Masolino was called to Rome, perhaps on more than one occasion.
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Founding of Santa Maria Maggiore
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 144 x 76 cm

DESCRIPTION: There he produced a major altarpiece for the church of Santa Maria Maggiore, one of the ancient basilicas of the city.
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Founding of Santa Maria Maggiore
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 144 x 76 cm

DESCRIPTION: The central panel depicts the foundation of the church on the 5th of August when after a miraculous snowfall, the pope traced its ground plan in the snow.
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Founding of Santa Maria Maggiore
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 144 x 76 cm

DESCRIPTION: Masolino produced a memorable scene, with Mary and Christ in a circular halo supervising the event
AUTHOR: MASOLINO da Panicale
TITLE: Founding of Santa Maria Maggiore
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and gold on panel, 144 x 76 cm

DESCRIPTION: On the left wing, an angel with large wings outspread, brings the news that St Anne is with child to Joachim, as he kneels beside a rock, his hands raised in adoration
AUTHOR: MASSYS, Quentin
TITLE: St Anne Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: The left wing shows Salome offering the head of St John the Baptist to Herod.
AUTHOR: MASSYS, Quentin
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: In this panel every face bears the stamp of evil.
AUTHOR: MASSYS, Quentin
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: Herodias uses the tip of her knife to make her mark in the saint's forehead; she is presented as the perfect courtesan untrustworthy and vindictive.
AUTHOR: MASSYS, Quentin
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: Herod himself, with his thick lips, hooked nose and narrowed eyes, even seems a little frightened by what he has just done.
AUTHOR: MASSYS, Quentin
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: The whole panel is marked by an extraordinary sense of profane pleasure in such a sumptuous display of rich colours
AUTHOR: MASSYS, Quentin
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: The painting is inscribed at upper left: AN AETATIS SVAE; at upper right: 30·1544
AUTHOR: MASTER of 1540s
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: The Master of Ávila is identified as Garcia del Barco.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Ávila
TITLE: The Embrace

DESCRIPTION: He was influenced by Gallego and he carried expressionism even further than Gallego, combining it with foreshortening to achieve some unusual effects, which nevertheless remain compatible with a notable precision of composition and form.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Ávila
TITLE: The Embrace

DESCRIPTION: His finest work is the Nativity in the Lázaro Galdiano Museum in Madrid, which forms part of a triptych
AUTHOR: MASTER of Ávila
TITLE: The Embrace

DESCRIPTION: The painting is very reminiscent of the style of Duccio da Buoninsegna
AUTHOR: MASTER of Badia a Isola
TITLE: Maest?

DESCRIPTION: This master was a Netherlandish artist who often painted young girls playing musical instruments or reading.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Female Half-lengths
TITLE: Concert of Women

DESCRIPTION: His graceful, rather mannered style is close to that of Massys.The present scene depicting ladies making music - a kind of love allegory - includes the score of a chanson by Claudin de Sermissy (1490-1562), who composed music at the French court
AUTHOR: MASTER of Female Half-lengths
TITLE: Concert of Women

DESCRIPTION: This picture is typical of the Master of the Female Half-lengths, who specialised in small-scale panels in a courtly style depicting elegant and fashionably-attired women reading, writing or making music, often shown against a plain or neutral background
AUTHOR: MASTER of Female Half-lengths
TITLE: Virgin and Child
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 40 x 29 cm

DESCRIPTION: In his Nativity the Master of Flémalle (Robert Campin) proved himself a sensitive painter of landscape, who knew how to portray the atmospheric subtleties of light and air; but he does not always use nature as the background for his compositions.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: The Crucified Thief

DESCRIPTION: In the Crucified Thief, the one surviving panel of a lost altarpiece, he resorts to the archaic device of a gold background, contrasting its abstraction with the marked individuality of the figures.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: The Crucified Thief

DESCRIPTION: The thief's face is contorted with pain, and the wounds where the cords have cut into the flesh are rendered in an extraordinarily brutal manner.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: The Crucified Thief

DESCRIPTION: The Roman soldiers looking on, particularly the one whose curly hair is held back by a white band and who is placing one hand on his heart, are portrayed with a realism that was at that time outstanding
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: The Crucified Thief

DESCRIPTION: Based on its style the Annunciation is attributed to the Master of Flémalle and dated between c.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The painter's provisional name refers to the "Abbey of Flémalle" where certain of his works are assumed to have been painted.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: However, in this village near Liège there was never any abbey.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: Today the master is commonly identified with the Tournai artist Robert Campin.The scene takes place inside a bourgeois dwelling, a novelty in the painting of the time, as until then the scene had always been depicted in or in front of a church.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: In line with tradition, Gabriel enters the room from the left.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin is seated in front of a low bench on the tiled floor, a sign of her humility.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The edge of her mantle is decorated with an inscription, another innovation of the Master of Flémalle.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: Its text appears to be inspired by the popular medieval Marian hymn Salve Regina.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin's gestures illustrate her acceptance.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: Her right hand rests on her breast, her eyes modestly cast downwards.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: On Mary's lap is an open book, a second one lies on the table.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: This motif is possibly taken from devotional tracts of around 1400, which state that the Virgin was meditating on the Holy Scriptures when Gabriel entered.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The books also indicate her as the possessor of divine wisdom.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: In this connection, the bench is decorated with little lions, as was once the throne of Solomon, the Old Testament king who used to be seen as the epitome of wisdom.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The stained glass figures possibly represent prophets who foretold the coming of the Messiah.Other apparently everyday objects also have an additional, deeper significance.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The hand broom next to the chimney symbolises the purification from the stain of sin, and the white lilies in the maiolica vase Mary's virginity.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The open window probably alludes to her honorary title as 'fenestra coeli', the window of heaven.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The candles and their holders refer to Christ and the Virgin.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The fact that the candles are snuffed out indicates that conception has already taken place.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: One intriguing detail is the woodcut above the chimney, depicting St Christopher carrying the Child across the river.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: This motif is a good illustration of the chronological jumps frequently found in the paintings of Flemish Primitives, as according to the main scene, depicting the Annunciation, the Saviour has not even been born
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Annunciation

DESCRIPTION: The sitter probably was Robert de Masmines, a distinguished Burgundian soldier, identifiable on the basis of a drawing now in Arras.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Portrait of a Fat Man

DESCRIPTION: The daring white background is calculated to heighten every aspect of the sitter's jowly, stubbly physiognomy, his ducal ties indicated by the court's characteristic short haircut and fur-trimmed robes
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Portrait of a Fat Man

DESCRIPTION: X-rays of the left-hand panel indicate that the identity of the artist of this part is more likely to be Rogier van der Weyden, Campin's most gifted pupil.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Mérode Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: In this scene the patrons of the altar, Peter Engelbrecht and his wife, are depicted, kneeling devoutly, along with a man standing by a gate in the background.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Mérode Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: The discovery of additional layers of paint has led to the conclusion that the donor's wife and the man at the gate were added at a later stage
AUTHOR: MASTER of Flémalle
TITLE: Mérode Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: The Master of Moulins (Jean Hey) may have trained in Ghent, but his work, such as the present painting, also suggests familiarity with painting in Bruges
AUTHOR: MASTER of Moulins
TITLE: St Victor with Donor

DESCRIPTION: Although in the 1440s Filippo Lippi explored a variety of solutions for showing the Madonna and Child within or against an architectural niche, with the Child resting on a parapet - the finest example is that in Washington - in none of these is there a similar illusionistic intent, with the parapet and tabernacle window conceived as though projecting into the viewer's space.
AUTHOR: MASTER of Pratovecchio
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: The point of reference for the author of this painting was certainly Donatello' Pazzi Madonna.The artist of this picture certainly spent time in the workshop of Filippo Lippi: the spherical heads and curiously boneless hands relate to Lippi's works of the late 1430s - especially the Tarquinia Madonna and the Barbadori Altarpiece
AUTHOR: MASTER of Pratovecchio
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: This panel was probably the central part of a triptych similar to the triptych by Bernardo Daddi conserved in Berlin
AUTHOR: MASTER of San Lucchese
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This scene on the south wall is in the second bay of the nave
AUTHOR: MASTER of St Francis
TITLE: Scenes from the Life of St Francis: St Francis Receives the Stigmata

DESCRIPTION: Christ hangs bleeding on the cross.
AUTHOR: MASTER of St Francis
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 92 x 71 cm

DESCRIPTION: In the terminals are, on the left, the mourning Virgin supported by Mary Magdalene in red and one of the other Marys, and on the right the mourning St John the Evangelist and the centurion who recognised at the Crucifixion that Christ was the Son of God
AUTHOR: MASTER of St Francis
TITLE: Crucifix
TECHNIQUE: Egg tempera on wood, 92 x 71 cm

DESCRIPTION: This double-sided panel shows on one side the martyrdom of St Lawrence and on the other a woman offering drink to a bedridden man.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Martyrdom of St Lawrence (interior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: The work is a fragment of an altarpiece shutter, in which the St Lawrence scene on gold ground would have been oriented to the interior, visible in the altarpiece's open state.Three other double-sided panels were recognized as part of the same altarpiece.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Martyrdom of St Lawrence (interior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: These panels also depict acts of mercy on the exterior, namely Beheading of John the Baptist (interior) and Providing Shelter to Strangers (exterior) and Feast of Herod (interior) and Feeding the Hungry (exterior), both panels in the Stadtmuseum Simeonstift, Trier, as well as St Lawrence before the Emperor (interior) and Clothing the Naked (exterior) in a private collection.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Martyrdom of St Lawrence (interior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: The dismantled altarpiece was attributed to an unknown master in Salzburg named after this ensemble as Master of the Acts of Mercy.A plausible reconstruction assumes a total of six acts of mercy, and arranges the wing scenes in two tall columns, displaying the Acts of Mercy in the closed state, and three scenes each from the lives of St John the Baptist and St Lawrence in the open state.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Martyrdom of St Lawrence (interior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is suggested that two missing acts, tending the sick and visiting the imprisoned were shown at the top of the wings.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Martyrdom of St Lawrence (interior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: The centre of the altarpiece was probably a painted or a sculpted shrine
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Martyrdom of St Lawrence (interior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: This double-sided panel shows on one side the martyrdom of St Lawrence and on the other a woman offering drink to a bedridden man.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Giving Drink to the Thirsty (exterior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: The work is a fragment of an altarpiece shutter, in which the St Lawrence scene on gold ground would have been oriented to the interior, visible in the altarpiece's open state.Three other double-sided panels were recognized as part of the same altarpiece.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Giving Drink to the Thirsty (exterior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: These panels also depict acts of mercy on the exterior, namely Beheading of John the Baptist (interior) and Providing Shelter to Strangers (exterior) and Feast of Herod (interior) and Feeding the Hungry (exterior), both panels in the Stadtmuseum Simeonstift, Trier, as well as St Lawrence before the Emperor (interior) and Clothing the Naked (exterior) in a private collection.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Giving Drink to the Thirsty (exterior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: The dismantled altarpiece was attributed to an unknown master in Salzburg named after this ensemble as Master of the Acts of Mercy.A plausible reconstruction assumes a total of six acts of mercy, and arranges the wing scenes in two tall columns, displaying the Acts of Mercy in the closed state, and three scenes each from the lives of St John the Baptist and St Lawrence in the open state.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Giving Drink to the Thirsty (exterior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is suggested that two missing acts, tending the sick and visiting the imprisoned were shown at the top of the wings.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Giving Drink to the Thirsty (exterior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: The centre of the altarpiece was probably a painted or a sculpted shrine
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Acts of Mercy
TITLE: Giving Drink to the Thirsty (exterior)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on fir panel, 74 x 47 cm

DESCRIPTION: This panel belonged to a cassone (marriage chest)
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Cassoni Campana
TITLE: The Taking of Athens by Minos, King of Crete
TECHNIQUE: Oil on poplar panel, 69 x 155 cm

DESCRIPTION: The Master of the Castello Nativity (Maestro della Natività di Castello) was a pupil of Filippo Lippi.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Castello Nativity
TITLE: Madonna and Sts Justus and Clement

DESCRIPTION: He must have worked closely with Filippo Lippi, as many of his paintings are direct copies of Lippi's compositions of the late 1450s.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Castello Nativity
TITLE: Madonna and Sts Justus and Clement

DESCRIPTION: This altarpiece comes from the small parish church of Santi Giusto e Clemente in Faltugnano in the hills north of Prato.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Castello Nativity
TITLE: Madonna and Sts Justus and Clement

DESCRIPTION: The three panels which formed the predella are now in the Philadelphia Museum of Art and in the National Gallery, London
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Castello Nativity
TITLE: Madonna and Sts Justus and Clement

DESCRIPTION: The Master of the Holy Blood was a Bruges follower of Quentin Massys and he takes his name from a triptych in the Holy Blood Museum in Bruges, which formed the nucleus around which his oeuvre has been reconstructed.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Virgin and Child with St Catherine and St Barbara
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 87,5 x 66 cm (central panel), 88,5 x 28 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: This triptych in the Groeninge Museum - displayed in the original frame - is one of his best surviving altarpieces.The main scene represents a Rest on the Flight into Egypt in which the seated Virgin with the Child on her lap is accompanied by St Catherine, who as Christ's bride receives the symbolic ring, and St Barbara who holds a peacock's feather in her hand.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Virgin and Child with St Catherine and St Barbara
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 87,5 x 66 cm (central panel), 88,5 x 28 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: It is a rather exceptional combination of the biblical theme with that of the Virgo inter Virgines.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Virgin and Child with St Catherine and St Barbara
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 87,5 x 66 cm (central panel), 88,5 x 28 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: There is an echo of Memling in both the general layout as a triptych and the composition of the main scene, which is remotely reminiscent of the St John altarpiece (Memlingmuseum, Bruges).In the middle ground of the rocky landscape three angels are picking figs (a `poetic' variant of the palm-tree miracle) and on the right walks Joseph, perhaps taking the figs to Mary, who indeed holds a fig in her left hand.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Virgin and Child with St Catherine and St Barbara
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 87,5 x 66 cm (central panel), 88,5 x 28 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The donors on the wings, protected respectively by St Joachim and St Judocus, were identified as Joachim Christiaens, orator of the deanery in Bruges (regularly mentioned between 1535 and 1552) and city councillor (in 1530, 1534, 1536 and 1544), and his second wife Jossine Lamsins.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Virgin and Child with St Catherine and St Barbara
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 87,5 x 66 cm (central panel), 88,5 x 28 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: In the background of the three panels small scenes are depicted from the legend of the saints in the foreground.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Virgin and Child with St Catherine and St Barbara
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 87,5 x 66 cm (central panel), 88,5 x 28 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: On the left wing at the level of the founder's head is the Preaching of St John the Baptist, a scene connected with the patron saint of the former donor.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood

DESCRIPTION: The pilgrim begging for alms in the right wing at the back is connected with the story of St Judocus.The exterior features an Annunciation in grisaille on a red marbled background.The triptych, which dates from around 1520-25, is the first work by this anonymous master to be found in which donor figures appear, and since it is clearly of Bruges origin, there can be no more doubt about his being active in Bruges.Joachim Christiaens died in 1552 and Jossine Lamsins in 1557.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood

DESCRIPTION: Lucretia, the virtuous wife of Lucius Tarquinius Collatinus, committed suicide, as she could not endure the shame of being raped by Sextus Tarquinius, as Livy related.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: This deed secured the legendary Roman lady a place in the series  of exemplary females that in European  painting, particularly in court circles, were depicted as examples of virtue.In this painting Lucretia is a genteel Flemish bourgeois lady, who having undone her fashionable gown, grasp the dagger with both hands and stabs herself in the heart.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: This makes the muddy-green veil on her head start an elegant dance and the wide arms of the gown flutter gently.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: Lucretia is unaccompanied by any of the protagonists of the story, a characteristic of this painting that corresponds to the trend shared by both the North and the South
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Blood
TITLE: Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: The subject of Christ's relatives had been very popular from the beginning of the 15th century.On the left-hand wing are Sts Nicasius and Roch with the Cologne donor Nicasius Hackeney, who ran the fiscal administration of the imperial court; on the right are Sts Gudule and Elizabeth with the donor's wife, Christina (née Hardenrath).
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Kinship
TITLE: The Holy Kinship Altarpiece (central panel)

DESCRIPTION: On the exterior of the wings are Sts Hermolaus, Achatius and his followers on the left, and on the right Sts Cecilia, Genevieve, Helen and Catherine, each with members of the donor's family.

TITLE: The Holy Kinship Altarpiece (central panel)

AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Kinship

TITLE: The Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: It was sold for the Acquisitions Fund in 2013.The style of this master and his workshop was greatly influenced by Flemish painters, in particular, Hugo van der Goes, whose Monforte Altarpiece may be seen as a direct inspiration for the individual figures in this work (particularly the second kneeling King in the Adoration).
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Holy Kinship
TITLE: The Adoration of the Magi

AUTHOR: MASTER of the Isaac Stories

AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence
TITLE: Joseph and the Wife of Puthiphar

DESCRIPTION: His numerous older brothers were strictly only half-brothers, being the sons of Leah or of handmaidens.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence
TITLE: Joseph and the Wife of Puthiphar

DESCRIPTION: The events of his romantic life story have been depicted continuously in Christian art from the 6th century onwards.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence
TITLE: Joseph and the Wife of Puthiphar

DESCRIPTION: The medieval Church saw the episodes of his life as a prefiguration of the life of Christ, and it is to this that he owes his important place in Christian art.When in Egypt as a slave, Potiphar, captain of the Pharaoh's guard, bought Joseph from the Ishmaelites and made him steward of his household (Gen.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence
TITLE: Joseph and the Wife of Puthiphar

AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence
TITLE: Joseph and the Wife of Puthiphar

DESCRIPTION: He refused her though she continued to press him.
AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence
TITLE: Joseph and the Wife of Puthiphar

AUTHOR: MASTER of the Joseph Sequence

DESCRIPTION: At this, Joseph fled so precipitately that he left his cloak at her hands.

TITLE: St Sebastian

TITLE: St Sebastian

TITLE: St Sebastian
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 70 x 27 cm

TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Master Theoderic, a highly original artist, broke free of the styles that were dominated by Italian, Austrian and French art and tried to develop his own distinctive style.
AUTHOR: MASTER THEODERIC
TITLE: Paintings of Saints

DESCRIPTION: Painted between 1360 and 1365, the 30 icon-like portraits of the saints which decorate the Chapel of the Cross at Karlstein Castle are one of the most impressive results of these efforts.
AUTHOR: MASTER THEODERIC
TITLE: Paintings of Saints

DESCRIPTION: The robust features of the individual saints are impressively depicted.Three-dimensional objects have been added, such as carved coats-of-arms, mounted in the manner of collages on the surface of the paintings.
AUTHOR: MASTER THEODERIC
TITLE: Paintings of Saints

DESCRIPTION: Ornamented with discs of gilded Venetian glass and strips of marble encrusted with semiprecious stones, the chapel seems like a Byzantine treasure chamber.
AUTHOR: MASTER THEODERIC
TITLE: Paintings of Saints

DESCRIPTION: It is possible that this room and the adjacent 'privatorium' were intended by the Emperor to create a vision of his future Eastern empire
AUTHOR: MASTER THEODERIC
TITLE: Paintings of Saints

DESCRIPTION: Matteo di Giovanni is best known for four monumental compositions of the Massacre of the Innocents, three for Sienese churches and one in inlaid stone for the pavement of the Duomo.
AUTHOR: MATTEO di Giovanni
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: In the version in Sant'Agostino, the arches and columns of Herod's palace suggest that the artist  had visited Rome.
AUTHOR: MATTEO di Giovanni
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: He has left no foreground space and every inch of Herod's hall is occupied by screaming mothers, dead or dying babies, and bloodthirsty soldiers.
AUTHOR: MATTEO di Giovanni
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: The marble pavement is covered by infant corpses.
AUTHOR: MATTEO di Giovanni
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: Impassive courtiers flank Herod's throne, while the gloating king is portrayed as a monster: one hand is outstretched to order the butchery; the other, like a claw, clutches the marble sphinx on the arm of his throne
AUTHOR: MATTEO di Giovanni
TITLE: Massacre of the Innocents

DESCRIPTION: The Golden Legend, drawing on the apocryphal gospels, tells how the Virgin Mary was brought up as a child in the Temple at Jerusalem 'with other virgins'...and was visited daily of angels', since it had been foretold to her parents, Joachim and Anne, that their daughter was to be consecrated to the Lord as the 'chosen vessel' of Christ's Incarnation.
AUTHOR: MAULBERTSCH, Franz Anton
TITLE: The Education of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The theme became popular in the 16th century and remained so after the Counter-Reformation in spite of some disapproval by the Church because of its apocryphal character.
AUTHOR: MAULBERTSCH, Franz Anton
TITLE: The Education of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Mary is seen in earlier examples teaching her young companions, sewing the priest vestments or being ministered to by angels who bring bread and water.
AUTHOR: MAULBERTSCH, Franz Anton
TITLE: The Education of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: But the favourite theme, especially in Counter-Reformation art, depicts her education in the strict sense, at the knee of her mother Anne, learning to read.You can view other depictions of the Education of the Virgin in the Web Gallery of Art
AUTHOR: MAULBERTSCH, Franz Anton
TITLE: The Education of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The painting was comissioned for the Parish Church at Balassagyarmat, Hungary
AUTHOR: MAULBERTSCH, Franz Anton

DESCRIPTION: Luis Meléndez trained under his father Francisco Antonio Meléndez (1682-1752), a specialist royal portrait miniaturist, who was instrumental in the encouragement of Philip V to establish an academy of fine arts in Madrid, which he eventually founded in 1744, making the artist an honorary director of painting.
AUTHOR: MELÉNDEZ, Luis
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist

DESCRIPTION: Luis Meléndez was one of the first students admitted into the new academy (which was later named the Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando in 1753), where he rapidly excelled in the art of drawing, an event celebrated in his handsome self-portrait (and remarkably the only known portrait by Meléndez) of 1746, now in the Musée du Louvre, Paris.
AUTHOR: MELÉNDEZ, Luis
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist

DESCRIPTION: The highly accomplished skill displayed in this portrait reflects the experience gained by the artist during his apprenticeship to the royal portrait painter Louis-Michel van Loo from 1738 until 1744.
AUTHOR: MELÉNDEZ, Luis
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist

DESCRIPTION: The artist holds one of his drawings

DESCRIPTION: The early decades of the sixteenth century in Cremona were some of the most turbulent in its political history.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: In these years of constantly changing foreign rulers, the local leaders of Cremona pursued an elaborate project of decoration with remarkable consistency.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: From 1506 to 1522 the community had the chancel and nave of the twelve-century cathedral frescoed.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: By continuing the decoration through all the changes in government, the community represented its own identity; it was an act of local self-assertion.The decoration was begun in the semi-dome vault of the apse in 1506.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: Boccaccio Boccaccino depicted, following a time-honoured scheme, the Epiphany of God in the Last Days (Christ in Majesty) as the principal and culminating image within the church space.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: Later, in 1514 Boccaccino received the commission to begin a fresco cycle of the life of Mary and Christ on the walls of the nave.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: They begin on the left wall, running from the façade to the apse and then on the right wall from the apse back to the façade.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The left wall is dedicated to Mary and Christ's childhood; the right to the Passion.Boccaccino painted the scenes above the first four arches of the nave, and Giovan Francesco Bembo had been active above the fifth arch.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: He was not awarded another commission, the fresco cycle was continued by the Cremonese artist Altobello Melone.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello
TITLE: Flight to Egypt

DESCRIPTION: His contract regarding the frescoes above the next arch stipulated that his works should surpass in beauty Boccaccino's frescoes of the first two arches, which had been unveiled in 1515.
AUTHOR: MELONE, Altobello

AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel

AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: A Young Woman Composing Music

AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel

TITLE: Portrait of the Artist with His Wife Isabella de Wolff in a Tavern
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

DESCRIPTION: The man is laughing and puts his left arm around the young woman's shoulders, a gesture echoed by her arm as she hands him some berries.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist with His Wife Isabella de Wolff in a Tavern
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel

TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

DESCRIPTION: Beside the couple a table is laid with a silver pot, some dried fish and a small loaf of bread, but the way it has been truncated at one end gives it the look of a stage prop.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist with His Wife Isabella de Wolff in a Tavern
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

DESCRIPTION: The rear of the tavern is in shadow, so that all that may be distinguished is the incidental figure chalking up orders in front of the fireplace, a narrow shelf, and an empty birdcage hanging above.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist with His Wife Isabella de Wolff in a Tavern
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

DESCRIPTION: The room opens up to the rear at the right, giving a view of a sunny courtyard in which a market stall has been erected.Although the painting was for many years known simply as The Lovers at Breakfast, the two protagonists, quite different in type, have been identified as the artist and Isabella de Wolff, whom he married in 1658 and who was a niece of the painter Pieter de Grebber.The iconography of the painting distinguishes it as part of a painting tradition well-known to the educated contemporary viewer: the carousing, feasting couple, the ambience of the tavern with the landlady at the blackboard, the highly significant bread and fish still-life on the table.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist with His Wife Isabella de Wolff in a Tavern
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

DESCRIPTION: All of these elements point to the subject of the 'prodigal son regaling with the harlots in the inn'.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel

TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 31 cm

DESCRIPTION: Market and kitchen scenes originally came from Flemish painting and above all are linked in the sixteenth century with Pieter Aertsen and Joachim Beuckelaer.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

DESCRIPTION: In sharp contrast to Dutch still-life specialists, the Leiden Feinmalers around Gerard Dou reactivated these subjects for their small-format genre paintings, in which market goods were showed off to their best advantage in small, select groups.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

DESCRIPTION: Metsu's Poultry Seller depicts just such a group of varied items, arranged along the painting's lower and left-hand margins; the precision with which they have been painted testifies to a supreme virtuosity in the Feinmaler style, and is accentuated in part by the use of light and dark contrasts.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

DESCRIPTION: But importantly, each surface receives the same amount of attention: from different woods - a bamboo rod, basketwork, a barrel and a bare tree — to the fluffy fur of the rabbit beside the pale flesh of the plucked hen in the basket, or from the bird's skeletal head, a strong contrast with the luminous red head of the turkey, to the trader's thick wool stockings that differ so from his young customer's delicate, filmy gauze apron.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

DESCRIPTION: Metsu is not simply content, however, to use the Feinmalers' technique of applying flat, narrow brush strokes one beside the next.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

DESCRIPTION: The tree and the row of houses in the background reveal his command of a far more relaxed and expansive style.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

DESCRIPTION: Furthermore, his colours are richer than those of the Leiden Feinmaler, and reveal a love of clear reds, blues and greens demonstrated, for instance, in the young woman's clothes
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: The Poultry Seller
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 62 x 46 cm

AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Tuning a Mandolin

AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel

DESCRIPTION: In both paintings, the way the silvery daylight flows over the figures set against light walls is not surpassed by Vermeer.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

DESCRIPTION: The pendants offer a small drama: the handsome man writes a letter, and its patient recipient attentively reads it by the light of a window.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

DESCRIPTION: Here letter writing and reading are most likely associated with love.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

DESCRIPTION: The discreet waiting maid pulls aside a curtain hanging from a rod to reveal a choppy seascape, possibly but not demonstrably a reference to the popular adage that love is as hazardous as a sea voyage.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

DESCRIPTION: The maid's momentary movement contrasts with the concentration of the young woman who, one senses, will not move until she has finished reading the letter.The curtain over the painting is not an unusual detail.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

DESCRIPTION: The Dutch often protected paintings with curtains, either to keep off the light and dust, or to look at them only occasionally, as is the traditional way of the Chinese and, Japanese - a practice that comes from the fine feeling that a work of art cannot be looked at continually.
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

DESCRIPTION: Trompe l'oeil curtains on rods painted to give the illusion that they have been drawn aside to reveal a framed picture are not uncommon either; best known is the one Rembrandt included in his intimate Holy Family at Kassel
AUTHOR: METSU, Gabriel
TITLE: Woman Reading a Letter

AUTHOR: MEUCCI, Vincenzo
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: This frame, especially characteristic of Rome, was popular both in sacred and secular contexts, and was also frequently used in horizontal-format compositions.
AUTHOR: MEUCCI, Vincenzo
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: The ceiling in the library of Palazzo Corsini, painted by the Florentine Vincenzo Meucci, is a good example.
AUTHOR: MEUCCI, Vincenzo
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: Befitting the stature of the Corsini family, which supplied a pope in Clement XII, the pictorial program combines motifs alluding to the function of the library (church fathers and scholars) with the personification of Ecclesia, angels, putti, virtues, and vanquished vices
AUTHOR: MEUCCI, Vincenzo
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: This painting belongs to the unspecified battle scenes.

TITLE: A Cavalry Battle

DESCRIPTION: The painters visualised current events in a general way.
AUTHOR: MEULENER, Pieter

AUTHOR: MEULENER, Pieter
TITLE: A Cavalry Battle

DESCRIPTION: Meunier found his main subject in about 1880: man at work.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: from 1885, he also turned to this particular subject in his sculpting.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: The title of this relief is a reference to the puddling and Krupp burning process used in iron-making.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: Only a small area of the blast furnace, the actual place of work, is shown on the right-hand edge of this relief.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: The middle one of the three labourers is one of the most impressive to be seen in any of Meunier's works.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: His right foot is pressed against the furnace, his torso is stretching backwards.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: Every muscle, every sinew is tensed as he works the iron with all his strength.Meunier's labourers are types rather than individual people and are idealised.
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: The artist heroized labour in his approach to the working world in what was the age of industrialization
AUTHOR: MEUNIER, Constantin
TITLE: Puddlers

DESCRIPTION: On the left, in a space delimited by the leafy boughs of the tree standing out against the bright sky, and the moderate diagonal formed by the rocks, beyond the trunk of a dead tree, a colloquy of gestures takes place between the tempting serpent - which has assumed the appearance of a woman - and Adam and Eve, with their youthful, athletic bodies, bathed in rosy light
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The Fall

DESCRIPTION: On the right, an angel extends his sword to show the sinners the way to exile from the Garden of Eden.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Expulsion from Garden of Eden

DESCRIPTION: In a desolate landscape, Adam and Eve set out toward their destiny of pain and death, their bodies contracted and suddenly aged, their drawn  faces vividly expressing their remorse and anguish
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Expulsion from Garden of Eden

DESCRIPTION: Seen against an indistinct natural background that is only just hinted at, as if it were the dawn of the world, the youthful, athletic figure reclining on a grassy slope, almost on the edge of an abyss, seems as if he is about to rise from the ground.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Creation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: He holds out his arm toward that of the Lord, who, borne aloft amidst a flight of angels, stands out brightly against the shell of shadow of his huge purple mantle.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Creation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: The remarkable invention of the outstretched arm and the forefingers   about to meet becomes a metaphor for the vital energy that passes from the Creator to the creature fashioned in his image, awakwening his heroic vigor
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Creation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: In planning the architectural design Michelangelo first had to accommodate his program to the pre-existing building, including the windows, which were the source of light for his decoration.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: The wreath of openings still provides the principal viewing light.Michelangelo devised a long central area framed by a fictive marble cornice and separated into nine sections by broad pilaster strips bent across the ceiling, also in imitation white marble.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: Sections of alternating dimensions are framed between wider and narrower bands.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: Within them Michelangelo varied the size of the actual narratives, giving only the smaller ones a marble frame.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: Four ignudi (male nudes), among the most admired elements of the ceiling, ostensibly support ribbons attached to large medallions painted to look like bronze.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: Twenty in all, they are in different poses, producing, together with the Prophets and Sibyls, a "handbook" of alternatives for the seated figure for later artists.At the corners of the ceiling Michelangelo has painted four salvation subjects, including David and Goliath and Judith and Holofernes.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: Triangular-shaped compartments are repeated in a continuous band along the entire border of the ceiling; they contain bronze-colored nudes that alternate with the renowned Prophets and Sibyls set into marble thrones which, in turn, have paired marble putti in a variety of poses and positions that expand upon the tradition of Donatello and Luca della Robbia.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: The ancestors of Christ are painted on the flat side walls, the only section of the decoration that did not require the visual adjustments posed by painting on a curved surface
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: The ceiling

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the Ignudo at the lower right corner of the Drunkenness of Noah (above the Delphic Sibyl).Only the head, a shoulder, and the feet are now visible of this ignudo.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: The rest of the body was destroyed by the detachment of intonaco caused by the explosion of the powder magazine at Castel Sant'Angelo in 1797.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: A sixteenth century engraving shows that the figure was a mirror image of the one facing it, and it is likely that it was executed using the same cartoon reversed
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the Ignudo at the upper left corner of the Separation of the Earth from the Waters (above the Persian Sibyl).The poses of the pairs of ignudi become gradually more dynamic and agitated.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: The two above the Persian Sibyl (at the left) bend backward in opposite directions, while one of those above the prophet Daniel (at right) bends forward, casting an apprehensive glance at the viewer, and the other raises his arm in a movement reminiscent of Hellenistic sculptures of dancing fauns
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the Ignudo at the upper right corner of the Separation of the Earth from the Waters (above the prophet Daniel).The poses of the pairs of ignudi become gradually more dynamic and agitated.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: The two above the Persian Sibyl (at the left) bend backward in opposite directions, while one of those above the prophet Daniel (at right) bends forward, casting an apprehensive glance at the viewer, and the other raises his arm in a movement reminiscent of Hellenistic sculptures of dancing fauns
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ignudo

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the two pairs of putti next to the throne of Joel.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Putti

DESCRIPTION: Simulating stone reliefs, the putti appear to support the projection of the cornice.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Putti

DESCRIPTION: The figures are placed symmetrically at the side of each throne, in graceful poses that at times resemble dances.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Putti

DESCRIPTION: They imitate and vary, with a fresh vein of creativity, the typical repertoire of Florentine Renaissance sculpture, from the singing galleries to the glazed terra-cottas
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Putti

DESCRIPTION: "Matthan begat Jacob.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Jacob - Joseph

DESCRIPTION: Jacob begat Joseph, the husband of Mary, of whom was born Jesus, who is called Christ."
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Jacob - Joseph

DESCRIPTION: (Matthew 1:15-16)At the top of the entrance wall of the chapel, to the right of the viewer, next to the Eleazar-Matthan lunette, there is the one concluding the genealogical sequence of the ancestors of Christ in the Gospel of St Matthew.Sullen and perplexed, wrapped in a huge yellow ochre cloak and seemingly withdrawn, the old man - generally believed to be Jacob - dominates the family group on the left due to his expressive power and the quality of the colour.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Jacob - Joseph

DESCRIPTION: Similarly, on the right, the female figure, usually thought to be Mary, is more prominent than the other members of the Holy Family and the child holding a mirror.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Jacob - Joseph

DESCRIPTION: Behind Mary in the shadow, Joseph holds the Christ child, who stretches out an arm toward the round mirror held out at the height of his face by a naked female child, possibly an allegory of the Church.The compositional schemes of the two neighbouring lunettes correspond: in both there is a female figure in the foreground seen in full, or half, profile and facing the outer wall of the chapel, and a male figure, on the internal side, with his torso seen frontally.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Jacob - Joseph

DESCRIPTION: "Eliakim begat Azor.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: Azor begat Zadok.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: Zadok begat Achim."
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: (Matthew 1:13-14)This is the first lunette on the north wall.The absence of information regarding the figures represented has thwarted any attempt to identify them.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: On the left a seated woman is shown indicating something outside the lunette to a boy (or a girl) who seems to be engrossed in writing or drawing and turns somewhat hesitantly.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: The woman's pose, with its great naturalness and self-possession, is a variation on the twisted head, shoulders, and legs of the other figures.On the other side of the lunette, seen sideways on, but with his head turned toward the viewer, sits a solitary mature man, his face furrowed by deep lines.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: Tightly wrapped in his yellow ochre mantle, from which only his head and an arm emerge, he appears to be prey to distressing thoughts.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: The body, modelled concisely with great plastic power by the interplay of light and shade, and the pattern of the folds of the mantle, stands out clearly against the background.The number of figures present in this lunette is half that of the first lunettes painted by Michelangelo.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: This sense of isolation intensifies the expressive power of the figure of the pensive man, which some interpreted as being an imaginary self-portrait of the artist
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Azor - Zadok

DESCRIPTION: "Solomon begat Rehoboam.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: Rehoboam begat Abijah.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: Abijah begat Asa."
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: (Matthew 1:7)Astonishing naturalness and a large variety of poses characterize the figures in the last lunettes, which are known to have been painted with great rapidity.On the left a woman is depicted in profile; she sits alone, gazing out into the chapel, leaning backward with her elbow on the back of the seat.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: This is a detail that is only found here, and it may be compared to the low step on which, on the other side of the lunette, the sleeping young man rests a foot.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: The woman's right arm and hand are stretched out on her leg, while her left hand points to the unborn child she is carrying in her womb.The young man at right is seated bent forward in an attitude of complete abandon.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: His head, with his face turned toward the wall, is resting on the hand placed on his right knee; his other arm hangs down at his side.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: Behind him, a young boy seems to be trying to make him sit upright by grabbing his shoulder.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: The juxtapositions of bright colours in the woman's clothes - a green scarf over her head and shoulders, a violet-rose pinafore, a reddish-orange mantle with yellow ocher lining - are matched by equally rich, but more delicate, tones in those of the young man
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Rehoboam - Abijah

DESCRIPTION: The figures are in the trianglar spandrel in the second bay between Joel and the Erythraean Sibyl.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: The spandrel is above the Zerubbabel-Abiud-Eliakim lunette.It is generally believed that Zerubbabel is depicted here, together with his parents and a brother
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: The figures are in the triangular spandrel in the sixth bay between Ezekiel and the Persian Sibyl.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: The spandrel is situated over the Rehoboam-Abijah lunette.Michelangelo painted a family group in this lunette.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: The woman, seen in profile, is seated in the foreground, in an absorbed attitude, her chin resting on her hand; with her other arm she embraces her child.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: Behind her, the gray-haired head of a male figure emerges from the shadows.Above, on each side of the ram's skull, the bronze nudes no longer take the form of motionless, reclining figures, but are howling demons who struggle furiously in almost acrobatic positions in the restricted space enclosing them.
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: Although their poses are perfectly symmetrical, their hair seems to be blown in the same direction, as if by a sudden gust of wind.It is usually assumed that the male figure in the shadows represents Solomon, the father of Rehoboam
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Ancestors of Christ: figures

DESCRIPTION: The medallion in the third bay, above the Erythraean Sibyl, represents the Destruction of the Statue of the God Baal
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Medallion

DESCRIPTION: The medallion in the ninth bay, above the Jeremiah, represents the Elijah Ascending to Heaven on the Chariot of Fire
AUTHOR: MICHELANGELO Buonarroti
TITLE: Medallion

DESCRIPTION: This painting is an example of the Bambocciata painted by Dutch artists in Rome.
AUTHOR: MIEL, Jan
TITLE: Dance in the Trattoria

DESCRIPTION: (Bambocciata: genre scene of popular life in the suburbs of Rome made popular by the Netherlandish painter Pieter van Laer, known in Italy as Il Bamboccio.)
AUTHOR: MIEL, Jan
TITLE: Dance in the Trattoria

DESCRIPTION: A Genoese nobleman commissioned Miel to paint scenes from the Roman carnival for his Roman apartment.
AUTHOR: MIEL, Jan
TITLE: Dance in the Trattoria

DESCRIPTION: In this canvas the painter set the popular characters of the Comedia dell'Arte in a small trattoria
AUTHOR: MIEL, Jan
TITLE: Dance in the Trattoria

DESCRIPTION: This painting is one of the earliest of its kind in Dutch art.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Willem van der Meer

DESCRIPTION: In composition these works could be considered the unsavoury counter-parts of civic-guard company portraits, which often depicts the officers around a table laden with food.The painting was commissioned by the surgeon's guild in Delft from the leading painter of the city, Michiel van Miereveld.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Willem van der Meer

DESCRIPTION: It is specified in the Latin inscription on the railing that the painter's elder son, Pieter, actually carried out the painting following his father's design.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Willem van der Meer

DESCRIPTION: No independent pictures by Pieter is known, and he died six years after working on the painting, at the age of twenty-seven
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Anatomy Lesson of Dr. Willem van der Meer

DESCRIPTION: In 1607 the Delft city fathers commissioned the Delft portraitist Michiel van Miereveld to paint a portrait of the Dutch stadholder Prince Maurits (1567-1625).
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of Maurits, Prince of Orange-Nassau

DESCRIPTION: Van Miereveld went to The Hague to record his subjects's features and produced this portrait of the prince in armour, with sword and baton, representing his role as captain general of the Dutch army.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of Maurits, Prince of Orange-Nassau

DESCRIPTION: This picture became the model for all the later portraits of the prince.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of Maurits, Prince of Orange-Nassau

DESCRIPTION: (A full-length version of this portrait from 1615-20 is now in the Rijksmuseum Amsterdam.)
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of Maurits, Prince of Orange-Nassau

DESCRIPTION: The portrait was engraved by Jan Muller in 1608and, like countless copies from Van Mireveld's workshop, hung in homes throughout the Netherlands.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of Maurits, Prince of Orange-Nassau

DESCRIPTION: A bust-length version of the 1607 composition hangs above the fireplace in A Man Weighing Gold by Cornelis de Man
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of Maurits, Prince of Orange-Nassau

DESCRIPTION: Hundreds of conservative portraits dating from the first half of the seventeenth century follow the patterns employed by Van Miereveld and the artists he influenced, such as Jan van Ravesteyn in The Hague and Paulus Morelsee in Utrecht.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: Van Miereveld's reputation rested not upon invention or painterly effects but upon fidelity to appearance and exceptional craftsmanship.The identity of the sitter is not known.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed and dated right centre: A° 1630.
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: / M. Mierevelt
AUTHOR: MIEREVELD, Michiel Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: Mieris's work are marked by the exceptional thoroughness of details, an effective variety of textures, and a smooth manner of painting akin to that of enamel miniatures.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Frans van, the Elder
TITLE: Oyster Eaters

DESCRIPTION: The everyday subject has an obvious erotic subtext: the richly furnished interior and elegant attire mask the vice that is cultivated in this establishment dedicated to gratification.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Frans van, the Elder
TITLE: Oyster Eaters

DESCRIPTION: The gentleman offers oysters, a symbol of lust and base pleasures.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Frans van, the Elder
TITLE: Oyster Eaters

DESCRIPTION: The woman's feigned shyness cannot hide her satiated ennui
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Frans van, the Elder
TITLE: Oyster Eaters

DESCRIPTION: The biblical story depicted in the paintings is the following.Hagar, the Egyptian hand maiden of Sarah was the mother of Ishmael, Abraham's first son.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Willem van
TITLE: Expulsion of Hagar
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas mounted on panel, 44 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: When Isaac, Sarah's son, was born Ishmael mocked his younger brother so that Sarah asked Abraham to banish him, together with his mother.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Willem van
TITLE: Expulsion of Hagar
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas mounted on panel, 44 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: Abraham provided them with bread and a bottle of water and sent them off into the desert of Beersheba.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Willem van
TITLE: Expulsion of Hagar
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas mounted on panel, 44 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: When the water was spent Hagar put Ismael under a bush to die and then sat some way off, weeping.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Willem van
TITLE: Expulsion of Hagar
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas mounted on panel, 44 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: But an angel appeared, by tradition the archangel Michael, and disclosed a well of water near by, so they were both saved.
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Willem van
TITLE: Expulsion of Hagar
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas mounted on panel, 44 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: Two scenes, the banishment, and the appearance of the angel are common in 17th century Italian and Dutch painting
AUTHOR: MIERIS, Willem van
TITLE: Expulsion of Hagar
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas mounted on panel, 44 x 34 cm

DESCRIPTION: In the middle of the eighteenth century numerous native portraitists - in addition to a few foreigners - were active in Holland.
AUTHOR: MIJN, George van der
TITLE: Elizabeth Troost

DESCRIPTION: They could be relied upon for truthful portrayals and good conversation pieces.
AUTHOR: MIJN, George van der
TITLE: Elizabeth Troost

DESCRIPTION: The high level they could attain is seen in van der Mijn's small pendants of the wealthy timber merchant, great collector, and amateur artist Cornelis Ploos van Amstel and his wife Elizabeth Troost.At the time, Amsterdam's art world was closely knit.
AUTHOR: MIJN, George van der
TITLE: Elizabeth Troost

DESCRIPTION: Elizabeth's sister Sarah married Ploos van Amstel's brother.
AUTHOR: MIJN, George van der
TITLE: Elizabeth Troost

DESCRIPTION: and George van der Mijn was a close friend of his patron who had contact with the foremost artists, collectors, and intellectuals of the city.Van der Mijn portrait of Elizabeth Troost holding a small cup is as sympathetic as a Chardin lady.
AUTHOR: MIJN, George van der
TITLE: Elizabeth Troost

DESCRIPTION: The touch in passages of the portrait is remarkable free and the colour harmonies are beautiful
AUTHOR: MIJN, George van der
TITLE: Elizabeth Troost

DESCRIPTION: Earlier the painting was attributed to Paul Troger

TITLE: Baptism of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Under Louis XIV, the two main landscape painter of the time were Pierre Patel and Francisque Millet.
AUTHOR: MILLET, Francisque
TITLE: Imaginary Landscape

DESCRIPTION: They were largely derivative in their styles, but this was the secret of their success.
AUTHOR: MILLET, Francisque
TITLE: Imaginary Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Both of them are relatively little known today.Francisque Millet was more talented than Patel, though his present reputation is also obscure.
AUTHOR: MILLET, Francisque
TITLE: Imaginary Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Flemish in origin like Philippe de Champaigne, he worked mainly in Paris, specializing in classical landscapes inspired by the works of Dughet and Poussin.
AUTHOR: MILLET, Francisque
TITLE: Imaginary Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Millet had imagination and good powers of observation, but he never painted anything without a classical format.
AUTHOR: MILLET, Francisque
TITLE: Imaginary Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Millet preferred an intense blue for his landscapes (as did Poussin), which gives then an unnatural air.The ideal landscape in Budapest characterizes well the style of this French painter of Flemish origin
AUTHOR: MILLET, Francisque
TITLE: Imaginary Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Hendrik van Minderhout painted a number of large exotic harbour scenes such as this which follow in the tradition of Jan Baptist Weenix and Johannes Lingelbach.
AUTHOR: MINDERHOUT, Hendrik van
TITLE: A Levantine Harbour

DESCRIPTION: He favoured compositions built around a central quay lavishly staffed, with Dutch vessels in the open water to the left and Roman ruins or a steep hill to the right to create a high repoussoir and offset his scenes against a richly coloured early evening sky.The present painting shows a Levantine harbour with a galley and a man-of-war coming in to anchor, together with many figures on shore
AUTHOR: MINDERHOUT, Hendrik van
TITLE: A Levantine Harbour

DESCRIPTION: The architectonical elements of quadratura, or trompe-l'oeil, decoration provide the grand duke's Private Audience Hall with startling illusionistic effects.
AUTHOR: MITELLI, Agostino
TITLE: View of the Sala dell'Udienza del Granduca

DESCRIPTION: On its rear wall Mitelli painted a grand double staircase that visually enlarges the actual size of the room through a deceptive perspectival device.
AUTHOR: MITELLI, Agostino
TITLE: View of the Sala dell'Udienza del Granduca

DESCRIPTION: The figure of a court official, painted by Mitelli's partner Angelo Michele Colonna (c.
AUTHOR: MITELLI, Agostino
TITLE: View of the Sala dell'Udienza del Granduca

DESCRIPTION: 1600-1687) is seen in the act of climbing the imaginary stairs, thus adding a sense of illusionary reality.In the Palazzo Pitti commission the Colonna-Mitelli collaboration developed a successful model that the pair was able to translate to other situations.
AUTHOR: MITELLI, Agostino
TITLE: View of the Sala dell'Udienza del Granduca

DESCRIPTION: The best example of this is the painting, from a few years later, in the salone of the d'Este summer residence in Sassuolo, near Modena
AUTHOR: MITELLI, Agostino
TITLE: View of the Sala dell'Udienza del Granduca

DESCRIPTION: The painting reveals the influence of Guercino on Mola's style

DESCRIPTION: This signed painting depicts a winter landscape with a horse-drawn sled and many figures skating on the frozen riverbank, a farmhouse on a small hill to the left
AUTHOR: MOLENAER, Klaes
TITLE: Winter Landscape
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 39 x 33 cm

DESCRIPTION: Two out of three winters in Holland during the 17th century saw particularly extended periods of frosts and snow.
AUTHOR: MOLENAER, Klaes
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: During the 1660s the level of snowfall increased significantly and two of the harshest winters were in 1662-63 and 1671-72.
AUTHOR: MOLENAER, Klaes
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Dutch artists, among them Jacob van Ruisdael and Klaes Molenaer produced many winter landscape in this period.
AUTHOR: MOLENAER, Klaes
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Molenaer's winter scenes are characterised by a great interest in the harmony and balance between the figures and their surroundings, more akin to the work of the Haarlem painter of the previous generation, Isack van Ostade, than the atmospheric landscapes of Jacob van Ruisdael.The landscape elements in the present scene are broadly repeated in other works by Molenaer.
AUTHOR: MOLENAER, Klaes
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: This painting depicts a winter landscape with skaters on a river near a walled town
AUTHOR: MOLENAER, Klaes
TITLE: Winter Landscape
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 37 x 49 cm

DESCRIPTION: The present late work by Pieter de Molyn depicts a hilly landscape with wanderers at the foot of a castle ruin.
AUTHOR: MOLYN, Pieter de
TITLE: Hilly Landscape

DESCRIPTION: The artist often used towering manmade structures, such as towers or windmills, as framing devices in his works
AUTHOR: MOLYN, Pieter de
TITLE: Hilly Landscape

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the result of a co-operation of three artists, Joos de Momper (landscape), Hendrik van Balen (figures) and Jan 'Velvet' Brueghel (flowers).
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: It is an attractive work with a harmonious landscape.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: The foreground and background merge gradually with one another, forbidding rocks give way to a grand valley, in which the mythological scene forms a balanced component.Ovid describes (Met.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: 5:250-268) how Minerva visited the Muses on Mt Helicon, their home, to listen to their song and story and to see the sacred spring, the Hippocrene, which flowed from a rock after it had been struck by the hoof of the winged horse, Pegasus.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: The scene is a wooded mountain-side where the company of Muses are playing their instruments.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: Pegasus is seen in the background leaping from a high rock from which water gushes.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: The association of Minerva and the Muses was in line with the tradition that made her patroness of the arts
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Helicon or Minerva's Visit to the Muses

DESCRIPTION: Momper is rightly regarded as the most important Flemish landscape painter between Pieter Brueghel and Rubens.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Winter landscape

DESCRIPTION: Brueghel's influence is clearly evident in this winter landscape, and it is quite probable that his son Jan also painted a number of the figures in this picture.Momper's personal achievement lies in his rendering of landscape as a picturesque subject matter in its own right.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Winter landscape

DESCRIPTION: What we see here is no longer a great universal landscape full of symbolically charged allusions, but a scene whose aesthetic appeal is valued for its own sake.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Winter landscape

DESCRIPTION: Momper's painting is divided into various planes by a kind of backdrop, against which silhouettes are highlighted by a pale light or dark, thundery clouds.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Winter landscape

DESCRIPTION: People are making their way along tortuous paths on terrain that seems to be hazardous.Rain-laden stormclouds, sunshine and snow set the atmosphere of the painting.
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Winter landscape

DESCRIPTION: In this respect, Momper has taken an important step towards emancipating the landscape painting as an autonomous genre in which the landscape is not merely a setting for some event, but is treated as a subject matter in its own right
AUTHOR: MOMPER, Joos de
TITLE: Winter landscape

DESCRIPTION: The painting, monogrammed P.M, has a companion-piece in the same private collection

TITLE: Hôtel des Roches Noires in Trouville

TITLE: Hôtel des Roches Noires in Trouville

DESCRIPTION: In this painting, thanks to the rapid, expressive brushwork, the clouds appear foreshortened and the flags are fluttering as if in tatters in the wind.

TITLE: Hôtel des Roches Noires in Trouville

DESCRIPTION: Even the figures, like the man raising his hat on the left, are sketchily captured with just a few brush strokes
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
