DESCRIPTION: Till 1878 Monet lived at Argenteuil.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Bridge at Argenteuil

DESCRIPTION: The two road and rail bridges rebuilt after the war were a subject Monet repeatedly painted, and here he could experiment with the spatial effects of diagonals.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Bridge at Argenteuil

DESCRIPTION: Engineering achievements using iron, and steaming railway trains or the flow of traffic across a road bridge, also introduced an element of modernity into Monet's landscapes
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Bridge at Argenteuil

DESCRIPTION: Two women, accompanied by their children, are walking through the tall grass in a field full of poppies.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: A Field of Poppies

DESCRIPTION: Their fashionable hats and the parasols indicate that they are from the city and have come to take a restful walk in the country.Monet showed this small picture at the first group exhibition held by the Impressionists in 1874.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: A Field of Poppies

DESCRIPTION: The picture is clear evidence of the Impressionist's preoccupation with the then very modern themes of leisure and relaxation
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: A Field of Poppies

DESCRIPTION: Flags were flown on 30 June, 1878, to mark the opening of the Great Exhibition.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rue Montorgueil in Paris, Celebration of 30 June 1878

DESCRIPTION: On that day, a sea of flags was fluttering in the wind, and countless people filled the streets.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rue Montorgueil in Paris, Celebration of 30 June 1878

DESCRIPTION: Monet chose a high vantage point in order to emphasize the huge gathering of people.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rue Montorgueil in Paris, Celebration of 30 June 1878

DESCRIPTION: Viewed at close quarters, the milling throng gives the illusion of an ethereal carpet of colour.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rue Montorgueil in Paris, Celebration of 30 June 1878

DESCRIPTION: It is not until one is at a certain distance from the painting that the concrete aspect of the picture comes into focus, and the people on the streets become recognizable as well as the individual flags, which look as though they have been released from the façades of the houses to the left and right
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rue Montorgueil in Paris, Celebration of 30 June 1878

DESCRIPTION: It was after moving to Giverny, 80 kilometres northwest of Paris, in 1883 that Monet first took a keen interest in the rural landscape.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Meadow at Giverny

DESCRIPTION: While there he became fascinated with the effect of fog obscuring the boundaries of objects and softening colours.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Meadow at Giverny

DESCRIPTION: It was also in Giverny that he would paint his celebrated series of water lilies
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Meadow at Giverny

DESCRIPTION: In the spring of 1889 Monet was the guest of the poet and composer Maurice Rollinat in Fresselines, in the valley of the Creuse between Orléans and Limoges.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Valley of the Creuse (Sunlight Effect)

DESCRIPTION: He painted 23 landscapes here, treating motifs in different versions.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Valley of the Creuse (Sunlight Effect)

DESCRIPTION: The present painting belongs to a group of eight compositions which differs only in the condition of light
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Valley of the Creuse (Sunlight Effect)

DESCRIPTION: When Monet began his serial compositions in the late 1880s, which initially featured haystacks, then polars, and in the early 1890s the cathedral at Rouen, these works constituted a logical progression of his artistic interests.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rouen Cathedral in Full Sunlight

DESCRIPTION: By constantly portraying the same subject, the variables determined by the time of the day and the lighting could be particularly strongly accentuated.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rouen Cathedral in Full Sunlight

DESCRIPTION: Different times of day and a changing colour palette were substituted for innovative subject matter.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rouen Cathedral in Full Sunlight

DESCRIPTION: Monet included the time of the day and the dominant colours in the respective titles of his paintings as a matter of course.Sometimes he worked simultaneously on two canvases, in order to be able to react immediately to changing light conditions.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rouen Cathedral in Full Sunlight

DESCRIPTION: As a result, the subject of the picture receded further and further into the background.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rouen Cathedral in Full Sunlight

DESCRIPTION: At first glance we can see the shape of a cathedral, but on closer inspection the cathedral architecture dissolves before our eyes into a vibrant ensemble, composed merely of a collection of brush strokes
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Rouen Cathedral in Full Sunlight

DESCRIPTION: This canvas belongs to a series of eleven paintings executed after Monet's stays in London.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: The Parliament building is viewed from a window of St.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: Thomas's Hospital located on the opposite shore of the Thames.During his four visits to London between 1900 and 1905, Monet did a series of paintings of the Houses of Parliament.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: In these works his art attained new heights.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: Everything visible is resolved in the reflection of light.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: The subtitle of the painting, "With the Sun Shining through Fog", is significant.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: Not only the sky, but also the river and even the buildings are fused together in dazzling colour tones.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: The Houses of Parliament rise up out of the fog like a vision.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: It is not the building which seems to be present but rather its optical effect
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Houses of Parliament in London

DESCRIPTION: Monet traveled to Venice with his wife Alice in 1908 and 1909.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Grand Canal in Venice

DESCRIPTION: He painted several pictures with views of the Canal Grande, Rio de la Salute, San Giorgio Maggiore, and various palaces such as the Palazzo Contarini.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Grand Canal in Venice

DESCRIPTION: However, these paintings were executed from memory in his studio in Giverny
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: The Grand Canal in Venice

DESCRIPTION: In 1893, Monet purchased land with a pond near his property in Giverny, and he built here his water lily garden with a Japanese bridge spanning the pond at its narrowest point.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Bridge over a Pond of Water Lilies

DESCRIPTION: In 1899, he began a series of eighteen views of the wooden footbridge over the pond, completing twelve paintings, including the present one, that summer.
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Bridge over a Pond of Water Lilies

DESCRIPTION: The vertical format of the picture, unusual in this series, gives prominence to the water lilies and their reflections on the pond
AUTHOR: MONET, Claude
TITLE: Bridge over a Pond of Water Lilies

DESCRIPTION: This is one of a pair of similar still-lifes
AUTHOR: MONNOYER, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Bouquet of Flowers in Glass Vase on Marble Ledge

DESCRIPTION: This is one of a pair of similar still-lifes
AUTHOR: MONNOYER, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Bouquet of Flowers in Glass Vase on Marble Ledge

DESCRIPTION: Monnoyer was, in his prime in the 1670s, the foremost still-life painter in Europe, but his skill has been much underestimated in recent years, due to the proliferation of incorrect attributions to him.
AUTHOR: MONNOYER, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Still-Life of Flowers and Fruits

DESCRIPTION: He specialized in flower pieces of the most elaborate design, although in the early part of his career he produced more conventional still-life paintings, such as the one in the Musée Fabre at Montpellier.The painting was executed in 1665 and submitted to the Academy at the time of the painter's admission in the same year.
AUTHOR: MONNOYER, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Still-Life of Flowers and Fruits

DESCRIPTION: Following the upheavals of the Revolution in 1789, it was deposited at Montpellier in 1804.
AUTHOR: MONNOYER, Jean-Baptiste
TITLE: Still-Life of Flowers and Fruits

DESCRIPTION: This is the primary signed and dated version of three panels representing the young Christ which Montagna executed in or around 1507 when the artist was in Verona.The iconography of representations of the young Christ was well established in the Veneto in the 16th century.
AUTHOR: MONTAGNA, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Young Christ

DESCRIPTION: The inspiration for many of these representations probably depended on a lost prototype by Leonardo or on Albrecht Dürer's Christ Among the Doctors, which was in Venice in the early 16th century.The panel is signed, inscribed and dated on the ledge: CHRISTVS VIVIFICAT SVAM FIGVRAM .
AUTHOR: MONTAGNA, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Young Christ

DESCRIPTION: MDVII ./ MONTAGNAE CELEBRIS MANVS VENVSTAT.
AUTHOR: MONTAGNA, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Young Christ

DESCRIPTION: DIE.
AUTHOR: MONTAGNA, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Young Christ

DESCRIPTION: III MARCII
AUTHOR: MONTAGNA, Bartolomeo
TITLE: The Young Christ

DESCRIPTION: The painting represents Steven van Herwijck (c.1530- 1565/67)
AUTHOR: MOR VAN DASHORST, Anthonis
TITLE: Portrait of a Goldsmith

DESCRIPTION: Iconoclasm is the deliberate destruction within a culture of the culture's own religious icons and other symbols or monuments, usually for religious or political motives.
AUTHOR: MORELLI, Domenico
TITLE: The Iconoclasts

DESCRIPTION: It is a frequent component of major political or religious changes.
AUTHOR: MORELLI, Domenico
TITLE: The Iconoclasts

DESCRIPTION: People who engage in or support iconoclasm are called "iconoclasts", a term that has come to be applied figuratively to any individual who challenges established dogma or conventions
AUTHOR: MORELLI, Domenico
TITLE: The Iconoclasts

DESCRIPTION: The attribution to Moretto is debated
AUTHOR: MORETTO da Brescia
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: In this important early work by Moretto, Christ is mourned by the Virgin Mary, Saint John the Evangelist, and Mary Magdalen.
AUTHOR: MORETTO da Brescia
TITLE: Piet?

DESCRIPTION: By introducing the grandeur and monumental composition of Venetian masters, particularly Titian, Moretto brought new stature to the local Brescian shool of painting
AUTHOR: MORETTO da Brescia
TITLE: Piet?

DESCRIPTION: Berthe Morisot's style was principally influenced by Manet then, following his death by Renoir, in particular his paintings of women, as in the present work, in which she depicted a young woman getting dressed in front of a cheval-glass (a long mirror mounted on swivels in a frame)
AUTHOR: MORISOT, Berthe
TITLE: The Cheval-Glass

DESCRIPTION: The Palazzo Grassi, overlooking the Grand Canal opposite the Ca' Rezzonico in Venice.
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: was built for the Grassi family by Giorgio Massari between 1749 and 1766.
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: The architect adopted an innovative solution on the ground floor, with its two-story high main hall, large colonnaded courtyard, and "imperial style' main staircase, which proceed with grand theatrical effect from the Grand Canal façade through to the back of the building.For the decoration of the first staircase landing, Massari turned to his trusted sculptor, Giovan Maria Morlaiter, who is responsible for the large bas-relief that depicts Concord.
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: It was the celebrated sculptor, who suggested his own son, Michelangelo, to execute the frescoes on the second landing.
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: The architecture was painted by Francesco Zanchi (active 1734-1772).Morlaiter's decoration develops along the walls of the staircase space, at the level of the second landing.
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: Inside seven large arches delimited by Ionic pilasters, he painted a large faux loggia, closed off at the back by a marble wall, against which statues of goddesses stand inside aedicules surmounted by rectangular tympanums.
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: A carnival-like reception is under way on the loggia, and the participants include a number of elegant ladies and noblemen, some in wigs, some in three-cornered hats, as well as a prelate and an Eastern figure, all busy conversing amiably, or sipping coffee and liquors served by efficient waiters in livery.In spite of the fact that Morlaiter's authorship is well documented, in the nineteenth century the frescoes were attributed to several painters, among them Pietro Longhi
AUTHOR: MORLAITER, Michelangelo
TITLE: Decoration of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: The reputation of Moroni of Bergamo rests primarily on his numerous portraits although, like his master, Moretto da Brescia, he also painted altarpieces and religious compositions.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Foscarini

DESCRIPTION: His models were, for the most part, the patricians, bourgeois scholars and artisans living in the small towns of Northern Italy.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Foscarini

DESCRIPTION: Usually he painted them at work with the tools of their particular trade: the scholar is seen holding a book or writing implements, the tailor is about to cut his cloth.According to a later inscription at the top right, this is a portrait of Jacopo Contarini, Podesta of Padua.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Foscarini

DESCRIPTION: However, Padua never had a Podesta of this name and, since it is known that Jacopo Foscarini filled that office when the picture was painted, we can only assume that the inscription is inaccurate and that the portrait is indeed of Foscarini.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Foscarini

DESCRIPTION: He is shown as a distinguished man of middle age with an air of seriousness that commands respect.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Foscarini

DESCRIPTION: Only the serene harmony of greys and reds resolves the sombre mood of the painting
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Foscarini

DESCRIPTION: The inscription below is NOSCE TE APHTON (Recognize yourself).
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: Formerly it was attributed to Tiitan as a portrait of Aretino due to an erraneous reading of the last word of the inscription (Areton instead of Aphton)
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: Moroni was one of the most accomplished portraitists in Lombard painting in the 16th century.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of a Soldier

DESCRIPTION: For a long time he did not obtain the recognition he deserved, because some of his best portraits were attributed to Titian.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of a Soldier

DESCRIPTION: His teacher was Moretto da Brescia (Alessandro Bonvicino), like-wise a skilled portraitist.
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of a Soldier

DESCRIPTION: There is no documented evidence of Moroni ever having visited Venice, but his oeuvre demonstrates that he was familiar with the work being done there
AUTHOR: MORONI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Portrait of a Soldier

DESCRIPTION: This painting looks like a genre picture but the bread and wine indicate that these are Mary, Joseph and the Christ Child
AUTHOR: MOSTAERT, Jan
TITLE: The Holy Family at Table

DESCRIPTION: Numerous portraits have been attributed to Jan Mostaert.
AUTHOR: MOSTAERT, Jan
TITLE: Portrait of Abel van den Colster

DESCRIPTION: These range from those of ancient nobility to lesser Dutch aristocrats and burghers.
AUTHOR: MOSTAERT, Jan
TITLE: Portrait of Abel van den Colster

DESCRIPTION: The royal portraits are all copies after originals painted for Margaret of Austria, but the others are taken from life and then imbued with an aristocratic flavour through the settings.
AUTHOR: MOSTAERT, Jan
TITLE: Portrait of Abel van den Colster

DESCRIPTION: Such is the case in the present portrait where a coat of arms in the architecture and the initials on the cushion beneath his hands identify the sitter, who was a knight of a well-known Haarlem family
AUTHOR: MOSTAERT, Jan
TITLE: Portrait of Abel van den Colster

DESCRIPTION: An engraving of the same subject by Muller is also known
AUTHOR: MULLER, Jan Harmensz.
TITLE: Lot and His Daughters

DESCRIPTION: The sequence opens with Christ's prayer on the Mount of Olives.
AUTHOR: MULTSCHER, Hans
TITLE: Prayer on the Mount of Olives

DESCRIPTION: This is followed by Christ before Pilate.
AUTHOR: MULTSCHER, Hans
TITLE: Prayer on the Mount of Olives

DESCRIPTION: The Roman procurator has just pronounced the death sentence and is washing his hands as  a sign that he is innocent of the death of the Lord.
AUTHOR: MULTSCHER, Hans
TITLE: Prayer on the Mount of Olives

DESCRIPTION: The next scene is of Christ carrying the cross to Calvary.
AUTHOR: MULTSCHER, Hans

DESCRIPTION: The sequence concludes with Christ's resurrection.

DESCRIPTION: The outlaw's life and figure was a major concern for Munkácsy ever since his childhood.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: It is known from his "Memoirs" that  he suffered much during the years of apprenticeship and that he always  wanted to see a living outlaw as a symbol of free life even  if he had to wait for him under a table in the inn.In the drama of  "Condemned Cell", he painted the embarrassed apprentice.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: Munkácsy had followed the life of his hero in his earliest genre pictures painted in 1867 or illustrations for journals.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: He needed an immense amount of skill in order to paint a true picture of a man condemned to death who had been given proper food and looked after for three days, and then his family, friends and enemies were to come to say good-bye to him.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: His wife is sobbing her heart out in a corner, his little daughter is pottering about not knowing what is going on and she is munching something.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: The outlaw must have resigned to his lot and has nothing more to expect of life: he throws the Bible to the ground.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: A patch of the blue sky becomes visible behind  the bars
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: The Condemned Cell

DESCRIPTION: Munkácsy often spent the summer at his wife's estate in Colpach.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: Colpach Castle, located in Colpach-Bas near Ell in western Luxembourg, dates from the beginning of the 14th century.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: The castle was originally a small medieval stronghold surrounded by a moat, it was adapted as a manor house in the 18th century.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: In about 1870, Baron Edouard de Marches, the first husband of Munkácsy's wife, laid out the gardens surrounding the castle.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: Munkácsy and his wife spent their summers in Colpach Castle and the winters in Paris.Munkácsy painted this landscape in Colpach.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: Partially  owing to the influence of László Paál, Munkácsy's landscape painting started to bloom during the 1880s.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: This painting is also closely related to Paál's intimate and lyrical landscapes.
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: The light is sifting through the foliage, radiating intimacy: the multitude of hues and tones within the brown basic colour make the painting exciting
AUTHOR: MUNKÁCSY, Mihály
TITLE: Line of Trees

DESCRIPTION: Murillo painted over thirty versions of the Immaculate Conception, each with its own peculiarities, unique grace, richness of detail, and delicate colours.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: However, conventionalism can be observed in some of these paintings
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: Murillo's Immaculada has nothing of a Queen of Heavens.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: Standing on a crescent moon, as described in the Apocalypse, surrounded by angels holding the mirror as a sign of purity and the palm frond as a sign of suffering, she stands in a relatively unaffected poses.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: Her face is pale, her eyes gaze upwards in yearning.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: We can sense the pain she has experienced and her mourning for her son.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: Quiet and introverted, she epitomises the humble anticipation of the hereafter, transfigured only by a mild smile, that is a hallmark of Murillo's paintings of this period; the 'Estilo vaporoso' - the vaporous style
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: Immaculate Conception

DESCRIPTION: According to tradition, the models were from the province of Galicia and attained a certain notoriety as courtesans in Seville.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: A Girl and her Duenna

DESCRIPTION: A man of the people, Murillo obviously intended this picture to both surprise and amuse the spectator.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: A Girl and her Duenna

DESCRIPTION: Yet the casualness of this painting masks a sure sense design - note how the girls' heads form a diagonal that bisects the canvas - and great technical skill.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: A Girl and her Duenna

DESCRIPTION: Although he had begun by selling his pictures at fairs, Murillo became conversant with and influenced by the works of Velázquez, Titian and Rubens, presumably as a result of studying the royal collections in Madrid.
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: A Girl and her Duenna

DESCRIPTION: But Murillo never lost his popular appeal or his gift for the telling expression, such as the smile of the uppermost woman, indicated only by her eyes and cheeks
AUTHOR: MURILLO, Bartolomé Esteban
TITLE: A Girl and her Duenna

DESCRIPTION: In this studio scene one could interpret the way in which the painter looks at the viewer as a welcome to his imaginary workplace
AUTHOR: MUSSCHER, Michiel van
TITLE: The Painter's Studio

DESCRIPTION: In 1701 the marquis Scipione Repeta engaged Vincenzan architect Francesco Muttoni to rebuild the old family palace located in Piazza San Lorenzo, Vicenza.
AUTHOR: MUTTONI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: The project was completed in 1711.
AUTHOR: MUTTONI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: The monumental double-flight staircase leading to the piano nobile was completed in 1707, according to the inscription above the arch next to the second landing.
AUTHOR: MUTTONI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: The ceiling of the staircase was frescoed by the French artist Louis Dorigny, who displayed a masterly skill in his use of perspective.At the top of the grand staircase, beneath a stucco cartouche that contains the representations Painting and Sculpture, Dorigny has painted a figure of Hercules as a bronze statue within an illusionistic niche
AUTHOR: MUTTONI, Francesco
TITLE: View of the grand staircase

DESCRIPTION: Many of Naiveu's later works depict the performing of plays or as here, a scene from a play.

DESCRIPTION: The dramas depicted in Naiveu's theatrical pictures are seldom identifiable.

DESCRIPTION: In this picture the man entering to the right carries over his arm the costume of a Harlequin, or the Commedia dell'Arte figure of Arlecchino.

DESCRIPTION: Although the room depicted is arranged as a theatre set, it is probably not a literal depiction of the enactment of a play before an audience

DESCRIPTION: Gerrit Dou's success attracted many pupils and followers.

DESCRIPTION: Joseph Bonnier de la Mosson (1702-1744) was the scion of a family of well-to-do cloth merchants from the southern French city of Montpellier.
AUTHOR: NATTIER, Jean-Marc
TITLE: Joseph Bonnier de la Mosson

DESCRIPTION: He served as an officer in the French royal army until the death of his father in 1726.
AUTHOR: NATTIER, Jean-Marc
TITLE: Joseph Bonnier de la Mosson

DESCRIPTION: He was a polymath who prided himself on his knowledge of literature, music, and the sciences.
AUTHOR: NATTIER, Jean-Marc
TITLE: Joseph Bonnier de la Mosson

DESCRIPTION: He died unexpectedly on July 26, 1744.Nattier began Bonnier's portrait in early 1744, the year of the sitter's death; he signed and dated the canvas the following year.
AUTHOR: NATTIER, Jean-Marc
TITLE: Joseph Bonnier de la Mosson

DESCRIPTION: The portrait has few rivals in French portraiture of the time, not only for the elegance of its composition and the refinement of its colouring, but also for its vivid delineation of character
AUTHOR: NATTIER, Jean-Marc
TITLE: Joseph Bonnier de la Mosson

DESCRIPTION: Nattier in 1748 produced the relaxed, homely, though still charming image of Louis XV's neglected queen, Marie Leczinska
AUTHOR: NATTIER, Jean-Marc
TITLE: Marie Leczinska

DESCRIPTION: The scene is set in a basement, the light creeps in beneath the floor boards above
AUTHOR: NATUS, Johannes

DESCRIPTION: That is not surprising since in the mid-1550s Navarrete stayed in Rome

DESCRIPTION: This painting represents a river at sunset, with boats, cows, and travelers enlivening the landscape.

TITLE: Landscape at Sunset

DESCRIPTION: A village with a church appears on the left, while farmhouses and a tower are visible in the right background

DESCRIPTION: Van der Neer's first pictures date to the 1660s, the decade in which Dou, Frans van Mieris, Gerard Terborch, and Gabriel Metsu were at the height of their careers, working in a flourishing market awash with disposable income.
AUTHOR: NEER, Eglon van der
TITLE: A Lady Drawing

DESCRIPTION: Van der Neer's paintings from this early period, among them his Lady Drawing of about 1665, clearly resembles these masters' works.
AUTHOR: NEER, Eglon van der
TITLE: A Lady Drawing

DESCRIPTION: Its subject can be linked to a work by Metsu while the lady's shimmering satin attire and the overall, serene ambience of the panel strongly recall paintings by Terborch.The Lady Drawing is probably not meant to represent a professional woman artist at work but rather a female member of the upper classes practicing drawing.
AUTHOR: NEER, Eglon van der
TITLE: A Lady Drawing

DESCRIPTION: Daughters of elite families were sometimes taught the rudiments of art (which could encompass drawing, painting, or even calligraphy), along with music and poetry in order to enhance their standing in society, particularly among respectable suitors
AUTHOR: NEER, Eglon van der
TITLE: A Lady Drawing

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed and dated lower left: Egelon van der Neer fe 1680
AUTHOR: NEER, Eglon van der
TITLE: The Fainting Fit

DESCRIPTION: The artist painted other versions of this subject
AUTHOR: NEER, Eglon van der

DESCRIPTION: His principal patrons were successive Regents of the Netherlands, Margaret of Austria and Mary of Hungary.

DESCRIPTION: Van Orley is at his best in portraits
AUTHOR: ORLEY, Bernaert van

DESCRIPTION: Margaret of Austria was the Governess of the Netherlands.

TITLE: Portrait of Margaret of Austria

AUTHOR: OS, Jan van

DESCRIPTION: The painting represents a group of peasants crowding around the hearth.

TITLE: Interior of a Farmhouse with Skaters

DESCRIPTION: They are talking, drinking and smoking
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Interior of a Farmhouse with Skaters

DESCRIPTION: The artist was strongly influenced by Rembrandt in the period of the execution of this painting.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Village Musicians

DESCRIPTION: The grotesque peasants carousing, brawling, or engaged in swinish gluttony in disorderly hovels are characteristic of Ostade's boisterous work of his early phase.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: In the 1640s his interiors gain in spaciousness and atmosphere.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: By the middle of the century Ostade had changed to a more idyllic style.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: His figures became calmer and more respectable.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: There is a new emphasis on local colour and an orderly arrangement.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: The reason for the shift in Ostade's mood has not been established.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: Perhaps it is related to a change in his clientele, to his own conception of himself, and his ideas about his task as an artist
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Adriaen Jansz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Family

DESCRIPTION: Isaack van Ostade, like his brother Adriaen, depicted peasant and low-life scenes.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: Farmhouse Interior

DESCRIPTION: This untidy farmhouse interior is typical of Haarlem painting in the first half of the seventeenth century, with its low-key use of colour.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: Farmhouse Interior

DESCRIPTION: The painting would be taken as a warning against a dissolute life
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: Farmhouse Interior

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts a winter landscape with figures on a frozen river, a town beyond.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Highlighted near the centre, a group of figures stand in conversation, amongst whom a white horse - a recurring motif in Isaac van Ostade's work - stands with its head bowed.The theme of crowded winter landscapes, pioneered by Pieter Brueghel the Elder, became extremely popular in the seventeenth century.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: It was one of van Ostade's favourite subjects, and he became one of the genre's finest exponents
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: Winter Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Isack van Ostade was the short-lived younger brother of the painter of scenes from peasant life, Adriaen van Ostade.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: A Winter Scene

DESCRIPTION: They were both born, lived and worked in Haarlem, and Isack was a pupil of his brother who was eleven years his senior.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: A Winter Scene

DESCRIPTION: Isack joined the guild in 1643.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: A Winter Scene

DESCRIPTION: His earliest paintings - the first dated picture is from 1639 - are peasant interiors dependent on Adriaen's, but towards the end of his brief career he became more interested in outdoor scenes and produced a series of beautiful and original landscapes, often set in winter.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: A Winter Scene

DESCRIPTION: This deliberately picturesque view, its low viewpoint serving to outline the wooden bridge against the sky, is one of his finest paintings.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: A Winter Scene

DESCRIPTION: It is rich in its treatment of the details of peasant life, whose harsh aspects (as seen, for example, in the figure of the man labouring under his load of faggots) are relieved by the pleasure taken by the child in the anticipation of skating on the frozen river.
AUTHOR: OSTADE, Isaack van
TITLE: A Winter Scene

DESCRIPTION: Isaak Ouwater was the best follower of Jan van der Heyden.
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

DESCRIPTION: He concentrated on cityscapes.
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

DESCRIPTION: Although Ouwater's paintings can be a little dry and airless, and, when compared to to van der Heyden's, appear timid, he always displays a fine sense of design as is evident in his Lottery Office.Here his debt to van der Heyden's execution also is unmistakable; in it his minute handling is best enjoyed with a magnifying glass.
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

DESCRIPTION: But his close, frontal view of the street scene is original.
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

DESCRIPTION: The painting is an exact rendering of the façades of three houses in the Kalverstraat in Amsterdam which have an antiquarian interest that enhances the painting's historical value.
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

DESCRIPTION: The lottery office that the crowd is trying to enter was first inhabited by Clement de Jonghe, who posed for Rembrandt and was a publisher of Rembrandt's etchings.
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

DESCRIPTION: The house on the right was once occupied by Jacob van Ruisdael, the one on the left by Aert van der Neer
AUTHOR: OUWATER, Isaak
TITLE: The Lottery Office

AUTHOR: PACE DEL CAMPIDOGLIO, Michele

DESCRIPTION: This painting depicts a gathering of thirteen expensively dressed young men and women who are enjoying the pleasure of eating, drinking, smoking, and making music in each other's company.
AUTHOR: PALAMEDESZ., Anthonie
TITLE: Company Dining and Making Music

DESCRIPTION: As is often the case in Palamedesz's interiors, a group of people is crowded into the right half of the picture, leaving the space at the left almost empty.
AUTHOR: PALAMEDESZ., Anthonie
TITLE: Company Dining and Making Music

DESCRIPTION: This imbalance is compensated by placing in the empty corner the figure of the servant boy dressed in red and pouring wine for the merrymakers.This painting is strongly reminiscent of works with similar subject matter by artists active in northern Holland, such as Dirck Hals, Pieter Codde, Willem Duyster, and Hendrick Pot
AUTHOR: PALAMEDESZ., Anthonie
TITLE: Company Dining and Making Music

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed and dated lower left: A. Palamedes.
AUTHOR: PALAMEDESZ., Anthonie
TITLE: A Musical Party with an Allegory of the Five Senses

DESCRIPTION: Pannini was one of the most accomplished vedutisti (view-painters) of the eighteenth century.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: He came from a long tradition of Emilian view-painters and scenery-painters.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: In 1715 he moved to Rome where he first worked as a decorator painting counterfeit architecture in various palaces.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: He then found a fuller creative voice by painting scenes of holidays or special events.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: The spectacular backdrops he used for these works were the squares and buildings of Rome.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: The beauty of these monumental backgrounds, bathed in clear light that seemed to exalt the very notion of the Eternal City, was so powerful that he had no need of a narrative pretext for them.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: Many of Pannini's paintings are simple views animated by lively little figures.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: He had a considerable influence on Canaletto and the great Venetian view-painters of the eighteenth century.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: The Piazza and Church of Santa Maria Maggiore

DESCRIPTION: This view is taken from the Arch of Constantine looking northwards to the Capitoline Hill.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: View of the Forum Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: It testifies to the artist's originality when recording the topography of his city, combining the ancient and the modern and animating it with figures drawn from contemporary life.The painting is signed with initials and dated on a fragment of masonry, lower left: I. P. P.
AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: View of the Forum Looking towards the Capitol

AUTHOR: PANNINI, Giovanni Paolo
TITLE: View of the Forum Looking towards the Capitol

DESCRIPTION: In the inventory of Cardinal Pietro Aldobrandini's paintings compiled by Giovanni Battista Agucchi in 1603, a double-sided picture is mentioned, with a Nativity on one side and a Madonna on the other.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: In 1638 the painting was left by Ippolito Aldobrandini to his only niece Olimpia, who had married for a second time to Camillo Pamphilj senior.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: In a list of the same property made prior to 1665, the work is recorded as still being in one piece, "with gilded frame at the front of the Parmigianino [and] with a pedestal covered with crimson velvet and gold trimming."
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: The work was obviously held in high regard, and probably intended, from the outset, for use as a small altar for private devotion.The votive picture was still in this state in 1709 and only subsequently split into two separate parts.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: Before this investigation of the archives was carried out, the two pictures had been considered two separate works intended as companion pieces.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: Curiously, in 1603 Cardinal Pietro Aldobrandini's collection contained another small Nativity surrounded by angels, also by Parmigianino but not the same as the one here.This delightful example of sacred painting with its curved and supple lines, in which the Madonna with her hands joined in moving and gentle spirituality and the Child with a dove perched on an open book, undoubtedly inspired by Correggio, are set against a background of trees stirred by a light breeze, probably dates from around 1525.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: It would therefore have been painted at the time of the Fontanellato frescoes, that is prior to the artist's stay in Rome
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Madonna and Child

DESCRIPTION: In the 1530s Parmigianino frescoed the under-arch above the altar in Santa Maria della Steccata.

DESCRIPTION: He graced his painted coffer articulation with sculptural rosettes.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Decoration of the under-arch above the main altar

DESCRIPTION: A colourful variety of fruit garlands, animals, and grotesques, in red and gold, produces a magnificent effect.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Decoration of the under-arch above the main altar

DESCRIPTION: At the spring line of the arch, Parmigianino painted two sets of three beautiful, graceful women in various side views, suggesting the Three Graces.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Decoration of the under-arch above the main altar

DESCRIPTION: Their elegance is analogous to the perfected sweeping forms of the precious vessels they bear on their heads.
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Decoration of the under-arch above the main altar

DESCRIPTION: Grisaille figures of Adam and Eve and Moses and Aaron frame the group of women
AUTHOR: PARMIGIANINO
TITLE: Decoration of the under-arch above the main altar

DESCRIPTION: Toward the end of the seventeenth century, Cesare Alessandri, a wealthy Venetian merchant had a wing erected to the side of his villa, to be used as foresteria (guest quarters).
AUTHOR: PELLEGRINI, Giovanni Antonio
TITLE: View of the northwest room in the foresteria

DESCRIPTION: Decorations embellish three rooms on the second floor; the paintings in the central hall and in the northwest room are attributed to Giovanni Antonio Pellegrini.
AUTHOR: PELLEGRINI, Giovanni Antonio
TITLE: View of the northwest room in the foresteria

DESCRIPTION: The fresco cycles in these two rooms constitute the first private fresco commission given to Pellegrini after his return to Venice from Rome.
AUTHOR: PELLEGRINI, Giovanni Antonio
TITLE: View of the northwest room in the foresteria

DESCRIPTION: His stay in Rome had been beneficial to his development, enabling him to incorporate into his own visual repertory the language of Luca Giordano and Baciccio.The frescoes that adorn the northwest room, with the scene Hannibal Swearing his Hatred of the Romans, one can detect a certain stiffening of the figures compared to the rendering of those in the central hall.
AUTHOR: PELLEGRINI, Giovanni Antonio

DESCRIPTION: In the 1880s, Lombardy began to play an active part in Italian art.
AUTHOR: PELLIZZA DA VOLPEDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Washing in the Sun

DESCRIPTION: The movement that originated there declared its loyalty to the great Italian tradition, and was particularly interested in atmospherics of light, colour, and texture.
AUTHOR: PELLIZZA DA VOLPEDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Washing in the Sun

DESCRIPTION: In the 1890s, such work came into its own with divisionist or pointillist paintings.In the work of Pellizza, the most important Lombard Neo-Impressionist, the goals of the leading French pointillist, Seurat, were most consistently pursued.
AUTHOR: PELLIZZA DA VOLPEDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Washing in the Sun

DESCRIPTION: This was apparent not only in his relinquishing romantic natural scenes such as Impressionism favoured, and preferring an art based upon ideas; he also dispensed with clear outlines, and used strong contrasts of juxtaposed colours.
AUTHOR: PELLIZZA DA VOLPEDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Washing in the Sun

DESCRIPTION: His thematic range was great, and included curiously symbolic paintings such as Washing in the Sun
AUTHOR: PELLIZZA DA VOLPEDO, Giuseppe
TITLE: Washing in the Sun

DESCRIPTION: Pérez Sierra's flower paintings were appreciated by some of the most distinguished collectors of his time, including the king himself.

TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: On the death of Charles II, the 1700 inventory of the Buen Retiro palace mentioned a series of six flower pieces by his hand, of which four are known today, the painting shown here is one of them.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ SIERRA, Francisco
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: These works show the distinctive personality of this artist in the genre.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ SIERRA, Francisco
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: Their low viewpoint endows the flower pieces with a degree of monumentality and reflects the fact that they were conceived for display over windows or doors, or another such high point on a wall.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ SIERRA, Francisco
TITLE: Vase of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: This painting of a basket of flowers and its pair (Madrid, Museo del Prado) follow closely a type of flower piece made popular by Juan de Arellano in which the flowers occupy an open weave wicker basket placed on a rough stone ledge.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ, Bartolomé
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: Such images of flowers casually arranged and filling an open weave basket differ from the formal presentations of bouquets in vases and were perhaps intended to be seen as recently-gathered fresh flowers on short stems.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ, Bartolomé
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: Although the paintings have been considered early works by Pérez for reasons of their closeness to the typology of Arellano s works, they show that the painter was evidently in full possession of the technical resources that distinguish his mature style.In the 17th century, flower paintings commonly made up the decoration of chapels and monastic institutions.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ, Bartolomé
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: While it does not appear that symbolism played a significant role in Spanish flower paintings, viewers of a more sombre cast of mind could have read a Vanitas message in such pictures, in which the brief life of the flowers was a metaphor for human existence.
AUTHOR: PÉREZ, Bartolomé
TITLE: Basket of Flowers

DESCRIPTION: The fresco is from the cycle of the life of Christ in the Sistine Chapel, it is located in the fifth compartment on the north wall.Likely in charge of the entire project of the fresco decoration on the walls of the Sistine Chapel, Pietro Perugino retained for himself not only representations on the altar wall (which eventually were replaced by Michelangelo's Last Judgment) but also other significant scenes, such as Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter, a most fitting subject for Pope Sixtus' chapel.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The fresco is located in the fifth compartment on the north wall.Among his frescoes in the Sistine Chapel the Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter is stylistically the most instructive.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The main figures are organized in a frieze in two tightly compressed rows close to the surface of the picture and well below the horizon.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The principal group, showing Christ handing the gold and silver keys to the kneeling St Peter, is surrounded by the other Apostles, including Judas (fifth figure to the left of Christ), all with halos, together with portraits of contemporaries, including one said to be a self-portrait (fifth from the right edge).
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The flat, open piazza is divided by coloured stones into large foreshortened rectangles, although they are not used in defining the spatial organization.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: Nor is the relationship between the figures and the felicitous invention of the porticoed Temple of Salomon that dominates the picture effectively resolved.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The triumphal arches at the extremities appear as superfluous antiquarian references, suitable for a Roman audience.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: Scattered in the middle distance are two secondary scenes from the life of Christ, including the Tribute Money on the left and the Stoning of Christ on the right.The style of the figures is dependent upon Verrocchio.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The active drapery, with its massive complexity, and the figures, particularly several apostles, including St John the Evangelist, with beautiful features, long flowing hair, elegant demeanour, and refinement recall St Thomas from Verrocchio's bronze group on Orsanmichele.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The poses of the actors fall into a small number of basic attitudes that are consistently repeated, usually in reverse from one side to the other, signifying the use of the same cartoon.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: They are graceful and elegant figures who tend to stand firmly on the earth.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: Their heads are smallish in proportion to the rest of their bodies, and their features are delicately distilled with considerable attention to  minor detail.The octagonal temple with its ample porches that dominates the central axis must have had behind it a project created by an architect, but Perugino's treatment is like the rendering of a wooden model, painted with exactitude.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The building with its arches serves as a backdrop in front of which the action unfolds.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: Perugino has made a significant contribution in rendering the landscape.
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro
TITLE: Christ Handing the Keys to St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The sense of an infinite world that stretches across the horizon is stronger than in almost any other work of his contemporaries, and the feathery trees against the cloud-filled sky with the bluish hills in the distance represent a solution that later painters would find instructive, especially Raphael
AUTHOR: PERUGINO, Pietro

DESCRIPTION: Among the parts of the polyptych that have unfortunately not survived there is also the central panel which represented the Virgin Enthroned.St Michael was one of the four side panels depicting four saints (St Augustine and St Michael at the left side and St John the Evangelist and St Nicholas of Tolentino at the right).Archangel Michael is portrayed as an ancient warrior, his athletic limbs made more elegant by his precious armour, by the graceful tunic and by his beautiful boots decorated by with tiny pearls.

AUTHOR: PIERO DI COSIMO

AUTHOR: PIETRO DA MILANO
TITLE: Alfonso of Aragon in Triumph with his Court

TITLE: Alfonso of Aragon in Triumph with his Court

AUTHOR: PIETRO DA MILANO
TITLE: Alfonso of Aragon in Triumph with his Court

DESCRIPTION: Sculptural work was allocated to different workers, ensuring a speedy completion of the project.The attic story of this arch is decorated by a relief of The Triumphal Entry of Alfonso into Naples.
AUTHOR: PIETRO DA MILANO
TITLE: Alfonso of Aragon in Triumph with his Court

DESCRIPTION: In this relief, groups of figures, all carefully coordinated in size and scale, even though carved by different hands, enact an idealized and simplified version of Alfonso's triumphal entry into Naples a decade earlier.

TITLE: Alfonso of Aragon in Triumph with his Court

AUTHOR: PIETRO DA MILANO
