AUTHOR: PIETRO DI GIOVANNI D'AMBROGIO
TITLE: Virigin and Child
TECHNIQUE: Tempera and tooled gold on poplar panel, 98 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the view from the window wall of the entry wall with the scenes of the presentation of Frederick III to Eleonora of Portugal and Enea Silvio Piccolomini being elevated to cardinal.The ten compartments are separated by painted pilasters with grotteschi decoration, while each individual scene is framed by illusionistic jambs and arches decorated with simulated red and white marble paneling.
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: View of the Piccolomini Library

DESCRIPTION: Wee seem to be looking through the arches of a gigantic loggia into scenes from Enea Silvio's life.
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: View of the Piccolomini Library

DESCRIPTION: The pageant-like incidents display a panoply of colourful costumes against fanciful architectural or landscape backgrounds, except when a recognizable setting was required by the narrative
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: View of the Piccolomini Library

DESCRIPTION: The decorative skills of Pinturichio are apparent in the vault of this room he painted in the papal apartments of the Vatican.
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: Vault decoration

DESCRIPTION: He accentuated the ribs of the vault and in doing so created strong framing elements within which he placed the scenes of the vault.
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: Vault decoration

DESCRIPTION: Pinturichio filled all of the available surface with imagery, reserving the direct centre of the ceiling for the Borgia coat of arms.
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: Vault decoration

DESCRIPTION: A later pope, Julius II, found serious objection to the decoration, and refused to live in the apartments.The frescoes depict the myth of Isis and Osiris
AUTHOR: PINTURICCHIO
TITLE: Vault decoration

DESCRIPTION: Pissarro's health obliged him to paint less in the open, where it was windy, and more indoors, from the window.
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Morning, Overcast Weather, Rouen

DESCRIPTION: In Paris (1893, 1897-98, 1902), Rouen) (1896 and 1898), Dieppe (1901) and Le Havre (1903) he rented rooms from which he enjoyed dynamic perspectives of squares and boulevards, the city and the river, or harbour and bridges.
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Morning, Overcast Weather, Rouen

DESCRIPTION: He painted variations and repeated views in order to capture various atmospheric moods and also to have something to offer to as many buyers as possible
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Morning, Overcast Weather, Rouen

DESCRIPTION: Pissarro's landscapes include the people who live and work there; unlike his Impressionist friends Monet and Renoir, these are not city people who travel to the country to relax on the weekend, but peasant farmers and their wives, herdsmen, and shepherdesses.
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Harvest at Montfoucault

DESCRIPTION: Yet, unlike Millet, Pissarro does not monumentalise his agricultural labourers.
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Harvest at Montfoucault

DESCRIPTION: They are not posed, and they themselves form an integral part of the landscape
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Harvest at Montfoucault

DESCRIPTION: In the first half of the 1880s, Pissarro the landscape painter became a figure painter.
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Turkey Girl

DESCRIPTION: The most striking of his new departures concerned his market scenes featuring a larger number of figures, and particularly open-air or indoor scenes in which farmers or maids are given dominant roles to play
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Turkey Girl

DESCRIPTION: In spring 1884 Pissarro settled in Eragny on the River Epte, where he, his wife, and their six children remained for the rest of their life.
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Woman in the Orchard. Spring Sunshine in a Field, Eragny

DESCRIPTION: He painted here simple landscapes such as the present painting
AUTHOR: PISSARRO, Camille
TITLE: Woman in the Orchard. Spring Sunshine in a Field, Eragny

DESCRIPTION: A similar composition by the artist is in the Fitzwilliam Museum, Cambridge
AUTHOR: POELENBURGH, Cornelis van
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: This group of gods on the clouds illustrates a frequently depicted sentence by Terence: Sine Cerere et Baccho friget Venus - Without Ceres (bread) and Bacchus (wine) Venus freezes.
AUTHOR: POELENBURGH, Cornelis van
TITLE: Sine Cerere et Baccho friget Venus

DESCRIPTION: In the painting there is an unusual reversal of distances between sky and earth, other examples of which can be found in Guido Reni's and Giovanni Lanfranco's paintings which Poelenburgh would have seen in Rome
AUTHOR: POELENBURGH, Cornelis van
TITLE: Sine Cerere et Baccho friget Venus

DESCRIPTION: Antonio was the older and the more powerful of the Pollaiolo brothers.
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: David Victorious

DESCRIPTION: Working in many media, including engraving, he infused these with a vital, virile line.
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: David Victorious

DESCRIPTION: His graceful David Victorious is surprisingly small, he suggests not biblical heroism but the dangers that may lie in store for a middle aged man who loses his head over the airs and graces of a willowy Florentine youth
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: David Victorious

DESCRIPTION: This small panel, the companion-piece to "Hercules and Antaeus", refers to three panels representing the Labours of Hercules which Antonio del Pollaiuolo painted for Lorenzo de' Medici around 1460, lost works we know about only from later versions.Here too is represented a ferocious fight between the hero, his body tensed into an agile, muscular mass and the legendary multi-headed monster.
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: Hercules and the Hydra

DESCRIPTION: The outlines are very sharply defined, and the movement of nerves and tendons observed down to the last detail.
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: Hercules and the Hydra

DESCRIPTION: Antonio del Pollaiuolo worked at time when thorough studies of anatomy were being made, and he therefore renders the human body realistically in its moments of greatest emotional excitement.The dramatic force of the episode is expressed in the hero's grimace of fatigue and horror, but also his certainty of victory.
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: Hercules and the Hydra

DESCRIPTION: Behind the proudly barbaric figure blue rivers meander through a broad landscape of green and brown fields, the sky above an enamel blue
AUTHOR: POLLAIUOLO, Antonio del
TITLE: Hercules and the Hydra

DESCRIPTION: The large dark vine leaves and fruit are back-lit and are sharply silhouetted against the luminous background, to quite dramatic effect.
AUTHOR: PONCE, Antonio
TITLE: Still-Life of Apples, Pears and Figs in a Wicker Basket on a Stone Ledge

DESCRIPTION: Ponce's use of this effect strongly indicates the indirect influence of Caravaggio's Basket of Fruit in the Pinacoteca Ambrosiana, Milan, almost 50 years after it was created
AUTHOR: PONCE, Antonio
TITLE: Still-Life of Apples, Pears and Figs in a Wicker Basket on a Stone Ledge

DESCRIPTION: The painting belongs to the series of four entitled Scenes from the Life of Joseph the Hebrew, now in the National Gallery, London.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: These works, together with others by Andrea del Sarto, Francesco Granacci, Bachiacca and Franciabigio, were intended for the decoration of the nuptial chamber of Francesco Borgherini and Margherita Acciaioli, who married in 1515.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The group of fourteen paintings, broken up at the end of the 16th century, was contained within a wooden decoration made by Baccio d'Agnolo.In this panel the thesis proposed by Mannerism is fully elaborated: the painter is no longer to be bound by perspective, or by the necessity of presenting his subject in a rational, objective manner.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: He may use light and colour, chiaroscuro and proportion as he pleases; he may borrow from any source he chooses; the only obligation upon him is to create an interesting design, expressive of the ideas inherent in the subject, and the various parts need bear no relationship to each other.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The colour must be evocative and beautiful in itself.This work, traditionally entitled Joseph in Egypt, depicts the most significant episodes of Joseph reuniting with his family of origin.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The painting is divided into four distinct zones.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: In the left foreground Joseph presents his family, who he invited to move to Egypt, to the pharaoh; according to Vasari, the boy with dark cloak and brown tunic sitting on the first step of the stairs on which the figures are arranged, is a portrait of the young Bronzino.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: On the right, Joseph is seen sitting on a triumphal cart pulled by three putti; hoisting himself up with his left arm and clutching firmly onto a putto with the other, he bends toward a kneeling figure who is presenting him a petition or reading him a message; a fifth putto, wrapped in a piece of cloth blown by the wind, dominates the scene from the top of a column, appearing to mime the gesture of one of the two half-living statues represented in the top left and centre of the painting.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: A restless crowd, curious to see what is going on, throngs the adjacent space between the two buildings in the background.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: Other mysterious figures, resting against one of the large boulders that dominate the landscape, turn their attention toward the action in the foreground.The clothes, expressions and features of all these figures are inspired by northern European painting, as is the large castle and surrounding trees depicted in the background.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: On the unrailed staircase of the imposing cylindrical building to the right, Joseph takes one of his children by the hand; higher up, the other is greeted affectionately by his mother.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: Lastly, Joseph and his sons, Ephraim and Manasseh, are portrayed inside the room at the top of the building, where Jacob, now old and near to death, imparts his paternal blessing.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: The curious combination of all these elements confers to the painting an anomalous and intriguing quality
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Joseph in Egypt

DESCRIPTION: This painting was painted after a cartoon executed by Michelangelo in the early 1530s.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Noli Me Tangere

DESCRIPTION: The panel painting was intended for the private collection of the artist's close friend Vittoria Colonna, who was particularly devoted to the penitent Magdalen
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Noli Me Tangere

DESCRIPTION: The portrait represents Maria Salviati in a widow's veil with a little girl.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici

DESCRIPTION: Salviati's only child was Cosimo I de' Medici, the girl was identified as one of Alessandro de' Medici's illegitimate daughters - either Giulia or Porzia -  who after their birth were placed in Salviati's care.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici

DESCRIPTION: The younger of the two, Porzia, was placed in the Augustinian convent of San Clemente, therefore Giulia is more likely the girl depicted in the painting.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici

DESCRIPTION: The mother of Alessandro's children is not known.The medal that Salvia holds is probably one of the pieces depicting Alessandro produced by Francesco del Prato or Domenico de' Vetri
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Maria Salviati with Giulia de' Medici

DESCRIPTION: The Deposition can perhaps justly be described as the artist's masterpiece.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The compositional idea is extravagant and totally unprecedented: an inextricable knot of figures and drapes that pivots around the bewildered youth in the foreground and culminates above in the two lightly hovering figures emerging from vague background.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: This complicated bunch of forms arranged in the shape of an upturned pyramid defies any attempt at a rational exploration or identification of planes.The compositional complexity is accompanied by a significant and probably deliberate ambiguity in the representation of the subject, which may be interpreted as halfway between the theme of the Deposition and that of the Pietà or Lamentation over the Dead Christ.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The painting appears to represent the moment in which the body of Christ, having been taken down from the cross, has just been removed from the mother's lap.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin, visibly distraught, and perhaps on the point of fainting, still glazes longingly towards her Son, and gestures with her right arm in the same direction.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: In the centre of the painting, the moment of the separation is underlined by the subtle contact of Mary's legs with those of Christ, now freed from his Mother's last pathetic embrace.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The twisted body of Christ is reminiscent of Michelangelo's Vatican Pietà (1498).An intense spiritual participation in the grief of the event profoundly affects the expressions and attitudes of all the figures present, even that of the woman turned away from the onlooker, probably Mary Magdalene, who communicates her anguished psychological condition by reaching out sympathetically towards the swooning body of the Virgin.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: Some scholars have interpreted the two young figures holding up the deceased's body as angels in the act of drawing Christ away from the main group and leading him finally into the arms of his Father.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The general direction of the movement is, in fact, a rising one, and is created by the ethereal quality of the weightless figures, and their slow, almost dance-like rhythm.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The two presumed angelic presences, moreover, seem to be unaffected by the weight of the lifeless body, and the figure in the foreground appears to be in the act of raising himself up by lightly pressing down on the front part of his foot.The intricately connected group of figures, involved in a highly dramatic atmosphere, takes on the appearance of a rich frieze in the harmony of highly refined colour tones of pinks, blues and greens.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: The transparent shadows do not annul the colours, but actually become them, in the flesh tones invested with subtle shades of pink and green.The cloaked man wearing a strange hat, almost imperceptible against the background of the painting behind the arm of the Virgin, may possibly be the artist himself.
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: Staring at something beyond the confines of the painting and looking as though he were about to leave the pictorial space, he presents us with this complex and refined decoration of colours, forms
AUTHOR: PONTORMO, Jacopo
TITLE: Deposition

DESCRIPTION: Pordenone's enormous artistic freedom compared to the main Venetian school is beautifully expressed in this altarpiece.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Madonna and Child Enthroned with Saints

DESCRIPTION: The traditional layout of the scene is subverted by the asymmetrical architectural backdrop behind the group.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Madonna and Child Enthroned with Saints

DESCRIPTION: It is also upset by the uneasy but effective way that each member of the group is gesticulating
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Madonna and Child Enthroned with Saints

DESCRIPTION: The decoration was executed by Pordenone and Bernardino Gatti.Domes, which vault the crossing and altar of countless churches, lend themselves well to being transformed into paintings of the sky.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: The round shape above our heads seems to  open onto a higher world, so that God and the things of heaven become visually present at the church holiest spot.Astonishing dynamic effects in dome decorations were achieved by Pordenone.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: In the large ribbed dome of Santa Madonna di Campagna in Piacenza, in 1530-32, Pordenone began to fresco a complex theological program.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: God the Father floats in the cupola, mysteriously illuminated by invisible windows.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: Putti, animals, and illusionistic reliefs of Old Testament stories decorate the ribs.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: In between them heroic sibyls, prophets, and other Old Testament figures are seen against views of the heavens.
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: In 1543 Bernardino Gatti added apostles on the pilasters of the drum below, stories from the life of Mary on the next level, and finally evangelists on the pendentives
AUTHOR: PORDENONE
TITLE: Decoration of the main dome

DESCRIPTION: Along with Giuseppe Recco and Giovan Battista Ruoppolo, Paolo Porpora was one of the leading figures in Neapolitan still-life painting during the Baroque.
AUTHOR: PORPORA, Paolo
TITLE: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab

DESCRIPTION: In his first period in Naples he painted fish and kitchen still-lifes in great variety.
AUTHOR: PORPORA, Paolo
TITLE: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab

DESCRIPTION: In the late 1640s he moved to Rome and, after coming into contact with the Northern European masters Matthias Withoos and Otto Marseus van Schrieck, active in the city at that time, he began to produce his famous underbrush paintings.
AUTHOR: PORPORA, Paolo
TITLE: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab

DESCRIPTION: The painting in Nancy is one of the few examples of these works that remained
AUTHOR: PORPORA, Paolo
TITLE: Underbrush with Tortoise and Crab

DESCRIPTION: Frans Post was the first trained European artist to depict the landscape of South America.
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Brazilian Landscape

DESCRIPTION: As a young man he traveled to the north-east of Brazil with Johan Maurits, Count of Nassau-Siegen, who was Governor General of the Dutch colony there.
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Brazilian Landscape

DESCRIPTION: A very few paintings that he made there have come down to us, but the drawings that he must have made there (though very few survive), and above all his own recollections of the seven years he spent there, served as the basis for his entire output over the remaining 35 years of his life
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Brazilian Landscape

DESCRIPTION: This Brazilian landscape with labourers, an armadillo and a tamandua (two exotic creatures) was painted in the period when the artist enjoyed his strongest commercial success.
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Brazilian Landscape with Labourers

DESCRIPTION: The carefully staged composition includes many of the diverse elements employed by Post during this phase of his career
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Brazilian Landscape with Labourers

DESCRIPTION: The building to the left is almost certainly the end of a sugar mill, probably a structure erected by the Portuguese and taken over by the Dutch colonists.
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Landscape in Brazil
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 20 x 27 cm

DESCRIPTION: Similar sugar mills, constructed of local limestone arcading with open gable-ends, can be see in many of Post's paintings of Brazil.
AUTHOR: POST, Frans
TITLE: Landscape in Brazil
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 20 x 27 cm

DESCRIPTION: A colonel, three captains, two lieutenants, three sergeants, a reserve officer and the troop's servant are portrayed on the staircase of their shooting gallery, the St Adrian Gallery.
AUTHOR: POT, Hendrick Gerritsz
TITLE: Officers of the Civic Guard of St Adrian

DESCRIPTION: A small part of the guard portrait painted by Cornelis van Haarlem in 1583 is visible through the window
AUTHOR: POT, Hendrick Gerritsz
TITLE: Officers of the Civic Guard of St Adrian

DESCRIPTION: The initials "HP."
AUTHOR: POT, Hendrick Gerritsz
TITLE: The Miser

DESCRIPTION: with which the painting is signed for a long time deceived critics into thinking its author was Horatius Paulyn.
AUTHOR: POT, Hendrick Gerritsz
TITLE: The Miser

DESCRIPTION: At the beginning of the twentieth century the painting's attribution was changed in favour of Pot
AUTHOR: POT, Hendrick Gerritsz
TITLE: The Miser

DESCRIPTION: Both documentary and dramatic, The Bull by Paulus Potter is painted as a fact of life
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Bull

DESCRIPTION: In the work of Paulus Potter views of nature and animals are seen for their own sake, and not as a backdrop for human action.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: Potter can paint equally well the bright sunlight and the cool air, but his real fame lies with his penetrating portraits of animals.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: His best-known work is the life-size Young Bull, an unusual heroization of a single animal, a counterpart to the monumental trend of Ruisdael and Cuyp.Although at first sight it appears to be a portrait of a prize young bull Potter most probably composed his famous beast from studies of more than one animal since its dewlap, horns, and teeth belong to bulls of different ages.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: The ancient Greek painter Zeuxis used a similar method; when he painted his portrait of Helen in the city of Croton he chose five beautiful virgins, in order to copy the finest features of each, for in one woman he felt he could not find perfect beauty.What makes this painting so special is the fact that Potter painted something as ordinary as a bull on such a grand scale - which had never been done before.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: And despite this large size, he paid great attention to the smallest details.During the nineteenth century the Young Bull by the twenty-two-year-old Potter ranked close in fame to the Night Watch of Rembrandt.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: Later generations have been less captivated by Potter's fidelity to nature when he worked life-size.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: Although the shapes of the farmer, the tree, and the bull against the light sky are impressive and the textures of the animals have been convincingly represented by the use of an original impasto which approaches relief, the entire foreground of this huge canvas seems airless.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: Atmosphere enters the picture only in the lovely distant view on the right, where a sunny light plays upon the cattle in the meadows and on the woods, making this passage one of his loveliest landscapes.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: Potter is more consistent on a small scale, and his cabinet pieces show him at his best.
AUTHOR: POTTER, Paulus
TITLE: The Young Bull

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the pendant of the Portrait of a Man, also in the Hermitage
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Elder
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman

DESCRIPTION: In 1599, the childless marriage between Marguerite de Valois and Henri IV, king of France, was annulled.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Louis XIII of France at Age Ten

DESCRIPTION: Early in 1600, Henri wed Maria de' Medici, and later that year Louis, heir to the throne, was born.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Louis XIII of France at Age Ten

DESCRIPTION: Henri was assassinated in 1610; Louis became king, but Maria ruled as regent until he came of age seven years later
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Louis XIII of France at Age Ten

DESCRIPTION: Two Flemish court painters of Bruges descent who earned their reputation abroad, Frans Pourbus the Younger (1569-1622) and Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger (1562-1636), were active at the close of the sixteenth century and especially in the first quarter of the seventeenth.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 107 x 77 cm

DESCRIPTION: They are linear descendants of famous Bruges painter families.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 107 x 77 cm

DESCRIPTION: Their solid, old-fashioned technique and the rigid, immovable expression of their figures seem more like an extension of the sixteenth century than a herald of the seventeenth.Frans Pourbus the Younger was Pieter Pourbus' grandson.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 107 x 77 cm

DESCRIPTION: He was trained in Antwerp and worked briefly for the Archdukes Albert and Isabella before going on to become court painter at Mantua, under Duke Vincenzo Gonzaga, and in Paris, under Marie de' Medici and Louis XIII.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 107 x 77 cm

DESCRIPTION: Until about 1600, Pourbus painted in the smooth and technically brilliant style established by his grandfather, which he augmented with an analytical realism attributable to Adriaan Key.
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 107 x 77 cm

DESCRIPTION: The Portrait of Petrus Ricardus, a famous doctor and professor at the University of Leuven, is a good example of his first period
AUTHOR: POURBUS, Frans the Younger
TITLE: Portrait of Petrus Ricardus
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 107 x 77 cm

DESCRIPTION: Poussin's scenes, created in his early years in Rome, require of the viewer an extensive acquaintance with ancient mythology.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Bacchic Scene

DESCRIPTION: At Cupid's command, the goat-legged shepherd-god Pan has knelt and taken Venus, the goddess of love, on his shoulders.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Bacchic Scene

DESCRIPTION: A little winged putto is giving a hand, and the group is accompanied by a sturdy faun bearing a basket of fruit on his shoulder.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Bacchic Scene

DESCRIPTION: The lively ensemble has been set in an Arcadian landscape
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Bacchic Scene

DESCRIPTION: In Greek legend Midas was a king of Phrygia who was granted a wish by Bacchus in return for a good deed he had done to Silenus, a follower of the god.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Midas and Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: Midas wished that everything he touched be turned to gold, but soon realized his mistake when all food became inedible.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Midas and Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: Bacchus ordered him to wash in the River Pactolus in Lydia.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Midas and Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: Hence the popular aetiology of the gold-bearing properties of the river, thought to have been the source of wealth of the kings of Lydia, of whom Croesus was the last.Midas is depicted penitently before Bacchus, a drunken Silenus sleeping nearby.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Midas and Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: Another version of the subject by Poussin (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York) depicts Midas washing in the river, while the river god reclines on his urn
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Midas and Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: Poussin showed a preference to dealing with subjects such as the sentimental and melancholic scenes from Tasso's "Gerusalemme Liberata", for example the strange encounter Tancred and Erminia in dusky twilight.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Tancred and Erminia

DESCRIPTION: The scene is played out between two attentive horses - one bay the other white
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Tancred and Erminia

DESCRIPTION: The Triumph of Pan was one of several paintings commissioned from Poussin, in 1636 the leading French artist in Rome, by Cardinal Richelieu.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: They were intended for a room in his château in Poitou which would also house mythological pictures by Mantegna, Perugino and Costa.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Poussin must have been advised about the scale not only of the canvases but also of the figures, for although he never saw the Renaissance paintings his personages are much the same size as theirs.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: He must also have been told that the pictures were to be set above a high dado, divided by gilt caryatids, gold fleur-de-lys against a blue ground, and marine battles, all under a gilt ceiling.The Cabinet de la Chambre du Roy in Richelieu's château celebrated the cardinal's 'gift' to Louis XIII of mastery of the seas.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: The room, with its 'Combat of Wealth and Art', as a contemporary panegyric puts it, and furnished in addition to paintings and panelling with porphyry vases and ancient busts, must have presented a formidable challenge to Poussin.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Not only would he be competing with some of the foremost Italian Renaissance artists, his pictures also had to contend with the glittering décor - hence the colours here are among the most brilliant he ever lavished on a painting.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Sadly, the room was dismantled long ago and the pictures dispersed, so we can judge the full effect only in our mind's eye.Poussin carefully allowed for the spectator's point of view.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Nimble visitors to the Gallery can sit on the floor to look at this picture in order better to appreciate its spatial construction, and thus its full significance.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: The revellers occupy a raised stage extending back to where rocks and vine-hung trees screen off the backdrop of sky and distant mountains.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Propped up vertically against this earthen stage are a timbrel and two masks - an ancient satyr mask and a modern Italian Columbine.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Behind them a Punchinello mask joins a still life drawn from the imagery of ancient bacchanals: thyrsoi - staffs wreathed with ivy and surmounted by pine cones - the crooked stick and pipes of Pan, wine in a metal bowl or crater, and a Greek wine jar showing the god Dionysus, the Roman Bacchus.The composition is indebted to an engraving after Giulio Romano, a pupil of Raphael, but Poussin also demonstrates his first-hand access to antiquarian lore.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: The mixture of modern and ancient masks, and the stage-like construction, allude to the origins of theatre in bacchic rites.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: The main scene represents the 'triumph' or worship of the armless bust of a horned deity mounted on a pillar, his face smeared red with the juice of boiled ivy stems.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: This is the 'term' of Pan, Arcadian god of shepherds and herdsmen, and Priapus, a phallic god of fertility, protector of gardens, whose cult was imported into Greece from the Near East.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Confused with each other, both were associated with Dionysus/Bacchus: Dionysus, god of the grape-vine, who died, descended into Hades then rose again was himself identified with seasonal decay and rebirth.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: All the participants are members of his entourage (as we find them in Titian's Bacchus and Ariadne): nymphs and their lewd playmates the satyrs; maenads who rend deer limb from limb or strew flowers from the winnowing basket sacred to Dionysus.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: A world of pagan imaginings is brought to life in all its cruel and seductive charm, without a hint of anachronistic moralising
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Triumph of Pan

DESCRIPTION: It was already apparent to Poussin's contemporaries that the artist had given much thought, in The Israelites Gathering Manna, to the means by which painting could unfold a sequence of events before the eyes of the viewer.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert

DESCRIPTION: The artist combines selected aspects of the biblical story into one scene, so as to illustrate the scale of the Israelites' divine rescue from hunger and misery.This painting can be considered a variation on the Raphael fresco, The School of Athens, in the Vatican.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert

DESCRIPTION: Moses in particular, in his draperies and pointing gesture, directly cites the figure of Plato in Raphael's fresco.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert

DESCRIPTION: Poussin has simply transformed the latter's architectural backdrop into a rock formation and rotated the setting - which in the fresco lies parallel to the pictorial plane - as if on a turntable towards the right, so that it now leads away at a diagonal into the depths
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Jews Gathering the Manna in the Desert

DESCRIPTION: The huge altarpiece was painted for the Sainte-Chapelle in Saint-Germaine-en-Laye
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Institution of the Eucharist

DESCRIPTION: This picture marks the beginning of Poussin's final period, that in which poetry rises to an all-embracing feeling for the world - still, however, interpreted through a mythological guise.The subject was borrowed from "Metamorphoses" by Ovid.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Landscape with Polyphemus

DESCRIPTION: A terrible one-eyed giant Polyphemus anamoured of nymph Galathea is singing of his love on a pipe
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: Landscape with Polyphemus

AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas

AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: Poussin illustrated events from the life of Moses at least nineteen times.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: It has been pointed out that when he could, he avoided painting scenes of saintly visions or martyrdoms, the stock-in-trade of seventeenth-century religious art.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: He concentrated instead on the central themes of Christianity, relating them both to their historical context in the ancient Near East and to the basic tenets of other religions, following an intellectual fashion of the day.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: Of the Old Testament subjects which he painted, the majority belong to the category of types, or prefigurations, of Salvation.From Early Christian times the Old Testament was read by Christians for its analogies with the New.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: Thus the waters of the Nile to which the infant Moses is consigned by his mother in 'an ark of bulrushes', following Pharaoh's cruel order to drown all the male Israelite babies (Exodus 1:2), were likened to the waters of baptism.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: But Poussin's interest in Moses may have been prompted also by his identification with pagan deities; as a contemporary writer influenced by these ideas wrote of this picture: 'He is Moses, the Mosche of the Hebrews, the Pan of the Arcadians, the Priapus of the Hellespont, the Anubis of the Egyptians.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: 'All these ideas reverberate throughout the painting.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: The baby on whom Pharaoh's daughter has taken pity resembles the Christ Child blessing the Magi or the shepherds in a scene of the Adoration.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: In the background on the left an Egyptian priest worships the dog-shaped god Anubis (barely visible now that the surface paint has grown thin and transparent).
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: We know we are in Egypt because on the rock above the main scene a river god, symbolising the Nile, embraces a sphinx, palm trees stand on the shore and an obelisk rises up behind a stately temple.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: (Curiously, the many-windowed buildings with which Poussin, who had never been there, endows Pharaoh's country now resemble modern resort hotels.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: )The main interest and beauty of the painting, however, do not reside in its possible symbolism, but in the wonderful grouping of the figures, all women to contrast with an analogous group of men in Christ healing the Blind Man (now in the Louvre), painted for the same patron the year before.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas

DESCRIPTION: Each plays her role in the dramatic tale, the princess generous and commanding, the maids curious and delighted.

DESCRIPTION: The humbler figure in a white shift at Moses' head may be his sister who watched from nearby to see what would happen to him, and recommended their mother to Pharaoh's daughter as a wet nurse.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas

DESCRIPTION: It is tempting to see their brilliant draperies as a compliment to Poussin's patron, the Lyon silk merchant Reynon.
AUTHOR: POUSSIN, Nicolas

DESCRIPTION: Bodies and colours, each distinct and separate, combine in ample rhythms across the picture surface, echoed by the rocks beyond.

DESCRIPTION: It is at once solemn and joyful, as befits a scene in which a child is rescued from death, and through him an entire people is saved.

DESCRIPTION: This spectacular composition is almost an inventory of Baroque architectural ceilings and their final triumph.

DESCRIPTION: According to Jesuit ideas, the space within a church was a single area in which the faithful congregated.
AUTHOR: POZZO, Andrea
TITLE: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work

DESCRIPTION: In Sant'Ignazio space is stretched (Pozzo was clever at the illusion of "doubling" the perspective of the real architecture) before exploding into light and glory.

TITLE: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work

DESCRIPTION: Saints, angels, allegories, and floating clouds accentuate the virtuoso effect.

AUTHOR: POZZO, Andrea
TITLE: Nave vault: Allegory of the Jesuits' Missionary Work

DESCRIPTION: The monumental figures (Judith, David, Samson, Jael) have an imposing physicality, emphasized by their bright colours and strong contrasts
AUTHOR: POZZO, Andrea

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the ceiling fresco in the Hercules Hall of the Liechtenstein Garden Palace at Rossau.The decorative scheme of the Hercules Hall culminates in the ceiling fresco by Andrea Pozzo.
AUTHOR: POZZO, Andrea
TITLE: Deeds of Hercules and his Apotheosis

DESCRIPTION: The monumental painting relates the story of Hercules from his birth and the strangling of the snakes placed by his cradle by Juno, to his fight with the Nemean Lion and other monsters, his defeat of Antaeus and the Amazons, his humiliation by Omphale, his punishment of Nessus to his suicide on a funeral pyre, with Hebe suspended above it, and the allegorical triumph of his translation to Olympus.The ceiling frescoes, on which Pozzo worked for four years, are his main work north of the Alps
AUTHOR: POZZO, Andrea
TITLE: Deeds of Hercules and his Apotheosis

DESCRIPTION: This early painting by Preti is notable for its rare literary subject and clear stylistic allusion to Paolo Veronese.

DESCRIPTION: The heroine Erminia inscribed his lover Tancred's name on every tree and branch.

DESCRIPTION: The choice of subject matter was doubtless inspired by Pietro da Cortona and Nicolas Poussin, both of whom had painted stories from Tasso in Venetian influenced styles

DESCRIPTION: Mattia Preti's Concert is a work which has a bearing on the artistic links between Italy and the Netherlands.

DESCRIPTION: Its style is strongly influenced by Caravaggio, particularly in its formal aspects: the strong chiaroscuro reaches an extreme degree in the faces of the three figures.
AUTHOR: PRETI, Mattia
TITLE: The Concert

DESCRIPTION: At the same time, the painting also demonstrates the interest in depicting everyday life so characteristic of the art of northern Europe, and takes pleasure in painting the details of the clothing and objects.The composition of the scene and the descending ray of light that isolates the three youths in the darkness reflect the influence of the tavern and gambling scenes painted by Bartolomeo Manfredi and Valentin de Boulogne and other early followers of Caravaggio
AUTHOR: PRETI, Mattia
TITLE: The Concert

DESCRIPTION: The refined way in which it is painted, however, as well as the use of elegant details and the classically-inspired pose of the saint's statuesque body bathed in a ray of light are all extremely revealing about the painter's extensive and important travels.
AUTHOR: PRETI, Mattia

DESCRIPTION: In fact, Preti amalgamated the most disparate influences with great originality

DESCRIPTION: Three compositions, executed in a delicate monochrome and showing the Theological Virtues (Faith, Hope and Charity), combine to form the predella of an altarpiece that Atalanta Baglioni commissioned from Raphael, possibly toward the middle of the year 1506, for the family chapel in the church of S. Francesco al Prato in Perugia.
AUTHOR: RAFFAELLO Sanzio
TITLE: Theological Virtues (Faith)

DESCRIPTION: The noblewoman intended the work to commemorate her son, Grifonetto, who had been assassinated in July 1500 during the struggles between rival branches of her family to establish control over Perugia.The altarpiece was originally composed of a large central panel showing the Deposition of Christ (now in the Borghese Gallery, Rome), a pinnacle with God the Father, Blessing between Angels (painted by a pupil, now in the National Gallery of Umbria, Perugia), and the predella.
AUTHOR: RAFFAELLO Sanzio
TITLE: Theological Virtues (Faith)

DESCRIPTION: Both the main panel and the predella were carried from Perugia to Rome by Pope Paul V. They were replaced by copies in 1608.Charity, which dominates the predella from its central position, is the most complex of the three predella figures.
AUTHOR: RAFFAELLO Sanzio
TITLE: Theological Virtues (Faith)

DESCRIPTION: The tondo with the personification of the virtue has clearly been influenced by Michelangelo's Pitti Madonna; on one side a putto holds a flaming torch on its shoulders, while on the other a putto tips coins out of a bowl.
AUTHOR: RAFFAELLO Sanzio
TITLE: Theological Virtues (Faith)

DESCRIPTION: Hope, forming the right-hand section of the predella, has at its centre the allegorical figure.
AUTHOR: RAFFAELLO Sanzio
TITLE: Theological Virtues (Faith)

DESCRIPTION: On either side are putti in confident attitudes.
AUTHOR: RAFFAELLO Sanzio
TITLE: Theological Virtues (Faith)

DESCRIPTION: A new fresco occupied Raphael during the period 1511-1512: the Prophet Isaiah painted for Johannes Goritz of Luxemburg, Head Chancellor of the Papal Court.

DESCRIPTION: That the work was commissioned by a foreigner is indicative of the extraordinary fame that Raphael had acquired.

DESCRIPTION: This powerful but composed prophet and the putti who surround him echo Michelangelo's figures in the Sistine Ceiling.

DESCRIPTION: Nonetheless, the putti, whose glances and poses are enlivened by a strong spiritual tension, are transformed by Raphael into tender and formally controlled children.

DESCRIPTION: Even the action of the wind that blows Isaiah's mantle is a life-giving device rather than an expression of dramatic feeling.

TITLE: The Prophet Isaiah

DESCRIPTION: The dedicatory inscription in Greek (which alludes to St Anne, patron of Goritz) and the Hebrew scroll which the Prophet holds, reflect the learned environment in which the work was conceived.According to Vasari, Raphael repainted it after seeing Michelangelo's prophets.

DESCRIPTION: Later, however, the couple's fortunes are restored by their son, Tobias, who goes to find the money his father has lost and to marry a rich wife.

DESCRIPTION: On the way he meets the Angel Raphael, who instructs him when they come to a river to catch a large fish, the entrails of which are afterwards applied to Tobit's eyes to cure his blindness.In this work Rembrandt depicts the psychological tension between the two protagonists.

TITLE: Tobit Accusing Anna of Stealing the Kid

DESCRIPTION: The mood of the blind old Tobit suddenly becomes one of suspicion and despair when he wonders how his wife, Anna, has managed to lay hands on a kid.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn

DESCRIPTION: She in turn is baffled by his mistrust.The space depicted is confined but packed with domestic detail: onions hanging up by the window, a basket on the wall, cooking utensils on the shelves, part of Anna's sewing apparatus glimpsed between the two figures, and, in the foreground, Tobit's stick, his dog and a modest fire.Such meticulously painted still-life detail had been a characteristic of Netherlandish art since the fifteenth century.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Tobit Accusing Anna of Stealing the Kid

DESCRIPTION: However, in contrast to so many examples of its use up to and including the seventeenth century, it appears here to be without ulterior symbolic meaning; the purpose is to give the maximum reality to the events of the story

DESCRIPTION: Even in reproductions it is possible to see something of the fluctuating quality of his late paint, the vibrations of the tones, and the harmonious fusion of the whole; but they can hardly suggest the warmth of the fiery scarlets, the golden yellows, the delicate blues and olives, the powerful whites, and deep blacks of his late palette.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: This reveals a touch of classical taste, but the use of colour in the portrait is quite unclassical.Like The Night Watch, this is another misnamed masterpiece by Rembrandt which it would be insensitive to re-title.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: To be sure, the painting does not represent a Jewish bridal couple in the sense which the nineteenth century, which invented the title, would have had in mind.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: The picture would then have been regarded as a romantic costume-piece, its very strangeness and aura of secretiveness suggesting that it showed some exotic rite, which was outside the experience of a predominantly Christian society.There can be no doubt, however, that an intimate relationship between the two figures was intended by the artist.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: The man places his hand on the woman's breast, while she moves instinctively to protect her modesty, in the classic pose of the Venus pudica which Rembrandt would have known from engravings or casts of classical statues.

DESCRIPTION: The theme most widely favoured by modern scholars is Isaac embracing his wife Rebecca while they were being spied on by Abimelech (Genesis, Chapter XXVI), which Rembrandt had previously represented in a drawing.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: To summarize the Bible narrative, Isaac, staying in the land of the Philistines, passes off Rebecca as his sister, because, if the Philistines had wanted to seduce her and had known she was Isaac's wife, they would have felt obliged to kill him first.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: One day, Abimelech, the Philistine King, observes the couple from a window making love in secret and guesses the truth, namely that they are man and wife.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride

DESCRIPTION: He reproves Isaac for the deception, pointing out that any man might have lain with Rebecca in all innocence, not realizing she was a married woman, and would thus have brought dishonour on himself and his people
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Jewish Bride
