AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue number: Bredius 410.Probably Rembrandt's most famous and most controversial painting was given its erroneous title the Night Watch in the early 19th century.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: The title referred to the subdued lighting and led art critics to seek all manner of hidden mysteries in the painting.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: The original title, recorded in the still extant family chronicle of Captain Banning Cocq, together with a sketch of the painting, sounds rather dry by comparison: "Sketch of the painting from the Great Hall of Cleveniers Doelen, in which the young Heer van Purmerlandt [Banning Cocq], as captain, orders his lieutenant, the Heer van Vlaerderdingen [Willem van Ruytenburch], to march the company out.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: "It is, therefore, a "Doelen" piece or group portrait in which the captain can be seen in the foreground wearing black and the lieutenant wearing yellow.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: What sets Rembrandt's group portrait apart from other comparable paintings is his use of chiaroscuro as a dramatic device.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: Interpretations seeking a plausible action fail to take into account that the scenery is made up more or less of individual "types".
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: The painting includes the entire repertoire of portrait poses and gestures from Rembrandt's store of figures.There is inevitably a sense of celebration in the portrayal of individuals in a Dutch group painting.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: Yet whereas Frans Hals, for example, draws together his individual participants around a banquet scene, Rembrandt breaks up the group, so that individual characters and participants become absorbed in their own actions, each standing alone
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: The Nightwatch

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue number: Bredius 415.The painting, popularly called The Syndics, Rembrandt's largest portrait commission during his late years, is an ideal solution of the principal problem of painting a portrait group.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: Equal importance has been given to each of the five officials - their servant, wearing a skull cap, is in the centre yet the whole is united by ingenious psychological and formal means.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: The subtle composition, the glowing colouristic harmonies, and above all the sympathetic interpretation and profound psychological grasp of the personalities of the six men make this Rembrandt's greatest group portrait.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: The total impression is of delicately adjusted harmony and tranquillity.Rembrandt brilliantly exploits horizontals - a classical rather than a Baroque device - for the unification of the group.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: Three horizontals run through the picture at almost equal intervals: the edge of the table and the arm of the chair at the left mark the lowest one; the middle one is established by the prevailing level of the heads; and the upper one runs along the edge of the wainscoting.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: But here again Rembrandt avoids all formal rigidity.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: These repeated horizontals are broken by sharp deviations on all three levels.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: The sharpest is in the group itself, in the strong curve of the head on the left.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: With a kind of contrapuntal effect, this movement is echoed by the slight rise in the upper horizontal on that side.While this style of composition is similar to the relief-like manner of grouping favoured by artists who worked in the classical tradition, there is an increased effect of space and atmosphere by Rembrandt's use of chiaroscuro and colour.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: The harmonies are definitely on the warm side.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: A flaming red in the rug on the table, which is the most outstanding accent, is interwoven with golden tints.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: Golden browns reappear in the background, in the panels of the wall, and within these warmly coloured surroundings the strong blacks and whites in the men's costumes have a noble and harmonious effect.The traditional interpretation of the painting is that the men were shown seated on a platform, before the assembly of the Drapers' Guild and that they are giving to the assembly - unseen by the viewer - an account of the year's business.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: The official seated near the centre of the picture makes a gesture with his right hand which most seventeenth-century observers understood immediately; the gesture was a standard one employed by orators demonstrating evidence
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Sampling Officials of the Drapers' Guild

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue number: Bredius 6.The attribution of this painting to Rembrandt is questioned by some critics, who think that it was painted in the workshop or by a follower
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Self-Portrait with Lace Collar

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue number: Bredius 440.Around 1640 Rembrandt turned increasingly to images with a more local, Dutch flavour, and he increasingly produced drawings and etchings rather than paintings of such scenes.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Landscape with a Stone Bridge

DESCRIPTION: Examples include the painted Landscape with a Stone Bridge, the etched Windmill (1641), and several etched Cottages (1641/42)
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Landscape with a Stone Bridge

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue number: Bredius 87.Although the painting is signed and dated, it is now ascribed to the school of Rembrandt.
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: The identification of the sitter is debated, perhaps she is the artists's wife, or more probably, his sister
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Woman

DESCRIPTION: Catalogue number: Bredius 589.This painting could be a student work that depends on a Rembrandt etching
AUTHOR: REMBRANDT Harmenszoon van Rijn
TITLE: Christ and the Woman of Samaria

DESCRIPTION: In the Boeotian version of the legend, followed by Ovid (Met.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: 10:560-707), Atalanta was an athletic huntress.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: Her way with her suitors was to challenge them to a race in which the loser was punished with death.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: She remained unbeaten and a virgin until Hippomenes (elsewhere named Melanion) took her on.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: As they ran he dropped three golden apples, given to him by Venus, and since Atalanta could not resist stopping to pick them up she lost the race.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: They later made love in a temple of Cybele, which offended the goddess so much that she turned them both into lions.In the picture Atalanta is shown in the act of stooping to pick up an apple as Hippomenes overtakes her.There are two versions of this paining, one in Naples and another in Madrid, and recently there have been heated debates about both their autography and dating.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: While most scholars recognize the Madrid canvas as an autograph work, there have been serious reservations about the Neapolitan canvas, deemed it a workshop copy.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Atalanta and Hippomenes

DESCRIPTION: During Guido Reni's second stay in Rome he directly tackled themes from classical Antiquity.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Aurora

DESCRIPTION: While this composition was openly derived from classical art, it was meant in the spirit of purest love and has a genuine if rather insipid beauty.Though a ceiling decoration, it is composed in the form of a frieze as if painted on a wall.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Aurora

DESCRIPTION: Here the artist was rebelling against the spatial researches which at that time were exciting such passionate interest in Lanfranco and Pietro da Cortona
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Aurora

DESCRIPTION: During his career Reni and his workshop produced two types of images of St Sebastian, which exist in various versions.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: The first type, from around 1615, exists in the autograph work now in the Musei di Strada Nuova, Palazzo Rosso in Genoa.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Reni returned to the subject around 1616-17, with a different, larger composition.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Many versions exist of this work, the painting in the Dulwich Gallery, London, is most likely the original and first one.Powerfully Caravaggesque in its dramatic chiaroscuro, Reni's Sebastian is shown as a striking nude, indebted in its form to antique sculpture and to the classicism of the Bolognese school of the Carracc
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: During his career Reni and his workshop produced two types of images of St Sebastian, which exist in various versions.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: The first type, from around 1615, exists in the autograph work now in the Musei di Strada Nuova, Palazzo Rosso in Genoa.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Reni returned to the subject around 1616-17, with a different, larger composition.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Many versions exist of this work, the painting in the Dulwich Gallery, London, is most likely the original and first one
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: St Sebastian

DESCRIPTION: Lucretia, the virtuous wife of Lucius Tarquinius Collatinus, committed suicide, as she could not endure the shame of being raped by Sextus Tarquinius, as Livy related.
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Death of Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: This deed secured the legendary Roman lady a place in the series of exemplary females that in European painting, particularly in court circles, were depicted as examples of virtue
AUTHOR: RENI, Guido
TITLE: Death of Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: This picture was painted in the Oriental style which was in fashion since Delacroix's Women of Algiers.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Odalisque (Woman of Algiers)

DESCRIPTION: The model for the painting was Lise Tréhot, the artist's mistress
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Odalisque (Woman of Algiers)

DESCRIPTION: Monet recounted what happened that day in his Argenteuil garden.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Camille Monet and Her Son Jean in Their Garden

DESCRIPTION: Renoir appeared, and, attracted by the atmosphere, decided to paint the same subject as painted by Manet, Camille Monet and Her Son in Their Garden.It is interesting to compare the two works painted that day.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Camille Monet and Her Son Jean in Their Garden

DESCRIPTION: We see that Manet's painting seems both more carefully thought out and more ambitious than Renoir's.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Camille Monet and Her Son Jean in Their Garden

DESCRIPTION: Manet remains allusive, lacking the spontaneity shown by Renoir.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Camille Monet and Her Son Jean in Their Garden

DESCRIPTION: But then, Renoir was practiced at this kind of painting, whereas Manet was the beginner
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Camille Monet and Her Son Jean in Their Garden

DESCRIPTION: This picture is one of Renoir's largest composition.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Dance in the Moulin de la Galette

DESCRIPTION: It features the cheerful attitude to life and the Impressionist theme of figures in the open air.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Dance in the Moulin de la Galette

DESCRIPTION: The assembled company are enjoying the carefree mood of a Sunday and the agreeable warmth of the sunlight filtering through the leaves.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Dance in the Moulin de la Galette

DESCRIPTION: Renoir painted the canvas directly from the scene, the models in the foreground are his friends.The Moulin de la Galette was a dancing garden, created by converting two old windmills in Montmartre, where the public could come and dance on Sundays
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Dance in the Moulin de la Galette

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows a young girl in a theatre box.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: At the Theatre (La Premi?re Sortie)

DESCRIPTION: The subject of a theatre box had been treated earlier by Renoir in 'La Loge' (London, Courtauld Institute)
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: At the Theatre (La Premi?re Sortie)

DESCRIPTION: Alphonse Daudet (1840-1897) was a French novelist.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Portrait of Madame Alphonse Daudet

DESCRIPTION: As a close friend of Goncourt, Flaubert, and Zola, he belonged to the Naturalist school of prose.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Portrait of Madame Alphonse Daudet

DESCRIPTION: In 1867 Daudet married Julia Allard (1844-1940), French poet and essayist, author of Impressions de nature et d'art (1879), L'Enfance d'une Parisienne (1883), and some literary studies written under the pseudonym "Karl Steen.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Portrait of Madame Alphonse Daudet

DESCRIPTION: This painting was executed during Renoir's trip to Italy in 1881.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: The Palazzo Ducale in Venice

DESCRIPTION: In Italy he found new inspiration in the works of Renaissance artists
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: The Palazzo Ducale in Venice

DESCRIPTION: This painting was executed during Renoir's trip to Italy in 1881.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Piazza San Marco in Venice

DESCRIPTION: In Italy he found new inspiration in the works of Renaissance artists
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Piazza San Marco in Venice

DESCRIPTION: Renoir had numerous patrons from the newly prosperous professional class of later-nineteenth-century Paris.
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Children's Afternoon at Wargemont

DESCRIPTION: This led to his keen sense for the harmony of ideal bourgeois domestic happiness in the Children's Afternoon at Wargemon
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: Children's Afternoon at Wargemont

DESCRIPTION: The painting represents Claude, Renoir's the third son at the age of eight
AUTHOR: RENOIR, Pierre-Auguste
TITLE: The Clown

DESCRIPTION: Marinus van Reymerswaele, a Calvinist from Zeeland, was studying in Antwerp at the time when Quentin Massys was the undisputed leader of the city's painters.
AUTHOR: REYMERSWAELE, Marinus van
TITLE: St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: In his Saint Jerome Van Reymerswaele - realist, mannerist and even expressionist - carried on the tradition of Massys' genre works in a picturesque, precious and almost caricature fashion
AUTHOR: REYMERSWAELE, Marinus van
TITLE: St Jerome

DESCRIPTION: Reynolds was the first president of the Royal Academy and the author of 15 discourses on painting, which are classics of the theory of art.
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Colonel George K. H. Coussmaker, Grenadier Guards

DESCRIPTION: In this dismounted equestrian portrait, Reynolds presents Colonel Coussmaker in a pose of casual but studied negligence, the line of his body repeated in the curving neck of the horse.
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Colonel George K. H. Coussmaker, Grenadier Guards

DESCRIPTION: The summer before Reynolds painted the portrait, he traveled to Holland and Flanders and profited by his observation of Rubens's works, especially in the creation of a free and painterly surface treatment
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Colonel George K. H. Coussmaker, Grenadier Guards

DESCRIPTION: In 1788, when Reynolds was at the summit of his reputation, he painted this portrait for one of his aunts, Anna Maria Lady Jones.
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Master Hare

DESCRIPTION: The sitter was Francis George Hare, the nephew or adopted son of Lady Jones.Two years after it was painted this picture was already famous.
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Master Hare

DESCRIPTION: It was bought by Baron Alphonse de Rothschild in 1872 and bequeathed to the Louvre in 1906
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Master Hare

DESCRIPTION: The episode depicted, narrated by Livy and Valerius Maximus, tells of how after the taking of Carthage in 209 BC Scipio had treated with respect a beautiful virgin, one of the hostages who had been consigned to him, and had sent her back to her intended husband and parents with the sole recommendation that her suitor strived for peace between Rome and Carthage
AUTHOR: REYNOLDS, Sir Joshua
TITLE: Continence of Scipio

DESCRIPTION: Ribera's stay in Rome lasted only a few years.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Sense of Taste

DESCRIPTION: Only a handful of pictures from his Roman period has been identified, of which the most important is a set of the Five Senses, supposedly made for a Spanish client.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Sense of Taste

DESCRIPTION: The Sense of Taste, which typifies these pictures, is an ingenious representation of a theme made popular in the Netherlands during the late sixteenth century.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Sense of Taste

DESCRIPTION: Northern artists treated the subject as an allegory with classicising figures.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Sense of Taste

DESCRIPTION: However, Ribera rejects this model and takes a direct, naturalistic approach, embodying the sense of taste  in a beefy, gluttonous type, poised to descent on a bowl of pasta and wash  it down with a jug of wine
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Sense of Taste

DESCRIPTION: The most famous of the Cynics, the philosopher Diogenes of Sinope, who died in 323 BC, is provided here with a lamp by way of an attribute.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Diogenes

DESCRIPTION: According to his own statement, he used it in broad daylight to find a 'genuine person' on a bustling marketplace.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Diogenes

DESCRIPTION: The subject was much loved throughout Baroque Europe, although it appears that the Italians preferred to depict the philosopher alone, as with this and another painting by Ribera, while the densely populated scenes were more popular in the Netherlands.Ribera was interested in studying different types of people, and even his religious paintings seem to be populated with figures taken from the everyday world about him, in the tradition of Caravaggio.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Diogenes

DESCRIPTION: The subject of this portrait must have prompted this depiction of an eccentric outsider, his hair tangled, his beard unkempt, his hands work-worn, dressed in simple apparel, and directing a penetrating gaze at the beholder
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Diogenes

DESCRIPTION: Ribera was a sumptuous colorist.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: The Holy Family with St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: His style evolved from an early preoccupation with "tenebrist" techniques, through a period of experiment with a silvery light, to a final stage characterized by warm and golden tones.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: The Holy Family with St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: One of his most beautiful paintings is the Holy Family in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: The Holy Family with St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Especially notable is the beautiful still-life as well as the brilliant rendition of the fabrics and the tender expressions
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: The Holy Family with St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Although the precise identity of the Jesuit is unknown, the presence of a lion on which the man rests his hand suggests that he might have been a missionary
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Portrait of a Jesuit Missionary

DESCRIPTION: Ribera studied in Francisco Ribalta's workshop in Valencia, but when still young he went to Naples, then under Spanish rule, where he worked for the rest of his life.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: He was called there as Lo Spagnoletto.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: He obtained most of his commissions from the Spanish Viceroy and his entourage, but he also completed a good many paintings for the churches of the city.The influence of Caravaggio was felt throughout southern Italy and there can be little doubt that Ribera was the artist with the strongest and most independent personality of all his followers.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: Ribera represented crude reality boldly and without embellishment.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: The construction of his pictures is monumental and he reveals a strong sense of drama, empahasized by means of strongly contrasting light and shade.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: The poor inhabitants of Naples and the peasants of southern Italy were his models, and he depicted them without flattery or idealization as enormous figures clothed in rags.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: The painting of Saint Onufri also shows the influence of Caravaggio
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: Saint Onufri

DESCRIPTION: The seventeenth century was a very productive period for Spanish painting.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: St Paul the Hermit

DESCRIPTION: Spain's extensive trade links brought with them an interchange of artistic ideas, particularly with Italy.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: St Paul the Hermit

DESCRIPTION: Jusepe de Ribera played an important role in this.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: St Paul the Hermit

DESCRIPTION: He began his studies with Ribalta but left Spain early on and went to Italy, where he discovered the work of Caravaggio.
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: St Paul the Hermit

DESCRIPTION: His style is characterized by strong light and shade, together with a realistic portrayal even of religious themes, as seen in his St Paul the Hermit of 1647
AUTHOR: RIBERA, Jusepe de
TITLE: St Paul the Hermit

DESCRIPTION: This canvas depicts the scene when St Anthony of Padua is healing a youth who had amputated his foot to punish himself for striking his mother
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: St Anthony of Padua Healing a Youth

DESCRIPTION: The pair of canvases, depicting The Bacchanal in Honour of Pan and The Feast of Silenus, were commissioned by the celebrated patron of the arts, Johann Matthias von der Schulenburg (1661-1747).
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Feast of Silenus

DESCRIPTION: A German aristocrat and general of the Saxon and Venetian armies, Schulenburg settled in Venice upon his retirement where he began to amass a spectacular collection, acquiring paintings by the likes of Raphael, Giorgione and Correggio.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Feast of Silenus

DESCRIPTION: In addition to the present canvases, Ricci painted two further versions of these pendants
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Feast of Silenus

DESCRIPTION: This is an elegant painting of almost neoclassical taste that transforms the savage scene of the bacchanal into gracious cameos, as can be seen in the bleeding lamb's head held up by a charming ribbon by the putto on the right.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bacchanal in Honour of Pan

DESCRIPTION: Ricci was an exuberant personality, internationally renowned and an archetypal "traveling" painter.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: After training in the Veneto, Ricci spent some time in Emilia (Bologna, Parma and Piacenza).
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: This proved crucial to his development as his style was influenced by the local classicism, deepened when Ricci made a trip to Rome, where Annibale Carraci's frescos in Palazzo Farnese deeply moved him.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: After a brief trip to Vienna, Ricci went back to Venice in 1708, where his art changed.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: His Altarpiece of St Gregory the Great was a deliberate homage to Paolo Veronese and inaugurated a totally new era in eighteenth-century Venetian painting, trying to revive the glories of its Renaissance.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: Compared to his earlier works, his art was now remarkably free in composition and brushwork.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: This new style of painting was an immediate success.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: By 1711 Sebastiano had joined his nephew Marco Ricci in London where he remained for five years, working for many great noblemen.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Altar of St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: In Greek mythology Phaethon was the son of Helios, the sun-god.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: Helios drove his golden chariot, a 'quadriga' yoked to a team of four horses abreast, daily across the sky.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: Phaethon persuaded his unwilling father to allow him for one day to drive his chariot across the skies.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: Because he had no skill he was soon in trouble, and the climax came when he met the fearful Scorpion of the zodiac.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: He dropped the reins, the horses bolted and caused the earth itself to catch fire.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: In the nick of time Jupiter, father of the goods, put a stop to his escapade with a thunderbolt which wrecked the chariot and sent Phaethon hurtling down in flames into the River Eridanus (according to some, the Po).
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: He was buried by nymphs.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: Phaethons's reckless attempt to drive his father's chariot made him the symbol of all who aspire to that which lies beyond their capabilities.Undoubtedly Sebastiano Ricci's dashing virtuoso technique had its roots in the Baroque.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: In his hands, however, it was translated into an explosive, light-hearted energy.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Fall of Phaethon

DESCRIPTION: The composition of this painting is similar to that of another painting of the same subject by Sebastiano Ricci, now in the Staatliche Museen, Berlin.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba at her Bath

DESCRIPTION: Both painting follow the scheme used for representing the toilette of Venus.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba at her Bath

DESCRIPTION: Bathsheba is identified only by the barely visible spying figure in the Budapest painting and by the figure of a maid approaching with a letter from King David.Apparently Ricci liked to use buildings with columns to close up the background, no doubt inspired by Veronese.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba at her Bath

DESCRIPTION: Slender columns, light, almost floating balconies provide a picturesquely decorative framework for the figures grouped on the stage in front.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba at her Bath

DESCRIPTION: The whole scene is pervaded by a shimmering silvery light; shadow and dimness have vanished completely; the painter applies light and colour for modelling.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba at her Bath

DESCRIPTION: The colouring, with its nacreous lustre, is particularly attractive; the hues are delicately shaded, enhancing the interplay of form and content
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba at her Bath

DESCRIPTION: Attended by four maids and on the far right, a boy with a mirror, Uriah's beautiful wife, Bathsheba, devotes herself to her elaborate toilette in an enclosed garden.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba

DESCRIPTION: The sight of Bathsheba inflamed King David's desire, and he is usually depicted in a palace-window in the background.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba

DESCRIPTION: Here, however, a maid approaches on the far left with a letter from the king.The painting dates from about 1725 and thus belongs to the artist's late period: its refinement of form and colour is reminiscent of the golden age of Venetian painting in the 16th century, in particular of Veronese.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba

DESCRIPTION: One of the most influential painters of his time, Ricci was well on the road to international success by the turn of the 17th century.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba

DESCRIPTION: His career took him to Parma, Bologna, Rome, Milan, Florence, Venice and London.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba

DESCRIPTION: His style bridges the impetuous baroque paintings of Luca Giordano and the Rococo-like, Venetian elegance of Tiepolo
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Bathsheba

DESCRIPTION: The biblical story (Genesis, chapter 21) depicted in the paintings is the following.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Repudiation of Hagar

DESCRIPTION: Hagar, the Egyptian hand maiden of Sarah was the mother of Ishmael, Abraham's first son.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Repudiation of Hagar

DESCRIPTION: When Isaac, Sarah's son, was born Ishmael mocked his younger brother so that Sarah asked Abraham to banish him, together with his mother.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Repudiation of Hagar

DESCRIPTION: Abraham provided them with bread and a bottle of water and sent them off into the desert of Beersheba
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Repudiation of Hagar

DESCRIPTION: The Rape of the Sabine Women and its companion-piece the Battle of the Romans and the Sabines illustrates the legend of Rome's foundation.Romulus, the founder of Rome, succeeded by a ruse in ensuring the future growth of the population.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Battle of the Romans and the Sabines

DESCRIPTION: He arranged a festival to which were invited the inhabitants of neighbouring settlements including the Sabines, with their wives and children.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Battle of the Romans and the Sabines

DESCRIPTION: During the festivities, at a given signal, the young men of Rome broke into the crowd and, choosing only unmarried maidens of the Sabines, carried them off.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Battle of the Romans and the Sabines

DESCRIPTION: The Sabine women accepted their lot.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Battle of the Romans and the Sabines

DESCRIPTION: But later a Sabine army attacked the city in force and succeeded in overcoming part of it.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Battle of the Romans and the Sabines

DESCRIPTION: They were prevented from going further by the intervention of the Sabine women which brought about peace between the warring soldiers.The glowing colours of the two paintings reveal the influence of Paolo Veronese, while the pastel illumination of Ricci's palette anticipates the Rococo
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Battle of the Romans and the Sabines

DESCRIPTION: The largest room on the ground floor is the Sala d'Ercole, a hall with two window bays.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: It has three entrances and presents an elaborate painted decoration extending across all four walls and the entire ceiling.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: The decoration was executed with the collaboration of Giuseppe Tonelli (1668-1732), one of the best known quadratura painters in Florence.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: The pictorial program contains the Labours and Apotheosis of Hercules.A simple, rhythmic arrangement of columns, backed by a gilt ground, structures all four walls in the room.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: On three sides it is interrupted by a large, arched centre opening.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: The compositions for these imaginary openings are three of Hercules's more significant labours.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: Prominent on the end wall is the depiction of the young Hercules at the Crossroads between Vice and Virtue, the other two openings contains Hercules and Cacus, and Hercules and Nessus.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: On the window wall a painted sculpture depicting Hercules and Antheus can be found.In the Sala d'Ercole Ricci's fluid, elegant, and atmospheric style attains a brilliance and airiness that set him apart from all his famous contemporaries, and has been shown to anticipate features of Rococo painting
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Hercules at the Crossroads

DESCRIPTION: In the Sala d'Ercole, the figure of Mercury hovers directly above the door to the foyer.
AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano
TITLE: Mercury

DESCRIPTION: The god's pose quotes Giambologna's famous sculpture

DESCRIPTION: Ricci painted this large-format oil painting for the room on the ground floor of the Palazzo Marucelli-Fenzi in which the ceiling fresco presents Youth between Virtue and Vice.

DESCRIPTION: This painting hangs on the wall in its original location, complementing the subject in the ceiling fresco

TITLE: Lucius Quinctius Cincinnatus Called from the Plow to the Dictatorship

AUTHOR: RICCI, Sebastiano

TITLE: Death of the Prince de Talmont

DESCRIPTION: The most original paintings by the Swedish artist depict the Venetian lagoons enlivened by boats.

DESCRIPTION: He frequently used the 'camera obscura' like in the case of this painting.

TITLE: View of the Giudecca Canal

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows the profile of Venice as it appears from the present-day Giardini when approaching the city by boat from the Lido.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan

DESCRIPTION: To the far left is the island of San Giorgio Maggiore, with the church of the same name and the complex of the Benedictine monastery.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: Just to the right of the island appear the Magazzini del Sal, dazzlingly illuminated, the Dogana and Santa Maria della Salute on the spit of land known as the Dorsoduro.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: The Campanile of San Marco looms right on the vertical axis, counterbalancing the predominant horizontals.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: On the right, the Riva degli Schiavoni stretches beyond the church of the Pieta.The glassy green surface of the water with the dark bank in the foreground, the contrasting light on the various buildings and the snow-white clouds lend the painting an atmosphere all its own.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: The boat and the shadows in the foreground are motifs which also occur in works of late seventeenth-century Dutch painters of harbour views such as Abraham and Johannes Storck, who may have served Richter as a source of inspiration.Typical of Richter's work are the boats in the foreground painted horizontal to the picture plane.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: The present canvas occupies a special position among Richter's identified works.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: He usually worked in the style of Carlevaris, whom he imitated deceptively well.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: However, in this picture Canaletto's spacious views of the Lagoon were his principal source of inspiration.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: The remarkable colour combination — green and black — recalls Canaletto's work of the early 1730s.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: Richter, who died in 1745, must have painted this view of the Bacino toward the end of his career.
AUTHOR: RICHTER, Johan
TITLE: The Bacino di San Marco

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the principal works of Rippl-Rónai's "black" period.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Skittle-players

DESCRIPTION: The figures, delineated with just a few bare contours and dark areas of colour, bear witness to the calm and economy of motion that attracted Rippl-Rónai to the game.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Skittle-players

DESCRIPTION: This and other similar paintings of the time, slightly sketched with a thin coat of paint, reveal the influence of an important group of artists including Vuillard Bonnard, Valloton and Denis, wwho came to regard Rippl-Rónai as one of their group
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Skittle-players

DESCRIPTION: A great example of intimate interior pictures, it was awarded with the prize of the National Society of Art in 1906.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: When One Lives on Memories

DESCRIPTION: It is closely linked  to the atmospheres and colours of "White Wall with White Furniture" and "Flox and Filox", but the intensity and variety of its colours are in favour of "When One Lives on One's Memories".
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: When One Lives on Memories

DESCRIPTION: Its composition is superb: by applying space near and far he expresses the physical and psychic departure of  the old woman, the central figure of the picture, whose relationship to the world is slowly fading.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: When One Lives on Memories

DESCRIPTION: Greyish-blue of the second space are in an intrinsic contrast with the cheerful foreground full of colours, with elements of Rippl's former pictures, e.g.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: When One Lives on Memories

DESCRIPTION: the red of the colourful head kerchief.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: When One Lives on Memories

DESCRIPTION: The mirror in the axis of  the window and  the door symbolizes that life and mortality cannot be helped: it is out of use and serves decoration only
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: When One Lives on Memories

DESCRIPTION: The picture represents a major milestone in Rippl's oevre where two periods meet: elements of  intimate interior pictures  and those of the next decorative period with  corn are present.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: There is a constant figure of interior pictures: a old man smoking the pipe while he is meditating.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: He is present in this picture, too, he is sitting by the artist's father lost in thoughts.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: Unlike his previous pictures showing interiors, he limits space and does not show details, only relevant things.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: It integrates less formal pictures arresting emotions and atmospheres with pictures of strict composition.In the case of this picture everything is planned, colours and figures serve the unity of the composition.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: Spots and patches painted with wide brushstrokes can be seen in the figure of Uncle Piacsek and the lively yellow of the plain background.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: Neither the new technique, nor  the noisy colours  (yellow wall, burning-red table-cloth)  serve unrestrained decorativity, they balance the strict composition.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: This is why an armchair  with blue striped cover  and a green cover are placed  on both sides by the yellow background.
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: The wine-jug and the two glasses have the same function in composition
AUTHOR: RIPPL-RÓNAI, József
TITLE: Father and Uncle Piacsek Drinking Red Wine

DESCRIPTION: During his stay in Italy from 1754 to 1765 Robert made a large number of red chalk drawings of the most important sites in Rome.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: A Scene in the Grounds of the Villa Farnese, Rome

DESCRIPTION: A signed preparatory drawing for this painting, depicting a scene in the grounds of the Villa Farnese, Rome, with a mother and child seated upon an antique stair, a classical rotunda beyond, is known
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: A Scene in the Grounds of the Villa Farnese, Rome

DESCRIPTION: The pair of paintings of identical size, Roman Figures under an Arcade and Roman Figures in a Cave, were executed by Robert during his stay in Rome.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Roman Figures under an Arcade

DESCRIPTION: They recall the work of Pannini, one of Robert's teachers, in their subject matter and colourful, classically draped figures amongst Roman ruins
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Roman Figures under an Arcade

DESCRIPTION: French painting in the second half of the 18th century displays the overlapping or intermingling of pre-Romantic and Neoclassical pictorial ideas, and nowhere is this clearer than in the work of the 'painter of ruins', Hubert Robert.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins

DESCRIPTION: He obtained his ideas from Italy, where he admired the paintings of ruins by Giovanni Paolo Pannini, and witnessed the first excavations in Pompeii.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins

DESCRIPTION: Praised by Diderot, he was immediately consulted when antique pieces were to be placed in the park of Versailles.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins

DESCRIPTION: But his great work was the realization of the Louvre Museum.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins

DESCRIPTION: A comparison of two of his paintings, the first showing a ruined barrel-vault hall, and the second the Grande Galerie in the Louvre, immediately reveals the source of the idea for the top lighting and the "antique effect" that the newly designed gallery is open to the sky.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins

DESCRIPTION: The sublimity of antique ruins was to be transferred to the real building, and this in turn was to be a treasure chest of art and a worthy successor to its antique models
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre in Ruins

DESCRIPTION: Hubert Robert painted many views, both real and imaginary, of the Grande Galerie of the Louvre.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: His imaginary vies really constitute a set of designs for an ideal museum.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: When he painted this picture (the finest in the series) in 1796, the Galley was nothing but an interminably long corridor, lit only by side windows, which linked the Louvre to the Tuileries.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: The architects who were later responsible for the lighting and redecoration of the Grande Galerie were merely executing the original ideas of Hubert Robert.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: In this painting several of the masterpieces of the Museum Central can be recognized, notably Raphael's Holy Family of François I and Titian's Entombment
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Design for the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: This painting belongs to a series depicting partly imaginary, partly later realized plans to transform the Grande Galerie of the Louvre into an exhibition space.
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: Ten paintings of the series are exhibited in the Musée du Louvre
AUTHOR: ROBERT, Hubert
TITLE: Imaginary View of the Grande Galerie in the Louvre

DESCRIPTION: The three paintings in the Cini collection, representing St Catherine of Alexandria, St Jerome, and St George, respectively, were in the side columns of the polyptych commissioned from Ercole de' Roberti and Francesco del Cossa by Floriano Griffoni from Bologna for his private chapel in the church of San Petronio

AUTHOR: ROBERTI, Ercole de'
TITLE: Predella of Stories of Christ: 3. Road to Calvary

AUTHOR: ROMANINO, Girolamo
TITLE: Piet?

DESCRIPTION: The panel was painted for the Chapel of the Holy Passion in the old church of San Lorenzo in Brescia and in it we can see Romanino's predilection for Titian's sonorously rich colour transposed onto a plane of popular narrative strengthened by a romantic, imaginative pathos.
AUTHOR: ROMANINO, Girolamo
TITLE: Piet?

DESCRIPTION: Against the background of a landscape which itself seems constricted in its atmosphere of profound anguish, the figures of the foreground seem to float to the surface in sharply cadenced groupings painted in timbres of a blazing quality.
AUTHOR: ROMANINO, Girolamo
TITLE: Piet?

DESCRIPTION: The influence of Lombard style which can be noted in the roundish faces painted after the fashion of Bramante, are accompanied by the influence of Northern European painting which can be seen in the view of the town glimpsed through the steamy, stormy atmosphere, in the objective quality of the portrait of the man, in the expressionistic deformation of the little human figures moving around the crosses at Golgotha.In this earliest attributable work by Romanino, the characteristic quality of the artist's style is already evident: an expressionistic realism which seems to offer an extremely personalized reflection of the political, social and religious crises that shook the Western world in the first half of the sixteenth century
AUTHOR: ROMANINO, Girolamo
TITLE: Piet?

DESCRIPTION: Antonio Rossellino and his workshop played an important role in the creation of the burial chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal.
AUTHOR: ROSSELLINO, Antonio
TITLE: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
TECHNIQUE: White and coloured marbles, width of chapel 480 cm

DESCRIPTION: This elaborate undertaking was the result of the collaboration of an architect (Antonio Manetti), four sculptors (Antonio Rossellino, his brothers Bernardo and Giovanni, and Luca della Robbia), three painters (Alesso Baldovinetti, Antonio and Piero del Pollaiuolo), their workshops, and other craftsmen as well, and yet the chapel today - which looks exactly as it must have looked in the 1470s - is a stylistically unified totality rather than a demonstration of the diverse talents of a number of individuals.James (Jaime), a prince of the Portugal royal family who was made a cardinal at twenty-two, died of tuberculosis in Florence when he was only twenty-five.
AUTHOR: ROSSELLINO, Antonio
TITLE: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
TECHNIQUE: White and coloured marbles, width of chapel 480 cm

DESCRIPTION: He had expressed a desire to be buried at San Miniato, and immense sums poured in for his funerary chapel.The chapel was designed by Antonio Manetti, a pupil of Brunelleschi, and the architectural detail was carved by Giovanni Rossellino, third of the five Rossellino brothers.
AUTHOR: ROSSELLINO, Antonio
TITLE: View of the Chapel of the Cardinal of Portugal
TECHNIQUE: White and coloured marbles, width of chapel 480 cm

DESCRIPTION: The tomb was designed by Antonio Rossellino, who was helped in the execution by his brother Bernardo, and several assistants.

TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper fixed onto canvas

DESCRIPTION: The central section on paper is by Rubens, and this is fixed onto canvas and connect- ed to a generic background comprising a tree and curtain hanging on the right, by a late seventeenth-century painter probably from the Veneto.Despite its critical vicissitudes over the centuries, there is no lack of elements substantiating the author of the painting and its very high quality: the brilliant quality of the afresh tones, especially in the children; the emotional intensity of the looks; the material richness and the expert technique evident in the several tones of Titian-style red on which the chromatic distribution of the entire fragment is based.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Virgin and Child with the Infant St John
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper fixed onto canvas

DESCRIPTION: Deep layers of solid and glazed lacquer are superimposed, often tone on tone and finely touched, from the clothes of the Virgin shaded in the grey filaments and earth green of the veil falling on her neck, to the profiles and extremely tender tips of the two children's fingers, heightened in white with the tip of the brush.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Virgin and Child with the Infant St John
TECHNIQUE: Oil on paper fixed onto canvas

DESCRIPTION: Then there is the skillful painting of the Virgin's ear and of every other element in the work; the power of invention and of colour evident in the small patch of sky; the effect of shaping on form, seen in the facial features and breast of the Virgin, portrayed to great plastic effect, and partly the entire placement of the figures and overall composition, sensitive to the lessons of Caravaggio
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Virgin and Child with the Infant St John

DESCRIPTION: The subject comes from a line by the Roman comic poet Terence (d.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: 159 BC) which frequently figures in the emblem literature that developed from the mid-16th century: 'Sine Cerere et Libero friget Venus' - without Ceres and Bacchus, Venus would freeze.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: Love is impossible without food and drink.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: Rather than depicting a boisterous feast, Rubens has opted for a rather restrained scene that must be read as a plea for moderation in pleasure.Rubens produced this painting a few years after his eight-year stay in Italy, where he was employed at the court of Duke Vincenzo Gonzaga of Mantua, and also in Rome.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: The knowledge of antiquity he gained then was put to use in this painting, as also in a later work on the same theme in 1614, (Royal Fine Arts Museum, Antwerp), Ceres' pose being taken from the Crouching Venus of the Hellenistic sculptor Doidalsas, dating from around 240-230 BC.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: Rubens certainly knew the marble copy in the Farnese collection in Rome (today in the National Archaeological Museum, Naples).What he particularly appreciated in Hellenistic and Roman sculpture was its formal dynamism, although he saw in ancient sculpture generally a realm of flawless, ideal nature.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: In painting from such antique models, he says in his De Imitatione Statuarum, a treatise 'on the imitation of sculpture', the statuary has to be humanised, translated into flesh and blood.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Venus, Cupid, Baccchus and Ceres

DESCRIPTION: The story, depicted in the painting is part of the legendary history of Athens and it has echoes of a primitive fertility rite.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: It tells how Vulcan, in a clumsy attempt to ravish Minerva, accidentally let his semen spill over the ground, and Mother Earth, thus fertilized, gave birth to Erichthonius.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: Minerva shut the infant in a basket, which she entrusted to the three daughters of Cecrops, king of Attica, forbidding them to open it.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: But one of them, overcome by curiosity, did so and discovered that the child had a serpent's tail for legs (or that a serpent lay beside it).
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: Maddened with terror the three threw themselves from the top of the Acropolis.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: Erichthonius, brought up by Minerva, became king of Athens.The three sisters are depicted in the act of opening the basket, out of which a snake uncurls itself.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: The infant lies inside.

TITLE: The Discovery of the Child Erichthonius

DESCRIPTION: Mother Earth is represented by a statue of Diana of Ephesus, the many-breasted goddess of fertility.

DESCRIPTION: The theme is most often found in 17th century Netherlandish painting

AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Rape of Europa

DESCRIPTION: The source of the subject is Ovid's Metamorphoses.The love affairs of gods never bode well for mortals; there were times when they caused nothing but suffering even for some of the nymphs.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: Io, the beautiful daughter of the river god Inachus, fell prey to the passion of Jupiter, who - in order to hide her from his jealous wife - turned the girl into a cow.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: The wily Juno talked her husband into giving her the fine-looking animal and had the hundred-eyed Argus guard it.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: Jupiter gave Mercury the task of killing the wicked guard.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: The inventive god (the Greeks called him "Hermes dolios", the schemer) approached the meadows, herding some goats which he had stolen along the way, and played songs on his pipe.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: The guard was charmed by the new and masterful melodies.Mercury watches intently as Argus is mesmerized by the sound of the flute, and he is already reaching for the weapon with which he will behead the sleepy guardian.Rubens depicted a fipple flute in place of a Pan-pipe.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: From the aulos used at feasts of Antiquity and the Roman tibia through the medieval bagpipes and Renaissance-Baroque horns and musettes, all the way to the saxophone of our times, every wind instrument was attributed with having a dangerous mesmerizing power
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Mercury and Argus

DESCRIPTION: This painting is also known as the Allegory of Fertility
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Nymphs and Satyrs

DESCRIPTION: Thanks to his organisational capacities, Rubens could meet demand and revolutionise the problem of large-scale pictorial decoration.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: His renown extended well beyond the frontiers of his country, and in 1621 Marie de Médicis, widow of Henri IV of France and mother of the reigning king Louis XIII, invited him to Paris.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: She wished him to decorate one of the galleries of the newly built Palais de Luxembourg with 24 monumental paintings commemorating episodes in the lives of herself and her renowned husband.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: The creation of a cycle of tapestries had, in a sense, been Rubens' technical apprenticeship for this demanding task, the composition of a cycle of vast narrative paintings dedicated to a living queen who had already entered history.Giving epic treatment to this biographical subject, Rubens was also able to give free rein to his fertile invention.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: He prepared two series of oil sketches, with detailed figures drawn in, which it then fell to his assistants to scale up to the dimensions of the canvases commissioned.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: These were then meticulously retouched by the master so that they might be ultimately be described, at least in the final layers of paint, as his own works.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: The entire commission was completed in only three years.All of his prodigious culture was drawn on for these works: his encyclopaedic knowledge of classical mythology was exploited to the full in transforming the queen's entire career - Henri slipped rather into the background - into a kind of operatic sequence largely of Rubens' own invention.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: Metamorphosing life into myth, he freely mingled historical personages with the gods of Olympus, who came to represent them.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: The scheme of this apparatus was invented as he went along, the - often gratuitous - interpolations of the divine gracefully leavening the uneventful royal life.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: It had required all of Rubens' imaginative resources and natural verve to ennoble and illustrate the relatively colourless circumstances of the Queen Mother's life.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: These qualities were essential; Rubens' international renown depended on his success in this formidable commission.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: His solution was to populate his compositions with nude goddesses, pagan gods, curvaceous undines, mischievous tritons, and genii unspecified.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: His customary contrasts are at work in the playful opposition of gleaming cuirasses and lusty bodies, fragile silks and the rugged hulls of dreadnoughts.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: The poverty of his subject was utterly transcended; this is pure painting, nothing but painting.Certainly, it was not the rather heavy features of the Medici family, particularly evident in the queen, that had attracted Henri IV, but the scale of her dowry.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: Rubens nevertheless contrived to render her portrait agreeable.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: He disguised her now as an attractive Bellona, now as a proud horsewoman in The Capture of Juliers.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: The royal couple become Olympian deities in The Meeting of Marie de Médicis and Henri IV at Lyon, while The Fate Spinning Marie's Destiny and The Triumph of Truth became pretexts for a proliferation of female convexity
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: The Landing of Marie de Médicis at Marseilles

DESCRIPTION: His broad hat identifies the painter as a bit of a dandy, while the brushwork representing his collar displays his skill and the virtuoso modernity he learned from Titian

DESCRIPTION: He was a reputable philologist, Neo-Latin poet and historiographer.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Jan Gaspar Gevartius

DESCRIPTION: Characteristically for his intellectual circles he had his name Latinized to Gevartius.After a stay in Holland and Paris Gevartius became the Registrar of the city of Antwerp.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Jan Gaspar Gevartius

DESCRIPTION: In this function he was in charge of official ceremonies in the city and in 1635 helped Rubens with the "Pompa Introitus Ferdinandi", one of Rubens most impressive projects.Rubens here intends to represent his friend's humanist attitude: he is sitting at his desk, with a bust of the Roman Emperor and philosopher Marcus Aurelius, on whom he wrote an unpublished commentary.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Jan Gaspar Gevartius

DESCRIPTION: The painting is dated around 1628.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Jan Gaspar Gevartius

DESCRIPTION: The composition of the work is not baroque, but fits more easily into the 16th-century tradition of homely portraits of humanists
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Jan Gaspar Gevartius

DESCRIPTION: Don Ambrogio Spinola Doria, marqués de los Balbases (1569-1630), was an Italian general, at the service of Spain.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Ambrogio Spinola

DESCRIPTION: He is often called "Ambrosio", especially in Spanish-speaking countries.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Portrait of Ambrogio Spinola

DESCRIPTION: The most significant act of his career was the taking of Breda, depicted in the famous painting by Velázquez.This portrait of Spinola can be compared with his other portrait by Rubens, presently in Braunschweig
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul

DESCRIPTION: Rubens painted this picture at the end of his life when he was living in his country residence at Het Steen.

TITLE: Landscape with a Rainbow

DESCRIPTION: The contrast between the two halves of the composition, a sunlit prosperity on the left and a gloomy wood on the right, suggest an analogy with the Last Judgment, the rainbow representing the Arc of the Covenant.The late landscapes by Rubens, such as this work, with their atmospheric appearance, often in subdued golden light of an early summer evening, make an elegiac impression.
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul
TITLE: Landscape with a Rainbow

DESCRIPTION: This makes Rubens come close to the spirit of Titian who exercised such a profound influence on his other late work
AUTHOR: RUBENS, Peter Paul

TITLE: Deesis Range: The Archangel Michael

DESCRIPTION: During the years from about 1650 to about 1655, the heroic quality of Ruisdael's landscapes increases.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: The forms become larger and more massive.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: Giant oaks and beeches as well as shrubs acquire an unprecedented abundance and fullness.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: Colours become more vivid, space increases in both height and depth, and there is an emphasis on the tectonic structure of the compositions.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: He strove to achieve heroic effects without sacrificing the individuality of a single tree or bush.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: An outstanding example of this tendency is his mighty view of Bentheim Castle.Ruisdael visited Bentheim, a small town in Wesphalia near the Dutch-German border, when he travelled to the region with his friend Berchem in the early fifties.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: Bentheim's castle is, in fact, on an unimposing low hill, but in his painting Ruisdael enlarged it into a wooded mountain providing the castle with a commanding position.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: His invention is a superb expression of his aggrandizement of solid forms during this phase.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: The dense mass of the mountain, obliquely stretching away into depth, and the coulisses on either side of the front edge of the painting are reminiscent of compositional schemes used by the generation of his teachers, but the spatial clarity is new, as are the strong colours, the energy of the brushwork, and the way he unifies the close view of a nearly overwhelming wealth of detail with the most distant parts of the landscape into a consistent whole.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: The impact of the broad prospect is as intense as the vegetation seen close up.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: Ruisdael continued to include Bentheim Castle in his landscapes, seen in various settings and from different viewpoints, until his very last years
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Bentheim Castle

DESCRIPTION: Besides the Bentheim Castle, another motif Ruisdael discovered on his trip to the Dutch-German border region was the water mill.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice

DESCRIPTION: The half-timbered overshot and undershot mills he favoured were found in the eastern provinces of the Netherlands and in the area near Bentheim.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice

DESCRIPTION: Of course, earlier artists included watermills in their pictures but he was the first to make them the principal theme of a painting.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice

DESCRIPTION: The subject became one of the specialities of his pupil Meindert Hobbema, and today, when we think of them, his paintings not Ruisdael's come to mind.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice

DESCRIPTION: But in judging their respective accomplishments it is helpful to recall that Ruisdael painted powerful ones, such as Two Water Mills and an Open Sluice, which impresses by the cohesion of its forms and clear daylight effect, before Hobbema held a brush in his hand
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Two Watermills and an Open Sluice

DESCRIPTION: The animals were painted by Adriaen van de Velde.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Hunt

DESCRIPTION: Ruins sometimes play a prominent role, and gloomy skies set a melancholy mood.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: Ruisdael's rare ability to create a compelling and tragic mood in nature is best seen in his famous Jewish Cemetery at Dresden.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: A larger, more elaborate autograph version is at the Detroit Institute of Arts.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: These works are moralizing landscapes that were painted with a deliberate allegorical programme.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: The combination of their conspicuous tombs, ruins, large dead beech trees, broken trunks, and rushing streams alludes to the familiar themes of transience and the vanity of life and the ultimate futility of human endeavour, while the burst of light that breaks through the ravening clouds in each painting, their rainbows and the luxuriant growth that contrasts with the dead trees offer a promise of hope and renewed life.The masterliness of the Dresden painting lies in the artist's clear and concentrated presentation of these ideas.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: The eye focuses on the three tombs in the middle distance, where the light is centralized.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: They present a truthful picture of the actual, identifiable sarcophagi as they can still be seen in the Portuguese-Jewish Cemetery at Ouderkerk on the Amstel River near Amsterdam.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: Ruisdael made carefully worked-up drawings of the tombs, one of which he used as a preparatory drawing for the paintings.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: But the landscape settings of the Dresden and Detroit paintings bear no resemblance whatsoever to the site at Ouderkerk.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: They are Ruisdael's inventions.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: The cemetery never had monumental ruins.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: Those seen in the Dresden version were transplants from the shattered remains of Egmond Castle near Alkmaar, a site about forty kilometres from Ouderkerk; they also are based on a preparatory drawing.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: The ruins seen in the Detroit painting are probably derived from the ruins of Egmond's old Abbey Church.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: A rushing stream does not bisect the actual burial ground.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: (Would anyone in his right mind place tombs near a vigorous stream which would wreak havoc with the tombstones and coffins beneath them when it flooded?)
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: The stream was included as a traditional allusion to the passage of time.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: Most remarkable is the barren beech tree in the Dresden picture that gestures toward the three tombs and heavenwards.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: If ever a tree was capable of seducing a viewer to accept the pathetic fallacy of endowing natural forms with human feelings and emotions it is this dead beech.The iconographical programme of Ruisdael's two versions of the Jewish Cemetery leaves no doubt that they were intended as moralizing landscapes.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: He made no others that can be given a similar unmistakable reading.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: None of his other existing paintings include tombs; those done by his contemporaries are rare, and some of them are based on his depictions of the sarcophagi at Ouderkerk.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: However, Ruisdael made numerous pictures that include identifiable or imaginary ruins, dead and broken trees, rushing streams, rivers, and waterfalls.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: Were these motifs invariably intended by the artist as symbols of transience and the vanity of life, and does the handful of them that include rainbows allude to hope?
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: It has been argued that this is indeed the case, and that these motifs not only offer the iconographical essence of Ruisdael's landscapes but offer the key to the meaning to seventeenth-century landscape painting.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: According to this interpretation they were intended as visual sermons to convey the biblical message that man lives in a transient world beset by sinful temptation, but may hope for salvation
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: The Jewish Cemetery

DESCRIPTION: Panoramic views of the flat plains in Holland are often said to be the most distinctive contribution of Dutch landscape painting.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: They differ from the 'world panorama' of earlier Flemish art by seemingly recording the momentary view of a single scene, rather than being composed of a collection of separate visual memories.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: Formally, they are characterized bb a low horizon line, implying a low viewpoint.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: Although Ruisdael, perhaps the greatest and the most versatile Dutch landscape specialist, did not invent this type of picture, he became one of its most distinguished practitioners.This painting may represent a view in Gooiland, a district to the east of Amsterdam; there are, however, at least four other, smaller landscapes by Ruisdael that show the same view or part of it with considerable variations, and it is clear that he was not attempting strict topographical accuracy.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: Despite the pretence of spontaneity, this work, like all landscape paintings of the time, is a synthetic product of the artist's studio.Its dominant feature is the sky, to which two thirds of the picture surface is devoted and which is also reflected in the water of the foreground.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: This is the real, moisture-laden sky of Holland billowing with clouds, the sun breaking sporadically through scattering shafts of light across the countryside - effects which Constable was later to emulate.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: Almost more remarkable than the truthful record of the shape, density and illumination of the clouds is the illusion that they are moving through space and over our heads (we tend to think that perspective does not govern cloudscapes, but these seem to taper towards the horizon and broaden at the upper edge of the painting).
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: The long horizon too seems to extend beyond the frame, broken only by church spires and the tiny white sails of a windmill.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: But our sense of inhabiting the landscape is compromised by our viewpoint in relation to the foreground.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: By letting us look down into the bastion standing below the horizon line, the painter suggests that we are viewing it from some improbably high place, higher also than the shore on which the peasants graze their flock (both figures and animals were painted by Adriaen van der Velde, a division of labour quite common in Dutch landscapes).
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: This implied detachment, however, strengthens the elegiac mood aroused by the sight of overgrown ruins, melancholy reminders of a distant and more heroic past
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: An Extensive Landscape with a Ruined Castle and a Village Church

DESCRIPTION: Ruisdael never visited Scandinavia, but he borrowed the idea of Norwegian landscapes from Allaert van Everdingen, an artist who worked for a time in Haarlem and had success with such works.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Waterfall in Norway

DESCRIPTION: A rush of water carrying away a broken tree, a house huddled on a slope, and tiny figures beneath a clouded sky - all these components make it possible to see the painting as a piece of 17th-century speculation on the romantic opposition of man and the elements
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Waterfall in Norway

DESCRIPTION: This is one of Ruisdael grandest landscapes.After Ruisdael had settled in Amsterdam about 1656-57 his compositions broaden, and a certain heaviness in the foreground disappears.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Landscape with Waterfall

DESCRIPTION: The opening of the view suggests that he was impressed by Philips Koninck's panoramic views, but the fresh atmospheric effect, the brilliant glittering daylight which brightens the landscapes, the reflections, and vivid colours in the shadows are completely personal.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Landscape with Waterfall

DESCRIPTION: In the late fifties Ruisdael also began to represent waterfalls in mountainous northern valleys, and in the sixties they became an important theme in his oeuvre.
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van
TITLE: Landscape with Waterfall

DESCRIPTION: This motif was popularized by Allart van Everdingen after he returned to Holland in 1644 from a trip to Norway and Sweden, and Ruisdael, who never visited Scandinavia, derived his torrential falls in northern landscapes from Everdingen's art
AUTHOR: RUISDAEL, Jacob Isaackszon van

AUTHOR: RUYSDAEL, Salomon van
TITLE: The Ferryboat

DESCRIPTION: Within this constellation even the ferry in the left foreground, laden low with a four-in-hand and a large number of passengers, appears like a fallen leaf carried along effortlessly by the river, the connecting feature stretching through this landscape.Within Salomon van Ruysdael's work, catalogued by Wolfgang Stechow, this painting represents an exception from his otherwise typical use of diagonals in his compositions.
AUTHOR: RUYSDAEL, Salomon van
TITLE: The Ferryboat

DESCRIPTION: But whenever in later works he returns to this traditional pattern, this Ferryboat appears to have been a key work for the discovery of new waterside motifs, providing the viewer with variety and entertainment during his visual walk along never-ending river banks
