TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: It represents the Triumph of Divina Sapientia.The Palazzo Barberini, residence of the papal family Barberini, set a new standard for Roman palace architecture and its painted decoration.
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: Planning for the expansion of the sixteenth-century structure was first undertaken by Carlo Maderno, then transferred after his death to Gian Lorenzo Bernini, who here distinguished himself as an architect for the first time.The first commission for the painted decor was given to Andrea Sacchi who in 1629-30 painted the ceiling of the largest room in the wing occupied by Anna Colonna, Taddeo Barberini's wife.
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: Sacchi painted here the fresco identified as Triumph of Divina Sapientia (divine wisdom).
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: Sirens in the room corners hold up small sun disks that extend up into the fresco.
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: They anticipate the theme of the ceiling, in which the sun plays a central role.The design of the ceiling omits architectural elements completely.
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: Viewers find themselves confronted with a startling heavenly vision including, among other things, realistically depicted astronomical bodies - Earth and the sun hand directly above them.
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: The personification of Divine Wisdom is seated on the Solomonic lion throne, crowned by two Barberini bees, before a huge radiating solar disk in yellow-gold.
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

DESCRIPTION: Imaginative cloud formations fill the greater part of the picture surface, creating a perspective pull that graphically suggests the vast distance between the smaller Earth at the bottom edge of the picture and the gigantic sun.It is obvious that Sacchi's ceiling presents a commentary on the then current issue of Galileo Galilei's heliocentric worldview
AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: Ceiling fresco

AUTHOR: SACCHI, Andrea
TITLE: The Vision of St Romuald

DESCRIPTION: It was after this dream Romuald declared that the Order should henceforth be dressed in white

DESCRIPTION: Trumpets announce the arrival of Fame from the globe on which the allegorical figure stands and knights arrive to honour her.The feathers on the frame are a reference to Lorenzo's father Piero de Gouty, and the reverse of the tondo features other references to the Medici, as well as to the family of Lorenzo's mother, Lucrezia Tornabuoni
AUTHOR: SCHEGGIA
TITLE: Triumph of Fame (a Birth Salver)
TECHNIQUE: Tempera, silver and gold on wood, diameter 93 cm (with frame)

DESCRIPTION: The most striking feature of this panel is the contrast between the realism, austerity and sobriety of the donors and the idealization, spontaneous movement and freshness of the group formed by the Virgin and Child
AUTHOR: SCOREL, Jan van
TITLE: Madonna of the Daffodils with the Child and Donors

DESCRIPTION: The triptych was ordered in 1526 by Herman Lochorst, canon of the cathedral in Utrecht.
AUTHOR: SCOREL, Jan van
TITLE: Lochorst Triptych

DESCRIPTION: The central panel depicts the Entry of Christ into Jerusalem.
AUTHOR: SCOREL, Jan van
TITLE: Lochorst Triptych

DESCRIPTION: The interior wings present saints venerated in Utrecht: Agnes, Pope Cornelius, and Anthony on the left, Sebastian, Gertrude of Nivelles, and Christopher on the right.
AUTHOR: SCOREL, Jan van
TITLE: Lochorst Triptych

DESCRIPTION: Of these figures, St Agnes is the most striking in her charming classical pose and the sheer, gauzelike chiton she wears.
AUTHOR: SCOREL, Jan van
TITLE: Lochorst Triptych

DESCRIPTION: On the outsides of the wings (not shown here) the donor and his family are presented, kneeling in front of their patron saints
AUTHOR: SCOREL, Jan van
TITLE: Lochorst Triptych

DESCRIPTION: This painting, representing the area neighbouring Rotherhithe in the extreme North East of the London borough of Southwark, shows the influence of Canaletto, who arrived in London in 1746
AUTHOR: SCOTT, Samuel
TITLE: Shipping on the Thames off Rotherhithe

DESCRIPTION: The painting was executed for Giovanni Grimani, Patriarch of Aqquileia from 1546 to 1593.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Christ Carrying the Cross

DESCRIPTION: There are two other version of the same subject by Sebastiano, one in Rome (Castel Sant'Angelo) and Berlin (Staatliche Museen)
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Christ Carrying the Cross

DESCRIPTION: This altarpiece depicts St John Chrysostom with Sts Catherine, Magdalen, Lucy, John the Evangelist, John the Baptist and Theodore.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: San Giovanni Crisostomo Altarpiece

DESCRIPTION: It is a painting with an official, doctrinal message, based on the association of the three Johns.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: San Giovanni Crisostomo Altarpiece

DESCRIPTION: Chrysostom is sitting side on, not in compliance with any mannerist idiosyncrasy but simply to enable us to see and read the book of his golden Word.The altarpiece has at the centre an old man reading, oblivious of the saints around him.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: San Giovanni Crisostomo Altarpiece

DESCRIPTION: It is a tightly knit and crowded group, the slightly yearning figure of St John the Baptist on the right looking inwards is balanced by a trio of grandly assured, superb Venetian beauties looking forwards and outwards at the spectator.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: San Giovanni Crisostomo Altarpiece

DESCRIPTION: The figures are in an architectural setting.This altarpiece is the major work of Sebastiano executed in Venice before he removed to Rome permanently in 1511
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: San Giovanni Crisostomo Altarpiece

DESCRIPTION: Of the many painters who assimilated and vulgarised the contemplative, romantic manner of Giorgione, Sebastiano del Piombo was inspired by the monumental form and by the possibility of making it solemn with the use of colour.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Death of Adonis

DESCRIPTION: It is precisely in this contained plasticism that we find the result of the integration of the two pictorial cultures.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Death of Adonis

DESCRIPTION: This painting shows a still Giorgionesque atmosphere - the view of the lake and the sunset - in which three superb examples of sculptural nudity are inserted: a doleful Venus, and her attendant maidservants, who turn abruptly to silence a bearded Pan who is continuing to play his flute
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Death of Adonis

DESCRIPTION: In the Loggia di Galatea of the Villa Farnesina, Sebastiano del Piombo depicted the cyclops Polyphemus sitting on a charming, idyllic coastline with a dog, a flute, sand a shepherd's crook.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Polyphemus

DESCRIPTION: He is looking longingly at the sea, out to the right, where in the adjacent field of the wall Raphael depicted the voyage of the nereid Galatea.
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Polyphemus

DESCRIPTION: Sebastiano's Polyphemus is a Venetian painting of mood, rich in atmosphere, treated in an airy and loose style
AUTHOR: SEBASTIANO DEL PIOMBO
TITLE: Polyphemus

DESCRIPTION: This painting is the product of Seddon's second voyage to Egypt in the company of Holman Hunt, in 1854.
AUTHOR: SEDDON, Thomas III
TITLE: Pyramids of Gizeh, Sunset Afterglow

DESCRIPTION: It is a view of the great Pyramids of Gizeh from the east, with the peaks of the pyramids of Khufu and Khafre burnt by a glowing sunset
AUTHOR: SEDDON, Thomas III
TITLE: Pyramids of Gizeh, Sunset Afterglow

DESCRIPTION: In his years in Italy, Gerard Seghers conformed to the ideas of the 'Tenebrosi'.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: After his return to Antwerp he could take full advantage of the fashionable interest in Caravaggist painting, which had become an international phenomenon.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: He became celebrated for his monumental half-length genre scenes.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: But he was highly regarded in the 1620s for his large religious and allegorical pictures, conceived in a genre style, and mostly done in landscape format.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: These paintings, such as the Denial of St Peter, contain scenes with numerous characters, depicted with lively poses and facial expressions, grouped compactly together against an undefined background; they are painted half-length or are cut off by the edge of the painting.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: The concealed candlelight casts a flickering and sharply contrasting gleam on the multi-coloured, theatrical clothing of the figures creating a powerful dramatic effect.These Caravaggist group compositions differ only in subject from contemporary secular genre paintings and just like them are ultimately derived from the compositions of Caravaggio's pupil Bartolomeo Manfredi.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: There is also a strong relationship with the style of Gerrit van Honthorst of Utrecht, who must have known Seghers in Rome
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Gerard
TITLE: Denial of St Peter

DESCRIPTION: Hercules Seghers was a gifted contemporary of Rembrandt.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Hercules
TITLE: View of Rhenen

DESCRIPTION: His view of Rhenen demonstrates a low horizon and incipient drama that, along with Seghers's unique etching style, were very well known to Rembrandt.
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Hercules
TITLE: View of Rhenen

DESCRIPTION: Both artists' landscapes seem far more than just what meets the eye, becoming transcendental visions reflecting eternity and mutability alike
AUTHOR: SEGHERS, Hercules
TITLE: View of Rhenen

DESCRIPTION: Segna di Buonaventure worked in Siena and was a pupil of Duccio.
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Magdalen

DESCRIPTION: He had a large workshop with many pupils
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Magdalen

DESCRIPTION: This panel belonged to a now dismembered pentaptych (five-paneled altarpiece).
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Silvester Gozzolini
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on wood, gold ground, 125 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: In its original configuration, St Benedict was the left, St Silvester Gozzolini the right and the Madonna and Child the centre panels (all in the Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York).
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Silvester Gozzolini
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on wood, gold ground, 125 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The centre panel was flanked by panels depicting St John the Baptist (Perkins Collection, Sacro Convento di San Francesco, Assisi), and St John the Evangelist (Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York).When intact, the altarpiece would have resembled Duccio's polyptych in the Pinacoteca Nazionale, Siena (the so-called polyptych 47).
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Silvester Gozzolini
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on wood, gold ground, 125 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The pairing of Sts John the Baptist and John the Evangelist - the forerunner of Christ and the beloved disciple - to either side of the Madonna and Child is not uncommon and may relate either to the dedication of the chapel or to the name of the patron.
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Silvester Gozzolini
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on wood, gold ground, 125 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: On the other hand, the presence of Sts Benedict (c.
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Silvester Gozzolini
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on wood, gold ground, 125 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: 480–543) and Silvester Gozzolini (1177–1267) virtually assures that the altarpiece was painted for a monastery of the Silvestrine order, which was founded by Silvester in 1231 and followed the rule of St Benedict
AUTHOR: SEGNA DI BUONAVENTURE
TITLE: St Silvester Gozzolini
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on wood, gold ground, 125 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: This lively portrait - combining the styles of the Florentine mannerists and Titian - is one of the best in the oeuvre of the artist.
AUTHOR: SEISENEGGER, Jacob
TITLE: Portrait of Wilhelm Neythart

DESCRIPTION: The goblet in the hand of the sitter is presumably a royal gift
AUTHOR: SEISENEGGER, Jacob
TITLE: Portrait of Wilhelm Neythart

DESCRIPTION: The reliquiary on the St Sebastian Altar in the Padua cathedral had seven decorating panels four of them representing scenes from the life of the Saint.
AUTHOR: SEMITECOLO, Nicoletto
TITLE: St Sebastian Beaten with Sticks

DESCRIPTION: The panels are now in the sacristy of the canons of the cathedral of Padua.The picture shows one of the panels representing St Sebastian beaten with sticks
AUTHOR: SEMITECOLO, Nicoletto
TITLE: St Sebastian Beaten with Sticks

DESCRIPTION: This painting depicts a view of the Morro Castle and boom defence before the attack.
AUTHOR: SERRES, Dominic
TITLE: The Capture of Havana, Cuba, 1762

DESCRIPTION: It shows the Spanish preparations before the siege.
AUTHOR: SERRES, Dominic
TITLE: The Capture of Havana, Cuba, 1762

DESCRIPTION: The present painting is the small version of the composition.
AUTHOR: SEURAT, Georges
TITLE: The Models

DESCRIPTION: The large version (200 x 250 cm) is in the Barnes Foundation, Merion, Pennsylvania.
AUTHOR: SEURAT, Georges
TITLE: The Models

DESCRIPTION: The lean and altogether unerotic nudes are related to the completed Grand Jatte, which is partly to be seen on the studio wall
AUTHOR: SEURAT, Georges
TITLE: The Models

DESCRIPTION: The Grote Kerk in Weesp was originally a Catholic church consecrated to St Lawrence, in 1582 it became Protestant and its name was changed from Laurentiuskerk to Grote Kerk.For Dutch architectural painters the people in the church served as staffage to enliven the stone setting.
AUTHOR: SIBILLA, Gijsbert Jansz.
TITLE: Dutch Reformed Service in the Grote Kerk of Weesp

DESCRIPTION: This is different with Sibilla: for him the architecture is not central, but rather the depicted persons, who are very large in relation to the building.
AUTHOR: SIBILLA, Gijsbert Jansz.
TITLE: Dutch Reformed Service in the Grote Kerk of Weesp

DESCRIPTION: About seventy can be counted, a few of whom seem to be portraits.
AUTHOR: SIBILLA, Gijsbert Jansz.
TITLE: Dutch Reformed Service in the Grote Kerk of Weesp

DESCRIPTION: Certain elements, such as the dogs, bring a genre scene to mind.
AUTHOR: SIBILLA, Gijsbert Jansz.
TITLE: Dutch Reformed Service in the Grote Kerk of Weesp

DESCRIPTION: The combination of a church interior, group portrait, and genre scene is unique in Sibilla's oeuvre
AUTHOR: SIBILLA, Gijsbert Jansz.
TITLE: Dutch Reformed Service in the Grote Kerk of Weesp

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the wainscoting to the right of the entry.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Empedocles

DESCRIPTION: In the tondo a young man wearing turban, identified as Empedocles, a Greek philosopher (c.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Empedocles

DESCRIPTION: 490-430 BC), leans out of the window to watch the Apocalypse.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Empedocles

DESCRIPTION: On a small tablet set in among the grotesques, the painter's initials "LS" can be seen.If we look carefully at the anthropomorphic decorations, crowded with naked bodies in an incredible variety of poses, or the convulsive violence (that Scarpellini has compared to action painting) that runs through some of the foliage patterns or the groups of tritons and naiads like an electric current, we can really begin to understand Signorelli's great ability as a draughtsman, a talent that is further confirmed by his drawing production
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Empedocles

DESCRIPTION: The man lying on the ground and biting his hand in the badly damaged fragment on the altar walls thought to represent Cain.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Fresco fragment

DESCRIPTION: In fact, biting one's hand is a traditional symbol of envy, one of Cain's seven sins.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Fresco fragment

DESCRIPTION: In the medallion of the grotesque decor below, a murder scene with Triton-like creatures is depicted.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Fresco fragment

DESCRIPTION: Here the murder weapon is the jawbone of an ass, the one used by Cain in killing his brother Abel.This fresco fragment was discovered during a recent restoration
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Fresco fragment

DESCRIPTION: In the predella that Signorelli probably painted with the help of his assistant, Gerolamo Genga, four scenes from the Passion of Christ are represented: The Prayer in the Garden; The Last Supper; The Capture; The Flagellation.This picture shows the scene of the Flagellation
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: The Flagellation

DESCRIPTION: The individual apostles cannot be identified with the exception of Peter and John, who stand in the panel to the left of the Christ-Thomas grouping.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Pair of Apostles in Dispute

DESCRIPTION: The idea of presenting pairs of apostles in debate is borrowed from the bronze doors that Donatello created for the Old Sacristy at San Lorenzo, Florence.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Pair of Apostles in Dispute

DESCRIPTION: Signorelli borrowed not only some of the compositional features of Donatello's reliefs but also specific iconographic details.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Pair of Apostles in Dispute

DESCRIPTION: Like Donatello, he depicts his apostles barefoot and draped in classical garments, eschewing any identifying attributes and even halos
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Pair of Apostles in Dispute

DESCRIPTION: Very few portraits survive from Signorelli's hand.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: Indubitably his finest is the Portrait of an Elderly Man, probably of a humanist.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: It is often said to be of a jurist, that profession and humanism considered practically inseparable.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: Victories before a temple approach athletes in front of a triumphal arch, these all'antica themes pertinent to the sitter's scholarly calling or pretensions.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: The action taking place in the background may be on his mind, as suggested by his downcast eyes.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: The hard-won balance between hat, head, V-shaped scarf, and the far-smaller figures is among the major triumphs of his great portrait
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: Portrait of an Elderly Man

DESCRIPTION: In 1498 Luca Signorelli executed a great altarpiece for the Bichi Chapel in the church of Sant'Agostino, Siena.
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: St Augustine Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: Two wings, now in the Staatliche Museen, Berlin, flanked a statue of St Christopher ascribed to Francesco di Giorgio Martini (Musée du Louvre, Paris).
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: St Augustine Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: The predella is now divided between various museums.The left wing of the altarpiece represents Sts Catherine of Siena, Magdalen, and the kneeling St Jerome
AUTHOR: SIGNORELLI, Luca
TITLE: St Augustine Altarpiece (left wing)

DESCRIPTION: During a stay in Edinburgh in 1881, Signorini made several trips to Leith, where he collected impressions of this Scottish town that were later incorporated into this boldly cropped painting.
AUTHOR: SIGNORINI, Telemaco
TITLE: Leith

DESCRIPTION: The large advertisement sign for Rob Roy, a Robin Hood of Scotland and a character from a novel by Sir Walter Scott, was also intended as an allusion to Garibaldi, whose nickname was "Rob Roy of Italy.
AUTHOR: SIGNORINI, Telemaco
TITLE: Leith

DESCRIPTION: "The composition evokes certain elements of Degas's art
AUTHOR: SIGNORINI, Telemaco
TITLE: Leith

DESCRIPTION: After a few years of Duccio's Maestà, Simone painted his Maestà for the Palazzo Pubblico in Siena, as the ideal of the good and just government.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: This is the oldest painting that can be safely attributed to him.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: The end wall of the Sala del Mappamondo is entirely covered by this fresco.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: Surrounded by a frame decorated with twenty medallions depicting the Blessing Christ, the Prophets and the Evangelists and with smaller shields containing the coat-of-arms of Siena, the fresco shows a host of angels, Saints and Apostles, with the Madonna and Child in the centre.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: The whole scene, set against a deep blue background, is surmounted by an imposing canopy of red silk.The most obvious innovations present in Simone's style are his ideas of three-dimensional space.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: The supporting poles of the canopy are placed in perspective, thus giving a sense of depth to the composition.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: Under the canopy there is a crowd of thirty people: no more processions of people in parallel rows, but concrete spacial rhythms and animated gestures
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Maest? (Virgin with Child Enthroned between Saints and Angels)

DESCRIPTION: On the underside of the entrance arch of the Cappella di San Martino eight full-length saints are painted in four pairs.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: St Anthony of Padua and St Francis

DESCRIPTION: They are Saints Francis, Clare, and Anthony of Padua  - tributes to the Order that administered the Basilica - as well as other saints connected to Robert of Anjou: Louis of Toulouse, his older brother; Elizabeth of Hungary, the aunt of his mother, Mary; Louis IX, King of France, his great-grandfather; Mary Magdalene and Catherine of Alexandria, saints his father Charles II was particularly devoted to
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: St Anthony of Padua and St Francis

DESCRIPTION: The two Madonnas in the Siena Pinacoteca, one from Castiglione d'Orcia and the other from Lucignano d'Arbia, are clearly related and must date from more or less the same period.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Madonna and Child (from Castiglione d'Orcia)

DESCRIPTION: But we have no dates, no signatures and no documents containing any information at all regarding the dating of these works: stylistic analysis is the only element that critics have been able to use.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Madonna and Child (from Castiglione d'Orcia)

DESCRIPTION: This justifies the widely varying opinions that have been expressed on the subject: some scholars believe that they are totally autograph, while others think that Simone is responsible only for the drawings or for certain sections of the painting, while others still consider them entirely the work of the workshop assistants.Nonetheless, there are many analogies between the various paintings from this period, such as for example, the features of the Madonna in the San Domenico Polyptych, with her gentle and slightly dreaming eyes, repeated almost exactly in the Madonna in the Orvieto Polyptych; or the lively pose of the Child in the panel from Castiglione d'Orcia which is exactly the same as that of the Child in the Boston painting
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Madonna and Child (from Castiglione d'Orcia)

DESCRIPTION: A great deal has been written about the iconography of the Madonna from Lucignano d'Arbia, very unusual in Sienese painting.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Madonna and Child (from Lucignano d'Arbia)

DESCRIPTION: Mary is shown looking to the right, instead of to the left, and she holds a Child who is not yet a "puer" (as was the case in all the earlier paintings) but still an "infans" in swaddling clothes.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Madonna and Child (from Lucignano d'Arbia)

DESCRIPTION: The reason that led Simone to choose this iconography has yet to be explained, and it may have been a specific request from the client; but scholars do agree on the attribution of the panel to Simone
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Madonna and Child (from Lucignano d'Arbia)

DESCRIPTION: The fresco of Guidoriccio da Fogliano, depicting the conquest of the castles of Montemassi and Sassoforte in 1328, formed part of a fresco cycle "Castelli" which occupied the upper part of the wall opposite to the Maestà in the Sala del Mappamondo.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano

DESCRIPTION: The cycle, commemorating the castles conquered by the Sienese, was initiated in 1314 by the representation of the Castle of Giuncarico, it was continued by the Guidoriccio and in 1331 by the Castles of Arcidosso and Piano.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano

DESCRIPTION: The latter were destroyed in 1361 when Lippo Vanni painted the Battles of Valdichiana and Poggio Imperiale.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano

DESCRIPTION: In the 1970s, the famous fresco, which had always been, considered the greatest example of Martini's artistic excellence, was re-attributed to a much later artist.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano

DESCRIPTION: The controversy that followed this re-attribution, further stimulated by the discovery of a fresco below the Guidoriccio (a very beautiful one, and certainly much older as we can see from the overlapping of the intonaco), turned into an animated diatribe that has not yet been placated
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Equestrian Portrait of Guidoriccio da Fogliano

DESCRIPTION: The altarpiece known as Passion Polyptych (or Orsini Polyptych), with panels now in a number of European museums (Angel of the Annunciation and Virgin of Annunciation, as well as Crucifixion and Deposition in Antwerp, the Road to Calvary in Paris and the Entombment in Berlin) is signed "Pinxit Symon" on the two panels of the Crucifixion and the Deposition.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: It presents several problems, both in terms of stylistic analysis and dating.Some scholars, stressing the fact that it is so different stylistically from all the other works of Simone's Avignon period (nervous lines and expressions), think that it may have been painted earlier and then transported to France; others believe that it may be a late work, commissioned by Napoleone Orsini, who died in the Curia in Avignon in 1342.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: Orsini's coat-of-arms appears in the background of the Road to Calvary.
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: The polyptych was probably transferred to the charterhouse of Champmol, near Dijon, in the late 14th century
AUTHOR: SIMONE MARTINI
TITLE: Entombment

DESCRIPTION: Sisley went tirelessly in search of motifs along the Seine and its tributaries, he looked no further.
AUTHOR: SISLEY, Alfred
TITLE: Moret-sur-Loing in Morning Sun

DESCRIPTION: He abided by views of village streets, or of interesting groups of buildings, he would be drawn to an old stone bridge, the kind of subject that had fascinated painters since Corot.
AUTHOR: SISLEY, Alfred
TITLE: Moret-sur-Loing in Morning Sun

DESCRIPTION: In unprepossessing patches of gardens or meadows, landscapes on the skirts of towns or along river banks, he could often discover the most arresting colour or light effects
AUTHOR: SISLEY, Alfred
TITLE: Moret-sur-Loing in Morning Sun

DESCRIPTION: This small panel was probably made in the 1670s, when Slingeland executed most of his delicate, genre-like portraits.
AUTHOR: SLINGELAND, Pieter Cornelisz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady Holding a Rose

DESCRIPTION: It depicts in great detail a young woman standing in half-length and in three-quarter profile, with her head turned to the left, facing the viewer.
AUTHOR: SLINGELAND, Pieter Cornelisz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady Holding a Rose

DESCRIPTION: In her right hand the lady holds a single pink rosebud; her left arm rests gracefully on a stone balustrade.The painting is a betrothal or marriage portrait and in 1773 had a pendant, a portrait of a man with a statue of Mercury
AUTHOR: SLINGELAND, Pieter Cornelisz. van
TITLE: Portrait of a Lady Holding a Rose

DESCRIPTION: The painting depicts a wooded landscape with travellers and a horse-drawn wagon being ambushed by brigands and horsemen, a view of a church in the distance
AUTHOR: SNAYERS, Pieter
TITLE: A Wooded Landscape with Travellers

DESCRIPTION: Frans Snyders, Rockox's friend and neighbour and a witness to his last will and testament, was the leading still-life and animal painter of his time.
AUTHOR: SNYDERS, Frans
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: His fruitful career was linked in close symbiosis with the artistic world of Rubens, with whom he frequently collaborated.
AUTHOR: SNYDERS, Frans
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Both the paintings Snyders made alone and those he produced in collaboration with Rubens are so intimately bound up with Rubens' ideas and language of form that they have to be appreciated in this context.
AUTHOR: SNYDERS, Frans
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Just as in Rubens' work, Snyders assembles the elements of his paintings not only on the basis of their artistic characteristics, but also as elements with a part to play in the overall design and decorative effect of the canvas as a whole.
AUTHOR: SNYDERS, Frans
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: The luxuriant Still-Life is a representative example of Snyders' oeuvre
AUTHOR: SNYDERS, Frans
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: The painting is signed lower right: F. Snyders // Fecit 1614
AUTHOR: SNYDERS, Frans
TITLE: Still-Life with Dead Game, Fruits, and Vegetables in a Market

DESCRIPTION: This painting (presently on loan to the Brera from a private collection) can be considered one of the most refined of the panel paintings by Sodoma.The picture highlights the half-length figure of Christ, whose bound hands are crossed in front of his naked breast.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: Two figures emerges from the dark background: the man on the left seems to be a Roman soldier.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: The man on the right is of mature age, wearing a turban, and he seems to touch the shoulder of Christ from behind
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: Chigi's bedchamber was adjacent to the banquet hall, and he had Sodoma decorate two of its wall, probably in conjunction with the decoration of the hall.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: The surfaces of the walls open up onto a narrative with large-scale figures, as if inviting visitors to enter.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: In the painting on the wall to the right, the women of Darius's family approach the Macedonian ruler.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: Sisigambis, the mother of the defeated Persian ruler, initially mistook Hephaistion for Alexander, but the true ruler inclines graciously toward her.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: The painter revels in his depiction of female grace, pushing the female bodies close together before Alexander and the viewer.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: The forms on the left also repeat the triad of goddesses, Venus, Ceres, and Juno from Raphael's spandrel in the Loggia di Psiche.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: The smithy scene along the base of the wall alludes to the love themes and to the fireplace
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: The Women of Darius's Family before Alexander the Great

DESCRIPTION: In the Cappella di Santa Caterina of the Sienese church of San Domenico, Sodoma's mural paintings dominate the decoration.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: View of the Cappella di Santa Caterina

DESCRIPTION: The chapel was built in the late fifteenth century to house the relic of St Catherine's head in a marble tabernacle.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: View of the Cappella di Santa Caterina

DESCRIPTION: Sodoma transformed the space to appear as if it were an open loggia resting on piers.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: View of the Cappella di Santa Caterina

DESCRIPTION: The real altar is continued to the side as a painted balustrade, above which, in a wide opening on the left Catherine is seen fainting and, on the right, in ecstasy.Only the left-hand wall showing Catherine saving the soul of Niccolò di Tuldo was completed by Sodoma.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: View of the Cappella di Santa Caterina

DESCRIPTION: Here the artist uses particular means to bring us close to the scene: the lower balustrade is wide open; steps seem to lead out of the chapel to the site of the execution
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: View of the Cappella di Santa Caterina

DESCRIPTION: Scene 3 of the cycle on the life of St Benedict depicts Benedict repairing a broken colander through prayer.The painter made certain he would be forever associated with the cycle by including the prominent self-portrait in the scene of the colander miracle
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Life of St Benedict, Scene 3: Benedict Repairs a Broken Colander through Prayer

DESCRIPTION: Scene 33 of the cycle on the life of St Benedict depicts as Benedict gives posthumous absolution to two nuns, fleeing from their graves during Mass, whom he had threatened with excommunication.One notable scene of the cycle is devoted to the story of two haughty and talkative nuns whom Benedict had threatened with excommunication (Scene 33).
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Life of St Benedict, Scene 33: Benedict Gives Posthumous Absolution to Two Nuns

DESCRIPTION: Both died soon afterward, and during Mass their nurse saw how they rose up out of their graves and fled from the church.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Life of St Benedict, Scene 33: Benedict Gives Posthumous Absolution to Two Nuns

DESCRIPTION: Benedict promptly administered the host to the errant souls, thereby luring them back into the bosom of the community.The composition of this scene is clearly indebted to Pinturicchio's cycle in the Piccolomini Library in Siena.
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Life of St Benedict, Scene 33: Benedict Gives Posthumous Absolution to Two Nuns

DESCRIPTION: The shape of the interior and arrangement of the picture space are borrowed from the scene of Enea Silvio Piccolomini's coronation as Pius II, whereas the grouping of figures, especially that of the ones seen from the back in the foreground, recall the scene in which Piccolomini is elevated to the rank of cardinal
AUTHOR: SODOMA, Il
TITLE: Life of St Benedict, Scene 33: Benedict Gives Posthumous Absolution to Two Nuns

DESCRIPTION: This fresco is in the former chapter house adjacent to the Great Cloister

DESCRIPTION: The biblical source for the painting is Matthew 14:6-11 or Mark 6:21-8, where the daughter of Herodias danced for her stepfather, Herod, on his birthday.

AUTHOR: SOLARIO, Andrea

AUTHOR: SOLARIO, Andrea

DESCRIPTION: The painting is obviously replete with references to love and courtship.
AUTHOR: SORGH, Hendrick Maertensz.

DESCRIPTION: Playing musical instruments was long considered indispensable to fostering Eros and in this sense, Sorgh's foppish, lute player is entirely conventional.

DESCRIPTION: The scenes on the east wall are the following: St Benedict Departs the Monastery of Vicovaro (top left, scene 7 of the cycle), St Benedict Accepts Maurus and Placidus as Disciples (top right, scene 8), St Benedict's Prayer Enables the Monks to Lift the Stone on Which the Devil Is Sitting (bottom left, scene 12), St Benedict Recognizes the Sword Bearer Riggo Disguised as King Totila (bottom right, scene 14)

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows two scenes in the upper register of the east wall.

DESCRIPTION: Scene 7 (left) depicts when St Benedict departs the monastery of Vicovaro.
AUTHOR: SPINELLO ARETINO

AUTHOR: SPINELLO ARETINO
TITLE: Two scenes on the east wall

DESCRIPTION: More and more followers gather around Benedict and he is soon able to establish twelve monasteries, but also to keep disciples with him for better instruction in the spiritual life.

TITLE: Two scenes on the east wall

DESCRIPTION: Maurus and Placidus are two such disciples, both of whom come from distinguished Roman families

TITLE: Two scenes on the east wall

DESCRIPTION: In the right background a satyr hands a piece of fruit to a nymph, while on the right two satyrs and two nymphs return from the hunt.

AUTHOR: STEEN, Jan
TITLE: Twin Birth Celebration

DESCRIPTION: Steen's old man must be impotent — since common wisdom held that the aged were infertile — and therefore completely incapable of having sired one infant, let alone two.
AUTHOR: STEEN, Jan
TITLE: Twin Birth Celebration

DESCRIPTION: A younger, virile man must have fathered them as the old fool, much to his consternation, has suddenly realized
AUTHOR: STEEN, Jan
TITLE: Twin Birth Celebration

DESCRIPTION: The mythological story of the contest between the goddess Athena (Minerva to the Romans) and the mortal woman Arachne was perhaps told best by the Roman poet Ovid in his Metamorphoses (Book VI).
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: Arachne
TECHNIQUE: Oil on cedar panel, 57 x 45 cm

DESCRIPTION: According to Ovid, Arachne lived in the country of Lydia (which had a legendary reputation for producing some of the most splendid textiles in the ancient world), where she matured into one of the finest weavers ever known.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: Arachne
TECHNIQUE: Oil on cedar panel, 57 x 45 cm

DESCRIPTION: Arachne was in fact so adept at weaving that she became arrogant, and claimed that her ability rivaled that of the goddess Athena.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: Arachne
TECHNIQUE: Oil on cedar panel, 57 x 45 cm

DESCRIPTION: A contest was arranged, and having been bested by the mortal Arachne, the infuriated goddess cursed the girl, turning her into a spider in punishment for her effrontery.Strozzi's depiction of Arachne is part of a group of bust length depictions of female allegorical and historical figures and of saints that he began to create early on, perhaps in response to the visit to Genoa of Simon Vouet in 1620-22.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: Arachne
TECHNIQUE: Oil on cedar panel, 57 x 45 cm

DESCRIPTION: Whatever their inspiration, Strozzi produced these beautiful "portraits" throughout his career, adapting his depictions to the theme at hand - refined and ethereal for his saints; sensual and seductive for his profane subjects
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: Arachne
TECHNIQUE: Oil on cedar panel, 57 x 45 cm

AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo

AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo

AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo

DESCRIPTION: Gathered around Tobit are the key figures of the Old Testament account of his life: his wife, Anna, their son Tobias, the loyal dog that accompanied Tobias and the angel on their dangerous journey, and the fish that nearly killed Tobias before he caught it and removed its organs to make a medicine to restore his father's eyesight.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: The Healing of Tobit

DESCRIPTION: For Strozzi the main means of expression is colour, so bright and rich compared to his other paintings that it seems an eloquent metaphor for the end to the old man's blindness.This painting, a biblical story depicted as a genre scene, is one of the several versions of this subject painted by Bernardo Strozzi
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: The Healing of Tobit

DESCRIPTION: St Maurice is a legendary warrior saint, the commander of the 'Theban Legion', Roman troops from Thebes in Egypt, who served at Agaunum in Gaul (St-Maurice en Valais) in the 3rd century.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: St Maurice and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: He is dressed in medieval armour.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: St Maurice and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: The story, whose authenticity is debated, relates that the soldiers, at the instigation of Maurice, refused to participate in certain pagan rites.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: St Maurice and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: They were punished by the Emperor Maximian Herculeus first by decimation and finally by the wholesale massacre of the legion.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: St Maurice and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: Maurice and his fellow officers were executed in A.D.
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: St Maurice and the Angel

DESCRIPTION: 287.According to another interpretation, the warrior saint is identified as St Secundus
AUTHOR: STROZZI, Bernardo
TITLE: St Maurice and the Angel

AUTHOR: SUBLEYRAS, Pierre

DESCRIPTION: Inspired by the monumentality and realism of Veronese's religious paintings, and faithful to the canons of accessibility advocated by Poussin, with his sombre, intense palette, Subleyras succeeded in combining grandeur and familiarity in representing the episode
AUTHOR: SUBLEYRAS, Pierre

DESCRIPTION: In Greek mythology Silenus is a rural god, one of the retinue of Bacchus, a gay, fat old drunkard who was yet wise and had the gift of prophecy.Swart's secure oeuvre is limited to woodcuts and stained glass, and so although a number of panel paintings have been attributed to him on stylistic grounds, the authorship of these are at this time uncertain.
AUTHOR: SWART VAN GRONINGEN, Jan

DESCRIPTION: However, The Triumph of Silenus certainly seems to be stylistically consistent with this tentative oeuvre.

DESCRIPTION: Bertalan Székely was the most fastidious master of the style known as historicism.
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second

DESCRIPTION: He harboured the idea of painting The Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second already during the years he spent in Transylvania following his studies in Vienna.
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second

DESCRIPTION: After having clarified the role of each element of the composition, he painted the great work in 1860 in Munich, where he was studying under Piloty.
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second

DESCRIPTION: Working out the structure and the accent of colours in detail was of prime importance for Székely.The last Hungarian king from the Jagello Dynasty, the young Louis II (1516-1526), was slain in the Battle of Mohács.
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second

DESCRIPTION: His passing symbolizes the death of the nation and the beginning of the Turkish suzerainty which lasted 150 years.
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second

DESCRIPTION: The gestures of respect for the dead as well as the white shroud, which contrast dramatically with the sombre atmosphere, work in unison to focus our attention on the tragic figure of the Hungarian king
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Discovery of the Body of King Louis the Second

DESCRIPTION: This romantic picture is one of the most lyrical genre pictures in Hungarian painting
AUTHOR: SZÉKELY, Bertalan
TITLE: Boating Lovers

DESCRIPTION: The artist never accepted commissions to paint portraits; all the portraits he painted featured members of his family.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: These representations, each of which is a pearl of intimate Realism, reach the soul of the model.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: Szinyei began to paint portraits of this wife on several occasions, but he was not always able to finish them, because his wife, in sharp contrast with Szinyei's contemplating character, was ever so busy that she had difficulty tolerating the modelling sessions.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: She set both for the famous "Woman in Lilac Dress" (1874) and for the "Portrait in Shawl".
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: The latter portrait was not finished in 1880: the deep scarlet coloured velvet dress his wife is shown wearing was completed only around 1890, long after the couple's divorce in 1887.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: (In actual fact Szinyei's daughter was sitting as model.)
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: The painting is dominated by the delicate and sensitive beauty of the model's face, radiating from the background of warm colours.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: In Szinye's pictures, the women are often shown wearing in their hair or on their hats colourful flowers, or as in the case of "Portrait in Shawl", laces and ribbons.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: We can almost be certain that he did not use them just to conform with the fashion of the age.
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

DESCRIPTION: These colourful patches were necessary to emphasize the beauty of the face and the fine rosiness of the skin, as well as to produce a definite separation from the dark background
AUTHOR: SZINYEI MERSE, Pál
TITLE: Portrait of the Artist's Wife

AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: The governors who commissioned the work were men of considerable stature, too.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: They were entrusted by the city fathers with the day-to-day management of one of Leiden's nine textile sectors, known in Dutch as 'neringen'.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: In this capacity they were responsible for the manufacture of and trade in worsted, a sector that was booming at the time.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: Their seat of office was the brand-new building which has been known to this day as the Lakenhal.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: They wanted classicist decorations worthy of their modern building.Regarding the series, Minerva Crowns the Maid of Leiden originally served as the overmantel, while the other two, Mars Banishes 'Nering' and The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering' hung on the long wall beside one another.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: The latter two paintings form pendants, being the same size and related in subject-matter.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: The theme that connects them is 'nering', the term formerly used in Leiden for the production of and trade in textile.Whereas the Mars Banishes 'Nering' illustrates the misfortune caused by war, the painting The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering' embodies the antithesis, where freedom, justice and peace foster trade and industry.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: Here Minerva and Mercury return as witnesses of the principal scene in which the Maid of Leiden stands on a step in her purple gown and crimson mantel and extends a hand to Nering, while Liberty, with her broken weapons and the hat symbolising freedom, kneels at her feet.
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: Under her arm Nering clutches a bound volume containing the statutes establishing the worsted nering in 1638
AUTHOR: TEMPEL, Abraham van den
TITLE: The Maid of Leiden Welcomes 'Nering'

DESCRIPTION: This painting renowned work in the eighteenth century, partly due to its dissemination through engravings.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: A Cobbler in his Workshop

DESCRIPTION: It was the source of inspiration for a number of French artists, perhaps most notably Jean-Siméon Chardin.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: A Cobbler in his Workshop

DESCRIPTION: There is a direct connection between the present painting and one of Chardin's work in the Louvre, The Canary, which shows a woman teaching her canary to sing.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: A Cobbler in his Workshop

DESCRIPTION: The two works not only share thematic similarities, but also compositional ones.The painting is signed and dated lower right, on the work bench: 'D: TENIERS · FEC A 1671'
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: A Cobbler in his Workshop

DESCRIPTION: The huge collection owned by Archduke Leopold Wilhelm of Austria (1614-1662), Governor of the Spanish Netherlands from 1646 to 1656, was dominated by 16th-century Italian painting but contained a fair proportion of contemporary Flemish works by Van Dyck, Rubens, and others.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Art Collection of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels

DESCRIPTION: When he stepped down as governor, he took his collection back to Austria where it is now the nucleus of the collections of paintings in the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Art Collection of Archduke Leopold Wilhelm in Brussels

DESCRIPTION: The painting shows an interior with an old man with a pipe and a flagon seated at a table, other figures smoking by a fireplace beyond.This painting is known in several old copies, some perhaps produced in Teniers' own studio.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Old Man with a Pipe
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 33 cm

DESCRIPTION: The present work is now known to be the signed original - the large number of replicas testament to both its immediate and enduring popularity as a quiet but powerful image
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Old Man with a Pipe
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 36 x 33 cm

DESCRIPTION: In a large, open, barn-like structure, which serves as a guardroom, groups of monkeys wearing soldiers' uniforms are grouped around tables playing cards and back-gammon.Pictures of monkeys had been popular from the sixteenth-century and it was Teniers who developed the theme in the seventeenth-century.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Guardroom with Monkeys

DESCRIPTION: The primary role of the monkey in visual and literary sources of the sixteenth-century was to represent the irrational and foolish side of man's nature, but monkeys also were symbols of sinfulness and seen as devils
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Guardroom with Monkeys

DESCRIPTION: Depictions of the 'kermis' or rural fair belong to an iconographic and compositional tradition founded in the Netherlands in about 1550 by Pieter Brueghel the Elder.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: So when David Teniers painted his first country fair in i637, his native town of Antwerp could already look back on an almost century-long tradition in this genre.The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn shown here demonstrates how Teniers had grown away from Adriaen Brouwer and developed his own style, distinguished primarily by a lighter overall tone and warmer, more radiant colours.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: The scale of his figures is somewhat reduced in his village scenes, so that they fit more convincingly into his broad, expansive landscapes with their subtly shaded atmospheres.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: The festivities are being held here in a square, bounded on two sides by a wooden fence, in front of a village tavern similar to that in many other Flemish kermis paintings.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: A path leads off to the left in the direction of Antwerp Cathedral, which gives the rural festivities a local and municipal frame of reference.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: The sky, with its vivid stretches of cloud and the gold-tinged light of the evening on the left, is given a special weight, which lends the scene a cool, airy atmosphere and a festive mood.The joyful, lively antics of the farmers are not based on Teniers's own observations, but are pieced together from the handed-down repertoire of motifs for this genre, which were constantly varied and modified.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: They include the musicians standing on their podium, the three couples doing a round dance in the foreground, the drunk who is being helped home by two farmers, and the man who is leaning by the fence in an attack of nausea.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: At the end of the canvas on the right edge we also see the motif of the 'unequal couple': Teniers had already used lecherous old farmers hugging young girls as a single motif for a painting
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Kermis at the Half Moon Inn

DESCRIPTION: The depiction of village festivals was one of Teniers' most popular subjects.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Country Kermis

DESCRIPTION: A large group of standing figures provides an opportunity to deploy a range of poses, gestures and relationships
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Country Kermis

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows a countryside inn with revellers enjoying an afternoon's drinking, the innkeeper chopping wood in the foreground, and a pastoral landscape beyond.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Countryside Inn with Revellers

DESCRIPTION: Teniers delighted in the portrayal of peasant revelry for the scope of characterisation and gesture that it afforded him.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Countryside Inn with Revellers

DESCRIPTION: Drink is always present in his peasant scenes, and usually the cause of the subject at hand.It is noteworthy that the figures in the present image are larger than usual.The painting, which formerly belonged to the Hermitage in St.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Countryside Inn with Revellers

DESCRIPTION: Petersburg, is signed and dated on a rock lower centre left: D.TENIERS.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Countryside Inn with Revellers

DESCRIPTION: This is one of the many versions of this subject painted by Teniers.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Temptation of St Anthony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 22 x 16 cm

DESCRIPTION: St Anthony in his blue habit, crouched over a low table, book in hand, the temptress hag behind and a surrounding array of astonishing and unnatural creatures, such as the hideous ecorché dog, barking at the saint in the foreground
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: The Temptation of St Anthony
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 22 x 16 cm

DESCRIPTION: The Witches' Initiation was a popular subject in the circles of the Saftleven brothers in Rotterdam.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Witches' Initiation

DESCRIPTION: In Teniers's version the witching is taking place in the distant background, where a young, naked witch with a broomstick between her legs is being anointed before she flies off through the gaping hearth.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Witches' Initiation

DESCRIPTION: In the foreground two ladies are studying books in a civilised fashion.
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Witches' Initiation

DESCRIPTION: The assemblage of objects at right retains the character of a still-life
AUTHOR: TENIERS, David the Younger
TITLE: Witches' Initiation

DESCRIPTION: This painting having the popular title of Parental Admonition (another version in the Staatliche Museen, Berlin) was the subject of a charming passage by Goethe.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: In his "Die Wahlverwandtschaften" Goethe notes the delicacy of attitude of the figures.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: He remarks how the father quietly and moderately admonishes his daughter who is seen from behind.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: The woman in black, sipping from a glass, Goethe interprets as the young woman's mother, who lowers her eyes so as not to be too attentive to the 'father's admonition'.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: This moralizing title, however, is without foundation and not in accordance with Ter Borch's usual themes.The authoritative biographer of the artist interprets the picture in the opposite sense, as a brothel scene, assuming that the seated gentleman holds a coin in his right hand, offering it to the girl.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: In fact, the detail of the coin is not visible.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: (The coin is omitted in the engraving Goethe knew).
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: In the Berlin version the passage is rubbed; a former owner may have had it painted over because she or he found it an embarrassing allusion.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: The Amsterdam version does not show the coin either, but its original paint surface is generally abraded; thus it is impossible to tell if it ever included the tell-tale coin.Ter Borch's psychology is so delicate that the  common scenes he repeatedly painted are raised to the level of highly civilized life.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: That Goethe's interpretation was possible at all shows the refinement of Ter Borch's treatment.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: Even if he made a mistake, Goethe had the right feeling for the way Ter Borch treated his subjects.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: Psychologically and pictorially he retains a sensitive touch and delicacy.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: The young woman is seen from behind; thus her face is averted.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: The only flesh visible is her neck, which is modelled with tender, silvery grey shadows.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: We have, however, opportunity to admire the silver-grey satin and black velvet of her gown.Ter Borch's minuteness and nicety of handling concentrate largely on painting stuffs.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: Contrary to Vermeer's paintings, the dim light and the subdued chiaroscuro do not allow a forceful grasp of the whole field of vision.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: The light comes mostly from the front and stops at the glossy surfaces of the costumes and other textures
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: Paternal Admonition (Gallant Conversation)

DESCRIPTION: An officer set against a dark undefined background, stands on the left, looking down on a young man opposite him, who is seated with his legs apart at a simple low table writing a letter, and leaning forward in deep concentration.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: An Officer Writing a Letter
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 28 cm

DESCRIPTION: In Dutch seventeenth-century art it was usually the women who were represented in the act of writing letters, associated with love and courtship.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: An Officer Writing a Letter
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 28 cm

DESCRIPTION: Terborch depictions of officers writing or receiving letters is without precedent.
AUTHOR: TERBORCH, Gerard
TITLE: An Officer Writing a Letter
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 28 cm

DESCRIPTION: Earlier scenes with officers and soldiers were set in guardrooms.

DESCRIPTION: Dirck Hals, Jan Miense Molenaer, Willem Duyster and Pieter Codde focused on the disruptive characters of soldiers as they drank, gambled, quarrelled and assaulted civilians

DESCRIPTION: Later in 1629 Terbruggen painted another, larger version of this subject.

DESCRIPTION: The last version is in the Centraal Museum at Utrecht.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: The Calling of St Matthew

DESCRIPTION: In addition to the paintings by Caravaggio, Terbrugghen was also inspired by Northern imagery from the sixteenth century and by the subject matter and figure style of his contemporary, Dirck van Baburen.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass

DESCRIPTION: The two artists probably shared a studio in Utrecht, and around 1620 both artists produced series of genre scenes with single figures - musicians, singers, smokers and drinkers.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass

DESCRIPTION: These genre scenes were often produced in pairs.Terbrugghen's figures have often been interpreted as allegories of the Five Senses.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass

DESCRIPTION: The present painting has been seen as interpreting Taste.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass

DESCRIPTION: It was only partly executed by Terbrugghen, the painting was completed by another, inferior hand in his workshop
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Girl Holding a Tankard and a Glass

DESCRIPTION: This painting, which was altered by the artist and later cropped at the corners, depicts an almost claustrophobic interior, featuring a bare-chested prostitute clutching the fur garment of a man wearing a mask and pince-nez, both of which make him appear much older than he actually is.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Unequal Couple

DESCRIPTION: This churlish whore smiles at us knowingly, uncouthly exposing her discoloured teeth in the process
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Unequal Couple

DESCRIPTION: On returning from his sojourn in Italy, Terbrugghen developed in Utrecht a light, colourful Caravaggism inclined to musical and gallant themes.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick
TITLE: Woman Playing the Lute

DESCRIPTION: The fanciful garb of the figures, framed in half-length, recalls the theatrical world.
AUTHOR: TERBRUGGHEN, Hendrick

DESCRIPTION: Through Cassiano dal Pozzo, secretary of Cardinal Francesco Barberini and the patron of Nicolas Poussin, Testa gained access in Rome to the circle around Poussin.

AUTHOR: TESTA, Pietro

DESCRIPTION: He painted the Venus and Adonis in this style

DESCRIPTION: In the second half of the 17th century all of Europe admired - though no one really imitated - France's various academies: art (established in 1648), science (1666) and architecture (1671).
AUTHOR: TESTELIN, Henri
TITLE: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667

DESCRIPTION: These academies were not only repositories of knowledge, they also backed extensive operations such as factories (tapestries, mirrors)and specialized workshops directed by superintendents and their agents.
AUTHOR: TESTELIN, Henri
TITLE: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667

DESCRIPTION: Never had artistic life been organized so thoroughly, so precisely, so extensively.
AUTHOR: TESTELIN, Henri
TITLE: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667

DESCRIPTION: This was the work of Colbert and his circle
AUTHOR: TESTELIN, Henri
TITLE: Colbert Presenting the Members of the Royal Academy of Sciences to Louis XIV in 1667

DESCRIPTION: Our gaze roams from the vineyards on the slopes of Loessnitz into the far distance, where the city of Dresden appears as a silhouette, the tower of the Hofkirche still incomplete.
AUTHOR: THIELE, Johann Alexander
TITLE: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights

DESCRIPTION: The striking outlines of Alpsandsteingebirge can be seen on the horizon, with the fortress of Königstein standing out most noticeably.Thiele is at the peak of his abilities in this painting: the landscape swings rhythmically with the river and the chains of hills, until the contours all dissolve in the background.
AUTHOR: THIELE, Johann Alexander
TITLE: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights

DESCRIPTION: A feeling of distance is produced by the dark brown passages at the front.
AUTHOR: THIELE, Johann Alexander
TITLE: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights

DESCRIPTION: Late seventeenth-century landscapes, such as those of Pieter Gysels, perhaps, may have stimulated this view

TITLE: View of Dresden from the Loessnitz Heights

DESCRIPTION: The sinking of the ship appears in the background.

DESCRIPTION: He is rescued on the isle of Calypso.
AUTHOR: TIBALDI, Pellegrino

DESCRIPTION: When he left Calypso on a raft of his own making, he once again encountered Neptune's storm.

DESCRIPTION: The sea nymph Ino Leucothea gave him her veil, which carried the hero safely through the waves.Ino was a mortal queen of Thebes, who after her death and transfiguration was worshiped as a goddess under her epithet Leucothea, the "white goddess.

DESCRIPTION: The young Pellegrino Tibaldi, who was one of Daniele da Volterra's assistants in Rome, executed two murals in the newly constructed chapel of Cardinal Giovanni Poggi in San Giacomo, Bologna.
AUTHOR: TIBALDI, Pellegrino
TITLE: The Sermon of John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The chapel, which is dedicated to John the Baptist, has an elaborate system of architectonic articulation.
AUTHOR: TIBALDI, Pellegrino
TITLE: The Sermon of John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: Tibaldi's frescoes (The Sermon of John the Baptist; Annunciation of the Birth of John the Baptist) are restricted to one large field each on the left and right walls.
AUTHOR: TIBALDI, Pellegrino
TITLE: The Sermon of John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes are distinguished by unconventional iconography, learned allegory, and newly invented moments in history, that are at the same time commented on by painted manifestations in the heavens.In the left-hand mural John is baptizing and preaching repentance, while angels in heaven are putting devils into chains
AUTHOR: TIBALDI, Pellegrino
TITLE: The Sermon of John the Baptist

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes decorating the main hall of the villa in Massanzago in the Province of Padua were attributed until the 1980s to various eighteenth-century painters, such as Jacopo Guarana, Giovanni Battista Crosato or Giambattista Pittoni.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: However, it turned out that the frescoes are the early works by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: Obvious stylistic and iconographic similarities between these frescoes and other early Tiepolo works were pointed out.The work at the Villa Baglioni began immediately after the wealthy Venetian publisher Giambattista Baglioni acquired in 1718 the seventeenth-century villa in Massanzago.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes cover the entire wall surface of the main hall, illusionistically breaking through the walls and creating a boundless space, thanks to the faux architectural structure conceived by Girolamo Mengozzi Colonna, who henceforth would be Tiepolo's most frequent collaborator, working on almost all of his large-scale decorative projects in Venice and the Veneto.The theme of the frescoes is the Myth of Phaethon, based on Ovid's Metamorphoses.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The principal episode, Phaethon Asking His Father to Let Him Drive the Chariot of Sun, is staged on the east wall.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The opposite wall is divided into two parts by the doors that lead into the hall from the monumental staircase.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The right portion of the wall contains the Fall of Phaethon, the left part shows the Heliads, sisters of Phaethon.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes on the short walls depict monochrome figures of the Four Regions of the World.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The ceiling, which opens up to a faux sky, contains a depiction of The Triumph of Aurora
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the main hall

DESCRIPTION: The fresco is the largest version of this subject in European art, and it combines two different iconographic traditions: in the upper part of the picture, the Rosenkranzbild, in which Mary gives the Rosary to mankind, and, in the lower part, a depiction of the beneficence of the Rosary on earth, represented by St Dominic.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Institution of the Rosary

DESCRIPTION: As well as the Madonna of the Rosary, the fresco also extols St Dominic, the founder of the Dominican order, to whom the dog is a reference (lat.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Institution of the Rosary

DESCRIPTION: domini canes, God's hounds).
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Institution of the Rosary

DESCRIPTION: All manner of people are portrayed - represented among others by the Doge, a Turk, a nun, and a mother and child, a symbol of Christian charity - so that the viewer, whether rich or poor, could identify with them
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Institution of the Rosary

AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista

DESCRIPTION: However, the historical event of the meeting between the Queen of Egypt and the Roman Anthony takes second place to the creation of an opulent banqueting scene in the manner of Veronese.

AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
