TITLE: The Marriage of the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa to Beatrice of Burgundy

DESCRIPTION: The court jester, seen from behind, occupies a prominent position in the foreground at the foot of the steps to the altar, an example of Tiepolo's penchant for introducing witty and frivolous ideas to the agreed pictorial subject matter.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Marriage of the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa to Beatrice of Burgundy

DESCRIPTION: The steps to the altar lead us into the picture and, along with the colossal background architecture, create great spatial depth.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Marriage of the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa to Beatrice of Burgundy

DESCRIPTION: The musicians on the balcony in the background are a favourite motif of Tiepolo, which he uses to help make the historical subject matter topical
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Marriage of the Emperor Frederick Barbarossa to Beatrice of Burgundy

DESCRIPTION: The third room on the ground floor of the Palazzina was painted by Giovanni Battista Tiepolo with scenes after Virgil's Aeneid, depicting the legend of Aeneas.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the room of Virgil

DESCRIPTION: The scenes in this room are Mercury Appearing to Aeneas, Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido (scenes shown in the present photo), Venus Appearing to Aeneas on the Shores of Carthage, and Aeneas Encounters His Mother, Venus, in the Form of a Huntress
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the room of Virgil

DESCRIPTION: Queen Dido of Carthage has welcomed Aeneas.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido

DESCRIPTION: By way of thanks, the latter has his son Ascanius brought from the ship with gifts for the hostess.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido

DESCRIPTION: Venus swaps him for Amor underway, which leads to Aeneas and Dido falling in love.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido

DESCRIPTION: The subject matter of the fresco is the presentation of Aeneas' son, but the wings and the quiver of arrows point to the true identity of the god of Love.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido

DESCRIPTION: On the left, Dido, in splendid robes, sits enthroned underneath a kind of baldachin.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido

DESCRIPTION: The scene is furnished with an architectural backdrop typical of Tiepolo.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Aeneas Introducing Cupid Dressed as Ascanius to Dido

DESCRIPTION: Giambattista chose to decorate only one of the rooms in the foresteria at the Villa Valmarana.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Apollo and Diana

DESCRIPTION: In the so-called Olympus Room he frescoed Mars, Venus and Amor; Mercury; Time; Jupiter; and Apollo and Diana.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Apollo and Diana

DESCRIPTION: This last fresco shows the two deities sitting on a cloud.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Apollo and Diana

DESCRIPTION: Apollo, who faces the viewer, holds his lyre in his right hand and his quiver of arrows in his left, while Diana, partly concealed and with her back to the viewer, reclines to his right.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Apollo and Diana

DESCRIPTION: Apollo's golden yellow robe and the yellowish colour of the clouds are meant to allude to his office as Sun God
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: Apollo and Diana

DESCRIPTION: The lower half of the oval ceiling fresco displays the personification of the Spanish Monarchy, enthroned among the clouds and crowned by Mercury.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Apotheosis of the Spanish Monarchy

DESCRIPTION: To the right above her, Apollo stands in front of his sun-chariot, while in the upper half of the picture we see Jupiter on his throne, Fame with trumpets, as well as putti and other divinities.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Apotheosis of the Spanish Monarchy

DESCRIPTION: Below the Spanish monarchy, the personification of Ancient Castilia, the most important Spanish province, appears with a tower, below that are Venus and Mars, while the meeting of the Continents Europe and Africa at Spanish Gibraltar is symbolized at the bottom left by tHe pillars of Hercules
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: The Apotheosis of the Spanish Monarchy

DESCRIPTION: This is an extremely interesting early piece which borrows its compositional layout from scenes painted by his father.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Minuet

DESCRIPTION: The difference is that Giandomenico chose not to paint mythological or allegorical scenes.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Minuet

DESCRIPTION: The minuet is being danced by people wearing traditional masks and having a good time.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Minuet

DESCRIPTION: Its proper classification is therefore a genre painting.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Minuet

DESCRIPTION: It was works like this that made such a deep impression on the young Goya
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Minuet

DESCRIPTION: Giovanni Domenico Tiepolo decorated with frescoes the family villa at Zianigo which his father, Giovanni Baptista Tiepolo had bought on his return from the task of decorating the Prince-Bishop's palace in Würzburg and which he had restored and altered to his own needs.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: View of the Pulcinella Room

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes were painted over a fairly long period of time: between 1759 - the date shown on one of the monochrome scenes from the chapel - and 1797 - according to a now lost inscription read at the beginning of the twentieth century in a mural scene in the Pulcinella Room.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: View of the Pulcinella Room

DESCRIPTION: Almost all the frescoes in the small Zianigo villa were detached in 1906 and in 1936 they were moved to the Ca' Rezzonico and placed in small rooms, in a recomposition that closely repeats the original one, though with some differences and overlapping.The frescoes in the villa depict the stories of Pulcinella (also Punchinello, a classical character that originated in the Commedia dell'arte of the 17th century), scenes of villa life, games, the wars and affections of satyrs and fauns.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: View of the Pulcinella Room

DESCRIPTION: It is a comprehensive cycle which Giovanni Domenico painted for himself in successive stages in the non-monumental rooms of the country house.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: View of the Pulcinella Room

DESCRIPTION: When completed, the whole Zianigo work was a kind of grand recapitulation of many aspects and idiosyncrasies of Giovanni Domenico's art, while also representing the cultural passing of a period and a style.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: View of the Pulcinella Room

DESCRIPTION: It is almost a pictorial testament which, while valuing the past, did not conceal the drama of the present nor the uncertainty of the future
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: View of the Pulcinella Room

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows one of the two oblong monochrome scenes above the doors in the Pulcinella Room.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Cavalcade of the Pulcinellas

DESCRIPTION: It is traditionally entitled Cavalcade of the Pulcinellas and has been interpreted as a parody of the Napoleonic epic.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Cavalcade of the Pulcinellas

DESCRIPTION: An army of Pulcinellas parades by, preceded by banners, the commander , obviously intoxicated, mounts a donkey
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Cavalcade of the Pulcinellas

DESCRIPTION: This scene is on the wall of the room with Rustic Scenes in the Foresteria of the Villa Valmarana.Within curious frames interwoven with rings that were painted in advance by Girolamo Mengozzi Colonna, and almost seem to open up the walls of the space to the surrounding countryside, Tiepolo painted some of his most compelling works.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Peasants at Rest

DESCRIPTION: One is the Peasants at Rest in which the characters gather during the hot hours of the day to converse in the shade of a large tree near their house, having momentarily abandoned their wearying labour in the fields
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Peasants at Rest

DESCRIPTION: This scene is on the wall of the room with Rustic Scenes in the Foresteria of the Villa Valmarana.Farmhands like those represented played a major part in creating the wealth of Renaissance Venice, but they rarely appeared in painting of that period.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Family Meal

DESCRIPTION: The artist's unusual portrayal of them illustrates the wide focus of 18th-century culture
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Family Meal

DESCRIPTION: This scene is on the wall of the Camera Cinese, the last room in the suite in the Foresteria of the Villa Valmarana.The picture shows one of the allegoric scenes painted by Giandomenico in the Villa Valmarana.
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Offering of Fruits to Moon Goddess

DESCRIPTION: This scene is on the wall of the Camera Cinese, the last room in the suite in the Foresteria of the Villa Valmarana
AUTHOR: TIEPOLO, Giovanni Domenico
TITLE: Exotic Figures

DESCRIPTION: The painting, originally  in the church of Santa Croce in Milan, represents Sts Helen, Barbara, Andrew and Macario, another saint and the donor
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Sts Helen and Barbara Adoring the Cross

DESCRIPTION: One of the major achievements of Tintoretto's early works is the series of canvases painted in about 1550 for the Sala dell'Albergo of the Scuola della Santissima Trinitá.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: And of these the Creation of the animals is certainly unique for the swirling rhythm of the composition.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: In a blaze of golden light, which does not entirely escape the darkness still partly enveloping the newly created earth God the Father is portrayed as if suspended in mid-air in the act of creation.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: The animals rush forward from behind him while the birds shoot across the sky and the fishes dart through the water like arrows from his hand.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: The dramatic wind-swept scene is furrowed by the profiles of the animals which cross the canvas in running lines, conveying with extraordinary concision and expressiveness the theme of the work.Like Pietro Aretino's novel on the subject of Genesis, Tintoretto's painting shows the unicorn (right).
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: The alleged curative and decontaminating qualities of the narwhal tusk, an essential item in every Renaissance cabinet of curiosities, were regarded as proof of the existence of this fabulous creature.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: Exotic creatures like the ostrich walking on the shore were much admired as gifts from guests to the princely courts of northern Italy, and were portrayed in drawings or engravings.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: As a true Venetian, however, Tintoretto here devotes particular artistic skill to the fishes, including sturgeon, salmon and red mullet.Tintoretto's model for this composition was Titian's Bacchus and Ariadne (National Gallery, London); he adopted the flying divine figure as well as the setting.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Creation of the Animals

DESCRIPTION: This version of the subject was executed by the workshop of Tintoretto
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: Christ and the Adulteress

DESCRIPTION: St George and the Dragon is a small, even miniature, painting in the context of Tintoretto's work, detailed and highly finished.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: It was probably commissioned as a private altarpiece, and the conventional arched vertical format had never before, and has rarely since, been used to such dynamic and disturbing effect.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: The imagery also is unusual.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: The story of St George of Cappadocia, Roman officer and Christian martyr, was made popular in Western Europe through The Golden Legend, a calendar-book of tales of the lives of the saints compiled in the late thirteenth century.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: It is there that we find the story of a dragon terrorising the countryside demanding human sacrifice.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: When the fatal lot fell to Cleodolinda, the daughter of the king, St George, riding by on his charger, turned to help her and vanquished the dragon 'in the name of Christ'.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: In a departure from tradition, Tintoretto has shown the livid cadaver of a previous victim in the pose of the crucified Christ and included God the Father in the heavens blessing the victory of good over evil.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: The terrified princess, fleeing uphill from the dragon climbing out of the sea, nearly stumbles out of the foreground.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: St George has galloped into the painting from our right, the direction of a hidden source of light which picks out the trunks of the trees, the rump of the horse, the armour of the knight and the flesh and garments of Cleodolinda
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: St George and the Dragon

DESCRIPTION: The painting is the first of a series of works, painted in 1548 for the Scuola Grande di San Marco while Marco Episcopi, his future father-in-law was Grand Guardian of the School.The subject of the huge canvas is the miraculous appearence of St Mark to rescue one of his devotees, a servant of a knight of Provence, who had been condemned to having his legs broken and his eyes put out for worshipping the relics of the saint against his master's will.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Miracle of St Mark Freeing the Slave

DESCRIPTION: The scenes takes place on a kind of proscenium which seems to force the action out of the painting towards the spectator who is thus involved in the amazement of the crowd standing in a semi-circle around the protagonists: the fore-shortened figure of the slave lying on the ground, the dumbfounded executioner holding aloft the broken implements of torture, the knight of Provence starting up from his seat out of the shadow into the light, while the figure of St Mark swoops down from above.In keeping with the drama of the action is the tight construction of the painting, the dramatic fore-shortening of the forms and sudden strong contrast of light and shade
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Miracle of St Mark Freeing the Slave

DESCRIPTION: This oval painting is part of the ceiling decoration in the Sala dell'Albergo.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Apotheosis of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: After his arduous life of wanderings, narrated by the paintings in the neighbouring church, Roch finally reaches heaven, its angelic choirs, and the supreme vision "face to face.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Apotheosis of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: "The spirit of Michelangelo, who had only recently died, seems to permeate this ceiling picture.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Apotheosis of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: While the figure of God the Father is reminiscent of the Creator in the frescos of the Sistine Chapel, his encounter with the rising St Roch suggests Titian's famous Assunta, the epoch-making altarpiece of 1516/18 in the nearby Frari church, showing the Assumption of the Virgin.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Apotheosis of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: The muscular figure of the saint, patron of the victims of the plague, and the attractive representatives of the nine choirs of angels, slightly reminiscent of Gothic cathedral sculpture, seem to stand on the edge of an opening in the roof itself.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Apotheosis of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: This extreme and un-Venetian illusionism ultimately derives from the Mantuan ceiling pictures of Andrea Mantegna
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Apotheosis of St Roch

DESCRIPTION: As in the same subject-matter dealt with almost thirty years before in the large canvas in the Scuola of the Santissima Trinità and today in the Accademia Galleries, the figures of Adam and Eve revolve around a tree
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Fall of Man

DESCRIPTION: In the lower half enveloped in half-shadow Martha, the sister of Lazarus who is plastically outlined by the thread of light, stretches out her arms and stares motionless and as if unbelieving at Christ who sits down calm and unmoved after pronouncing the life-giving words.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Raising of Lazarus

DESCRIPTION: She is outlined from behind and her lost profile makes her very beautiful.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Raising of Lazarus

DESCRIPTION: At the top, among the leafy branches of the trees clearly outlined against the glow of the sky mingled with pink and blue-grey light, Lazarus, who is coming back to life, is freed from the bandages under the careful gaze of the crowd of spectators just made out beyond the small hill
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Raising of Lazarus

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the view toward the throne in the Hall of the Senate.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Senate

DESCRIPTION: Above the throne Tintoretto's The Dead Christ Adored by Doges Pietro Lando and Marcantonio Trevisan can be seen.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Senate

DESCRIPTION: In the centre of the ceiling decoration is the Triumph of Venice by Tintoretto and his son, Domenico Robusti
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Senate

DESCRIPTION: This work together with the Creation of Animals and the Murder of Abel, created between 1550 and 1553, was originally in the Scuola della Trinità.Adam and Eve are depicted not in a landscape thrown into confusion by the hand of the Creator but in a more serene, more human dimension.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Temptation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: In the leafy arbour the two nude figures moving around the trunk of the tree form the parallel diagonals of the composition.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Temptation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: A strong light gives a sculptural effect to their ivory-pink flesh.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Temptation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: But in the background, on the right, the tranquillity of the foreground scene gives way to the tumultuous epilogue to the fact of human disobedience to Divine will.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Temptation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: With rapid brushstrokes Tintoretto evokes the fiery angel who drives Adam and Eve out into the distant desolate hills and plains.Eve, temptation personified, is pressing close to the tree of knowledge; her arms prolong the line of the serpent thrusting down from above.
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Temptation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: Tintoretto confidently shows that he has now perfectly mastered not only the sculptural structure of a muscular, sinewy male body (a particular strength of Florentine painters, especially of Michelangelo) but also the reproduction of female grace and tenderness (the domain of Venetian artists, particularly Titian).The model for Adam is a chiaroscuro woodcut by Antonio da Trento
AUTHOR: TINTORETTO
TITLE: The Temptation of Adam

DESCRIPTION: This painting, depicting the Greek myth of Zeus's seduction of the beautiful Phoenician princess Europa, demonstrates the influence of French Rococo painting upon Tischbein's art.
AUTHOR: TISCHBEIN, Johann Heinrich the Elder
TITLE: The Rape of Europa

DESCRIPTION: In this period much of his work dealt with amorous themes, and this, together with the rich colouring, are reflective of the French influence
AUTHOR: TISCHBEIN, Johann Heinrich the Elder
TITLE: The Rape of Europa

DESCRIPTION: This painting depicts one of the figures of the painting Bad News, now in the National Museum of Wales, Cardiff
AUTHOR: TISSOT, James
TITLE: Tea

DESCRIPTION: This painting shows a girl in a yellow dress holding a bouquet of flowers.
AUTHOR: TITO, Santi di
TITLE: Portrait of a Girl

DESCRIPTION: It is a typical portrait of the artist showing the influence of his teacher, Agnolo Bronzino
AUTHOR: TITO, Santi di
TITLE: Portrait of a Girl

DESCRIPTION: In this half-length picture of the Madonna, Titian was still keeping entirely to a pictorial idiom typical of Giovanni Bellini.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna of the Cherries
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, transferred to canvas, 81 x 100 cm

DESCRIPTION: St Joseph is on the left, and Zacharias, the father of John the Baptist, on the right of the Madonna.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna of the Cherries
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, transferred to canvas, 81 x 100 cm

DESCRIPTION: John, depicted as a naked boy, is giving the Madonna the cherries that give the painting its name
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna of the Cherries
TECHNIQUE: Oil on wood, transferred to canvas, 81 x 100 cm

DESCRIPTION: Titian worked on this huge altarpiece for more than two years from 1516 to 1518.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: It has to be seen as a milestone in Titian's career establishing him as a more universal artist who drew inspiration from outside the confines of Venice.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Indeed the powerful figures of the Apostles reflect the influence of Michelangelo, whereas the painting demonstrates clear iconographical similarities with the works of Raphael.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Above all, what emerges most strongly in the assumption is Titian's desire to break definitely with the traditions of Venetian painting in order to arrive at a synthesis of dramatic force and dynamic tension which will become from this moment on the most obvious characteristic of his work.The picture is composed of three orders.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: At the bottom are the Apostles (humanity), amazed and stunned by the wondreous happening.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: St Peter is kneeling with his hand on his breast, St Thomas is pointing at the Virgin, and St Andrew in a red cloak is stretching forward.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: In the middle, the madonna, slight and bathed in light, is surrounded by by a host of angels that accompany her joyfully hailing.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Above is the Eternal Father, serene and noble majesty, calling the Virgin to him with a look of love.The painting is signed as "Ticianus" low down in the middle of the picture
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Assumption of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Titian was neither such a universal scholar as Leonardo, nor such an outstanding personality as Michelangelo, nor such a versatile and attractive man as Raphael.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: He was principally a painter, but a painter whose handling of paint equalled Michelangelo's mastery of draughtsmanship.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: This supreme skill enabled him to disregard all the time-honoured rules of composition, and to rely on colour to restore the unity which he apparently broke up.We need but look at Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family which was begun only some fifteen years after Giovanni Bellini's Madonna with saints to realize the effect which his art must have had on contemporaries.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: It was almost unheard of to move the Holy Virgin out of the centre of the picture, and to place the two administering saints - St Francis, who is recognizable by the Stigmata (the wounds of the Cross), and St Peter, who has deposited the key (emblem of his dignity) on the steps of the Virgin's throne - not symmetrically on each side, as Giovanni Bellini had done, but as active participants of a scene.In this altar-painting, Titian had to revive the tradition of donors' portraits, but did it in an entirely novel way.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: The picture was intended as a token of thanksgiving for a victory over the Turks by the Venetian nobleman Jacopo Pesaro, and Titian portrayed him kneeling before the Virgin while an armoured standard-bearer drags a Turkish prisoner behind him.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: St Peter and the Virgin look down on him benignly while St Francis, on the other side, draws the attention of the Christ Child to the other members of the Pesaro family, who are kneeling in the corner of the picture.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: The whole scene seems to take place in an open courtyard, with two giant columns which rise into the clouds where two little angels are playfully engaged in raising the Cross.Titian's contemporaries may well have been amazed at the audacity with which he had dared to upset the old-established rules of composition.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: They must have expected, at first, to find such a picture lopsided and unbalanced.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: Actually it is the opposite.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: The unexpected composition only serves to make it gay and lively without upsetting the harmony of it all.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: The main reason is the way in which Titian contrived to let light, air and colours unify the scene.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: The idea of making a mere flag counterbalance the figure of the Holy Virgin would probably have shocked an earlier generation, but this flag, in its rich, warm colour, is such a stupendous piece of painting that the venture was a complete success.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna with Saints and Members of the Pesaro Family

DESCRIPTION: At the sides of the altar in the sacristy of the Santa Maria della Salute, there are eight tondi by Tiziano, painted originally for the monastery of Santo Spirito.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St John the Evangelist

DESCRIPTION: They portray the Four Evangelists: St Matthew, St Mark, St Luke and St John, as well as the Doctors of the Church: St Jerome, St Augustine, St Ambrose, and St Gregory the Great.Titian worked on an oak base with dense brush strokes to create, in the case of St John, a penetrating shadow in the face
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St John the Evangelist

DESCRIPTION: At the sides of the altar in the sacristy of the Santa Maria della Salute, there are eight tondi by Tiziano, painted originally for the monastery of Santo Spirito.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: They portray the Four Evangelists: St Matthew, St Mark, St Luke and St John, as well as the Doctors of the Church: St Jerome, St Augustine, St Ambrose, and St Gregory the Great.Titian worked on an oak base with dense brush strokes
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St Gregory the Great

DESCRIPTION: Titian was involved in a number of public works undertaken by Doge Andrea Gritti.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St Christopher

DESCRIPTION: This St Christopher is over the staircase leading to the doge's private apartment as a talisman against assassination.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St Christopher

DESCRIPTION: The huge saint ensures the insouciant Child's protection for Venice, admirably depicted in the distance
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: St Christopher

DESCRIPTION: In 1529  Federico Gonzaga, Duke of Mantua ordered three more works from Titian.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: The only one to survive is probably identifiable with the Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Shepherd, known as the Madonna of the Rabbit.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: With a look of winning encouragement the Virgin restrains the rabbit, a symbol of fecundity, so that the child can clamber down and play with it.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: The richly dressed St Catherine, proffering her charge like a lady-in- waiting, introduces a courtly aspect, and in fact the Giorgionesque shepherd in the background may be a portrait of Federico himself: Since x-rays show that the Madonna's head was originally turned in his direction.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: In the foreground, the delicate wild flowers recall the locus amoenus or "idyllic setting" of classical poetry, and in the park-like landscape we see the Arcadia of the Concert Champêtre refracted through the smiling fertility of the Ferrara Bacchanals.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: Nowhere else does Titian so successfully integrate the traditions of the Sacra Conversazione and the Pastoral.This painting mainly captivates through the beauty of its colours and the marvellous landscape.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: The small format is a sign that this was a private devotional picture.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: What at first sight appears to be a normal picture of the Madonna gains an additional, very private dimension as a result
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Madonna and Child with St Catherine and a Rabbit

DESCRIPTION: Returning to Venice from Rome in 1546 Titian created a remarkable group portrait of the male members of the Vendramin.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: Here he domesticizes official work such as Bellini's votive portrait of Doge Agostino Barbarigo as well as frescoes he had seen in the papal apartments in Rome.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: While the painting has the look of an impromptu gathering, it is rooted  in prestigious models that betray political motives on the part of Titian and the Vendramin.Titian adapted elements such as the steps, massive altar and flickering candles from Raphael's Mass of Bolsena as a suitably impressive setting for the Vendramin family's adoration of a reliquary of a fragment of the True Cross.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: Although the relic was owned by the Scuola Grande di San Giovanni Evangelista, the Vendramin family was closely associated with it: one of their ancestors had donated the relic to the Scuola, and an Andrea Vendramin, namesake of Titian's patron, was famous for having rescued it when it fell into a canal.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: Titian suggests the intimacy of the family's relation to the relic by placing the current head of family (also named Andrea) in the centre of the composition, with one hand on the altar as he looks out of the picture, inviting the viewer's participation.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: At the left two other family members, dressed in senatorial red, pay their eloquent devotion to the relic, the middle-aged man reaching out as if to share his adoration with others.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: Titian records and contrasts the emotions of his subjects; the sober obedience of the adolescents at left and the innocent play of the children at right serve to underscore the maturity and depth of the adults' piety, as civic, as well as personal virtue.Titian is supposed to have said a painter only needed three colours: white, black and red.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: Looking at this painting, one may well believe it
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Vendramin Family Venerating a Relic of the True Cross

DESCRIPTION: According to an inventory taken in 1556, Emperor Charles V took a Christ on stone with him to the monastery of Yuste, to which he retired after his abdication.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: It was probably this painting, which is the only known work of this type by Titian
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: There is considerable disagreement about the attribution of this work to Titian.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Christ and the Good Thief

DESCRIPTION: While the manner in which the colours are applied is reminiscent of his late work, the extraordinary spatial effect, which is mainly produced by the turning of the thief's cross, can be observed in none of his later works.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Christ and the Good Thief

DESCRIPTION: The way the light falls would also be an unusual feature in Titian's works in the 1560s.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Christ and the Good Thief

DESCRIPTION: If this indeed is not one of his paintings, it is nonetheless one of the highest quality examples of the adoption of elements of his style by other artists
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Christ and the Good Thief

DESCRIPTION: The subject of this painting is taken from the New Testament.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Tribute Money

DESCRIPTION: The Pharisees ask Christ whether it is right to pay tax to the Romans.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Tribute Money

DESCRIPTION: Christ, sensing the trap, asks whose likeness and name are on the coinage: 'They say unto him, Caesar's.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Tribute Money

DESCRIPTION: Then he saith unto them, render therefore unto Caesar the things that are Caesar's; and unto God the things that are God's' (Matthew 22; Mark 12, Luke 20).This painting was probably painted for King Philip II and sent to Spain in 1568
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Tribute Money

DESCRIPTION: In the 17th century the painting was attributed to Giorgione, and later for a long time to Palma Vecchio.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Bravo

DESCRIPTION: However, recently it was given to Tiziano.The Bravo, so called because of the mysterious armed man with his back to us, falls into Titian's Giorgionesque phase and demonstrates an undercurrent of cruelty.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Bravo

DESCRIPTION: The subject has been convincingly identified as the arrest of Bacchus by Pentheus, King of Thebes, who opposed the Bacchic cult.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Bravo

DESCRIPTION: Bacchus' revenge was dire, and Pentheus was torn to pieces by his mother and sisters
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Bravo

DESCRIPTION: In 1516 Titian made contact with Alfonso I d'Este, Duke of Ferrara for whom he was to work for a decade on pictures destined for the Alabaster Chamber.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: In this period he painted a series of magnificent paintings of Dionysian themes: the Worship of Venus in the Prado, The Andrians (Bacchanalia), also in the Prado, and Bacchus and Ariadne, in the National Gallery, London.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: In these paintings Titian combines a richness of colouristic expression with a great formal elegance.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: These are the elements which characterize this whole so-called "classic" phase of Titian's development and which is dominated by the supreme masterpiece of the Frari Assumption of the Virgin.The first painting in this series is The Worship of Venus, whose subject is Love as the source of fertility and regeneration in nature.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: Titian's composition is based on a description by the late antique writer Philostratus, in his 'Imagines', of a painting of cupids gathering apples in the presence of Venus amid a tree-girt landscape.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: By basing himself on Philostratus, Titian was in effect recreating a lost masterpiece of antiquity.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: This would have flattered the patron, who could thus compare himself to Alexander the Great, the patron of Apelles, the most celebrated painter of the ancient world
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: The Worship of Venus

DESCRIPTION: In 1516 Titian made contact with Alfonso I d'Este, Duke of Ferrara for whom he was to work for a decade on pictures destined for the Alabaster Chamber.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: In this period he painted a series of magnificent paintings of Dionysian themes: the Worship of Venus in the Prado, The Andrians (Bacchanalia), also in the Prado, and Bacchus and Ariadne, in the National Gallery, London.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: In these paintings Titian combines a richness of colouristic expression with a great formal elegance.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: These are the elements which characterize this whole so-called "classic" phase of Titian's development and which is dominated by the supreme masterpiece of the Frari Assumption of the Virgin.Titian's sources for the Bacchus and Ariadne were a variety of classical texts (especially Catullus and Ovid), all of them concerning Ariadne, the daughter of the king of Crete.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: Because of her love for Theseus, she helped him escape her father's labyrinth by means of a ball of thread.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: However, Theseus deserted her on Naxos while they were returning to Athens.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: There, she became the lover of the god Bacchus.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: Above her, already visible, is a crown of stars representing the "Corona Borealis", into which she (or, according to a different tradition, her bridal head-dress) is eventually transformed.This painting is among Titian's most Raphaelesque, particularly in the contrapposto of Ariadne and the controlled energy of Bacchus and his train, who seem more numerous than they really are.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: To achieve colouristic brilliance, Titian has used the strongest pigments then available on the market
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Bacchus and Ariadne

DESCRIPTION: Between 1553 and 1554 Titian executed for the Habsburgs two classical mythological works of clearly erotic intent which he himself described as "poesie" (mythological fables).
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: These are the Danaë with a Nurse and the Venus and Adonis, both now in the Prado, Madrid.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: The Venus and Adonis became the prototype for a whole series of replicas of this subject.Venus, the goddess of love, falls in love with Adonis, a beautiful youth.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: Her love is not, however, enough to stop him pursuing his favourite pastime, hunting, which will lead to his undoing, for he is gored to death by a boar.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: There is an interesting letter from Titian to Philip II which deals with this painting.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: The artist makes a special point of mentioning that he was particularly interested in depicting the body from both sides.In both paintings the scene of the union of the lovers is bathed in the warm light of sunset, where the diffuse softness of the colours holds sway.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: The female nudes reveal the continuing inspiration of Michelangelo's sculpture, such as the Dawn and Night from the Medici tombs in Florence.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: But what is entirely personal to Titian is the quality of the colour, which fragments into patches of dazzling luminosity - a perfect complement to the ecstatic sensuous abandon of the figures.In its own day Venus and Adonis was considered one of Titian's most erotic works, especially in the compression of Venus' buttocks in her seated pose, but it also suggests the indulgent condescension of a younger man towards the frantic and overprotective reaction of an older woman
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Venus and Adonis

DESCRIPTION: This painting is one of the six 'poesie' painted by Titian for Philip II of Spain
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Perseus and Andromeda

DESCRIPTION: Titian and his workshop porduced several versions of the subject
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Tarquin and Lucretia

DESCRIPTION: Throughout his period of service to King Philip II, Titian continued to be regarded as the premier painter of the Venetian Republic.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Wisdom

DESCRIPTION: He still executed the occasional masterpiece for Venetian public buildings, such as the octagonal representation of Wisdom for the ceiling of the antechamber to the Reading Room in Sansovino's newly completed Library.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Wisdom

DESCRIPTION: Casually reclining on a cloud, and contemplating herself in a mirror held up by a putto, the figure is painted with a sovereign fluency and atmospheric suggestiveness
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Wisdom

DESCRIPTION: The portraits from the early period of Titian are strongly realistic.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman (La Schiavona)

DESCRIPTION: Among them the portrait of a woman, called La Schiavone, is of remarkably fine quality.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman (La Schiavona)

DESCRIPTION: Titian poses his sitters in such a way as to make the most of a novel compositional idea; the figures stand out in bold relief against the plain background and the colour emphasizes the unusual lighting, revealing the mood of the sitters as well as capturing their physical presence.The inclusion of the sitter's portrait carved in stone may refer to the much discussed issue of the relative merits of painting and sculpture
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of a Woman (La Schiavona)

DESCRIPTION: Probably in 1529, Alfonso d'Este asked Titian to provide a pendant to his (unfortunately lost) portrait, a portrait of his mistress, Laura Eustochia.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Laura Eustochia

DESCRIPTION: The widower Alfonso had taken up with Laura in 1526, and in the following year she had produced a son, who was named after his father.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Laura Eustochia

DESCRIPTION: Although unwilling to marry the humbly born Laura, Alfonso planned to include her son in his scheme for the succession
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Laura Eustochia

DESCRIPTION: Clarissa Strozzi was the daughter of Roberto Strozzi and Maddalena dei Medici, who lived in exile in Venice from 1540 to 1542.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Clarissa Strozzi

DESCRIPTION: Along with the portrait of Ranuccio Farnese, this painting is the second enchanting child's portrait Titian painted in 1542.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Clarissa Strozzi

DESCRIPTION: Clarissa is feeding her little dog, but, like Ranuccio, is looking at something taking place outside the picture.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Clarissa Strozzi

DESCRIPTION: This again creates a vivid sense of movement.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Clarissa Strozzi

DESCRIPTION: The putti on the relief emphasize Clarissa's childlike vitality
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Clarissa Strozzi

DESCRIPTION: The biographer Giorgio Vasari, in his Life of Titian, describes a similar portrait which he says could easily have been mistaken for a Giorgione if Titian had not signed it.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: This portrait was erroneously identified by early critics as the portrait of Ariosto; it is perhaps a likeness of Titian's earliest patron, a member of the noble Barbarigo family.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: In his early period, Titian's portraits are strongly realistic.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: The painting in its gripping tonal palpability and attention to detail, such as the stitching in the satin, has much in common with Giorgione's late portraits.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: But Titian, somewhat competitively, carries Giorgione's realism a step further in the way the sleeve billows out and invades our space, extending the boundaries of Giorgionismo in a burst of hyperrealism.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: The sitter's expression is arrogant, typical of the male dandy.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: The figure stands out in bold relief against the plain background and the colour emphasizes the unusual lighting, revealing the mood of the sitter as well as capturing his physical presence
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Man with the Blue Sleeve

DESCRIPTION: This portrait is considered to be a replica in his own hand of an almost identical portrait in the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa, which identifies the subject as Daniele Barbaro in an inscription.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: The picture in Ottawa is probably that mentioned in 1545 in a letter from Pietro Aretino, which once belonged to the portrait collection of Paolo Giovio in Como.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: With the body turned slightly to the right and the grave, spiritual face framed by the beard and hair, Daniele Barbaro's gaze is fixed on the viewer.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: His black gown reveals scarcely anything except the left hand and the book, which, as an attribute of scholarship, alludes to Barbaro's humanistic education.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: Barbaro was hardly 30 years old at this date
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: In the final period, which saw Titian focussing his attention on religious themes, he still found the energy to paint portraits.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Strada

DESCRIPTION: Between 1567 and 1568 he produced two of his greatest masterpieces in this field: the Prado Self-Portrait and the Portrait of Jacopo Strada in Vienna.The portrait of the well-known antiquarian Jacopo Strada, one of the most famous of Titian's late portraits, represents Jacopo Strada, an expert of antiquities as presenting a small Venus statue.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Strada

DESCRIPTION: On the table there are some objects, among them a letter addressed to Titian.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Strada

DESCRIPTION: The decorative frame with the inscription is a later addition from the workshop of Titian.The painting is of the very highest quality.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Strada

DESCRIPTION: It is painted in energetic dabs of brown and ochre yellow, offset by the black velvet jerkin with a silver fox fur flung around the shoulders.
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Strada

DESCRIPTION: The careful depiction of the details which allude to the profession of the sitter (the statuette, the coins, the cartouche and the books) do not distract from the characterization of Strada, who is looking enquiringly at someone outside the painting
AUTHOR: TIZIANO Vecellio
TITLE: Portrait of Jacopo Strada

DESCRIPTION: The Villa Chiericati was built in the first half of the sixteenth century for Ludovico Chiericati, a nobleman from Vicenza.
AUTHOR: TOEPUT, Lodewijk
TITLE: View of a wall

DESCRIPTION: It underwent numerous restorations and reworkings over time, resulting in its current architectural form, an extended structure with a simple façade that is barely enlivened by a tympanum supported by four Ionic pilasters.
AUTHOR: TOEPUT, Lodewijk
TITLE: View of a wall

DESCRIPTION: A room on the north side, called Room of Landscapes, was decorated with six frescoes of landscape scenes, each incorporating two zodiac signs, by Lodewijk Toeput.
AUTHOR: TOEPUT, Lodewijk
TITLE: View of a wall

DESCRIPTION: During one of the updatings the frescoes were painted over, and it was not until the beginning of the nineteenth century, on the occasion of yet another restoration, that they were finally revealed.The landscapes contain explicit references to the sequence of the seasons and their related zodiac signs, the marking of time that rhythmically measures the work and the days of good guardianship of the land.
AUTHOR: TOEPUT, Lodewijk
TITLE: View of a wall

DESCRIPTION: These are extremely naturalistic paintings, at times enlivened by the presence of slender little figures rendered with a touch of vitality.On the wall shown in the present picture, the vivid figure of the page and his greyhound stand out flanked by a Landscape between Autumn and Winter and a Winter Landscape
AUTHOR: TOEPUT, Lodewijk
TITLE: View of a wall

DESCRIPTION: Paul I (in Russian Pavel Petrovich) (1754-1801) was the Emperor of Russia between 1796 and 1801.
AUTHOR: TORELLI, Stefano
TITLE: Portrait of Grand Duke Pavel Petrovich

DESCRIPTION: He was the son of the Empress Catherine II
AUTHOR: TORELLI, Stefano
TITLE: Portrait of Grand Duke Pavel Petrovich

DESCRIPTION: The two frescoed vaults of the nave, one by Torriti and the other by the Isaac Master (the Master of the Isaac Stories), sum up the iconographic program of the walls beneath.
AUTHOR: TORRITI, Jacopo
TITLE: Deësis vault

DESCRIPTION: The vault of the Deësis celebrates the church triumphant in the four tondi depicting Christ giving his blessing, the Virgin Mary, and St Francis and St John flanked by angels.
AUTHOR: TORRITI, Jacopo
TITLE: Deësis vault

DESCRIPTION: The vault of the Doctors celebrates the Church militant, called on to prepare for the Kingdom of God on earth through the work of Jerome, Ambrose, Gregory, and Augustine
AUTHOR: TORRITI, Jacopo
TITLE: Deësis vault

DESCRIPTION: The frescoes in the clerestory of the two western bays of the nave are less closely related to Torriti's secure works.
AUTHOR: TORRITI, Jacopo
TITLE: Scenes from the Old Testament: The Sacrifice of Isaac

DESCRIPTION: Scenes like the Construction of the Ark and the Sacrifice of Isaac betray the persistent influence of Cimabue.This fresco is located in the clerestory of the north wall in the third bay of the nave
AUTHOR: TORRITI, Jacopo
TITLE: Scenes from the Old Testament: The Sacrifice of Isaac

DESCRIPTION: This scene was probably painted by an assistant of Torriti
AUTHOR: TORRITI, Jacopo
TITLE: The Marriage at Cana

DESCRIPTION: This painting of a woman with her make-up was purchased by Theo van Gogh (1857-1891) for his private collection.The sitter for this painting was probably Suzanne Valadon (1865-1938), a French painter who, in 1894, became the first woman painter admitted to the Société Nationale des Beaux-Arts.

DESCRIPTION: She is also the mother of painter Maurice Utrillo.

DESCRIPTION: She modelled for Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec (who gave her painting lessons), Pierre-Auguste Renoir, and Pierre-Cécile Puvis de Chavannes
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Rice Powder

DESCRIPTION: There are very different types of woman in Lautrec's female gallery, with whom he had more or less lasting relationships.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: The Toilet

DESCRIPTION: They tend to remain anonymous, known only by their first name, or by their portraits, which are rich in psychological, humorous human perceptions.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: The Toilet

DESCRIPTION: Most of them are red-heads, for Lautrec had a passion for red hair.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: The Toilet

DESCRIPTION: Between 1888 and 1891 he painted them all obsessively
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: The Toilet

DESCRIPTION: Lautrec was a good friend of the Dihau family, who came from Lille, and often visited them in their flat where he also sometimes met Degas.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Monsieur Désiré Dihau, Bassoonist at the Opera

DESCRIPTION: Désiré, portrayed here, was a brother of Marie Dihau and was also portrayed by Degas in his Orchestra at the Opera
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Monsieur Désiré Dihau, Bassoonist at the Opera

DESCRIPTION: Marie Dihau, the sister of Désiré Dihau, bassoonist at the Opera, was a successful singer at the Paris Opera in the 1870s.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Mademoiselle Marie Dihau at the Piano

DESCRIPTION: Later she gave piano and singing lessons.Marie Dihau gave all the paintings that Lautrec painted of her and other members of her family to the city of Albi in exchange for a life pension
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Mademoiselle Marie Dihau at the Piano

DESCRIPTION: Both the lithograph and the painting of this subject show the nude dancer and artist Cha-U-Kao (middle) dancing with a girlfriend, with Jane Avril to their right.Around 1880 Montmartre became the centre for the lesbians of Paris.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: At the Moulin Rouge: Two Women Waltzing

DESCRIPTION: No one protested when two women waltzed together, as in Lautrec's painting
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: At the Moulin Rouge: Two Women Waltzing

DESCRIPTION: Lautrec passionately admired Cha-U-Kao, a nude dancer, acrobat and clown, who pretended to be Japanese.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: The Clown Cha-U-Kao at the Moulin Rouge

DESCRIPTION: he painted numerous pictures of her in all kinds of costumes, instigating various special fancy-dress events at the Moulin Rouge for this purpose
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: The Clown Cha-U-Kao at the Moulin Rouge

DESCRIPTION: Maxime Dethomas (1868-1928), painter and graphic artist, was a friend of Lautrec's and one of his favoured companions on brother-crawls.
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Monsieur Maxime Dethomas at the Opera Ball
TECHNIQUE: Oil and gouache on cardboard, 67 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: His painting was strongly influenced by Lautrec, with whom he travelled to Normandy and Holland.

TITLE: Monsieur Maxime Dethomas at the Opera Ball
TECHNIQUE: Oil and gouache on cardboard, 67 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: Dethomas was tall and chubby but, in spite of his stature, tended to be insecure
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Monsieur Maxime Dethomas at the Opera Ball
TECHNIQUE: Oil and gouache on cardboard, 67 x 53 cm

DESCRIPTION: The sick Lautrec spent the winter of 1900/1901 in Bordeaux, where he visited the Grand Théâtre and painted scenes from Isidore de Lara's opera "Messaline" and Jacques Offenbach's operetta "La Belle Hélène."
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Messalina Enthroned

DESCRIPTION: In the last days of 1900 he painted six pictures in rapid succession
AUTHOR: TOULOUSE-LAUTREC, Henri de
TITLE: Messalina Enthroned

DESCRIPTION: Of all the Medici villas in the environs of Florence, Poggio Imperiale has the most imposing site and is also closest to the Palazzo Pitti, which became the official residence of the grand dukes in 1561.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: The property came into the possession of Cosimo I de' Medici in 1565.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: From 1618 Maria Magdalena of Austria, the wife of Cosimo II de' Medici invested  a great sum on improvements made under the direction of Giulio Parigi.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: In 1624 the property was officially named Poggio Imperiale with reference to the grand duchess's imperial lineage.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: The lineage was also featured in the ambitious pictorial program of the public rooms and bedrooms which lay on the ground floor.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: However, the villa was stripped of its precious furnishings and art treasures from the seventeenth century under the Habsburg-Lorraine regency (1737-65).The decoration of Poggio Imperiale started again under the reign of Peter Leopold (1747-1792) who succeeded his father as Grand Duke of Tuscany when his eldest brother became emperor as Joseph II in 1765.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: This decoration was intended to set a new artistic direction and propagate new standards of taste: Neoclassicism.Three rooms in the south wing were frescoed in 1768-72 by Tommaso Gherardini and Giuliano Traballesi with the collaboration of Giuseppe del Moro, one of the best Tuscan perspective painters of the time.
AUTHOR: TRABALLESI, Giuliano
TITLE: Ceiling decoration

DESCRIPTION: It was followed by the decoration of five rooms in the west wing in 1773-78.

DESCRIPTION: The Salone dei Mesi (Room of Months) in the Palazzo Schifanoia, one of the masterpieces of Italian palace architecture, was decorated with a series of allegorical frescoes symbolizing the months.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: The length of the room  is 24 m, the width 11 m and the height 7,5 m. The frescoes are attributed to Cosmè Tura, Francesco del Cossa, Baldassare d'Este and Ercole de' Roberti.On the southern wall January and February, on the eastern wall March, April and May, on the north wall June, July, August and September, on the west wall October, November and December were represented.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: Due to negligence it was in a very bad state already in the 18th century.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: Today there remained only fragments of the frescoes on the southern and western walls, while those on the eastern wall and most on the northern are in relatively good condition.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: This means that the visitor can view the surviving allegories of seven months (March, April, May, June July, August and September).
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: In all allegories the episodes are arranged in a three-tiered, frieze-like manner; in the upper sphere, the sphere of mythology, each month and its planet are paralleled by their ancient divinity in a triumphal procession.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: The middle layer shows the signs of the zodiac, while below are rendered the courtly events appropriate to the particular time of year.This view of the Salone dei Mesi in the Palazzo Schifanoia shows, from the left to the right, frescoes of the months of September, August, July, June, May, April, and May, respectively.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: View of the Salone dei Mesi

DESCRIPTION: The decoration was commissioned by Borso d'Este.

DESCRIPTION: They are emotionally charged, full of movement and intense expressionism.

AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: St George and the Princess

DESCRIPTION: Her fluttering, irregular draperies with decisive hills and valleys are carefully studied, but they do not follow the structure of her body or even her pose, becoming instead alive and rebelliously independent of the forms they hide.Light is effectively rendered as an expressive device without becoming a particularly naturalistic component, striking here and there, helter-skelter, although a certain concentration on the left may be isolated.
AUTHOR: TURA, Cosm?
TITLE: St George and the Princess

DESCRIPTION: Highlights are also found on the right-hand edges of forms, especially in the canvas showing St George impaling the dragon.

TITLE: St George and the Princess

DESCRIPTION: Color is equally antinaturalistic.

DESCRIPTION: There are strong echoes of Mantegna, perhaps in part filtered through Squarcione, in motives like the rendering of the winding trail with figures on the hill behind the princess and a tight application of paint, which permits abundant minuscule detail.

AUTHOR: TURNER, Joseph Mallord William

DESCRIPTION: Burning of Parliament is the popular name for the fire which destroyed the Palace of Westminster, the home of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, on 16 October 1834.
AUTHOR: TURNER, Joseph Mallord William
TITLE: The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons, October 16, 1834

DESCRIPTION: The fire lasted for many hours and gutted most of the Palace.

TITLE: The Burning of the Houses of Lords and Commons, October 16, 1834

DESCRIPTION: Those sections of the fresco cycle that are attributed to Paolo in the Chapel of Our Lady of the Assumption in Prato Cathedral display a perfect compositional organization, created through a precise perspective pattern that places the simple, elegant buildings and the numerous human figures within a perfectly balanced spatial rhythm.
AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: Disputation of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: Each of the characters has a different expression, evidence of a research into facial characteristics which will later become typical of Uccello's painting.In the scene of the Disputation of St Stephen, for instance, the beautiful face of the saint and those of the characters standing around him are portrayed with strongly marked expressions, in some cases even grotesque, in the attempt at giving each one individual characteristics.
AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: Disputation of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: Behind this group of figures there is an architectural construction that is reminiscent of Brunelleschi's buildings.
AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: Disputation of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: The accuracy and the perfect perspective of the drawing of this building is repeated also in the constructions in the background of the Stoning of St Stephen, for this reason correctly attributed to Uccello; the scene of Stephen's martyrdom, on the other hand, is the work of Andrea di Giusto
AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: Disputation of St Stephen

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the conclusive combat between the captains of the two armies: Niccolò da Tolentino unseating Bernardino della Ciarda.Uccello's obsession with displaying his mastery of perspective (such as the long white and red lances or the exceptional horses that have rolled over on the ground) and the dramatic nature of the clash between the knights combine with his almost magical story telling.

DESCRIPTION: The predella, today in the Museo Arcivescovile in Florence, belonged to an altarpiece that has been lost (but was originally painted for the church of San Bartolomeo at Quarate).

DESCRIPTION: It is stylistically close to the Prato frescoes, and it consists of three scenes: St John on Patmos, the Adoration of the Magi and Saints John and Ansano.Although some scholars do not believe it is the work of Uccello, it can be placed chronologically in the group of paintings accepted as Uccello's work.

AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: St John on Patmos (Quarate predella)

DESCRIPTION: A feeling of abstraction pervades these scenes, today no more than a group of fragments of faded and almost undecipherable images, in which we can make out a few architectural structures shown in accurate perspective and some monks laid out according to geometric patterns.
AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: St John on Patmos (Quarate predella)

DESCRIPTION: In the extravagant choice of colours Uccello appears to have given his fantasy free rein; in fact, as Vasari noted, "he did not pay much attention to the rule of consistency in colour, as was usual in the painting of stories; for he made the fields blue, the cities red, and the buildings the colour he felt like.
AUTHOR: UCCELLO, Paolo
TITLE: St John on Patmos (Quarate predella)

DESCRIPTION: This villa is typical of the Veneto Region with gardens and decorative murals.
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: It was owned by the Grimani family for more than 200 years and bequeathed to the comune by its last private owner, Elena Vendramin Calergi (married Andrea Valmarana in 1826).
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: It is now the seat of The Valmarana foundation named for her.The villa underwent extensive renovations in 1757 on the occasion of the marriage of Francesco Vendramin Grimani Calergi and Bianca Morosini.
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: This was the time when Andrea Urbani was engaged to fresco the portego (the large ground-floor room that traverses the building from front to back) and the seven rooms on the second floor.The decoration of the portego is limited to the walls, on which there are three large landscapes set within ornate, faux architectural settings, also designed by Urbani.
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: The west wall contains View of a Villa with a Pool and Landscape with Waterfall, while the opposite wall has View of a Large Renaissance Palace, divided into two parts by the staircase door.
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: In the centre foreground of each landscape, on a trompe-l'oeil pedestal, is a faux-bronze statuary group representing the struggle between Good and Evil
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the portego

DESCRIPTION: The decoration of the portego is limited to the walls, on which there are three large landscapes set within ornate, faux architectural settings, also designed by Urbani.
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of a Large Renaissance Palace (II)

DESCRIPTION: The west wall contains View of a Villa with a Pool and Landscape with Waterfall, while the opposite wall has View of a Large Renaissance Palace, divided into two parts by the staircase door.
