DESCRIPTION: In the centre foreground of each landscape, on a trompe-l'oeil pedestal, is a faux-bronze statuary group representing the struggle between Good and Evil
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of a Villa with a Pool

DESCRIPTION: In the Chinese Room Urbani painted scenes depicting The Judgment of the Mandarin and The Mandarin's Procession.
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the Chinese Room

DESCRIPTION: The scenes are set within frames made up of faux marble and open metalwork that "break through" the actual walls, creating a faux Eastern-style pavilion that opens into the surrounding space and also extends to the ceiling and the short walls.The "chinoiserie" motif had been fashionable in Venice since the early decades of the eighteenth century and was first employed porcelain decorations, then in many other craft forms
AUTHOR: URBANI, Andrea
TITLE: View of the Chinese Room

DESCRIPTION: The picture showing the Villa Medicea at Cafaggiolo is one of the 14 paintings in lunette form which represent the Medici villas.
AUTHOR: UTENS, Giusto
TITLE: Villa Medicea, Cafaggiolo

DESCRIPTION: They were made by artist in 1599-1602 for the third grand duke of Tuscany, Ferdinando I.The Villa Medicea di Cafaggiolo was one of the oldest and most favoured of the Medici family estates.
AUTHOR: UTENS, Giusto
TITLE: Villa Medicea, Cafaggiolo

DESCRIPTION: The villa was reconstructed following designs of the architect Michelozzo in 1452, becoming a meeting place for some of the greatest intellectuals of the Italian Renaissance.
AUTHOR: UTENS, Giusto
TITLE: Villa Medicea, Cafaggiolo

DESCRIPTION: The Medici visited it often: as a consequence, the villa was the scene of many momentous events in the history of the dynasty, ranging from the reception of Medici brides to the murder of a Medici wife
AUTHOR: UTENS, Giusto
TITLE: Villa Medicea, Cafaggiolo

DESCRIPTION: The picture showing the Villa Medicea at Castello is one of the 14 paintings in lunette form which represent the Medici villas.
AUTHOR: UTENS, Giusto
TITLE: Villa Medicea di Castello

DESCRIPTION: They were made by artist in 1599-1602 for the third grand duke of Tuscany, Ferdinando I
AUTHOR: UTENS, Giusto
TITLE: Villa Medicea di Castello

DESCRIPTION: There is a pendant of this picture, La Virgen Dolorosa, also in a private collection.
AUTHOR: VALDÉS LEAL, Juan de
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: Both paintings show the influence of Titian
AUTHOR: VALDÉS LEAL, Juan de
TITLE: Ecce Homo

DESCRIPTION: This canvas closely follows Caravaggio's naturalistic approach, both in terms of form and content.
AUTHOR: VALENTIN DE BOULOGNE
TITLE: David with the Head of Goliath and Two Soldiers

DESCRIPTION: A strong chiaroscuro governs the scene, highlighting the figure of David.
AUTHOR: VALENTIN DE BOULOGNE
TITLE: David with the Head of Goliath and Two Soldiers

DESCRIPTION: The artist has created a compact group of half-length figures situated behind a table on which David has rested the decapitated head of Goliath, all set against a dark background which could be a wall and which serves to block any recession into depth, creating a very shallow foreground space
AUTHOR: VALENTIN DE BOULOGNE
TITLE: David with the Head of Goliath and Two Soldiers

DESCRIPTION: In contrast with his Judith and Holofernes, Valentin de Boulogne's famous Judith presents the heroine not in the moment of action but after the victory
AUTHOR: VALENTIN DE BOULOGNE
TITLE: Judith

DESCRIPTION: The sitter was a brilliant court buffoon and a self-proclaimed count, well-known in Rome in the first quarter of the seventeenth century
AUTHOR: VALENTIN DE BOULOGNE
TITLE: Portrait of Raffaello Menicucci

DESCRIPTION: In the hunting palace at Stupinigi, outside Turin, erected by Filippo Juvarra between 1729 and 1731, a domed hall serves to link the themes of the four suits of rooms leading into it.
AUTHOR: VALERIANI, Domenico
TITLE: Ballroom decoration

DESCRIPTION: With its four free-standing pillars and continuous second-floor balcony, the architecture itself is so open and delightful that the frescoed vault with Diana stories, executed by the Valeriani brothers, plays only a subordinated role
AUTHOR: VALERIANI, Domenico
TITLE: Ballroom decoration

DESCRIPTION: The old rivalry between painting and sculpture, the sister arts devoted to the imitation of nature, resurfaces in this painting.
AUTHOR: VALLAYER-COSTER, Anne
TITLE: Attributes of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture

DESCRIPTION: The painters had shown that, in their two-dimensional pictures, they were quite capable of offering several views of a body that was equally beautiful from all sides.
AUTHOR: VALLAYER-COSTER, Anne
TITLE: Attributes of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture

DESCRIPTION: What theoreticians had presented as an advantage of sculpture became a particular challenge to painting.
AUTHOR: VALLAYER-COSTER, Anne
TITLE: Attributes of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture

DESCRIPTION: A plaster Academy model of the antique Belvedere Torso (1st century AD, Rome, Vatican) is here rendered in paint.
AUTHOR: VALLAYER-COSTER, Anne
TITLE: Attributes of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture

DESCRIPTION: Like painting and sculpture, architecture was also considered an art of draughtsmanship.
AUTHOR: VALLAYER-COSTER, Anne
TITLE: Attributes of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture

DESCRIPTION: Inspired by Chardin, this academic still-life is devoid of all reference to the theme of vanitas that was generally present in compositions on a comparable theme by the older Dutch masters: the focus now falls upon the enlightened erudition of art
AUTHOR: VALLAYER-COSTER, Anne
TITLE: Attributes of Painting, Sculpture, and Architecture

DESCRIPTION: Between 1360 and 1370 Lippo Vanni executed a cycle of fresco paintings for the church of the rural hermitage of San Leonardo al Lago just outside Siena.
AUTHOR: VANNI, Lippo
TITLE: The Betrothal of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Painted on the walls and entrance arch of the chancel of this church, the scheme includes narrative scenes from the life of the Virgin, such as the Presentation of the Virgin in the Temple, the Annunciation, the Betrothal of the Virgin, and the Assumption of the Virgin (over the chancel arch, now badly damaged)
AUTHOR: VANNI, Lippo
TITLE: The Betrothal of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: In this painting Varotari depicts a scene from the biblical story of Jacob.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: It shows Jacob telling Rachel and Leah that he wishes to leave Laban's service.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: Jacob urges Rachel and Leah to leave with him.According to the Bible, Leah becomes Jacob's wife through a deception on the part of her father, Laban.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: In the Biblical account, Jacob is dispatched to the hometown of Laban - the brother of his mother Rebekah - to avoid being killed by his brother Esau, and to find a wife.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: Out by the well, he encounters Laban's younger daughter Rachel tending her father's sheep, and decides to marry her.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: Laban is willing to give Rachel's hand to Jacob as long as he works seven years for her.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: On the wedding night, however, Laban switches Leah for Rachel.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: Later Laban claims that it is uncustomary to give the younger daughter away in marriage before the older one.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: Laban offers to give Rachel to Jacob in marriage in return for another seven years of work.
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: Jacob accepts the offer and marries Rachel after the week-long celebration of his marriage to Leah
AUTHOR: VAROTARI, Dario the Elder
TITLE: Scene from the Story of Jacob

DESCRIPTION: The Studiolo is a tiny chamber in the Palazzo dei Priori (Palazzo Vecchio), accessible by a hidden spiral staircase.
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: View of the Studiolo

DESCRIPTION: It was dedicated to the geological, mineralogical and alchemical interest of Francesco I de' Medici, son and successor of Cosimo I. Its walls are lined with two tiers of oil paintings on slate or panel that act as doors for cupboards containing Francesco's scientific books, specimens, and instruments.
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: View of the Studiolo

DESCRIPTION: Two doors, not distinguished in any way from the cupboard doors, cover the only windows: Francesco preferred to work by candlelight.The intimate scale of the project allowed Vasari and his pupils to develop their imaginative abilities, technical skill, and jewel-like delicacy of colour.
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: View of the Studiolo

DESCRIPTION: Eight sculptors made the bronze statuettes, and the paintings were by twenty-four artists.
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: View of the Studiolo

DESCRIPTION: This precious chamber is the only sixteenth-century room in Europe to survive with its oil paintings intact
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: View of the Studiolo

DESCRIPTION: This fresco is part of the paintings decorating the house of Vasari in Florence.It is characteristic of Vasari's self-confidence that the artistic and intellectual effort he invested in designing his own home was comparable to that which he expended on the residences of those who commissioned his work.
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: The Studio of the Painter

DESCRIPTION: He decorated his house in Arezzo between 1542 and 1548; toward the end of his life he also frescoed his Florentine house, which had been given to him by Duke Cosimo I in 1561.
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: The Studio of the Painter

DESCRIPTION: In both cases the paintings refer to the role of the painter, who saw himself in the tradition of ancient painters (to whom individual episodes of both cycles are devoted)
AUTHOR: VASARI, Giorgio
TITLE: The Studio of the Painter

DESCRIPTION: The Sala dello Scrutinio (Voting Hall) is the second largest hall of the Doge's Palace.
AUTHOR: VASSILACCHI, Antonio
TITLE: Conquest of Tyre

DESCRIPTION: The balloting and secret votes of the magistracies and the doge took place in this hall with the very complicated systems that the Venetian Republic had created to avoid intrigues and subterfuge during the elections and, above all, to ensure that the vote could not be bought especially from the poor nobility in favour of its richer equivalent.The iconographic theme of the hall of the Sala dello Scrutinio was inspired by the Venetian naval victories on the Eastern seas shown in the numerous ceiling canvases depicting virtues and symbolic figures.
AUTHOR: VASSILACCHI, Antonio
TITLE: Conquest of Tyre

DESCRIPTION: Vassilacchi's Conquest of Tyre on the wall of the Sala del Scrutinio depicts a historical event which occurred in 1123 under the rule of Doge Domenico Michiel, who commanded the Venetian fleet in the East
AUTHOR: VASSILACCHI, Antonio
TITLE: Conquest of Tyre

DESCRIPTION: The picture represents a still-life of roses, carnations and other flowers in a sculpted urn with fruit and other flowers below
AUTHOR: VEERENDAEL, Nicolaes van
TITLE: Still-Life

DESCRIPTION: Originally this painting, together with an Immaculate Conception (now in private collection), was in the Carmelite Convent in Seville
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: St John the Evangelist at Patmos

DESCRIPTION: The subject of the painting is the Greek philosopher Democritus expressing his amusement at the world, which stands on the table in front of him in the shape of a globe.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Democritus

DESCRIPTION: The man in the picture stands there smiling, shown half-length, turned to one side but with his face towards us.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Democritus

DESCRIPTION: His right hand is placed on his hip, in an attitude setting off the heavy folds of a red cloak.Democritus, who lived around 470-360 BC, taught that cheerful and moderate contentment was the way to happiness.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Democritus

DESCRIPTION: European painting of the Renaissance and Baroque periods repeatedly portrayed him as the "laughing philosopher", contrasting him with other intellectual types such as the pessimist, the stoic and the cynic
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Democritus

DESCRIPTION: The painting, asssumed by some art historians to be a self-portrait - is unfinished, the hands are only sketched in
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Young Man

DESCRIPTION: In this painting the restriction of surrounding areas and the general pose found in earlier portraits of the king are still present, but the subject's whole attitude is more relaxed, the flesh tints, probably under the influence of Rubens, are painted with more fluidity, the accents of colour - eyes gleaming like black tortoiseshell, the golden lights on the waves of the hair - are placed with more emphasis, and shapes conveying Baroque dignity, such as the profuse folds of the red curtain, have made their way into the formerly sparse interior.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Philip IV in Brown and Silver

DESCRIPTION: Above all, Velázquez's new delight in luxuriant colour is reflected in his depiction of the silk embroidery and the silver and brown tones of the king's clothing.The king is holding in his right hand a paper with the inscription "Senor/Diego Velázquez/ Pintor de V. Mg" - the opening words of a petition to him from Velázquez.The unattractive matt white of the stockings is the result of an unskilful restoration of the picture in 1936, but otherwise the work is a good example of the skilled manner that Velázquez had now mastered
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Philip IV in Brown and Silver

DESCRIPTION: Philip IV was a bold and enthusiastic huntsman, it was usual for the king to ride out with a small retinue in the extensive game preserves of the densely wooded Pardo.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: Emperor Charles V had built a watchtower on the way to the mountainous hunting grounds of the Sierra, as a place to stop and rest before the most strenuous stage of the journey.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: This tower was known as the Torre de la Parada, and Philip, who was particularly fond of it, extended it to make a comfortable hunting lodge.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: He was in haste to see it furnished, and commissioned Rubens to provide a large collection of new pictures on mythological subjects.After 1638, when the building itself was completed, it was the task of Velázquez to decide how they should be hung, and to contribute a series of hunting portraits himself, to hang with other appropriate works already in existence and with pictures by Dutch masters.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: This project cost him a great deal of time and trouble, but it also won him increasing appreciation at court.Velázquez's three extant hunting portraits (Philip IV as a Hunter, Prince Baltasar Carlos as a Hunter, and Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter) are life-size.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: Don Fernando, the king's younger brother, despite his spiritual calling, did not hesitate to indulge his passion for hunting.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: In this painting, showing him with his gun at the ready, he looks even more of a huntsman than his relations.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: His expressive outline balances the silhouette of the cinnamon-coloured dog sitting in front of him, a figure once again illustrating the court painter's skill in depicting animals.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: He pays them as much careful attention as he expends on human beings; while he is of course aware of the differences between animals and humans, he is also conscious of the dignity shared by all living creatures.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: The natural elegance of a horse's head or the body of a dog, their fiery or faithful natures - few painters have captured the beauty and individuality of animals as unforgettably as Velázquez
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Cardinal Infante Don Fernando as a Hunter

DESCRIPTION: As a court painter, Velázquez was required to paint group portraits as well as these actual or fictional portraits of individual figures.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews

DESCRIPTION: He organized a workshop of competent artists, and in 1633 recruited the services of his son-in-law Juan Bautista Martínez del Mazo.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews

DESCRIPTION: Mazo probably did a good deal of work on the picture of around 1636 showing Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews

DESCRIPTION: The Count-Duke stands in the middle ground to the right of the picture, with his master-at-arms; figures on the balcony above him include Philip IV, Queen Isabel and several courtiers who cannot be identified for certain.The belly of the horse on which the little prince is mounted is disproportionately convex and in fact so coarsely depicted that one suspects the unskilful hand of an apprentice rather than a deliberate distortion
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Prince Baltasar Carlos with the Count-Duke of Olivares at the Royal Mews

DESCRIPTION: In a manner that is always striking and sometimes curiously moving to modern observers, Velázquez shows human nature in all its diversity when he presents the gallery of dwarfs and jesters who lived at court and whose task it was to preserve the king from boredom in the midst of routine etiquette.Under cover of joking, the court jesters or buffoons, in Spanish truhanes, would often tell their lords and masters the home truths openly discussed by the ordinary people.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: They could move freely in the king's presence, trying to amuse the naturally melancholic Philip IV with their caustic remarks.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: To judge by their salaries, their position in society was quite high.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: Velázquez himself, on entering the service of the palace as a court painter, had at first been classed with the royal servants, and as a result shared the life of these truhanes.Velázquez painted a masterly picture of the buffoon Don Cristóbal de Castañeda y Pernia, who was first in rank among the court jesters.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: He gave himself airs as a great military expert, thus earning the nickname of Barbarroja (Barbarossa or Red-beard).
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: The ambitious buffoon aspired to military roles and he even acted as toreador in the arena although he was ill-fitted for doing it.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: His red robe is almost Turkish in style, and his head-dress suggests a fool's cap.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: He glares fiercely into space, and while he grips the sheath of his sword firmly, the sword itself is held in a relaxed position
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Buffoon Don Cristóbal de Casta?eda y Pernia (Barbarroja)

DESCRIPTION: It was customary at the courts of Europe during the seventeenth century for monarchs to keep dwarfs.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Court Dwarf Don Antonio el Inglés

DESCRIPTION: Velázquez's sympathy for the fools and dwarfs of the Spanish court is obvious: in the pathos and humane understanding demonstrated by the single portraits with which he (and he alone) paid tribute to them
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Court Dwarf Don Antonio el Inglés

DESCRIPTION: One of the tasks required of Velázquez, the court painter, was the painting of altarpieces, though to a lesser extent than painting portraits.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The Coronation of the Virgin was painted around 1645, possibly for the queen's oratory in the Alcazar in Madrid.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: The Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Angelic putti carry the virginal Madonna up to heaven on clouds; Christ and God the Father hold a wreath of roses over her head, and the dove of the Holy Ghost hovers above her in an aureole of light.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y

DESCRIPTION: "Las Meninas" is a Portuguese word used to name the Maids of Honour of the Royal children in the 17th century.Las Meninas or The Royal Family is one of the great problem pictures in the history of art.

DESCRIPTION: An almost infinite number of interpretations have now been proposed for the scene it shows.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: At first sight, however, Las Meninas seems to present no problems at all, and indeed appears perfectly straightforward in its sober geometry and good-humoured clarity.It is set in a room in the Alcázar, equipped by Velázquez as a studio, and shows the heiress to the throne, the Infanta Margarita, with her court.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: The other maid of honour, Dona Isabel de Velasco stands behind the princess, and beside her we see the grotesquely misshapen female dwarf Mari-Bárbola and the male dwarf Nicolasico Pertusato; the latter, as Palomino points out, is placing his foot on the mastiff lying in front of the group to demonstrate the lethargic animal's good temper.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: Further back, almost swallowed up in the shadows, are a man described only as guardadamas - a guard or escort to the ladies - and the lady in waiting Doña Marcela de Ulloa.Velázquez is standing with brush and palette in front of a tall canvas; we can see only the back of it.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y

DESCRIPTION: To the right of the mirror, on a flight of steps leading up to a doorway and a brightly lit adjoining room, stands Jose Nieto, the queen's palace marshal.There are several basic questions that have been asked again and again about this picture.

DESCRIPTION: What is Velázquez painting on the front of the canvas that is hidden from us?

DESCRIPTION: Where did he stand in order to paint the scene and himself in it?
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: What is the source of the image in the mirror - that is, just where in the room must the royal couple have been standing for their reflection to appear?
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: And finally, is there any significance in the fact that the red cross of the Order of Santiago is prominently applied to the artist's clothing?It was long thought that Velázquez was creating a picture without any metaphysical or speculative reference, and was merely recording a fleeting moment in permanent form, as if in a snapshot.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: According to this theory the subject was no more than an ordinary scene of palace life.A different hypothesis is put forward by art historians, who believe that intellect and keen perspicacity, as well as the artist's eye and hand, were involved in the painting of Las Meninas.
AUTHOR: VELÁZQUEZ, Diego Rodriguez de Silva y
TITLE: Las Meninas or The Family of Philip IV

DESCRIPTION: The largest number of interpretations have been put forward for the mirror on the back wall, sometimes also thought to be a painted canvas.

DESCRIPTION: Much learned industry has also been applied to the question of location: in which room in the palace is this scene taking place?

TITLE: Shipwreck

DESCRIPTION: This sublime and very effective scene is a good examapaale of his works
AUTHOR: VERNET, Claude-Joseph
TITLE: Shipwreck

DESCRIPTION: The two Mediterranean views, "Le Soir: A Mediterranean Harbour at Sunset with Fisherfolk and Merchants on a Quay" and "Clair de Lune: A Mediterranean Harbour by Moonlight with Fisherfolk by a Fire on the Shore, a Natural Arch Beyond" were painted by Claude-Joseph Vernet in Rome in 1752, the period that is considered to be the pinnacle of the artist's long and successful career
AUTHOR: VERNET, Claude-Joseph
TITLE: "Le Soir"

DESCRIPTION: Vernet's oil study Mazeppa of 1826, done in advance of the large painting in the Musée Calvet in Avignon, was based on a theme from Lord Byron's verse epic of the same name, which was translated into French soon after its publication in 1819.
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: Mazeppa

DESCRIPTION: The story relates how Mazeppa, a Cossack chief, made illicit advances to the daughter of a Polish prince.
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: Mazeppa

DESCRIPTION: As punishment, he was tied naked to the back of a wild horse, which galloped off with him.
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: Mazeppa

DESCRIPTION: Exhausted to the point of death, he was finally saved by a Cossack girl.Mazeppa not only represents a man whose animal instincts caused him to be subjected to an animal fate; he also embodies the outcast and pariah who is condemned by society.
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: Mazeppa

DESCRIPTION: In this regard, Mazeppa could figure as a romantic symbol of artistic self-reliance and determination
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: Mazeppa

DESCRIPTION: Horace Vernet enjoyed royal patronage, one of his earliest commissions was a group of ten paintings depicting Napoleon's horses.
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: A Saddled Race Horse Tied to a Fence

DESCRIPTION: These works reveal his indebtedness to the English tradition of horse painting.
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: A Saddled Race Horse Tied to a Fence

DESCRIPTION: The present painting was commissioned in Paris in 1828 by Jean-Georges Schickler, a member of a German based banking family, who had a passion for horse racing
AUTHOR: VERNET, Horace
TITLE: A Saddled Race Horse Tied to a Fence

DESCRIPTION: Blindman's buff is a children's game played as early as 2,000 years ago in Greece.
AUTHOR: VERON, Alexandre Paul Joseph
TITLE: Blindman's Buff

DESCRIPTION: To play the standard game of blindman's buff, one player is blindfolded and then disoriented by being spun around several times.
AUTHOR: VERON, Alexandre Paul Joseph
TITLE: Blindman's Buff

DESCRIPTION: The other players, who are not blindfolded, amuse themselves by calling out to the "blind man" and dodging away from him.
AUTHOR: VERON, Alexandre Paul Joseph
TITLE: Blindman's Buff

DESCRIPTION: In the Middle Ages blindman's buff was an adult game, and the blindfolded player was usually struck and buffeted as well, hence "buff."
AUTHOR: VERON, Alexandre Paul Joseph
TITLE: Blindman's Buff

DESCRIPTION: A player touched or caught by the blind man takes on the blindfold
AUTHOR: VERON, Alexandre Paul Joseph
TITLE: Blindman's Buff

DESCRIPTION: Despite several formal inconsistencies, the altar painting for the church of San Fermo Maggiore in Verona is an expression of Veronese's early mastery.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Madonna Enthroned with Child, St John the Baptist, St Louis of Toulouse and Donors

DESCRIPTION: It was apparently commissioned by Giovanni Bevilacqua-Lazise, and he and his deceased wife Lucrezia Malaspina are probably the donors in the picture
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Madonna Enthroned with Child, St John the Baptist, St Louis of Toulouse and Donors

DESCRIPTION: This picture shows the Holy Family with St Catherine of Alexandria and St Anne.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystic Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: According to a 9th-century legend, St Catherine was a princess converted to Christianity by a hermit.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystic Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: The child Jesus appeared to her later in a dream and handed her a ring as a sign of her engagement.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystic Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Under the worried gaze of Joseph, the saint - dressed as an elegant Venetian woman — turns lovingly towards the child sitting in his mother's lap, who reacts with excited pleasure
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystic Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Accompanied by Peter, James and John, Jesus had gone to Mount Tabor to pray, where the disciples were witnesses to his transfiguration (St.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Transfiguration of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Matthew 17, 5).
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Transfiguration of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Unlike Raphael's Transfiguration, in which the Transfiguration, Resurrection and Ascension are combined in the figure of Christ, Veronese's sticks to the text in emphasizing the mystic moment of transfiguration.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Transfiguration of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Linked in a richly graded scale of colour, Christ, Moses and Elijah greatly resemble the figures in his Coronation of the Virgin (in San Sebastiano) in style.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Transfiguration of Christ

DESCRIPTION: The angels tumbling from the clouds and the eloquent gestures of the prostrate disciples provide the dramatic touches
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Transfiguration of Christ

DESCRIPTION: Veronese painted the frescoes on the upper part of the nave of San Sebastiano between March and September 1558.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St Sebastian Reproving Diocletian

DESCRIPTION: The main pictures, representing ST Sebastian Reproving Diocletian and The Martyrdom of St Sebastian are located in the chancel.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St Sebastian Reproving Diocletian

DESCRIPTION: Painted architecture plays a preponderant role in these frescoes: a mock portico with columns, niches and windows frames them.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St Sebastian Reproving Diocletian

DESCRIPTION: They are treated like theatrical scenery
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St Sebastian Reproving Diocletian

DESCRIPTION: This ceiling painting in the sacristy of San Sebastiano has an unusual iconography compared with older depictions.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: Mary is being crowned by Christ, while God the Father touches His Son's shoulder with his left hand.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The date of completion of the ceiling painting is recorded in a book in one of the four corner tondos held by a winged angel.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The inscription reads: M.D.L.V./ DIE XXIII/ NOVEMBER (November 23, 1555)
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Coronation of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: The extraordinary beauty of the Venetian fabrics already to be found in the work of Palma il Vecchio is brought to unrivalled perfection by Paolo Veronese.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St John the Baptist Preaching

DESCRIPTION: In the St John the Baptist Preaching (c.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St John the Baptist Preaching

DESCRIPTION: 1562), which heralds the coming of Christ, the figures are wrapped in magnificent oriental silk robes and three are wearing turbans.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St John the Baptist Preaching

DESCRIPTION: Their differing reactions to the sermon are reflected in their facial expressions.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St John the Baptist Preaching

DESCRIPTION: The skilful composition of the painting creates a balance between the weight of the group of figures on the right and the perspective on the left
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: St John the Baptist Preaching

DESCRIPTION: Framed by a concave aedicule with double Corinthian columns, this large painting adorns the high altar of the church, the reconstruction of which materially involved Veronese's patron Michele Sanmicheli in 1552.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Martyrdom of St George

DESCRIPTION: After the completion of the architecture of the high altar, i.e.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Martyrdom of St George

DESCRIPTION: soon after 1564, work started on the iconographically unconventional altarpiece under the influence of Tridentine reformist ideas.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Martyrdom of St George

DESCRIPTION: It omits the gruesome torture of the martyrdom, concentrating instead on the saint's moment of intercession.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Martyrdom of St George

DESCRIPTION: The central figure is incorporated in a group composition full of movement.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Martyrdom of St George

DESCRIPTION: The scene of the martyr's unclothing is exaggerated by the presence of the Madonna in a bank of clouds accompanied by Sts Peter, Paul and the cardinal virtues Faith, Hope and Charity
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Martyrdom of St George

DESCRIPTION: In this work, originally the altar-screen of the church of St Catherine, Veronesian colour reaches a peak of richness and splendour.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystical Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Along the diagonal of the composition which terminates in the drapes billowing around the columns, new chromatic notes are struck; the 'fortissimo' of the steps and figures in the foreground harmonizes with the 'pianissimo' of angels and cherubs which emerge from the grey-gold clouds of the celestial kingdom in the background.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystical Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Linking the two planes of colour are two cherubs holding the martyr's palm and the heavenly crown above the Virgin and St Catherine while the angel below lifts her head and holds out her arms to receive the sign and the reward of martyrdom.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystical Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: All three are portrayed with Apollonian purity against the intense blue of the sky, an unforgettable example of Veronese's exquisite use of colour.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystical Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Even more appropriate is the 17th century comment by Marco Boschini: 'It is almost as if the painter to create his effects used gold, pearls and rubies, emeralds sapphires and purest, most perfect diamonds'.Here too, as in his pictures of religious feasts, Veronese successfully combines the religious subject with social pomp and ceremony, transforming the sacred event into a luxurious sixteenth-century festival.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystical Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: He achieves this in part by changing the setting of the episode, which no longer takes place in Alexandria but in a typically Venetian location
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Mystical Marriage of St Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Veronese's images of the Lamentation (he painted several versions of this subject) often convey a haunting reminder of a happy world, thereby increasing the pathos of the Passion.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Dead Christ Supported by Two Angels

DESCRIPTION: In this painting the heightened sensibility is achieved by the shocking contrast between flashes of elegant drapery (the angels' suavely tinted attire) and Christ still-beautiful, abused flesh.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Dead Christ Supported by Two Angels

DESCRIPTION: Such calculated inconsistency can make suffering far more moving than a more predictable, uniform pall
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Dead Christ Supported by Two Angels

DESCRIPTION: In the Sala dell'Olimpo, Veronese configured the lower part of the vault as a loggia, and standing the balustrade of this loggia are various figures dressed in contemporary clothing.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Portrait of Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: Two sons of Marcantonio and Giustiniana Giustiniani, Almorò, born in 1548 and Daniele, born in 1551, appear in the loggia, Almorò shown reading, Daniele attempting the hold back the dog that is determined to chase after the monkey climbing at the centre of the balustrade
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Portrait of Daniele Barbaro

DESCRIPTION: The walls in the Sala dell'Olimpo are punctuated by Corinthian columns, which, along each of the long sides enclose landscapes depicting river views and ruins of classical buildings.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Landscape

DESCRIPTION: Veronese derived the landscapes from a series of engravings published in 1551 by Hieronymus Cock, and from others published in 1561 by the Vicenzan artist Battista Pittoni
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Landscape

DESCRIPTION: In the Stanza del Lucerna there are once again two pairs of allegorical figures, on the one side Prudence with her traditional attribute, the mirror; leaning on her is an older man with the attributes of Hercules, a lion's skin and a club, who  is the personification of Manly Virtue.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Nemesis

DESCRIPTION: On the other side is the curious image of a man who has put a bridle on a woman.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Nemesis

DESCRIPTION: The bridle and measuring rod are the attributes of Nemesis, thus in this allegory the man assumes the role of Nemesis
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Nemesis

DESCRIPTION: In 1577 a serious fire in the Palazzo Ducale destroyed the Sala del Maggior Consiglio, originally the meeting place for the Venetian legislature.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: View of the Sala del Maggior Consiglio

DESCRIPTION: It necessitated the wholesale renovation of the pictorial decoration, and artists received explicit instructions about subject and even composition, the idea being to emulate the visual authority of the destroyed works as closely as possible.In the redecorated room the thirty-five ceiling canvases, some of them by Veronese, celebrate the glory of Venice allegorically and illustrate the Republic's military history.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: View of the Sala del Maggior Consiglio

DESCRIPTION: On the end wall Tintoretto and his pupils painted the enormous representation of Paradise.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: View of the Sala del Maggior Consiglio

DESCRIPTION: The oval ceiling painting visible in the present view is the Triumph of Venice by Veronese and his pupils
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: View of the Sala del Maggior Consiglio

DESCRIPTION: This painting was commissioned by the Venetian government for the ceiling of the Sala del Maggior Consiglio of the Palazzo Ducale.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Apotheosis of Venice

DESCRIPTION: It is one of the thirty five panels on the ceiling.Rising above the bank of clouds, the royally garbed personification of Venice sits enthroned between the twin towers of the city's Arsenal, about to be crowned with laurel by flying victories.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Apotheosis of Venice

DESCRIPTION: Arrayed at her feet and offering her wise counsel are personifications of peace, abundance, fame, happiness, honour, security, and freedom.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Apotheosis of Venice

DESCRIPTION: An especially splendid triumphal arch, fronted by twisting columns, marks the top of an enormous balcony which seems to burst through the ceiling into the ether beyond in order to accommodate the multitudes of celebrating people stipulated in the commission.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Apotheosis of Venice

DESCRIPTION: At the base, Venice's smiling subjects seem undisturbed by the enormous size and energy of careening horsemen in their midst reminder of Venice's considerable military might.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Apotheosis of Venice

DESCRIPTION: Illusionistic foreshortenings and dramatic light effects serve to give political allegory a previously unimagined dynamism and visual excitement
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: Apotheosis of Venice

DESCRIPTION: The Biblioteca Marciana was designed by Jacopo Sansovino to house the about thousand illuminated manuscripts donated to the Republic by Cardinal Bessarion.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: View of the Biblioteca

DESCRIPTION: The interior was adorned with paintings by Tintoretto, Paolo Veronese, Giovanni de Mio, Battista Franco, Giuseppe Salviati, Andrea Schiavone, and Giovan Battista Zelotti.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: View of the Biblioteca

DESCRIPTION: Veronese illustrated the Bible story in which the infant Moses was found by Pharaoh's daughter in a reed basket floating on the Nile.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: The princess and her ladies-in-waiting look with surprise at the find.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: This small painting, which probably came from the collection of Charles I of England, is one of the earliest and best versions of an Old Testament subject inspired by the works of the painter Bonifazio de'Pitati.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: Several replicas in Veronese's own hand are known, together with a number of variants and sundry derivations carried out with the help of the workshop.The scene is a river bank in a highly atmospheric landscape.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: The story tells of an infant boy left out in a basket on the Nile, who is found by Pharaohs daughter and brought up by her as her own son, Moses.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: The bridge and city are reminiscent of Verona.
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: The delicately nuanced interplay of light and shade, achieved with a fine brush, unfolds to produce the glowing effect of brilliant jewels
AUTHOR: VERONESE, Paolo
TITLE: The Finding of Moses

DESCRIPTION: This portrait of an unknown man follows a pattern used in several other half-length portraits by Verspronck in the 1640s
AUTHOR: VERSPRONCK, Jan Cornelisz
TITLE: Portrait of a Man

DESCRIPTION: The composition of this painting is loosely based on Lodovico Carracci's painting of the Circumcision, formerly in the church of San Bartolomeo di Reno in Bologna (destroyed in World War II)
AUTHOR: VIANI, Giovanni Maria
TITLE: Circumcision

DESCRIPTION: For long time it was thought that the painting represents Jacob and Laban.
AUTHOR: VICTORS, Jan
TITLE: Abraham's Parting from the Family of Lot

DESCRIPTION: However, in 1987 the subject was identified as Abraham's departure for Canaan, leaving his nephew Lot and his family, who will set off for Sodom.
AUTHOR: VICTORS, Jan
TITLE: Abraham's Parting from the Family of Lot

DESCRIPTION: This subject from the Genesis is rarely treated in art
AUTHOR: VICTORS, Jan
TITLE: Abraham's Parting from the Family of Lot

DESCRIPTION: The subject is taken from the Book of Ruth in the Old Testament.
AUTHOR: VICTORS, Jan
TITLE: Ruth and Naomi

DESCRIPTION: Naomi of Bethlehem was the Moabite Ruth's mother-in-law
AUTHOR: VICTORS, Jan
TITLE: Ruth and Naomi

DESCRIPTION: In 1773 Vien received the patronage of Mme du Barry, who for her Château de Louveciennes commissioned the series of four works depicting the Progress of Love in the Hearts of Young Girls.
AUTHOR: VIEN, Joseph-Marie
TITLE: Greek Maidens Adorning a Sleeping Cupid with Flowers

DESCRIPTION: Two from the series, the Greek Maidens Adorning a Sleeping Cupid with Flowers, and the Lover Crowning his Mistress, are in the Louvre
AUTHOR: VIEN, Joseph-Marie
TITLE: Greek Maidens Adorning a Sleeping Cupid with Flowers

DESCRIPTION: This portrait shows the Duchess of Caderousse, posed simply in the costume of a countrywoman.
AUTHOR: VIGÉE-LEBRUN, Élisabeth
TITLE: The Duchess of Caderousse

DESCRIPTION: It was painted by Élisabeth Vigée-Lebrun, the favourite portrait painter of Queen Marie-Antoinette
AUTHOR: VIGÉE-LEBRUN, Élisabeth
TITLE: The Duchess of Caderousse

DESCRIPTION: Thanks to talent and connections, Vigée-Lebrun was accepted into the Royal Academy of Painting and Sculpture at age 28 and became a favourite of Queen Marie-Antoinette.
AUTHOR: VIGÉE-LEBRUN, Élisabeth
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: her manner of painting captures the reign of the carefree Louis XVI
AUTHOR: VIGÉE-LEBRUN, Élisabeth
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: In the present still-life stacked peaches and grapes are gracefully illuminated against a dark background, enhancing their dimensionality.
AUTHOR: VIGNON, Charlotte
TITLE: Peaches and Grapes on a Draped Table

DESCRIPTION: Though the fruits appear casually placed on the draped table, the composition is carefully and perfectly balanced.
AUTHOR: VIGNON, Charlotte
TITLE: Peaches and Grapes on a Draped Table

DESCRIPTION: Vignon probably worked in Rome from around 1617 to 1623.
AUTHOR: VIGNON, Claude
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Matthew

DESCRIPTION: This painting is based on Caravaggio's Martyrdom of St Matthew in the Contarelli Chapel in San Luigi dei Francesi.The domineering executioner seen from the front seems to be a direct borrowing.
AUTHOR: VIGNON, Claude
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Matthew

DESCRIPTION: Yet Vignon's picture  is more of a commentary on the earlier work than a copy
AUTHOR: VIGNON, Claude
TITLE: The Martyrdom of St Matthew

DESCRIPTION: This rare subject is taken from the book of Bellum Gallico (Gallic War) by Julius Caesar (ca.
AUTHOR: VINCENT, François-André
TITLE: The Daughter of Ariovistus Made Prisoner by Caesar

AUTHOR: VINCENT, François-André
TITLE: The Daughter of Ariovistus Made Prisoner by Caesar

DESCRIPTION: The painting can be dated to the end of the 1770s when the painter was inspired by rare literary themes and painted from them several canvases with very free technique
AUTHOR: VINCENT, François-André
TITLE: The Daughter of Ariovistus Made Prisoner by Caesar

DESCRIPTION: In the magnificent gardens of a country palace a group of young and fashionable figures have assembled for a banquet beneath the trees.
AUTHOR: VINCKBOONS, David
TITLE: Elegant Party in an Ornate Palace Garden
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 51 x 98 cm

DESCRIPTION: It is an early example of fête galantes painted in the Netherlands in the early seventeenth century that would prove hugely influential on Dutch painting, especially in Haarlem, for a generation or more.
AUTHOR: VINCKBOONS, David
TITLE: Elegant Party in an Ornate Palace Garden
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 51 x 98 cm

DESCRIPTION: Esias van de Velde, Willem Buytewech and Dirck Hals, were, for example, all directly influenced by Vinckboons's examples
AUTHOR: VINCKBOONS, David
TITLE: Elegant Party in an Ornate Palace Garden
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 51 x 98 cm

DESCRIPTION: This academic costume scene illustrates a moment of history revisited: the great Renaissance artist Michelangelo, who was also an exquisite author of sonnets, reads aloud one of his poems among a circle of friends.
AUTHOR: VINEA, Francesco
TITLE: Michelangelo Reads his Poetry in the House of Aldovrandi

DESCRIPTION: A student of the Florence Academy, Vinea specialized in such interior scenes and gallant conversation pieces, and was critical of the more progressive Macchiaioli artists, who showed strong interest in realistic scenes of everyday life
AUTHOR: VINEA, Francesco
TITLE: Michelangelo Reads his Poetry in the House of Aldovrandi

DESCRIPTION: Vincent I Laurensz.
AUTHOR: VINNE, Vincent I Laurensz. van der
TITLE: Vanitas with a Royal Crown

DESCRIPTION: van der Vinne is best known for his vanitas still-lifes.
AUTHOR: VINNE, Vincent I Laurensz. van der
TITLE: Vanitas with a Royal Crown

DESCRIPTION: Beside Pieter van Roestraten, a genre and still-life painter (and the son-in-law of Frans Hals) Vinne is the only documented student of Hals; not a trace of their contact with him is evident in their works
AUTHOR: VINNE, Vincent I Laurensz. van der
TITLE: Vanitas with a Royal Crown

DESCRIPTION: The heavy plasticity of Bartolomeo Vivarini and Andrea da Murano was soon surpassed by the more balanced and harmonious three-dimensional quality of the works of Antonello da Messina.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: His St Cassiano altarpiece of 1476, fragments of which are now in the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna was studied and admired by a whole generation of painters.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: One of the first to be inspired by it was Alvise Vivarini, son of Antonio and follower of his uncle Bartolomeo, who soon went on to become a major exponent of Antonello's theories of crystalline form and colour.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: His major work coming from the first and much-admired studio of Messina is the Sacra Conversazione dated 1480, originally in the church of San Francesco in Treviso.The painting is composed with geometrical symmetry: the two groups of saints, Louis of Toulouse, Anthony of Padua and Anne on the left and Joachim, Bernardino and Francesco Gioacchino on the right, face inwards towards the enthroned Virgin.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: In their gestures immobilized by the cold light which comes from the top left-hand corner, the three-dimensional figures appear to form a kind of architecture the centre of which is the throne, a construction of cylinders and parallelepipeds, behind which the curtain falls heavily excluding from sight all natural elements apart from two small fragments of a cold, clouded sky.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: Shadows appear to cut into the floor, confirmation of the geometrical relationship between space and figures, while the clear line delineates areas of pure enamel-like colour.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: This theory of formal abstraction was to become during the last few years of the 15th century still more monumental, in contrast to the ideas of colourization and sublime naturalness represented by Giovanni Bellini.Recent examination has revealed that the green curtain in the background was added at a later date.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: The panel is signed and dated on the dais of the throne
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Alvise
TITLE: Virgin and Child Enthroned with Saints (Sacra Conversazione)

DESCRIPTION: The polyptych together with two others, all executed by Antonio Vivarini and Giovanni d'Alemagna, are in the Chapel of San Tarasio in the church of San Zaccaria.The Santa Sabina Polyptych portrays, in the lower centre the saint and martyr Sabina with St Jerome and St Licerius; in the upper section is an angel with St Agatha and St Margaret.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Santa Sabina Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: The size of the panels are 127 x 56 cm (lower centre), 115 x 38 cm (lower sides), 35 x 26 cm (upper centre), 62 x 38 cm (upper sides)
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Santa Sabina Polyptych

DESCRIPTION: In this grandiose triptych Antonio Vivarini, helped by his brother-in-law Giovanni d'Alemagna (active 1441-1450), achieved a highpoint of balance between the International Gothic tradition now in decline, and the rising Renaissance.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, 339 x 200 cm (central), 339 x 138 cm (each side)

DESCRIPTION: A natural light lends tenderness to the holy figures.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, 339 x 200 cm (central), 339 x 138 cm (each side)

DESCRIPTION: The Virgin, however, sits rigid like a Byzantine empress on a Gothic throne, surrounded by Masolinoesque angels who are holding the poles of the high canopy almost as if it were a game.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, 339 x 200 cm (central), 339 x 138 cm (each side)

DESCRIPTION: The saints Gregory and Jerome on the left and Ambrose and Augustine on the right, stand immobile in their heavy ecclesiastical garments shining with gold and colour.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, 339 x 200 cm (central), 339 x 138 cm (each side)

DESCRIPTION: The holy scene appears constrained by the marble walls with their Gothic fretwork, set in a perspective as improbable as it is ostentatious.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, 339 x 200 cm (central), 339 x 138 cm (each side)

DESCRIPTION: The sumptuous static scene is a final dazzling reminder of a fairy-tale world
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Antonio
TITLE: Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Tempera on panel, 339 x 200 cm (central), 339 x 138 cm (each side)

DESCRIPTION: The picture shows the central panel of the triptych depicting St mark with angels
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Pala di San Marco (central panel)

DESCRIPTION: The polyptych in on the altar of the Bernardo Chapel in the Frari's Basilica.
AUTHOR: VIVARINI, Bartolomeo
TITLE: Virgin Enthroned with Child and Saints (polyptych)

DESCRIPTION: The rich and graceful Renaissance frame is probaly by Jacopo di Faenza.

DESCRIPTION: This was nothing new in the world of Dutch art but it was new to the genre in Delft.
AUTHOR: VLIET, Hendrick Cornelisz. van
TITLE: The Pieterskerk in Leiden

DESCRIPTION: Van Vliet's production was consistent and systematic.
AUTHOR: VLIET, Hendrick Cornelisz. van
TITLE: The Pieterskerk in Leiden

DESCRIPTION: His constant search for new views in the churches of Delft, his trips to other towns and his use of standard schemes indicate work for the open market.The paintings shows a view of the interior in the Pieterskerk in Leiden from the northern transept to the southwest.
AUTHOR: VLIET, Hendrick Cornelisz. van
TITLE: The Pieterskerk in Leiden

DESCRIPTION: This is the earliest known dated architectural painting by Van Vliet.
AUTHOR: VLIET, Hendrick Cornelisz. van

DESCRIPTION: It employs Houckgeest's type of oblique perspective scheme, and an illusionistic archway and curtain
AUTHOR: VLIET, Hendrick Cornelisz. van

DESCRIPTION: Maria Mancini was the wife of a Colonna duke, and niece of Cardinal Mazarin.
AUTHOR: VOET, Jacob Ferdinand
TITLE: Maria Mancini as Cleopatra

DESCRIPTION: She poses as Cleopatra, about to dissolve a great pearl in wine and down it, so winning a bet with Mark Antony concerning her awesome capacity for conspicuous consumption
AUTHOR: VOET, Jacob Ferdinand
TITLE: Maria Mancini as Cleopatra

DESCRIPTION: Ortensia Mancini (1646-1699), was the fourth of the five celebrated Mancini Sisters (Laure, Olympe, Marie, Marie Anne and Ortensia), daughters of the sister of Cardinal Mazarin, the chief advisor of the young King Louis XIV of France and reputed lover of his mother, Anne of Austria.
AUTHOR: VOET, Jacob Ferdinand
TITLE: Portrait of Ortensia Mancini

DESCRIPTION: After their father's death in 1650, the Mancini girls were brought to France by their mother, who hoped that her brother would help find rich and titled husbands for her brood of girls.The five Mancini girls were to become the talk of Paris thanks to their sumptuous dark haired, olive skinned beauty and wild, flamboyant manners, with the young Ortensia (Hortense in Paris), her uncle's favourite niece being the most badly behaved of them all as she grew up into a bold eyed beauty, who was absolutely impossible to resist.At the age of fifteen Hortense was married to one of the richest men in all Europe, the Duc de Meilleraye, with the couple being declared Duc and Duchesse de Mazarin after their wedding day
AUTHOR: VOET, Jacob Ferdinand
TITLE: Portrait of Ortensia Mancini

DESCRIPTION: Voiriot was a highly successful portraitist who customarily included items relevant to the life of the sitter.
AUTHOR: VOIRIOT, Guillaume
TITLE: Portrait of M. Gilbert Desvoisins, Councillor of State in Ordinary

DESCRIPTION: In this case he portrayed M. Gilbert Desvoisins, his prominent patron, with the splendid lacquered bureau plat, the chinoiserie ink wells in ormolu mounts, as working at his papers
AUTHOR: VOIRIOT, Guillaume
TITLE: Portrait of M. Gilbert Desvoisins, Councillor of State in Ordinary

AUTHOR: VOLAIRE, Pierre-Jacques
TITLE: Seascape with Fisherman on a Rocky Shore
TECHNIQUE: Pastel on paper stretched on canvas, 53 x 65 cm

DESCRIPTION: Cornelis de Vos was an Antwerp portrait painter who occasionally worked for Rubens.

TITLE: The Triumph of Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: He also painted large historical and allegorical works
AUTHOR: VOS, Cornelis de
TITLE: The Triumph of Bacchus

DESCRIPTION: Family harmony is a source of prosperity and happiness.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: So proclaims the Latin inscription in the cartouche at the top of the picture.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: This is the message of this family portrait, which does much more than simply depict wealthy members of Antwerp high society.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: Antonius Anselmus, an alderman of the city from 1580 to 1582, and his wife Joanna Hooftmans, the daughter of a wealthy merchant, are placed in front of a neutral background, accompanied by their two children, both born in Antwerp, Gillis in 1575 and Joanna in 1576.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: A third child was to be born in Hamburg, where the family sought refuge for a time after the city of Antwerp was returned to the Catholics.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: The Anselmus family, like the Hooftmans, were Calvinists.The family's high social ranking is immediately visible in the various items of decor: the carved furniture, the silver inkwell on the table, and the fragile Venetian glass vase, as well as the costly lace on the parents' garments and the children's aprons.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: The little girl holds a sumptuous vermeil rattle, a prestigious object symbolising the wealth of the newly born child.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: This object was offered to very young children by a godfather or an important person.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: The one represented here has at one end a whistle and at the other a wolf's tooth, to which popular belief attributed the double power of protecting children against the evil eye and reducing teething pain.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: On the table between the couple are the marriage gloves and a rose, symbols of the love that unites them.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: The children express the prosperity of the couple as does the fruit being held by the elder.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: At the same time the tame bird on his shoulder is a metaphor for a successful education.Maerten de Vos, who excelled in the portrait genre, was also known for his religious paintings, producing, among other works, six paintings of episodes from the life of St Paul for the dining room of Gillis Hooftmans, Joanna's father.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: It is possibly following this commission that he painted the family portrait.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: By creating a unified and enveloping space around the figures, the artist succeeded in given a new dimension to the genre, intensifying both the psychological study and the allegorical significance.
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: A partial replica of this painting, containing the head of Joanna, is conserved at the Wallraf Richartz-Museum in Cologne
AUTHOR: VOS, Marten de
TITLE: Portrait of Antonius Anselmus, His Wife and Their Children

DESCRIPTION: The subject of the scene is an illustration of the popular adage "Sine Baccho et Cerere friget Venus" (Without Ceres and Bacchus, Venus would Freeze): without food (Ceres, the Roman god of agriculture) and wine (Bacchus), love (Venus) is left cold
AUTHOR: VOS, Simon de
TITLE: Allegorical Scene

DESCRIPTION: The theatrical scene is an anticipation of the great compositions of Vouet in Paris
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: The Last Supper

DESCRIPTION: The French Simon Vouet triumphed in Rome by becoming president of the Academy of St Luke in 1627.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: Birth of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: He painted the Birth of the Virgin for the S. Francesco a Ripa with an uncommonly powerful sense of composition
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: Birth of the Virgin

DESCRIPTION: This portrait was executed in Rome.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: Vouet’s early Roman portraits, like the present example, are animated and moody, governed by an effective use of chiaroscuro, the dark areas often nearly black, the highlights rich in white, creamy paint
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: Portrait of a Young Man

DESCRIPTION: This painting, formerly given to Pomarancio, has been reattributed to Simon Vouet.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: It may perhaps be identifiable with the Magdalene cited with an attribution to Sacchi in the 1648-49 inventory of the Palazzo Barberini at Monterotondo.The painting, which shows some stylistic and typological connections with the Vouet's David in Palazzo Bianco in Genoa, could date from the years (c.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: 1623-27) in which the French artist was in close contact with the Barberini, ending with his departure for France.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: Though the canvas is certainly rich in Caravaggesque qualities, Vouet is already showing himself as a full participant in the new classicism that was on the rise in the Roman art scene.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: At the same time he also shows signs of sympathy with the first fully baroque works that were being created in Rome.This painting poses interesting problems on account of its close compositional connections to the Magdalene by Guido Reni, dated to 1631-32 (also in the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Rome).
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: The cut of the scene anticipates the composition that Vouet adopted for his Portrait of Gaucher de Chatillon (Louvre, Paris), carried out for the Palace of Cardinal Richelieu between 1633 and 1634.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: Dominated by the monumental figure of the Magdalene, the picture opens out to a luxuriant perspectival landscape view in the left background.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: Another highly interesting element is the close stylistic analogy between the Magdalene and Vouet's Allegory of Peace, that was also in the Barberini collection (also in the Galleria Nazionale d'Arte Antica, Rome).
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: As the Allegory has been attributed to an anonymous brother of the Cavalier Muti (a student of Vouet and Claude Mellan), the similarities between the two pictures lead to basic questions about the true authorship of this extraordinary painting
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: St Mary Magdalene

DESCRIPTION: The fleshly opulence and joyful colouring of Simon Vouet made him, to some extent, a French Rubens.
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon

DESCRIPTION: On his return from Rome in 1627 he became Court Painter to Louis XIII and was the founder of that tradition of decorative panting which Le Brun developed
AUTHOR: VOUET, Simon
TITLE: Allegory of Wealth

DESCRIPTION: This scene of conflict possesses the decorative qualities and Vrancx's typically poised figures.
AUTHOR: VRANCX, Sebastian

AUTHOR: VRANCX, Sebastian
TITLE: Attack of Robbers

DESCRIPTION: It reveals Vrancx's delight in detailing his paintings with the dynamic qualities that make his compositions appealing on both an aesthetic and historical level
AUTHOR: VRANCX, Sebastian
TITLE: Attack of Robbers

TITLE: View of Delft from the Southwest

DESCRIPTION: This painting represents the full-length portrait of John 20th Earl of Crawford and Lindsay, "The Gallant Earl of Crawford" (1702-1749) dressed in Hussars' uniform holding a musket and standing in a highland landscape.
AUTHOR: WAITT, Richard
TITLE: Portrait of John 20th Earl of Crawford and Lindsay
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas laid onto board

TITLE: Portrait of John 20th Earl of Crawford and Lindsay
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas laid onto board

DESCRIPTION: Undoubted bravery, far-flung service, generosity of spirit, and courageous persistence in living with a painful wound made "the gallant earl" a hero to his contemporaries
AUTHOR: WAITT, Richard
TITLE: Portrait of John 20th Earl of Crawford and Lindsay
TECHNIQUE: Oil on canvas laid onto board

DESCRIPTION: This self-portrait shows the artist sitting at his easel pointing to a painting that he has just completed.
AUTHOR: WAITT, Richard
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: The painting of the nude on his easel is probably a representation of 'sight' from the traditional series of the five senses, explaining the little hand-mirror - and, of course, the unseen mirror into which Waitt himself looks.
AUTHOR: WAITT, Richard
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: Or perhaps the woman, who gazes towards the artist rather than her mirror, symbolises the art of portraiture itself
AUTHOR: WAITT, Richard
TITLE: Self-Portrait

DESCRIPTION: Taking Daubigny's floating studio as their model, Weissenbruch and Roelofs regularly went out in boats.

TITLE: View of Haarlem

DESCRIPTION: Weissenbruch's spacious Dutch scenes, such as View of Haarlem, contrast in their use of bolder and broader brushwork.
AUTHOR: WEISSENBRUCH, Jan Hendrik
TITLE: View of Haarlem

DESCRIPTION: In their own specific lyrical way, drawing foremost on the colourist juxtaposition of silvery blues and greens with warmer shades, Weissenbruch paintings nicely captured the moist atmosphere that lies upon Dutch landscapes
AUTHOR: WEISSENBRUCH, Jan Hendrik

AUTHOR: WERFF, Adriaen van der

DESCRIPTION: Sir Joseph Banks (1743-1820) was a naturalist and patron of science.
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: Joseph Banks

DESCRIPTION: From an early age, his declared passion was natural history, and in particular, botany.
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: Joseph Banks

DESCRIPTION: He joined Captain Cook's 1768 expedition on the Endeavour to Tahiti for astronomical observations (to observe the transit of Venus).In West's portrait he wears a Maori cloak and stands beside other trophies from New Zealand and Polynesia, as if in rebuke of his more conventional contemporaries who were portrayed in Rome with their purchases of classical antiquities
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: Joseph Banks

DESCRIPTION: The genre in which English painters were least happy in the second half of the 18th century was history painting; the efforts of Reynolds in this direction are strangely petrified for so living a painter.
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: The Treaty of Penn with the Indians

DESCRIPTION: Yet it was through history painting that Neo-Classicism invaded the art in England.
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: The Treaty of Penn with the Indians

DESCRIPTION: A Scot, Gavin Hamilton (1738-1820) and an American, Benjamin West, who enjoyed a prodigious success, were in advance of the French painter Jacques-Louis David in the conception of a painting as a scene from Classical history, based upon thorough archeological research.West was most successful when least pretentious; his illustrations of English historical events are simply illustrations, simply composed, uneffectedly direct.
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: The Treaty of Penn with the Indians

DESCRIPTION: Neo-classicism had trained West to give value to the facts of the scene depicted, removing anything merely decorative or liable to spoil the sense of witnessing an actual event
AUTHOR: WEST, Benjamin
TITLE: The Treaty of Penn with the Indians

DESCRIPTION: West began his career as a portrait painter in Philadelphia and New York.

TITLE: The Annunciation

TITLE: The Annunciation

TITLE: The Annunciation

TITLE: Braque Family Triptych

TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: They are represented against a landscape that is rendered down to the finest detail, with its rivers and mountains, grass and leaves so precisely drawn they could almost be counted and tiny figures visible in the distance in the streets of imaginary towns - a favourite motif of the Flemish masters.Pictures showing busts of Christ and the Virgin had existed earlier north of the Alps, but a sequence of several saints shown half length seems to derive from a type of altarpiece found in Italy from the 13th century onward.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: The innovation is to place them in front of a wide, coherent landscape relating to the figures themselves not realistically, but in context.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: It stands for the entire world ruled by Christ and to which He descended incarnate as man, as described at the beginning of the Gospel of St John: "And the Word was made flesh and dwelt among us."
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: If the dark exterior was a reminder of the inevitability of death, the wide, radiant interior with its saintly figures allowed the devout viewer to hope for salvation.Artistically, the triptych is very close to the Beaune Altarpiece.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: The head of the Virgin Mary, and in particular the head of Christ, are so like their counterparts in the picture of the Last Judgment that they must have been executed from the same cartoon (full-size design for a painting).
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: It is not certain whether the work is entirely by Rogier's hand; the underdrawing reveals thin lines not at all typical of him, and perhaps done with a pen instead of Rogier's usual brush.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: There are also some differences in the artistic execution: the Virgin's face, for instance, looks waxen, and inflexible around the eyes by comparison with the wonderful, tenderly painted, and lifelike Mary Magdalene, which is among Rogier's finest works
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Braque Family Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 41 x 68 cm (central panel), 41 x 34 cm (wings each)

DESCRIPTION: The right panel depicts the Beheading of St John the Baptist.As a lascivious worldly beauty, Salome wears a magnificent dress in the fashion of French princesses, with exotic decorative items including the pointed head-dress.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: The background shows the scene of the banquet in which Salome's mother, Herodias, stabs the decapitated head of the Baptist in her hatred for him.The shallow zone of the foreground is set off by the strong effects of depth in the side panels, where the rooms are almost like tunnels.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: This makes the narrative backgrounds of the left and right panels subordinate.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: In the beheading of the Baptist, the body of the executed man is part of the foreground group, and the executioner can set his sword against John's right shoulder, shown in a flat plane.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: At the same time, however, two mourners who belong to the background are placed directly above the cellar stairs where the dead man is lying, and a figure diminished to about one-third of the size of the foreground figures appears to be standing only a little farther back from them.The side panels of the St John Altarpiece do not merely show the beginning and end of the Baptist's earthly life.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: The parallels between the pictorial motifs also express moral conflict.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: On the right, the unchaste Salome, in magnificent and seductive clothing, holds the Baptist's head.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: She and the executioner are turning away from each other and from their victim, as if painfully conscious of the crime that has been committed.Interestingly, however, the figure of Salome looks like a variant on the Virgin Mary in the Annunciation scene of the St.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: Columba Altarpiece (Alte Pinakothek, Munich), where the figure's knees are placed apart in an even more balletic position.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: Rogier was obviously able to make effective use of this elaborate and artificial pose in various circumstances, and only the worldly magnificence of Salome's dress and the context cause the viewer to assess it differently here.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: In addition, Salome's grave and melancholy face does not in fact differ much from the face of the Virgin Mary in that Annunciation, although in this later version it is leaning at rather too pronounced an angle to express grace.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: The artist has not set out simply to make the figure of Salome merely despicable; indeed, in the context of this scene, her noble features give her a touch of complex ambivalence
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: St John Altarpiece (right panel)
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 77 x 48 cm

DESCRIPTION: The two small panels, representing the Madonna and St Catherine of Alexandria, respectively, probably formed a diptych.The busts of prophets on the outside of the Ghent Altarpiece by Jan van Eyck were the model for the bust of God the Father at the top of the left panel.

DESCRIPTION: The figures of Adam and Eve were from the same source.

DESCRIPTION: The picture is usually regarded as an early work by Rogier himself from the years 1432-35, but the figure of the Madonna is probably after Jan van Eyck's Madonna of the Fountain, dated 1439, in Antwerp.The right panel is rather weaker, and is not by the same painter as the Madonna.
