DESCRIPTION: The Abegg Triptych was painted for an Italian gentleman, an unidentified member of the Villa family from Chieri in Piedmont, who were active in banking in the Netherlands.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: Their coat of arms appears in the glazed window in the left wing.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The picture is generally regarded as a late work by one of Rogier's successors, perhaps not painted until the 1460s, though some of the figures of the Crucifixion were copied as early as 1447 by the Hamburg painter Hans Bornemann, who died in 1475.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The costume of the donor and the findings from dendrochronological investigation allow us to date the picture to the middle of the 1440s.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: Compared to figures in works by Rogier's own hand the figures here, particularly in the Crucifixion, seem excessively emotional; instead of radiating dignified grief they are uttering loud cries of lamentation.Once again, the design of the triptych must have been by an assistant in Rogier's workshop.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The figure of the red-robed St.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: John to the left of the Cross shows how he reworked the master's figural types to suit his own ideas.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The model is St John in Rogier's Deposition (Prado, Madrid), and it is followed faithfully in such details as the right foot.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The folds of the robe, however, are more strongly modeled.The cloak in particular, very dynamically draped and with a large fold flung backward over the shoulder, gives the figure a sense of agitation that is in tune with the character of this painting as a whole, but not with its model.
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: Similarly, Mary Magdalene's cloak slipping down from her hips picks up a motif from the Deposition, but combines it with an extrovert gesture foreign to that picture, with the saint suddenly flinging up her arms.The series of the three panels follows a chronological sequence: the sculptural Annunciation group in the donor's loggia refers to Christ's becoming man; in the central panel Christ has just died, and the sun and moon turn dark as His companions break into loud lamentations; on the right Joseph of Arimathaea, Nicodemus, and a servant are approaching with a ladder to take the dead body down from the Cross
AUTHOR: WEYDEN, Rogier van der
TITLE: Abegg Triptych
TECHNIQUE: Oil on oak panel, 102 x 70,5 cm (central), 103 x 31 cm (each wing)

DESCRIPTION: The name of the subject of the portrait was deduced from the grisaille on the reverse side of the panel.

DESCRIPTION: About 1650 the most interesting developments in architectural painting took place in Delft, where a new phase began with the church interiors by Gerard Houckgeest, Emanuel de Witte, and Hendrick Cornelisz van Vliet.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: Stylistic affinities with works done during the decade in the city by Carel Fabritius, Pieter de Hooch, an Vermeer are apparent, and Vermeer's own exceptional masterpieces in this branch of painting can be viewed as part of the new movement.In Saenredam's earlier church interiors the line of vision is always at an angle of about 90° to the centre of the nave or to the wall of the building he depicts.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: Houckgeest had the new idea  of shifting his position to the side to give an angle of about 45° to the principal axis of the church.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: The new position creates intriguingly intricate diagonal views across the church.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: Emanuel de Witte experimented with similar perspectival schemes about 1650.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: His earliest dated interior that employs the new point of view is the Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: It does not focus on a tomb of a hero, but on the minister preaching from a pulpit, which is still in place, to a large congregation.
AUTHOR: WITTE, Emanuel de
TITLE: Interior of the Oude Kerk at Delft during a Sermon

DESCRIPTION: In de Witte's painting the Word, not patriotism, is stressed

DESCRIPTION: Reveling in an expanse of sky, in the physical insignificance of Humankind, Wouwerman pays homage to the elements, to Nature's irrational, unbalanced aspects, with all of us in her thrall, never more so than in the dead of winter.
AUTHOR: WOUWERMAN, Philips
TITLE: Winter Landscape with Wooden Bridge

DESCRIPTION: Qualities of the picturesque, the irregular, decorative tricks of the eighteenth-century artist's trade, are anticipated by this scene
AUTHOR: WOUWERMAN, Philips

DESCRIPTION: Legend has it that in the reign of the Emperor Maxentius there lived a girl known as Catherine of Alexandria who was as intelligent and wise in debate as she was beautiful to look upon.
AUTHOR: YÁ?EZ DE LA ALMEDINA, Fernando
TITLE: Saint Catherine

DESCRIPTION: During the last years of pagan Rome she emerged victorious from every verbal encounter with the Roman sages and it was for this reason that, at the Emperor's order, on the 25th of November, in the year 307 A.D., she was broken on the wheel and then beheaded.
AUTHOR: YÁ?EZ DE LA ALMEDINA, Fernando
TITLE: Saint Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Catherine's emblems are therefore the wheel, the sword, the palm-branch and the book, the first two representing her martyrdom, the others her wisdom.Both her life and her death were favourite subjects for paintings in the Middle Ages, chosen even by the greatest artists of the Renaissance when it was only possible to paint a beautiful woman in the guise of a saint.
AUTHOR: YÁ?EZ DE LA ALMEDINA, Fernando
TITLE: Saint Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Thus in this painting by Yáñez we are shown a gentle young girl with a Leonardo-like smile, colourfully dressed and posed against a richly detailed background.
AUTHOR: YÁ?EZ DE LA ALMEDINA, Fernando
TITLE: Saint Catherine

DESCRIPTION: Yáñez was an artist of the Spanish Renaissance who, though influenced by Italian art, retained the vivid colouring and meticulous detail of the Flemish tradition
AUTHOR: YÁ?EZ DE LA ALMEDINA, Fernando
TITLE: Saint Catherine

AUTHOR: YKENS, Frans

DESCRIPTION: Landscape with River and Bridge is a fine example of the balance of colour and atmosphere achieved by Zais in his works of this period.

TITLE: Landscape with River and Bridge

DESCRIPTION: Here the traditional composition and classical composure of this carefully staged landscape are enlivened by a rustic element, as is often the case in the works of Zais
AUTHOR: ZAIS, Giuseppe

DESCRIPTION: The mid-nineteenth century in Italy was the period of the Risorgimento, the movement that culminated in Italian unification.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: That movement provided the political and cultural backdrop for one of the most important and influential groups in Italian art in the second half of the nineteenth century: the Macchiaioli.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: This group of landscape, portrait and genre painters, flourishing from about 1850 to 1880, was based on Florence.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: The core of the Macchiaioli consisted of eleven painters born between 1824 and 1838, most important of them among the older painters were Giovanni Fattori, Silvestro Lega, Serafino de Tivoli, and Vincenzo Cabianca, while Giuseppe Abbati and Telemaco Signorini belonged to the younger.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: There were some other artists associated with the group to varying extent, such as Guglielmo Ciardi, Giuseppe de Nittis, Federigo Zandomeneghi, and Giovanni Boldini.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: The last-named three all took their bearings from France, and eventually moved to Paris.Zandomeneghi settled in Paris in 1874, living a reclusive life, and, unsuccessful in his lifetime, was obliged to earn a living doing fashion drawings.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: He exhibited in the 1879, 1881, and 1886 Impressionist exhibitions.
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: In street scenes such as Place d'Anvers, Paris his brushwork was relaxed and sketchy
AUTHOR: ZANDOMENEGHI, Federico
TITLE: Place d'Anvers, Paris

DESCRIPTION: The scene on the south wall shows Authari returning to Italy
AUTHOR: ZAVATTARI, Franceschino
TITLE: Theodolinda Cycle (scene No. 11)

AUTHOR: ZELOTTI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Muses

DESCRIPTION: Muses with poets appear in the spaces between the caryatids, while personifications of rivers loom over the entrance doors.
AUTHOR: ZELOTTI, Giovanni Battista
TITLE: View of the Hall of the Muses

DESCRIPTION: The contribution of Battista del Moro in the decoration of this room is suggested by recent critics
AUTHOR: ZELOTTI, Giovanni Battista

AUTHOR: ZENALE, Bernardo
TITLE: St Anthony of Padua

DESCRIPTION: The painting has become one of the most celebrated images of eighteenth-century taste.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: Zoffany shows a group of connoisseurs and members of the nobility admiring works of art in the Tribuna, the principal room of the Uffizi in Florence, which was the most famous gallery in the world during the eighteenth century.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: The Tribuna had been built by Francesco de' Medici in 1585-9 to a design by Bernardo Buontalenti as a showcase for the most precious items in the Medici collection.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: Although Zoffany has depicted the architectural features of the Tribuna with a fair degree of accuracy, he has rearranged the works of art and in some cases altered their scale.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: In fact, he has also incorporated a number of paintings from that part of the Medici collection housed in the Palazzo Pitti, as well as including several additional pieces of sculpture.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: The painter thus successfully gives the gallery a more crowded and undoubtedly richer appearance than it had during the eighteenth century, and by this means has facilitated his rendering of the complicated sightlines of the room and the perspectival inlaid marble decoration of the floor.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: The setting is therefore somewhat idealised, but it remains a perfectly accurate representation of the significance of the Tribuna for eighteenth-century connoisseurship, with its emphasis on the antique, the High Renaissance, the Bolognese school and Rubens.Zoffany painted the picture in Florence expressly for Queen Charlotte, beginning in 1772.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: Much of the composition was completed the following year, but the artist continued working on it intermittently until late in 1777, making changes some of which are now only visible by X-ray.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: Notable among these changes is the inclusion of a self portrait on the left of the composition, where the artist has shown himself peering round the unframed canvas of the Virgin and Child by Raphael.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: For this purpose, it is almost as if the painter has abandoned his easel, partly visible in the lower right corner of the picture, and walked across or around the back of the room to partake in the discussion.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: The figures in the picture, all of whom are identifiable, fall into three groups: those on the left between the sculptures of Cupid and Psyche and Satyr with the Cymbals; those in the foreground, right of centre, gathered around the Venus d'Urbino by Titian; and those on the right around the Venus de' Medici.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: These portraits were meticulously painted by Zoffany and won widespread admiration, although apparently not from George III and Queen Charlotte, who claimed that such recognisable figures were inappropriate to the scene.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: In essence, however, Zoffany has amalgamated the traditional subject of a gallery view, much exploited by Flemish painters in the seventeenth century, with the conversation piece evolved by British painters during the eighteenth century, although recently other more cryptic levels of meaning have been sought in the picture.Royal patronage enabled the artist to have the Venus d'Urbino by Titian taken down from the wall for copying after the Grand Duke of Tuscany (Ferdinando I) had specifically decreed that the picture had been copied too much and should not be moved again for such a purpose.Correspondingly, there are one or two references in the picture to the Royal Collection: the Virgin and Child by Raphael, held by the artist, was a work that was offered to George III by Earl Cowper (this is the Niccolini-Cowper Madonna, now in the National Gallery of Art, Washington) and the Samian Sibyl by Guercino, seen at the lower edge of the composition, is a pendant to the Libyan Sibyl by the same artist bought by George III in the 1760s.The Tribuna of the Uffizi is a technical tour de force.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: The attention to detail and texture involves not just the portraits, but also the copies after the works of art nearly all of which are identifiable.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: Controlled brushwork and careful application are the hallmarks of Zoffany's style, and they are seen at their best in this famous picture without any of the loss of verve that such a long and elaborate undertaking might have forced upon the artist.
AUTHOR: ZOFFANY, Johann
TITLE: The Tribuna of the Uffizi

DESCRIPTION: This painting is on the altar of the Grimani Chapel in San Francesco della Vigna
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Federico
TITLE: Adoration of the Magi

DESCRIPTION: The art-historical importance of the Palazzo Farnese in Caprarola, near Viterbo, is the famous pentagonal ground plan and round interior courtyard, and the interior frescoes.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: The Palazzo was built for Cardinal Alessandro Farnese (1520-1589) who was made cardinal by his grandfather Pope Paul III (1468-1549), and named vice chancellor of the Holy Roman Church a year later, according him the highest position after that of the pope in the ecclesiastical hierarchy.The architect of the construction, Giacomo da Vignola, found that the form of the ground plan and the site of the building were dictated by an incomplete fortress begun in the 1530s by Antonio da Sangallo the Younger - a project that had not gone further than the exterior walls on the ground floor.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: Vignola approached the unfinished structure as a challenge and opportunity to create a unique solution.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: What was built from 1559 onward had the form of a fortress and the function of a villa, but was in its extravagance an urban palace.The commission for the interior decoration went to Taddeo Zuccaro, who was to make drawings and cartoons for the painting and stucco work but he had to work there only to review from time to time the work that had been carried out there.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: He largely assigned the execution to others, in particular his brother Federico.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: After the death of Taddeo Zuccaro in 1566, his younger brother Federico continued the work until 1569.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: His successor was Jacopo Bertoia, then Giovanni de' Vecchi, assisted by Raffaellino da Reggio.The principle according to which the walls and ceilings were painted was retained for all apartments: only in public rooms (halls and their antechambers) were frescoes painted on ceilings and walls, while painting in the private rooms was limited to the vaults, with walls covered in silk, brocade, and similar materials.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: The themes painted in the ground floor apartments, intended for various uses by guests, are all taken from classical mythology.
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: The themes of the apartments situated above these on the piano nobile focus decidedly on the master of the house and the function of the individual rooms.In the two rooms on the piano nobile suited for a larger public, the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani and the Sala del Concilio, Taddeo Zuccaro painted a cycle depicting, in a total of twenty-three scenes, the history of the Farnese family
AUTHOR: ZUCCARO, Taddeo
TITLE: General view of the Sala dei Fasti Farnesiani

DESCRIPTION: This small painting from Villa Medici in Rome was brought to the dressing room of Ferdinando I de' Medici in 1587
AUTHOR: ZUCCHI, Jacopo
TITLE: Age of Silver

DESCRIPTION: In 1627, while still resident in Llerena, Zurbarán painted this spectacular picture, that made him famous, for the Dominicans.
AUTHOR: ZURBARÁN, Francisco de
TITLE: Christ on the Cross

DESCRIPTION: It was placed in a small oratory chapel and made a strong impression.
AUTHOR: ZURBARÁN, Francisco de
TITLE: Christ on the Cross

DESCRIPTION: The represented drama in the composition is increased by the overpowering light, which heightens then transforms the real into superreal, thus expressing the dual nature of Christ
AUTHOR: ZURBARÁN, Francisco de
TITLE: Christ on the Cross
